webTitle: Consumers save for a sunny day

fields.headline: Consumers save for a sunny day
fields.trailText: Sterling hit another six-year low against the dollar yesterday. The fall followed government figures showing that consumers tightened their belts in April - raising hopes that British interest rates could be near their peak.
fields.body:
Sterling hit another six-year low against the dollar yesterday. The fall followed government figures showing that consumers tightened their belts in April - raising hopes that British interest rates could be near their peak.

Retail sales volumes fell 0.3% over the month, the Office for National Statistics said yesterday. Most analysts had expected a rise. With April the wettest month on record since 1776, analysts blamed the weather for some of the fall.

"The pattern of sales is consistent with wet weather hav ing hit demand," said Michael Hume, UK economist at Lehman Brothers.

"Non-food sales were entirely responsible for the drop in sales volumes: they fell 0.8% on the month, whereas food - something consumers have to go out and buy even in wet weather - grew 0.4%."

Retail sales prices rose by 0.3%, the first time in six months that they have gone up and not down.

Yesterday's figures cap a week of weak economic data which has prompted speculation that the Bank of England's next move could be to cut interest rates.

"We could quite possibly see a small reduction in interest rates by the end of the year _ the next move is as likely to be down as up," said Darren Winder, economist at Warburg Dillon Read.

Currency traders speculated that the half point interest rate differential between Britain and the US will widen.

The pound fell by a cent to a 6-year low of 1.4768 before recovering to close in London at 1.4809.

"If the peak in base rates has not already been reached, then it is not likely to be far off," said Dharshini David, UK economist at HSBC markets.

fields.headline: Occupation: nun
fields.standfirst: It's never easy when you know a sister's lying, an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: Brief encounters: A secretary at a Catholic school is pregnant and soon gets the sack. But the nuns deny they ever noticed ...
fields.body:
I have a weakness for nuns. I was educated in part by seventies sisters in reformed habits of clunky double knit polyester and shorty veils - a-line skirts, navy sweater vests and chunky shoes. Actually they would probably all look quite Prada now.

They were lovely on the whole though. There was a song we had to sing about "peace flowing like a river" (tee hee, peace, leave off the "ce" tee hee) accompanied by one sister on the guitar and one on the tambourine. The one who taught biology blushed a lot.

So I am feeling uneasy about my case this week. Mary, my client, was a school secretary at a Catholic school. She was unmarried and obviously pregnant (seven months) when the school sacked her. This should be an obvious case of sex discrimination, except that the nuns are all denying that they knew that Mary was pregnant. They are saying she was dismissed for "pilfering".

And still it should be easy. We have brought along photos of Mary at about the time she was sacked. She is five feet tall and looked like a children's book drawing of a worm which has swallowed an apple. The evidence of "pilfering" comes from one ancient sister who vaguely thought she might have left her rosary on Mary's desk. Or in the garden. Or possibly under her bed. I can tell the tribunal panel are uncomfortable too. The procreation / nuns combo is not working for anyone. The Chair does lots of hearty "heh-hehing".

"Well, I don't need to ask whether you'll be wanting to swear on the Bible," he joshes Sister Veronica with crushing levity.

The school's barrister (an opponent of yore) has been smirking at me continuously. When I ran into him before the tribunal in the Crumbly Muffin (where he was tucking into a full English breakfast) he said "I'm looking forward to you reminding the sisters they're on oath". I refrained from telling him he had egg yolk on his tie.

Sister Veronica has a bland soft face like fallen dough, lightly whiskered in the bright sunlight falling on the witness table. After she gives her evidence-in-chief, another nun beetles over to her and whispers in her ear. This is a big no-no.

Me: "Uhh, excuse me, Sister, do you realise that you are not supposed to talk to Sister Veronica whilst she is giving her evidence?"

Nun: "Oh well, I was just telling her our prayers were with her to give her strength in the ordeal ahead."

An epidemic of smirking breaks out. I commence the ordeal. Sister Veronica is resolute in her evidence that she "never notices that sort of thing" (pregnancy bumps), her mind being on other (higher) matters. I am reduced to: "Well, what about in pictures of the Virgin Mary before she gives birth to the baby Jesus? It must have struck you that her figure is somewhat altered."

A smile of great wiliness plays over Sister Veronica's lips: "Oh, but you see, dear, I would always be looking at her face, at her expression of exaltation, the sublime meekness with which she accepted her role as a vessel for the Lord..." and so forth.

The tribunal panel says it will sleep on the matter and give its decision in writing. I don't blame them. I don't think I could tell Sister Veronica she was lying to her face. But I feel rather melancholy, thinking of Sister Rita and her guitar - could she too have been so cunning?

fields.headline: Donegal at war
fields.standfirst:
Dolly West's Kitchen
Old Vic, London
Rating: * * * *
fields.trailText:
Dolly West's Kitchen
Old Vic, London
Rating: * * * *
fields.body:
In a remote part of Donegal in 1943 the West family is bringing the war back home to neutral Ireland. Elder daughter Esther exudes the dangerous discontent of a woman who hasn't married for love. Younger daughter Dolly feeds the family, but neglects her own emotional hunger and love for the Englishman Alec; and son Justin, an officer in the Irish army, is an uptight bigot, prepared to justify Ireland's neutrality in the war against Hitler because of his hatred of the English.

Into this already tense situation, the irrepressible, manipulative, benign matriarch Rima, a woman who cannot open her mouth without raising a belly laugh and causing her children discomfort, brings Alec and two American GIs stationed just over the border in Derry. One of the Americans, Marco, is a tough Bronx kid who is also gay.

This invasion of love, hate, different attitudes and perspectives changes the Wests' lives for ever. "Is the war over?" is the question at the end. Only in some ways, as the outbreak of peace marks the start of new struggles for the Wests and for Ireland, who must both come to terms with the scars of the past.

Frank McGuinness has written a bruiser of a play, solid and old-fashioned in that great Irish tradition that mixes sentimentality with punch and is both engrossing and blissfully funny. It works upon the consciousness like a singing kettle in a warm kitchen.

Not all of it works: Rima is hilarious but not entirely believable, Dolly's sudden rage against her sister is inexplicable and McGuinness's treatment of his characters and his emphasis on the good and bad in each of them is too even-handed to be totally satisfying. In the end you are more interested in the Wests themselves than in McGuinness's attempts to make them stand in as a metaphor for post-war Ireland.

But this is a terrific and chunky piece of West End theatre. Patrick Mason's production can do no wrong and the acting is so sure and true it brings a lump to the throat. Like Rima, McGuinness is a canny manipulator and a superb theatrical craftsman: in the silence before the audience's final roar of approval what you hear is the collective breaking of 1,000 hearts.

 Until August 5. Box office: 020-7928 7616.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Partners apart
fields.standfirst:
Luke Vibert/BJ Cole
Scala, London
Rating: * *
fields.trailText:
Luke Vibert/BJ Cole
Scala, London
Rating: * *
fields.body:
Music has seen its fair share of bizarre double acts: remember the infamous Bing Crosby and David Bowie Christmas collaboration of the 70s? But rarely have the worlds of traditional and modern collided so spectacularly as the day Luke Vibert met BJ Cole.

Vibert is a man of many guises. From the drum'n'bass twiddlings of Plug to the electronica of Wagon Christ, his has been a career in cool. Cole, on the other hand, has added the sound of his pedal steel guitar to the songs of everyone from the Verve to Kiri Te Kanawa. The pair's album, Stop the Panic, is less a set of songs than a collage of musical postcards, taking in countless influences from all around the world.

As Vibert and Cole amble onto the stage, it's difficult to decide who looks the most uncomfortable. Without a word, it's straight into the music. Bongo beats slap against a heavy bassline while Cole slides away, his face scrunched up in concentration. Vibert and Cole barely look at each other throughout the gig, each lost in different musical landscapes. Drum'n'bass, jazz, hip hop and big band sounds all make an appearance here, with Vibert's humorous but dark undertones resonating throughout. For Cole it's a case of keep up while you can; his delicate pluckings are often lost in the swampy epics.

The guitar god comes into his own during the cheesier songs: Cheng Pooey is a vision of Oriental loveliness, while Dischordzilla is a screwed-up horror film theme with scary twangings. But it's in the Hawaiian-influenced tunes, notably Fly Hawaiian, that this collaboration works best. The slippery steel guitar adds character in the absence of vocals and gives some cohesion to what can be fun, but just as often becomes a mess of sounds, squeaks and cleverness.

 Luke Vibert and BJ Cole play the Medicine Bar, Birmingham (0121-693 6001), tonight, then tour.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Homage to a great king
fields.standfirst:
Alfred
Royal Opera House, London
Rating: * * *
fields.trailText:
Alfred
Royal Opera House, London
Rating: * * *
fields.body:
Thomas Arne, born and buried in WC2, would be an apt patron composer for the annual BOC Covent Garden Festival. He might also be the most frequently sung of British composers, with God Save the King and Rule Britannia to his credit. It is for finishing with Rule Britannia that Arne's Alfred, written in 1740, is best known.

Today all the other choruses and the recitatives are lost, making it difficult to stage the work in a satisfactory way. Certainly the performers found it hard to maintain dramatic flow when the vocal numbers didn't lead naturally from one to the other and there was no recitative to connect them musically - or to explain what was going on in the story.

In Netia Davan Wetton's characteristically bold staging, in the Linbury Studios of the Royal Opera House, baroque music theatre met MTV. Stylised images, constantly moving and flickering, were projected onto a screen behind the characters. The dancers Floyd and Damian Hendrix acted out skirmishes between King Alfred's forces and the invading Danes as a fluid cross between kick-boxing and breakdancing. Yet for all Davan Wetton's audacity, her designs and direction were most successful when they were at their simplest. Critics at early performances complained of a lack of stage action in Alfred; but here the action often had the effect of drawing attention away from the music.

The music certainly deserved the audience's focus. From the harpsichord, Christian Curnyn directed a crisp, spirited and accomplished baroque orchestra. Alfred may be perceived as a one-hit wonder, but there are some fine arias, in particular a revenge number for Alfred's wife, sung by Elena Ferrari, and - the most beautiful - a touching song of filial love from his son Edward, sung with unaffected elegance by Sally Bruce-Payne. A subdued episode in which a woman mourns her dead husband had seemingly little place in the sketchy plot, but provided a welcome opportunity to hear Louise Mott, a polished and expressive mezzo.

Alfred himself, sung by tenor Daniel Norman, began wearing shirt sleeves, waxed jacket and the look of a slightly bewildered back bencher. A more regal bearing - and a stronger voice - emerged in the second act, without which the Danes would certainly have been the favourites in this particular battle.

 Ends tonight. Box office: 020-7413 1410.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: A million users but bills grow at Interactive Investor

fields.headline: A million users but bills grow at Interactive Investor
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Interactive Investor International said yesterday the number of its registered users has climbed to nearly 1m, making it the fifth largest internet site in the UK.
fields.body:
Interactive Investor International said yesterday the number of its registered users has climbed to nearly 1m, making it the fifth largest internet site in the UK.

But losses at the personal finance website in the six months to March 31 quadrupled to £9.6m from £2.6m on a 150% increase in turnover to £2.8m. The company blamed the widening loss on a £4m provision to cover potential national insurance costs on share options.

It also said activity levels across the site fell back in April, particularly on its small investor bulletin boards, in the wake of the collapse in dot.com shares. But the company is confident it can ride out the cashflow crisis which sent Boo.com into liquidation and threatens other dot.coms. It is spending around £1m a month, but it raised £70m from its float in February and still has £68m in the bank.

The number of iii users, who access the site for information on financial products and services, leapt to nearly 1m from 400,000 in February, and page impressions are running at more than 90m a month, compared with just 5m a year ago.

It says audited figures show that it is the biggest financial services portal in the UK and the fifth most visited website overall, behind Yahoo, Freeserve, BBC and Beeb.com.

Chief executive Tomas Carruthers said: "We are very pleased with these results. Our strategy to increase revenue from the sale of products such as Isas and stakeholder pensions is firmly on track, with transaction-related revenues up by 268%."

Over the next six months iii plans to develop websites in Germany and France as well as a mortgage service in a tie-up with IF, the new internet bank from Halifax. It is also opening a funds supermarket to sell a full range of unit trusts.

At its float in February, iii was 26 times oversubscribed, with 82,000 small investors applying for shares. In first day trading the shares leapt from 150p to 335p, reaching a peak of 415p a day later.

But recently it has fallen to little more than half its flotation value and yesterday's results failed to impress the City, which marked its shares down 10% to 82.5p .

At one point iii was valued at almost £700m, but at yesterday's closing price, is now worth about £150m.

webTitle: It all ends in tears at Boo

fields.headline: It all ends in tears at Boo
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A year ago Boo.com's founders, Ernst Malmsten and Kajsa Leander, were gracing the front cover of Fortune magazine and talking of world domination. Yesterday morning their dream ended in tears when the two 30-year-old Swedes gathered together the 250 staff at their office in Regent Street, London, and told them that their ambitions of becoming a global online sportswear retailer had failed.
fields.body:
A year ago Boo.com's founders, Ernst Malmsten and Kajsa Leander, were gracing the front cover of Fortune magazine and talking of world domination. Yesterday morning their dream ended in tears when the two 30-year-old Swedes gathered together the 250 staff at their office in Regent Street, London, and told them that their ambitions of becoming a global online sportswear retailer had failed. The business was in the hands of the liquidators.

In an emotional and tearful speech Mr Malmsten apologised profusely to his staff for his inability to raise the fresh funds that would have kept the business afloat and thanked them for "their incredible support".

"It was a very sad moment. There was a lot of hugging and tears and a standing ovation," said one Boo.com staffer now looking for another job.

When one angry contractor demanded to be paid he was booed out of the open-plan office. His revenge was to daub "crooks" on the pavement outside.

Most of the staff are in their 20s and are unlikely to be out of jobs for long; a recruitment agency was touting for business outside the front door from mid-morning and Mr Malmsten has said one of his priorities is to help find them new jobs.

The recriminations are likely to drag on much longer. Even before the ink was dry on the court order that authorised the liquidators to move in, venture capitalists, bankers, marketeers, entrepreneurs and even start-ups still looking for first-round funding all came crawling out of the woodwork offering to point out where Boo had gone wrong and how it could have been done differently.

Dr Mike Lynch, founder of the software company Autonomy - which he has guided from start-up to one of the most successful global e-businesses in four years - perhaps summed up sentiment best.

"There was a certain inevitability about this," he said. "The new media orthodoxies of just throwing money at something simply don't work. Investors seemed to think the internet was magic.

"There was an incredible arrogance among UK start-ups that the situation over here would be just like the US. Dr Therese Torris, an analyst at Forrester Research, said Boo's fundamental problem was that "it failed to meet sales targets and innovation dried out," while it spent too much on marketing and advertising. Boo mistakenly promoted its 3D technology as a key selling point, when in fact "99% of European and 98% of US homes lack the high-bandwidth access needed," Dr Torris added.

Peter Bradshaw, internet analyst at Merrill Lynch, predicted that 75% of European internet companies will disappear over the next few years, probably through consolidation - but Boo's failure did not mean that all dot.com's would go the same way.

The company attracted $120m in heavyweight backing from the likes of Bernard Arnault's LVMH luxury goods group, the Benetton family and US investment banks JP Morgan and Goldman Sachs.

Yet management controls at Boo.com were lacking - and although the business was packed with former consultants, few staff had experience of operating sizeable businesses in fast growth phases.

"You can't just hand a bunch of kids $120m and let them get on with it," said one source close to Boo.com. "They needed better guidance, support and supervision. Those investors should have known that better than almost anyone."

fields.headline: NatWest fined for options scandal
fields.trailText: NatWest yesterday received a £320,000 fine - the second largest on record levied by City regulators - relating to a £90m options pricing scandal which took place more than three years ago.
fields.body:
NatWest yesterday received a £320,000 fine - the second largest on record levied by City regulators - relating to a £90m options pricing scandal which took place more than three years ago.

The fine by the securities and futures authority, which is in the process of merging with the new financial services authority, was accompanied by a severe reprimand and a £100,000 contribution to the regulator's costs. The fine affects the NatWest group, now owned by Royal Bank of Scotland, and the NatWest Capital Markets operation, where the problems occurred.

As a result of the affair, uncovered by NatWest in February 1997 and ultimately the cause of NatWest's decision to sell off the bulk of its investment bank, the SFA said it had also fined two traders.

The regulator said it would expel Kyriacos Papouis from its register of traders, in effect banning him from working in the City, and fine him £50,000 as well as ordering him to make a £2,500 contribution to costs. His manager, Neil Dodgson, was reprimanded, fined £5,000 and required to pay £2,500 towards SFA costs.

The discovery of a "black hole" in the bank's trading books prompted NatWest Markets chief executive Martin Owen to quit and at least six people to leave.

The regulator said yesterday it had concluded that the disciplinary proceedings arose out of the "mismarking of interest rate options" by the two men and deficiencies in the "control environment" at the bank.

The SFA said that between January 1994 and February 1997 internal and external auditors told the bank's senior management of concerns about the manner in which NatWest monitored trading of the complex financial instruments.

But, the regulator said, it had taken into account the fact that the bank and the two individuals had cooperated with the investigation, that NatWest was trying to improve its control structure at the time of the incident and the "mismarking" of the positions did not result in any third party losing money.

The losses were uncovered by NatWest after Mr Papouis, who was 29 at the time of the incident, had left the bank. Mr Dodgson no longer works at the bank.

fields.headline: £3bn BT profits fail to impress
fields.standfirst: Growing rivalry and cost of expansion worry City
fields.trailText: British Telecom's efforts to woo its way back into City favour suffered another setback yesterday - despite a better than expected performance last year.
fields.body:
British Telecom's efforts to woo its way back into City favour suffered another setback yesterday - despite a better than expected performance last year.

Worries about the impact of intensifying competition at home and the costs of international expansion cast a cloud over the share price, which fell a further 7% yesterday - down 67p to 924p.

Pre-tax profits last year fell by almost a third to £2.94bn although the previous year's total was boosted by the surplus on the sale of BT's shares in MCI following the abortive merger. However, profits before exceptionals were down by a much more modest 5% at £3.1bn - ahead of City expectations of around £2.85bn.

Announcing the results yesterday, the chief executive, Sir Peter Bonfield, described the past 12 months as "an eventful, exciting and encouraging year".

The company would continue to see its margins squeezed in the core business in the UK but was well positioned in the key growth areas in the communications market, he said.

His enthusiasm was not shared in the City. "There's no doubt the UK side will get hard hit. They've got to persuade people that they have some potential to grow other businesses. At the moment it's not really clear to me that they have any particular advantages," said Paul Mount, an analyst at Nomura.

On the plus side, BT's turnover rose by a fifth to £21.9bn last year, but investment has pushed gearing close to the 100% level - a figure which finance director Robert Brace expects to be reached by the end of the current financial year.

Spending includes £4bn for a third-generation mobile phone licence - a sum BT has already handed over to the government - its purchase of Securicor's 40% of Cellnet and acquisition of the Irish telecoms group Esat.

Although overall turnover was sharply higher, revenue from fixed-line services - domestic and international calls from BT lines - fell 2%. The impact of price cuts, including a 25% reduction in fixed-to-mobile call prices in response to the competition commission inquiry, more than offset a 7% rise in volumes.

For shareholders the final dividend is being raised by 7.4% to 13.2p a share.

BT refused to be drawn into the continuing argument about whether telecoms companies had been forced to overpay for the third-generation mobile phone licences - although Sir Peter noted that British licences would cost more than the total investment in the networks.

Certainly that experience has not dented the company's appetite for new licences: it has bid or will bid for third-generation licences which are still on offer in the big European telecoms markets as well as in Japan.

Some observers have been disappointed because BT has failed to clinch a blockbuster acquisition to rank alongside some of the deals seen elsewhere in the industry.

The latest speculation centres on a possible link-up with Spain's Telefonica. But Sir Peter refused to respond to questions about the Spanish group. "We don't comment on market rumours. There are all sorts of rumours in this industry."

Asked about the potential for consolidation in the industry generally, Sir Peter said he expected it to happen "at some stage" but pointed out that it was "fraught with difficulties" - pointing to a series of high-profile merger failures.

BT also disclosed yesterday that pension costs - which last year totalled £167m - will double in the current year.

webTitle: Ferguson's promise persuades Sheringham to stay at United

fields.headline: Ferguson's promise persuades Sheringham to stay at United
fields.trailText: Teddy Sheringham yesterday agreed to stay at Manchester United for another year after the manager Sir Alex Ferguson assured him he would not buy a new striker.
fields.body:
Teddy Sheringham yesterday agreed to stay at Manchester United for another year after the manager Sir Alex Ferguson assured him he would not buy a new striker.

The 34-year-old, who came on as a substitute to score the equaliser in last year's Champions League final, could have moved on a free transfer but instead has signed a new one-year contract with the Premiership champions.

Sheringham had been worried about being pushed further into the background at Old Trafford, but the breakdown of Ruud van Nistelrooy's move from PSV Eindhoven, combined with Ferguson's promise not to look for another forward, has reassured him.

"I am really pleased that the matter has been resolved and that I am remaining a Manchester United player," said Sheringham, who signed for £3.5m from Tottenham in 1997. "All the players retain a real hunger for honours and we want to emulate the success of recent years, particularly that of 1999."

Ferguson said: "I had a chat with Teddy last week to assure him that he was very much part of our plans for next season. He has had a great time with the club and has benefited from the success we have enjoyed. Equally, so have we. It has been a great partnership for all concerned.

"It would have been easy for Teddy to have gone elsewhere but he doesn't want to leave and that's good for us all. The players, directors, staff and supporters all want him to stay."

Meanwhile the creation and subsequent popularity of internet sites aimed specifically at those who love to hate Manchester United, such as www.ihatemanutd.com, has prompted the world's richest club to seek legal advice.

"As an organisation Manchester United will do everything in its powers to protect the image and integrity of the club's name, whether it be on the internet or anywhere else," said United's marketing director Peter Draper.

"If people are falsely representing United or being mischievous about the club, we will take the necessary action to protect our interests."

In particular United are considering legal action against www.manutdsucks.com, which despite its title is concerned with the business world.

Another site, www.hatemanutd.com - not to be confused with www.ihatemanutd.com - took out audio advertisements at 60 grounds across the country shortly after going online in March.

"There is no way we would carry derogatory advertising that promoted a negative image of another club," said Draper. "Therefore it is not unfair to believe that other clubs should do likewise. If it means us talking to those clubs then we are quite happy to do that. Either that or possibly to the league or FA instead."

 West Ham's Marc-Vivien Foe has joined Lyon for £6m, according to the French club's official website.

webTitle: Bates pays £20,000 to start charity's net gain

fields.headline: Bates pays £20,000 to start charity's net gain
fields.trailText: Ken Bates paid £20,000 for some turf yesterday and it may not even have been the right turf. Ten million quid for a dodgy centre-forward, anyone?
fields.body:
Ken Bates paid £20,000 for some turf yesterday and it may not even have been the right turf. Ten million quid for a dodgy centre-forward, anyone?

The Chelsea chairman won the auction for the square of the Wembley pitch upon which, it was claimed, the ball bounced down from the crossbar when Geoff Hurst put England 3-2 ahead in extra-time of the 1966 World Cup final.

In the absence of the linesman who gave the goal - Tofik Bakhramov died seven years ago - the responsibility for digging up the appropriate piece of turf was shared by Sir Geoff Hurst and Hans Tilkowski, Germany's goalkeeper in the 1966 final.

Hurst seems to have won the argument once again. "I made sure the spade was marginally over the line," he reported.

The proceeds from the auction will go to the Bobby Moore Fund for Imperial Cancer Research. Bates's piece of turf is earmarked for Chelsea's proposed museum.

"It's a little bit of heritage and I wanted it in the right hands," Bates said. "We are building a soccer museum next year and it will be deposited there."

Naturally he remembers where he was when the goal was scored: "in the Bahamas with my family, sitting on a beach".

The pitch will be repaired before Bates returns to Wembley for the Cup final the day after tomorrow. "Wembley has a great deal of history," he said, "but, like me, it's a bit worn out."

Various other parts of the stadium - including another 149 spots on the pitch - are being sold on the internet through qxl.com.

Bidding for the spot of turf from which Hurst completed his hat-trick will end at 2pm today. Snickers has already posted a bid of £10,000.

Germany will be the visitors for the last game at the old Wembley on October 7. England have some catching up to do then and at the European championship game in Charleroi on June 17. Since 1966 they have beaten the Germans only twice in 14 matches.

webTitle: FA admits that violence is setback to World Cup bid

fields.headline: FA admits that violence is setback to World Cup bid
fields.trailText: The FA's executive director David Davies last night condemned the violence that overshadowed the Uefa Cup final and has jeopardised England's attempt to host the 2006 World Cup. Davies also pledged that the FA would "redouble efforts in terms of our safety and security preparations for Euro 2000 if it is possible for us to do".
fields.body:
The FA's executive director David Davies last night condemned the violence that overshadowed the Uefa Cup final and has jeopardised England's attempt to host the 2006 World Cup. Davies also pledged that the FA would "redouble efforts in terms of our safety and security preparations for Euro 2000 if it is possible for us to do".

He declared: "As far as the FA are concerned, we are very saddened and disappointed about the series of incidents over the past 18 hours. We especially regret the injury to Paul Dineen, an Arsenal fan for the past 26 years, who spent Tuesday night in hospital with a stab wound.

"It will be for Uefa to draw their conclusions from their investigations that will follow and it is not for us to discuss operational police matters here in Copenhagen, but we would stress that in advance of this match it was England and the FA, in conjunction with Uefa, that urged the total cooperation between Danish, Turkish and English security and police services.

"Leading up to yesterday we had done everything in our power to achieve a low-key build-up to the match despite the circumstances that everybody is aware of.

"Let us make it very clear that we deplore and condemn all those - be they Turkish or English - who have involved themselves in violent behaviour over recent hours. But it is not for us to say at this stage who was to blame for what and in what circumstances. The facts of this matter, I think, will emerge. Our priority now is a safe return home for all of our supporters."

Of England's attempt to host the 2006 World Cup, Davies added: "Clearly any event is unhelpful and we say that straight away. But the Fifa executive have always made clear that, of the bidding nations, there are a number of nations who have security or hooliganism problems.

"What we're talking about is criminal behaviour and that's something that we abhor, as everybody else does."

One of the FA's immediate priorities is to repair relations with their counterparts in Turkey, something which they were planning to do in any case after the stabbings of two Leeds sup porters in Istanbul last month.

Davies said: "Even before these events, after the Leeds semi-final we had talked to our opposite numbers in the Turkish FA as to how we would repair the relationship between Turkey and England after this game.

"I talked last night with the Turkish FA president and their deputy general secretary and we had a very friendly and worthwhile conversation.

"We will set in motion, and we were planning to do so even before last night's events, a meeting between the two football associations to get our relationship, as a matter of urgency, back on an even footing.

"We can't sadly put right what has happened over the past few weeks but we have always had good relationships with Turkey and have played them on a number of occasions. They are very keen to do that, as we are. It is essential."

webTitle: Outbreak of English disease close to epidemic

fields.headline: Outbreak of English disease close to epidemic
fields.trailText: David Lacey believes that the violence in Copenhagen is blown the lid on cosy assumptions that the hooligan excesses are a thing of the past, as well doing irrepairable damage to England's 2006 bid.
fields.body:
The carefully moulded facade of respectability that English football has acquired since the country's worst football hooliganism subsided after the excesses of the 70s and 80s is now in danger of being cracked wide open.

Whoever instigated the violent scenes in the middle of Copenhagen yesterday, and however widespread that mayhem was, the reality is that, with England's 2006 World Cup bid now at a crucial stage, worldwide television pictures have once more reminded the world that the English disease, far from being cured, is even now merely held at bay.

The latest bout of violence went on no more than 15 minutes but was extremely ugly while it lasted. And it will have taken only a few seconds of television time to convince viewers that the riotous background against which England began the 1998 World Cup in Marseille is almost certain to be repeated in Eindhoven and Charleroi in a month's time.

Should this happen then those presenting England's case for hosting the 2006 World Cup will be entitled to feel that they have been badly let down by some of the fans for whom so much organisation, travel and extensive lobbying have been undertaken. At the moment England's 2006 delegates are seeking votes in Malaysia. It is hard to believe that yesterday's TV pictures from Copenhagen will not have left them feeling profoundly embarrassed.

Last night David Davies, the Football Association's executive director, remained confident that Fifa had taken on board the undeniable fact that most bidders will have had hooligan problems of one kind or another. But it is what the rival bidders make of one another's problems which may count when the voting begins, and yesterday's incidents will have left England a little more vulnerable in this respect.

Should Euro 2000, or at least England's part in it, be completed without serious crowd scenes involving English, German, Turkish and Dutch or Belgian fans then it is possible that what happened here yesterday will be regarded as an unfortunate one-off incident. This, however, may prove to be the fondest of hopes.

The Uefa Cup, now an ill- regarded tournament after Uefa's decision to allow Champions League drop-outs such as Arsenal and Galatasaray to enter at the third-round stage, seems a poor excuse for reawakening the hooliganism dormant in the soul of English football.

Until this week Arsenal's record in Europe had been largely free of trouble. Certainly the victory of George Graham's team against Parma in the Cup Winners' Cup final played here in 1994 was free of disturbances both in the ground and in the city.

After yesterday's pre-match violence a Turkish TV reporter said he had noticed that some of those involved wore Leeds United shirts. Perhaps some sort of confrontation was inevitable after the stabbings in Istanbul from which two Leeds fans died before the first leg of the semi-final.

Yesterday, allowing groups of Galatasaray supporters to gather outside bars containing Arsenal fans and taunt them with chants did not seem the brightest move by the Danish police. Tensions were already running high after the knife attack on an Arsenal supporter the night before.

Yet before this latest incident descends into an argument about who did what to whom, the broader picture needs to be retained. The English domestic season has just ended with worrying evidence - at Stoke, Rotherham, Darlington and elsewhere - that the sort of hooliganism which became such a tedious regularity 25 to 30 years ago is on the point of breaking out anew.

The sad fact remains that any sort of English presence abroad is likely to provoke the sort of scenes witnessed yesterday. Uefa is already being pressed to shift England's Euro 2000 encounter with Germany on June 17 away from the tiny stadium at Charleroi. Maybe yesterday's reminder of how easily violence can break out before a game will help persuade the European body that this match should be switched to Brussels or Rotterdam.

Davis was at pains to explain that the FA and the security forces of England, Germany and Belgium were confident that the match in Charleroi would be trouble-free. But, as in Marseille, it is outside the stadiums that the worst violence is likely to occur, and the little town centre of Charleroi would quickly be overwhelmed by the sort of scenes witnessed in Copenhagen yesterday.

fields.headline: Arsenal pay the penalty
fields.standfirst:
Shoot-out misses by Suker and Vieira hand trophy to Turks
Aet: Galatasaray win 4-1 on pens
fields.trailText: Gheorge Popescu clinched the Uefa Cup for Galatasaray when he struck the decisive spot-kick in a penalty shoot-out after the sides had been deadlocked for 120 minutes here last night.
fields.body:
Gheorge Popescu clinched the Uefa Cup for Galatasaray when he struck the decisive spot-kick in a penalty shoot-out after the sides had been deadlocked for 120 minutes here last night.

After an entertaining second-half, extra-time proved an anticlimax despite the dismissal of Gheorghe Hagi for striking Tony Adams in the back.

In many respects Arsenal could consider themselves fortunate to survive. Either side of half-time Galatasaray had gone close, once hitting the post.

Sadly, the build-up to the match had been dominated by the outbreaks of violence in the city centre. The stabbing of an Arsenal fan in the early hours of yesterday morning was followed by further running battles and three stabbings on the afternoon of the game.

If the incidents were hardly surprising given the baggage carried over from Galatasaray's semi-finals against Leeds, it was notable that the mood for the most part had been peaceful, if noisy. Shortly before the second bout of trouble, rival fans were seen chatting, shaking hands or posing for photographs side by side.

Bottles were flying outside the stadium shortly before the start, but inside the atmosphere was relatively calm. Those who had come early enough were treated to a troup of Turkish dancers performing on the pitch. The Galatasaray fans, waving red and yellow balloons and scores of flags, were getting through some dancing of their own in the seats behind one goal.

Arsenal made a surprisingly nervous start. Inside three minutes their captain Tony Adams, one of three survivors from the George Graham team who won the Cup Winners' Cup here in 1994, uncharacteristically misjudged a header to allow Erdem Arif a shot which was deflected wide.

But without managing much in the way of flowing football or territorial domination in the early stages, Arsenal showed that they were always likely to prosper with their pace on the counter-attack.

First Thierry Henry and then Marc Overmars burst into promising positions without delivering a killer pass. And when an Overmars corner was flicked back by Patrick Vieira, providing a rare sight of goal, Henry shot too high.

It was, though, far from one-way traffic. With Vieira and Emmanuel Petit struggling to gain initial control of the midfield, Galatasaray enjoyed plenty of possession. As expected, Gheorghe Hagi drifted around to menacing effect, flicking passes and surging past opponents as if they barely existed.

Arif forced David Seaman to tip over from long range, and Hakan Sukur could never be disregarded, but Galatasaray were generally kept at arm's length. Perhaps more worrying for Arsenal was the tendency of certain opponents to tumble to the floor at the slightest touch. By half-time Martin Keown and Vieira had been booked.

Before the interval Overmars had Claudio Taffarel plunging at his near post to save a powerful low shot but the best opportunity fell to Galatasaray. When Hagi, Hakan Sukur and Davala Umit combined to set up Arif, the striker seemed certain to score. But unmarked and less than 10 yards out he screwed his shot beyond the far post as Arsenal looked in vain for offside.

Despite that escape, Arsenal did not seem to have learned their lesson. Only 47 minutes had gone when Galatasaray unhinged them once more. Hagi was the architect, releasing Hakan Sukur and the tall striker, who had got between his markers as he threatened all night, beat Seaman only to see his shot rebound off a post.

Henry at last managed a surge down the left side and along the byline before crossing. But Martin Keown, stretching at the far post, shot over.

Far from sparking a period of sustained Arsenal pressure that proved the signal for Galatasaray to threaten anew. A dangerous Hagi cross was sliced by Keown, and with the Turkish side harrying relentlessly, Arsenal were given little opportunity to find any time or rythmn. Too many passes were misplaced and Dennis Bergkamp was almost anonymous.

There was hope for Arsenal's subdued supporters when Henry beat Korkmaz Bulent only to shoot wide and Ray Parlour volleyed wide from an Overmars pass. But between times Arif had called Seaman into action and the goalkeeper had to deny Capone as well as the game opened up.

Galatasaray (4-3-1-2): Taffarel; Capone, Popescu, Bulent, Ergun; Okan (Hakan Unsal, 84min), Suat (Ahmet, 95), Umit; Hagi; Hakan Sukur, Arif (Hasan, 95).

Arsenal (4-4-2): Seaman; Dixon, Keown, Adams, Silvinho; Parlour, Vieira, Petit, Overmars (Suker, 115); Henry, Bergkamp (Kanu, 75). Referee: L Nieto (Spain).

webTitle: Villa or Vialli? That is the question

fields.headline: Villa or Vialli? That is the question
fields.standfirst: For the final word on the best FA Cup final bets, look no further than Mike Hodgkinson, our man standing by twin towers of used betting slips
fields.trailText: The final word on the best FA Cup final bets.
fields.body:
If Gianluca Vialli wants a Blue Day to match Chelsea's FA Cup win of 1997 he'll have to play it pretty cool during the build-up.

First, his side will be expected to win - not least by the bookmakers - and high expectation could become a millstone if he lets it.

Second, everyone from John Gregory to Ruud Gullit is reminding him of his under-achievement during a potentially massive season. "Luca hasn't won anything," carped Gullit, all matey. "Okay [Chelsea] reached the quarter-finals of the Champions Cup, but they haven't qualified for next season's competition."

And finally, Vialli's squad are on the point of breaking up whereas Villa have the look of a side marching onward and upward.

All of which points to victory for John Gregory's side - so where are the goals going to come from?

If his hamstring was in prime condition, Ian Taylor would be the first player to make it onto your short list of top-value first scorers. He's always looking for the chance to have a pop and should be well placed to nip in if the Chelsea defence is distracted by Dublin, Carbone and Merson.

Trouble is, the injury he picked up in the Bolton semi-final is still bothering him - so keep your eyes on the team sheet. If it looks like he's starting, presume he's fit and have a go at 16-1 (Ladbrokes) or bigger if you can find it.

If you prefer to trust your money with someone in a blue shirt, look no further than Dennis Wise. He looked extra-sharp against Derby last week. The universal 14-1 looks pretty fair from here.

Whatever happens at Wembley on Saturday, it won't be pretty. John Gregory knows his best hopes of upsetting Chelsea is to charge at them full tilt. That way, he'll hope, they won't be able to hit their fluent, Continental stride. Drill Sergeant Gregory can then engineer a gritty victory which will draw comparisons to great British military victories of the past. A bit dull maybe, but potentially effective.

Outside the stadium, Gregory styles himself as the last of the famous international playboys. If you saw On Side with John Inverdale you will no doubt have noticed the classic 'going-up-west' black jacket and Italian Riviera loafers. But his straightforward approach to Premiership touchline gear marks him down as grafter. Trust him to get the job done, bearing in mind that Chelsea and Villa have produced one own goal over their two most recent league meetings.

One nil to the Midlands side looks about right, Ian Taylor the scorer. It'll be their first FA Cup win since 1957.

Recommended bet
Correct score - Aston Villa 1 - 0 Chelsea
First scorer - Ian Taylor 16-1 (Ladbrokes)

fields.headline: Murder? More like clinical execution
fields.trailText: For all the pre-match psychobabble about "respecting the opposition", you always had the feeling that Nasser Hussain fancied England's chances. But 83 all out? David Lloyd had a phrase for this sort of thing, but today was more like clinical execution than murder.
fields.body:
For all the pre-match psychobabble about "respecting the opposition", you always had the feeling that Nasser Hussain fancied England's chances. But 83 all out? David Lloyd had a phrase for this sort of thing, but today was more like clinical execution than murder.

The myth that England are slow starters is becoming more and more urban. In 1997, they began the Test summer by humbling Australia for 118 at Edgbaston; a year later at the same ground they closed the first day of the series on 249 for 1 on a greentop against Donald and Pollock; and last season, again at their spiritual home in Birmingham, they bundled out the Kiwis for 226. Ok, so it may have been Zimbabwe they were duffing up this time, but at least it was at Lord's, where it's usually England who resemble the playground wimps.

Hussain was helped by winning the toss in overcast conditions in the middle of May (no Test has begun earlier in England), and by the frequent rain interruptions which allowed his bowlers to stay fresh, but they still had to put it in the right place. Andy Caddick, who probably can't remember when he last bowled a half-volley on leg stump, did that and more, finding the bounce and movement that eluded Darren Gough and generally making his new-ball partner look pedestrian by comparison. And Caddick might even have finished with six or seven wickets had he won his convincing appeal for caught behind against Andy Flower and so reduced Zimbabwe to 14 for 4. For all Ed Giddins's wickets - and well though he bowled - Caddick was indisputably the pick.

Other plusses included only two leg-byes in the extras column, and some sharp fielding - topped by Mark Ramprakash's reflex grab at short leg. A shame then that Ramps later fell leg before for 15 to take his Test tally at Lord's to 79 runs in nine innings at 8.78.

The only nitpick concerns Hussain's field settings. Zimbabwe scored 48 of their runs (58% of the total) through third man, which remained unprotected throughout the innings while mid-on twiddled his thumbs. It's one thing to attack; it's another to attack a team that barely played a shot in front of the wicket and existed off nudges and nurdles behind square. If mid-on had moved to third man, or even fourth slip, Zimbabwe would have struggled to pass their lowest score in Tests - the 63 they made in that thriller in Port-of-Spain in March.

It will take something suicidal for England to make a thriller out of this one.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

webTitle: Ethiopia gains upper hand in war with Eritrea

fields.headline: Ethiopia gains upper hand in war with Eritrea
fields.trailText: Ethiopia scored a major victory in its two-year border war with Eritrea after capturing the strategic town of Barentu and taking full control of the western battle front.
fields.body:
Ethiopia scored a major victory in its two-year border war with Eritrea after capturing the strategic town of Barentu and taking full control of the western battle front.

More than 200,000 Eritreans are fleeing the area after an advance by Ethiopian troops in a conflict reminiscent of the trench warfare of the first world war. Eritrea insists it made a strategic withdrawal, but presidential advisor Yemane Gebremeskel admitted hundreds of thousands of people were now leaving the area.

"The town of Barentu was evacuated prior to the withdrawal of the army," he said. "According to our relief organisation ... over 200,000 people from the Barentu area are heading east." Barentu, about 45 miles inside Eritrea, had served as a major command centre and supply route for Eritrea's army on the western Badme front.

Ethiopian forces launched a huge offensive last Friday and targeted Barentu in their drive to recapture territory they say has been occupied by Eritrea since May 1998, when a border dispute and trade policy differences exploded into war. "Losing Barentu is losing the whole western part of Eritrea," Ethiopian government spokesman Haile Kiros said.

He said the main objective was to secure the Barentu area and deploy troops and equipment eastwards to two other war fronts where Eritrean forces still occupy disputed territory. "We will keep enough troops here to defend the area and others will move to liberate the rest of our occupied territory," he said.

The UN security council yesterday imposed an arms embargo against the two countries for a year, but diplomats said the weapons ban would have little effect as both have plenty of weapons at their disposal. "Both sides have spent the last two years beefing up their armies," one diplomat said. "They have enough weapons to last for at least a year anyway."

The conflict has made it difficult for western aid agencies trying to provide relief for a region stricken by drought that could claim millions of lives. Ethiopia insists it was a victim of Eritrean aggression at the start of the war and blames the failure of all peace initiatives on Eritrean intransigence and the UN's refusal to take sides.

webTitle: Scottish anger as Straw lets Tyson fight

fields.headline: Scottish anger as Straw lets Tyson fight
fields.trailText: Politicians and women's groups in Scotland have condemned home secretary Jack Straw's decision to allow boxer Mike Tyson into the country for a fight on June 24.
fields.body:
Politicians and women's groups in Scotland have condemned home secretary Jack Straw's decision to allow boxer Mike Tyson into the country for a fight on June 24.

Members of the Scottish parliament have expressed anger that the convicted rapist should be granted an entry visa against the wishes of majority public opinion in Scotland.

However, Mr Straw said: "I am fully aware of the strong opinions which have been expressed on Mr Tyson's application, especially in Scotland - as I was when this matter last came before me in January.

"It is however my responsibility to make decisions of this kind as fairly and impartially as I can and that is what I have sought to do."

Scottish National Party leader Alex Salmond said: "This is a disgraceful decision, which will be greeted with dismay in Scotland.

"A London-based home secretary has overruled majority opinion in Scotland, and the clear view of the Scottish Parliament and even the Labour/Liberal administration."

Women's groups reacted angrily to the decision on Tyson, who was convicted of rape in the United States in 1992.

Oona Hay, training and development officers at the Rape Crisis Centre in Glasgow, said today: "We are very concerned that the feelings of Scottish people have been ignored.

"Our main concern is the message that is being sent to women and how seriously the government really takes violence against women."

fields.bodyText: Politicians and women's groups in Scotland have condemned home secretary Jack Straw's decision to allow boxer Mike Tyson into the country for a fight on June 24. Members of the Scottish parliament have expressed anger that the convicted rapist should be granted an entry visa against the wishes of majority public opinion in Scotland. However, Mr Straw said: "I am fully aware of the strong opinions which have been expressed on Mr Tyson's application, especially in Scotland - as I was when this matter last came before me in January. "It is however my responsibility to make decisions of this kind as fairly and impartially as I can and that is what I have sought to do." Scottish National Party leader Alex Salmond said: "This is a disgraceful decision, which will be greeted with dismay in Scotland. "A London-based home secretary has overruled majority opinion in Scotland, and the clear view of the Scottish Parliament and even the Labour/Liberal administration." fields.trailText: FA APOLOGISES FOR RIOT
fields.body:
FA APOLOGISES FOR RIOT

FA chief executive David Davies has apologised for the rioting in Copenhagen - but claims it won't damage England's bid to host the World Cup in 2006. "We apologise to the Danes for what happened in Copenhagen," he said today. "But the decision on 2006 will be about which country has the best bid, the best infrastructure and the best grounds. Something like this is unhelpful but other countries who are bidding have security and crime problems, perhaps more so than us."

The PFA chief Gordon Taylor has accused Uefa of failing to clamp down on Galatasaray's fans. "You didn't need to be Einstein to work out what was going to happen this week," said Taylor. "Galatasaray are a good side but as a club they have problems. There has been a regular trail of incidents involving that club and its supporters - and not just against English teams. When trouble brews with English supporters the punishments are strict but it doesn't seem to apply to the other countries."

Meanwhile, the organisers of Euro 2000 have responded to the rioting in Copenhagen by insisting they are ready to handle any hooligan threat. "We've been working on this for two years now. Every stadium is ready," said Euro 2000 spokesman Jan de Grave. "We cannot guarantee a 100% safe tournament but we are confident we've had the right preparation." Uefa have also confirmed that they will not switch England's Euro 2000 clash with Germany from Charleroi to Brussels despite fears over safety.

IT'S HAMMER TIME!

There's been plenty of activity in the East End today. Sadly, we've been warned off filing our report on how Eyebrows Geoff pulled off a very lucrative arms and drugs deal in Bow, so the news that West Ham have completed the permanent signing of Lyon striker Frederic Kanoute will have to do. Kanoute has cost the Hammers £4m, but as they've sent kick-happy Marc-Vivien Foe the other way for £6m, they've made a tidy profit of two (extremely) long ones.

West Ham had been worried that cheeky footpads Chelsea's of Chelsea would swipe Kanoute from under their noses after the Frenchman's shop-window period at Upton Park started impressively. Kanoute had shown he could cope with the quality of Premiership football in the Hammers' match against, er, Wimbledon, and that was enough to convince Gianluca Vialli to offer Lyon £4m for him. But Kanoute, who obviously understands what loyalty means in his new surroundings, has been as good as his word and pledged his future to the Hammers.

"I'm sure our supporters will be delighted we've signed Freddie and that he will be a valuable asset to the team," said no-cock-ups-as-of-yet Hammers official Paul Aldridge. "At the same time we are sorry to lose Marc," he continued, grinning like a nutter, "but it was always his intention to return to France and the deal represents good business for West Ham." True. But we don't expect Eyebrows Geoff to turn green at the news.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"With the Englishman [McManaman], Del Bosque has found the companion to Redondo in the heart of the side that had previously been occupied by mere stand-in tenants. McManaman has joined the axis and manages to magnetise all the play that Real Madrid want to control" - Former Spanish international Michel makes a bid for Pseud's Corner.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ABSOLUTELY FABULIST

Yesterday the Fiver may have given the impression that Lorenzo Amoruso - Glasgow O'Rangers captain and sometime mutterer of racist obscenities - had fallen out with his Ibrox paymasters. In fact, we may even have quoted an interview with Rangers News in which he said: "There is just no respect in football. When they don't need you they kick you in the backside." But today we are forced to admit that Lorenzo never did say them things. If you take Lorenzo's word for it, that is.

"All I said was if I am leaving the club this summer then it will be because both the club and I have agreed to it," Lorenzo said, with absolutely no fingers crossed, earlier today. "I didn't say anything about the club kicking me in the arse." Remembering sharpish that he was also the man who once claimed he had never called Victor Ikpeba a "black bastard", Lorenzo went on: "I am a little bit stupid sometimes but I am not so stupid I would say these things to the club newspaper."

Righty-ho then. So that would be why said club newspaper today issued a statement that read: "The Rangers News has no intention of falling out with Lorenzo Amoruso, we have too much respect for him. He spoke for himself here and accordingly, we have listened to our tape of the interview." Now the Fiver is no Lou Grant, but it sounds like the News are sticking to their story. Which raises the terrible possibility of the lank-haired Italian being made to look a fool twice in one week. You see, while Lorenzo is busy arguing about his future at the club, the club are also busy - trying to sign his replacement - (yet another) Dutch international Bert Konterman. Talk about a kick in the arse.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

French goalkeeper Fabien Barthez has denied reports he is set to join Manchester United. "I have not received any offer from Manchester," Barthez told a news conference. "I can tell you I will be at Monaco next season. I'm not trying to leave my club."

Chilean international midfielder Clarence Acuna is apparently off to Tottenham. Universidad de Chile president Rene Orozco admitted: "We have reached an agreement with the English. He is sold to England over the last few days."

Liverpool defender Rigobert Song has expressed an interest in joining Celtic after playing against them in Ronnie Moran's testimonial on Tuesday. "I know they have not yet got a new manager," he said, "but I hope that I impressed some of the people at Celtic."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Galatasaray manager Fatih Terim has revealed that he intends to step down as manager. "It is over for me," he said. "Enough is enough. We have won the Uefa Cup, let someone else win [Big Cup]."

David Dein has vowed to ban for life any Arsenal season ticket holders who are found guilty of violent conduct prior to the Uefa Cup final.

Paul Gascoigne returned to action for the first time since breaking his arm as Middlesbrough lost 1-0 to Libya earlier today. Gascoigne, the most recognisable of the visiting players, was cheered by the 16,000 Tripoli crowd after every touch.

Newcastle boss Bobby Robson has branded walkabout midfielder Silvio Maric a disgrace after he failed to turn up for the club's Caribbean tour. "He's been unprofessional, disrespectful to the club and his team-mates and it's a disgraceful act. Whatever the maximum fine is, he will get it," said a furious Robson.

Leeds United's plan to take a 9.9% stake in Oldham Athletic has been put on hold because the deal contravenes Football League regulations.

The Scotland squad to face the Republic of Ireland at Lansdowne Road on May 30 is: Gould, Sullivan, Dailly, Elliott, Naysmith, O'Neil, Ritchie, Telfer, Burley, Cameron, Durrant, Ferguson, Holt, Johnston, Lambert, Burchill, Dodds, Gallacher, Hutchison, McCann.

Fulham defender Chris Coleman has been ruled out of Wales' forthcoming friendly matches against Brazil and Portugal.

webTitle: Judges back family on death in custody

fields.headline: Judges back family on death in custody
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The family of a black remand prisoner who died after a struggle with warders won a five-year battle for justice yesterday when the lord chief justice set aside a decision by the director of public prosecutions not to prosecute anyone.
fields.body:
The family of a black remand prisoner who died after a struggle with warders won a five-year battle for justice yesterday when the lord chief justice set aside a decision by the director of public prosecutions not to prosecute anyone.

Alton Manning, 33, died at Blakenhurst privatised prison in Worcestershire in 1995, and an inquest two years ago ruled that he had been unlawfully killed. Yesterday Lord Bingham, sitting with Mr Justice Morison, ruled that the decision not to bring manslaughter charges against a warder who held the prisoner in a neck-lock was flawed and came "as something of a surprise".

Lord Bingham stressed that the director, David Calvert-Smith QC, was not required to prosecute, only to reconsider the question. "On the likely or proper outcome of that reconsideration we express no opinion at all," he added.

The ruling could result in the first prosecution for the death of a black man in custody, and was greeted with jublilation by the dead man's family and friends in the high court. "They made the right decision today and we'll just keep on fighting until someone is prosecuted," said his sister, Elizabeth Melbourne, who with his other sister, Patricia Manning, brought the action for judicial review.

The ruling also established the principle that, where an inquest jury found a prisoner had been unlawfully killed, the "ordinary expectation would naturally be that a prosecution would follow"; if not, the prosecutions director would be expected to give the family detailed reasons - something he had not been required to do.

The family's solicitor, Raju Bhatt, said it was a landmark ruling: "This decision is immensely significant, because it means no one is above prosecution - even when they wear the uniform of a prison officer or police officer."

A fortnight ago the high court had heard there was evidence "unreasonable restraint" was used when Mr Manning was asphyxiated during a struggle with several officers at Blakenhurst. The prisoner, who was facing trial on two assault charges, had been carried out of his cell in a neckhold, head first and face down, after allegedly assaulting an officer who had asked him to squat naked for a drugs inspection.

The crown prosecution service considered whether to bring charges in 1996, 1997, and again in 1999 following the inquest. It decided that, while there was a prima facie case against one warder, there was no realistic prospect of a conviction. The judges yesterday cited evidence that had not been addressed.

The prosecution service is considering whether to seek leave to appeal to the Lords.

webTitle: Hooligans hold World Cup in their hands

fields.headline: Hooligans hold World Cup in their hands
fields.standfirst: With the vote on the venue for the 2006 World Cup just six weeks away, the behaviour of England's fans could be the deciding factor, writes Matthew Joseph
fields.trailText: With the vote on the venue for the 2006 World Cup just six weeks away, the behaviour of England's fans could be the deciding factor, writes Matthew Joseph.
fields.body:
The violence and mayhem that preceded Wednesday night's Uefa Cup final in Copenhagen may not in itself adversely affect England's bid to stage the 2006 World Cup. But any repeat at Euro 2000 of the hooliganism that erupted in the Danish capital could wreck the entire £10 million programme of intensive lobbying by the English campaign team.

David Davies, the Football Association's executive director, did his best to play down Wednesday night's rioting in a statement this morning. But he knows all too well that the spectre of fans rampaging through Holland and Belgium in June represents the worst nightmare of those who have spent the best part of four years trying to bring the World Cup back to England for the first time since 1966, the nation's greatest footballing hour.

Davies insisted the contender with the best facilities - Germany, South Africa, Brazil and Morocco are the other candidates - would win the vote on July 6. That's what he said in public, at least. In private, he and everyone else associated with England's bid realise there is far more to it than that.

Only last week, Bobby Charlton, one of English football's best-loved heroes and the country's main 2006 World Cup ambassador, repeated again that hooliganism in Holland and Belgium was his only remaining fear in terms of losing out to one of the other candidates.

The eagerly awaited decision in Zurich by Fifa's 24-member executive committee is so close to the end of Euro 2000 that any members of the committee who have not made up their minds which way to vote could well be influenced by sudden outbreaks of fan violence a few days beforehand.

Charlton and campaign director Alec McGivan are currently in Kuala Lumpur trying to persuade the four Asian members of the Fifa executive committee to vote for England. McGivan, too, admits that any fan disruption in Holland and Belgium would "not be helpful" to England's cause . Privately, he concedes that the hooliganism in Marseille during the last World Cup forced his campaign team to step up the public relations effort in order to get the bid back on track.

By now, both McGivan and Charlton will know about events in Copenhagen and will almost certainly be requesting a full dossier of who caused it, especially since England and Turkey are scheduled to play within 24 hours of each other at Euro 2000, in cities that are less than 50 miles apart.

Significantly, Davies said in his statement today that further discussions would be held with the tournament authorities to discover whether any more could be done to prevent what has, in the past, been described as the "English disease".

To be fair, violent behaviour at English domestic games has ground to a virtual halt in recent months. There was hardly any trouble, for instance, at Euro 96. Policing of English matches is a highly-sophisticated operation these days.

World Cup campaigners would argue that English football traditionally exports its violence but that is unlikely to impress the 24 Fifa bigwigs who will file into a smoke-free room on July 6 to name the venue. To them, image will be all-important. Hence the concern of McGivan, Charlton and others.

So far, England have, in all probability, a maximum of six votes on board - enough to get them through the first round of balloting in Zurich but not enough to win the vote outright. Any Euro 2000 violence would play straight into the hands of the South Africans, especially if German fans were to also run riot.

With three weeks to go before Euro 2000, and six before the World Cup vote, a lot of fingers will be kept firmly crossed and a lot of finger-nails chewed to the bone.

Any Euro 2000 violence would play straight into the hands of the South Africans, especially if German fans were to also run riot. With three weeks to go before Euro 2000, and six before the World Cup vote, a lot of fingers will be kept firmly crossed and a lot of finger-nails chewed to the bone.

webTitle: How the GM cat got out of the bag

fields.headline: How the GM cat got out of the bag
fields.standfirst: The government should be honest about GM contamination and admit that it cannot control the spread of GM crops, says community affairs editor James Meikle
fields.trailText: Thursday, 4.30pm update: The government should be honest about GM contamination and admit that it cannot control the spread of GM crops, says community affairs editor James Meikle
fields.body:
Last night's revelation that conventional crop seed planted in Britain, but grown from nurseries on the Canadian prairie, had been contaminated by genetically modified neighbouring seed grown well over 800 metres away is not only a huge embarrassment to the government, it also raises serious questions about the quality of the scientific advice it has been getting.

Such cross-pollination over such distances was not meant to happen. If Advanta, the seed company, are "gob-smacked", how is the ordinary consumer meant to feel?

Ministers were yesterday presenting the disaster as if a few rogue GM seeds had got into batches of conventional seed. Oh, that it was that simple! That would be serious, but containable.

The fact that the international seed giants who want to carry on producing conventional varieties are now moving their fields hundreds or even thousands of miles (to New Zealand) to protect the purity of such products just shows how serious the problem really is.

The government may scoff at those who have called for six-mile exclusion zones round GM sites here - organic farmers and bee-keepers among them - but public trust is now bound to be seriously dented by an abject failure of national and international law.

This morning, government officials insisted there had been no intention to mislead. No law had been broken. It was up to farmers whether or not they wanted to destroy their crops. It is also apparently up to them whether they tell their local communities they have unwittingly been growing contaminated crops. There will not be a penny of government compensation for those who may lose business from food producers who may no longer want to trade with them.

This "not our fault, guv" attitude just will not wash. This "mistake" was revealed by random testing in a German state. We have not had such a system. We will now. But the government really must be secretly worried that it now cannot control the slow spread of GM crops across the country. Because we have been importing food with GM ingredients for years, it has effectively already admitted it cannot control international trade.

It says that GM trial crops are no risk to human health or the environment, yet says none will go on sale here until further trials are completed in 2003. It makes much of consumer choice saying people have a right not to eat even such "safe" food if they do not want to, but now it behaves as if it is powerless to act when GM-contaminated crops have in fact already been accidentally grown, processed and consumed in this country. It may be the case it is now powerless. If it is, ministers should have the guts to say so.

fields.headline: Charles Darwin
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the father of evolution on the net
fields.trailText: The bushy British naturalist is the new face of the £10 note
fields.body:
1. Charles Darwin has beaten Victorian rival Charles Dickens by a whisker to become the face of the new £10 note.

2. As anti-crime technology marches on, the Bank of England has decided that the eminent naturalist provides a better guarantee against forgery because he has such a great beard.

3. In the survival of the fittest, the vanquished novelist has learnt that bushiness is all.

4. Eminent figures have been a feature of banknotes since 1970.

5. Darwin is a profound influence on modern thought. In two books - The Origin of Species and The Descent of Man - he put forward a theory of evolution and said our ancestors were apes.

6. His ideas were controversial because he argued against creation as it is told in the Bible and undermined the ages-old distinction between man and beast.

7. Tennessee banned the teaching of evolution in 1925 from its schools and universities. Today, Arizona and Alabama have done the same.

8. Darwin's supporters are equally zealous. In 1912, Charles Dawson, Sir Arthur Smith Woodward and others used the Piltdown man hoax to claim they had found the missing link.

9. The theory of evolution came from Darwin's observation of Galapogos tortoises. Harriet the tortoise, who legend says was taken to London by Darwin, is still around today - and you can watch her 167th birthday video here.

10. The Journal of Mundane Behaviour suggests that facial hair like the father of evolution's is a signifier of masculinity that shifts with the times.
