webTitle: Pope under pressure to resign after jubilee

fields.headline: Pope under pressure to resign after jubilee
fields.trailText: The crowning moment of an extraordinary reign may turn sour today when Pope John Paul II's 80th birthday is expected to trigger the fiercest clamour yet for his resignation.
fields.body:
The crowning moment of an extraordinary reign may turn sour today when Pope John Paul II's 80th birthday is expected to trigger the fiercest clamour yet for his resignation.

As thousands of priests celebrate his birthday at a mass in St Peter's Square in Rome, leading theologians and clerics have warned that the Pope's ailing health is allowing rightwing bureaucrats in the Vatican administration - the curia - to seize control.

They claim that John Paul's focus on big events, such as visiting the holy land, mask a faltering grip on day-to-day power.

The Pope's own words can be cited in support of their view; four years ago he reaffirmed rules excluding cardinals over 80 from conclaves to elect a pontiff, saying: "The reason for this provision is the desire not to add to the weight of such venerable age the further burden of responsibility for choosing the one who has to lead Christ's flock."

The Pope's mental health remains sound but Parkinson's disease and the legacy of five major operations have left him with slurred speech, stooped and trembling.

Traditional low-key papal birthday celebrations will be cast aside to make today's mass a highlight of the Vatican's holy year, or jubilee.

Polish countrymen will sing the traditional birthday song Sto Lat (May you live 100 years) and the Vatican and Poland have also issued commemorative stamps showing the mature pope in profile.

Vatican sources say the Pope now wants to retire to a Polish monastery, but believes that God wants him to continue his reign and that his suffering offers a model for the faithful.

Vittorio Messori, who collaborated on John Paul's best-selling 1994 book, Crossing the Threshold of Hope, said he believes that the Pope is torn. "For some time, he has been asking God which is better, to keep bearing his cross or - for his own good and the good of the church - to lay it down," he said.

Praising his leadership, columnists from La Repubblica and La Stampa have urged John Paul to complete his 22-year reign by pulling off one final "revolutionary" surprise - resignation.

According to church law, a pope can resign but he has to do so freely and, since he is supreme pontiff, no one has to accept his resignation. The last to do so was willingly was Celestine V, who stepped down in 1294. Gregory XII abdicated reluctantly in 1415.

Cardinal Franz König, the former archbishop of Vienna, said that curia bureaucrats were hoarding power, causing the Pope "considerable suffering". He also hinted that John Paul was a prisoner in the Vatican.

The Tablet, a Catholic weekly, said other bishops shared that concern: "For it is clear that while John Paul continues to dominate his church, he is in frail health now, and cannot possibly shoulder the full extent of the papal burden."

The Vatican has been trying to dampen such speculation since January when Bishop Karl Lehmann, head of the German bishops' conference, suggested the Pope should resign if he felt he could no longer do the job.

Even the Catholic News Service has reported Vatican sources saying that a Pope who becomes so ill that he cannot speak could resign to create a smooth succession. One date often floated is Easter 2001, when the jubilee ends.

Liberals, many of whom are hoping the next pope will be more progressive, say he should retire for the church's good.

"I think it would be healthy for the Church to be open to the idea that a pope could retire. I don't think it should be mandatory, but possible," said Frances Kissling, president of the American dissident group Catholics for a Free Choice.

However Margaret Hebblethwaite, co-author of The Next Pope, said his retirement was a nightmare scenario. "He is such a strong personality, and the church's tradition of praising past popes is so strong, that it would not be so much a matter of having a backseat driver, à la Thatcher, as of having a puppet government.

"Let us enjoy his good points while he lives, and then have a clean break. There are not many voices in the church saying he should retire, though there are plenty saying 'Please God give us a different pope'. The more frail he becomes the more the curia have a free hand."

She said it was a matter of debate how much to blame the curia and how much to blame John Paul, who appointed them. "However, year by year, the curia come to be seen more and more as the bogeymen, and I'm sure that is right," she added.

Great and the good

Few popes have been as venerable, or reigned as long, as John Paul II, who was elected in October 1978. Needless to say, longevity and greatness are not always connected.

·St Peter, a Galilean fisherman and disciple, became the first pope after Christ was crucified. He built up the fledgling church by travelling widely. He founded the holy see at Rome but fell foul of Emperor Nero and was crucified around AD67. St Peter's basilica is built on the alleged site of his tomb.

·St Leo the Great reigned from AD440 to 461 and was credited with crushing heresy, persuading Attila the Hun to leave Italy and talking King Geiseric's Vandals out of massacring Rome's inhabitants.

·Pius IV reformed the church during his six-year tenure, 1559-65. Also known for burning up his corpulence with long country walks.

·Pius XII reigned from 1939 to 1958 and is remembered mostly for not speaking out against the Holocaust and curbing dissension.

·John XXIII reigned from 1958 to 1963, won acclaim for calling the second vatican council, which blew a liberalising gale through the church.

·John Paul I, the smiling pope, died in September 1978 only 33 days after his election. He laughed, spoke from the heart, abolished customs such as the coronation tiara and pioneered a simpler approach.

He was succeeded by the present pope.

fields.headline: Should the Pope retire?
fields.standfirst: Religious affairs correspondent Stephen Bates considers the implications of Pope John Paul II retiring early
fields.trailText: Thursday, 6pm: Religious affairs correspondent Stephen Bates considers the implications of Pope John Paul II retiring early
fields.body:
Today's celebrations at the Vatican for the 80th birthday of Pope John Paul II were overshadowed - as all such gatherings are these days - by the continuing gossip about the pontiff's health and ghoulish speculation about what will happen next.

It is not just the world's media which is sitting like crows on a gatepost waiting for the end, but the church's hierarchy, from the smart, cassock-clad young men of the curia to the most senior scarlet-accoutred cardinal discreetly checking the plane times for the conclave, which will choose the pope's successor.

Increasingly, there are murmurings that, as the pope grows ever more frail with Parkinson's disease, he might care to contemplate retirement to a monastery as a more comfortable alternative to a slow decline and then dying alone in his bed in the Vatican.

As his predecessor, Pope John XXIII, once mournfully murmured, there is something infinitely sad about knowing that you are going to sleep every night in the bed in which you will be one day destined to die - even if, for pontiffs as much as any other priest, death must surely only be the prelude to something infinitely more glorious, that they have spent their whole lives preparing for.

But before the papal chamberlain approaches the bed armed with the silver hammer with which he will strike the pope's head - the traditional test to determine whether he is really dead or merely sleeping - the retirement option is one which ought to be seriously considered.

There are precedents, though admittedly not recent ones, not many of them and not always embraced voluntarily, but John Paul II, who has already had the longest reign for more than 120 years, might like to consider the advantages of becoming the first pope since Gregory XII in 1415 to step down early.

The chances are that he will not do so. This is a Pope very sure of his destiny and of his personal indispensability. Like the Queen, he has many virtues, but resignation is not one of them. More than most, he will be keen that his legacy of rightwing theological orthodoxy is maintained.

He has consciously constructed it during the 22 years of his papacy: the curia is set in his image, and no less than 94 of the 106 cardinals who will choose his successor are his appointees. The fact that cardinals aged over 80 are no longer allowed to vote in papal elections and that he has now joined their age group will not trouble him in the least: he is set apart by virtue of his office. The Pope knows best.

These are all of course the very reasons why the present pope should stand down, in order to breathe new life and vigour into a waning papacy. Ironically, they may ultimately be the reason why that conclave of cardinals may choose a successor as unlike John Paul II as possible (the conclave has a history of doing this). How much better to step down now to preserve the integrity of his reign intact rather than waiting for the soft tread of the man with the silver hammer.

webTitle: Edward Woodward tipped to play Bond boss

fields.headline: Edward Woodward tipped to play Bond boss
fields.trailText: Edward Woodward is reported to be the first choice to play 007's boss and mentor M in the new James Bond picture
fields.body:
Edward Woodward is reported to be the first choice to play 007's boss and mentor M in the new James Bond picture. The 69 year-old actor will take over from Dame Judi Dench when the movie (working title: Beyond the Ice) begins shooting early next year. Dench has co-starred opposite Pierce Brosnan as the starchy-but-loveable M in the past three outings (The World is Not Enough, Tomorrow Never Dies and GoldenEye). Before that, the role was played by Bernard Lee, grandfather of actor Jonny Lee Miller.

According to a report in today's Daily Mirror, the brains behind the Bond series were impressed with Woodward after catching his performance in last year's update of the Seventies cop show The Professionals. The British actor has enjoyed cult status for his role as a virginal policeman in the 1970 chiller The Wicker Man and mainstream success as the star of the 80s American TV series The Equaliser.

In recent years, Woodward has limited his output after suffering a serious heart attack in the mid 1990s. He currently lives with his wife in semi-retirement in Cornwall, but may well be tempted back by the big money on offer for starring in a Bond movie.

fields.headline: Weblife: Shakespeare
fields.standfirst: Emma Gibson  surfs for the Bard and finds the world's her oyster
fields.trailText: Emma Gibson surfs for the Bard and finds the world's her oyster
fields.body:
After seven mis-informed years when I thought I was going to succeed as an actor (that is, spend more time in front of an audience than behind a cappuccino machine) I pretty much covered the full gamut of Shakespeare monologues for auditions. I was also a rather bored spear-carrier in some of his most popular plays.

That all-important Method approach to characterisation and research (which way to approach the role, which end of the spear to stab Macbeth with at the end of Act V), was backed up by the crucial Cole's Notes and the odd BBC video. There was little other material for such a busy jobbing actress to lay her hands on.

Five years on, I can look back fondly at my delusions and plummy tones without getting the urge to go back to drama school or get involved in yet another underpaid fringe show. I no longer go green with envy when one of my contemporaries shows up on TV. But it is not just my adolescent emotions that are moving forwards - for the time-pressed thespian, research resources are proliferating online.

I discovered this through a fairly innocuous inquiry about the plot of Richard II (which had only a little to do with wanting to play opposite Ralph Fiennes in the current London production). An initial simple search on William Shakespeare via www.yahoo.co.uk revealed a wealth of useful and useless information.

I found the plot summary I was looking for at www.gradesaver.com , but www.ardenshakespeare.com is also a good site. Arden also has a subscription-based online service, Ardenonline, which offers detailed teaching and research tools as well as the complete texts. All the study guides offer excellent plot summaries, scene breakdowns and character analysis. No need to get your Henrys in a muddle.

There are many e-texts at www.ulen.com/shakespeare/plays (no charge here) and first folio editions at http://etext.lib. virginia.edu/shakespeare/folio/ foliobrowse.html

For the novice, a good but uninspired history of Shakespeare can be found at http://encarta.msn.com.

www.ac.uk.globe/Globe.html, the official site of The Globe Theatre in London, offers slightly more refreshing information about the newly renovated Elizabethan Theatre and has links to other related sites (study guides, International Shakespeare Companies and generalised theatre listings). There are also virtual reality views of the rebuilt theatre.

The RSC website is also worth a visit, if only to find out what is showing and how many spear-carriers may be needed in forthcoming productions

One wonders if Shakespeare is chuckling from his great Bard heaven at the sudden resurgence of interest in his works - especially if he did not the write them. The authorship debate rages online. Edward de Vere, the 17th Earl of Oxford, is the most famous pretender and an excellent website to back up his case can be found at www.shakespeare-oxford.com.

Supporters of William himself can address the authorship problem at www.clark.net/pub/tross/ws/will.html. Bacon supporters have a site at www.sirbacon.org or if you feel that it is you who may have written the plays in a previous incarnation then it's worth testing your poetic abilities before you set up your own site.

Try www.shakespeare.com, "an interactive hypermedia environment dedicated to the increasingly popular understanding and enjoyment of Shakespeare's plays and other works". I particularly enjoyed the magnet poetry which picked a random array of the Bard's words and allowed me to put them together into a line of poetry. However, it soon became clear that I have never been the playwright in question.

For visuals, check out the VRML Dream website (link through the Globe's website) which offers an experiment in virtual reality Shakespeare online. The original full-length version of A Midsummer Night's Dream was broadcast over the net on April 26, 1998, with each viewer able to control their personal viewpoint.

Hard copies of all the plays can be bought from www.amazon.co.uk and there is a comprehensive listing of Shakespeare plays on video at www.trumedia.co.uk. If your credit card limit is back in the 16th century, like mine, then offload with some abuse. www.insults.net, has a plentiful supply of Shakespearean insults. Just choose your play and fire away.

Finally, check out some online discussion with the newsgroups. Vital questions pondering the Bard's sexuality and Gwyneth Paltrow's hairdresser often pop up. I went to www.dejanews.com and keyed in Shakespeare. For something a little more high brow, try the discussion group at humanities.lit.authors. shakespeare

So as I watch yet another production of Richard II and muse on what could have been, I can at least rest assured that I will have something to talk about in the bar afterwards. If a 400-year-old dramatist can be so comprehensively covered online, then surely it will not be long before Prospero spies on errant sailors through a web cam and Romeo sends his beloved an email via his mobile phone.

The internet is such a wonder - or in the words of the man himself, it's "the barber's chair that fits all buttocks". (Alls Well That Ends Well. Act II, scene ii, by Shakespeare, Bacon, Marlowe or De Vere...)

webTitle: May 18: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: May 18: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Ben Stiller ties the knot, the Motion Picture Association hits out at internet piracy, Hollywood musical chairs for Tony Scott, and Emily Watson and Michael York on the casting couch
fields.body:
 Ben Stiller has married his actress girlfriend Christine Taylor in a private ceremony on the Hawaiian island of Kauai. The service was attended by Stiller's parents, the actors Anne Mearer (The Daytrippers) and Jerry Stiller (best known as George's curmudgeonly dad in the sitcom Seinfeld). Stiller first met Taylor last autumn when they were working together on a TV pilot. Stiller, 34, rose to fame in films like Flirting with Disaster and Mystery Men. Taylor, 28, is best known for her turn as the apple-pie daughter Marcia Brady in The Brady Bunch Movie and A Very Brady Sequel.

 Jack Valenti, the venerated chairman of the Motion Picture Association of America, used his platform at the Cannes Film Festival to hit out at what he regards as the internet's damaging effect on international film production. In setting itself up as a conduit for pirated films, Valenti cautioned, the net was hurting film-makers from across the world. "Copyright is an issue which is drawing all content providers together," he told reporters. "...There are still a lot of people who believe that anything on the internet is free and even find it suitable to circumvent encryption on the absurd argument that it is part of their freedom of speech."

 In a classic example of Hollywood musical chairs, Tony Scott has bailed from the FBI drama Take Down and is in negotiations to direct the independent espionage thriller Spy Game. Scott will be filling the void left by Spy Game's original director, Mike Van Diem, who dropped out of the project last week due to "creative differences". Van Diem (who won a Best Foreign Film Oscar for his 1997 picture Character) is now considering directing a movie for Mel Gibson. Spy Game stars Robert Redford as a veteran CIA agent and Brad Pitt as his young rookie. The picture was originally conceived as a low-budget production, but its big-name cast and costly director now look set to push its budget to around the $70m mark.

 Breaking the Waves star Emily Watson has signed on to act in the thriller In Search of the Assassin, which tells the tale of a bomb attack in Central America. The film begins production this November in locations around Costa Rica and the UK. Lee Tamahori (Once Were Warriors, Mulholland Falls) will direct.

 British actor Michael York is to reprise his role as the ultimate villain in Megiddo, the sequel to last year's thriller The Omega Code. Bankrolled by a Christian organisation - the Trinity Broadcasting Network - and scoffed at by the critics, The Omega Code proved a surprise hit at the US box-office and cast York as Stone Alexander, the chairman of the European Union who turns out (get this) to be the Devil in disguise. "I was Judas betraying Christ," Stone explains at one point. "I was Hitler leading millions of Jews to be slaughtered. I was the drunk driver who killed your mother." With dialogue like that, it's small wonder that York is returning for another bite at the apple.

Taylor, 28, is best known for her turn as the apple-pie daughter Marcia Brady in The Brady Bunch Movie and A Very Brady Sequel.  Jack Valenti, the venerated chairman of the Motion Picture Association of America, used his platform at the Cannes Film Festival to hit out at what he regards as the internet's damaging effect on international film production. In setting itself up as a conduit for pirated films, Valenti cautioned, the net was hurting film-makers from across the world. "Copyright is an issue which is drawing all content providers together," he told reporters. "...There are still a lot of people who believe that anything on the internet is free and even find it suitable to circumvent encryption on the absurd argument that it is part of their freedom of speech."  In a classic example of Hollywood musical chairs, Tony Scott has bailed from the FBI drama Take Down and is in negotiations to direct the independent espionage thriller Spy Game. Scott will be filling the void left by Spy Game's original director, Mike Van Diem, who dropped out of the project last week due to "creative differences". Van Diem (who won a Best Foreign Film Oscar for his 1997 picture Character) is now considering directing a movie for Mel Gibson. Spy Game stars Robert Redford as a veteran CIA agent and Brad Pitt as his young rookie. The picture was originally conceived as a low-budget production, but its big-name cast and costly director now look set to push its budget to around the $70m mark.  Breaking the Waves star Emily Watson has signed on to act in the thriller In Search of the Assassin, which tells the tale of a bomb attack in Central America. The film begins production this November in locations around Costa Rica and the UK. Lee Tamahori (Once Were Warriors, Mulholland Falls) will direct.  British actor Michael York is to reprise his role as the ultimate villain in Megiddo, the sequel to last year's thriller The Omega Code. Bankrolled by a Christian organisation - the Trinity Broadcasting Network - and scoffed at by the critics, The Omega Code proved a surprise hit at the US box-office and cast York as Stone Alexander, the chairman of the European Union who turns out (get this) to be the Devil in disguise. "I was Judas betraying Christ," Stone explains at one point. "I was Hitler leading millions of Jews to be slaughtered. I was the drunk driver who killed your mother." With dialogue like that, it's small wonder that York is returning for another bite at the apple.

fields.headline: The government's GM confession
fields.standfirst: Extract from the written answers to House of Commons questions on 17 May 2000
fields.trailText: Agriculture, fisheries and food
fields.body:
Agriculture, fisheries and food

Seed Purity

Judy Mallaber [Labour MP for Amber Valley]: To ask the minister of agriculture, fisheries and food what action the government are taking to address the issue of seed purity.

Ms Quin [Joyce Quin, agriculture, fisheries and food minister]: We are taking several new steps to ensure seed purity, in addition to the current consultation on the importation and labelling of seeds. These include pressing internationally for agreed standards, testing of seed imports to the UK and working with the industry on a code of practice.

The need for action in this area is highlighted by the recent information we have received from Advanta Seeds UK that some of its conventional rapeseed sold and sown in 1999 and 2000 in several EU member states, including the UK, contained about 1 per cent. of genetically modified rapeseed.

The genetic modification in question has already been assessed and cleared for food use and for field trials in the UK. We have consulted both ACRE (The Advisory Committee on Releases to the Environment) and the Food Standards Agency who have confirmed the view that there is no risk to public health or the environment.

fields.headline: Copenhagen's hall of shame
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited editor Paul MacInnes berates the minority behind yesterday's violence in Copenhagen, but says that's no reason for the press to go off the rails when reporting the incident
fields.trailText: Thursday, 1pm: Football Unlimited editor Paul MacInnes berates the minority behind yesterday's violence in Copenhagen, but says that's no reason for the press to go off the rails when reporting the incident
fields.body:
As the dust settles over yesterday's events in Copenhagen, England is coming to terms with another day of shame. Once more, the nation has been embarrassed by a minority who travel to football matches looking for trouble. Time after time, they fail to take responsibility for the consequences of their actions. They are a disgrace to every right-thinking person in this country. And to be honest, it's about time the press grew up.

"They came to kill," screamed the Mirror this morning with a front-page photo of a "swaggering Turkish soccer lout" armed with a "murderous knife and an axe handle". The Sun reported on the "Battle of Copenhagen" (a phrase also to be found in the Daily Telegraph) with several large illustrations, including one of "an English skinhead wading into a Turk". The Daily Mail meanwhile accused Galatasaray of "shamefully" winning the "Cup of death".

There is no way that anyone can countenance the behaviour of those involved in the fighting in City Hall square. Neither should the media refrain from reporting these incidents. But the simple fact is that whenever such incidents occur abroad, they are covered in a crass and jingoistic manner with very little attention paid to the facts.

Fourty people were arrested after yesterday's disturbances. Eighteen of these people were English. More would be arrested during an average Saturday night in any British town. Police Superintendent Andrew Smith, the senior British police officer at the game, told BBC Radio 4's Today programme this morning that while "there were certainly two areas of confrontation of fans - in the main city square and in a smaller square a few 100 metres away", events were "more isolated than the impression given by some reports".

These reports gave the impression that the incidents, far from being isolated, were in fact bordering on anarchy; the same impression in fact that was given after the riots in Marseille during the 1998 World Cup in France, despite the fact that some of the most striking images seemed posed.

It also might not be too far-fetched to suggest that the sheer number of cameras and journalists in Copenhagen may have influenced the way hooligans behaved in front of them.

Whatever the truth behind yesterday's incidents - and the truth may never actually be determined - one thing is for sure: stories and, more importantly, gory images of hooliganism sell newspapers and provide tacit justification for editorial that veers from the prudishly outraged to the downright racist.

fields.headline: Look back in anger
fields.standfirst: It's time to look back on another season of crass decisions and compromise. WSC isn't happy
fields.trailText: It's time to look back on another season of crass decisions and compromise. WSC isn't happy.
fields.body:
It's an appropriate moment in the football season to look back, and not just on the past nine months. Actually, make that 11 months, since the Intertoto is just around the corner again for the lucky losers of the FA Cup final.

With the Uefa Cup final and the Champions League final sandwiching what was once the centre piece of the domestic season, it's worth reflecting on how all three have been bastardised, to the point where the description "devalued" is itself becoming devalued through overuse.

Two decisions stand out. The first was Uefa's concession to the big European clubs in allowing non-champions to take part in the Champions League. There are compromises that have to be made, but some that should never be made, and that was one of them. The result is that this year, like last, neither of the two teams in the Champions League final qualified for the tournament by winning their domestic league.

Valencia will surely have the sympathy of all neutrals on Wednesday, but the concept of "champions" will be stretched even further than it already has been if a club that finished fourth in its league turns up at the end to collect the trophy.

The Uefa Cup, never exactly a thoroughbred, has been hopelessly compromised by its function as a repository for failed Champions League teams, two of which contested this year's final. Naturally, Galatasaray will not be defending the trophy next season, unless of course they flunk out in the Champions League again.

It's hardly an original complaint, but even with the whole of Europe agog at the absurdities the current structure produces, Uefa can hardly be expected to go back on the main plank of the deal that headed off the alleged breakaway by the Milan-led superclubs. The Champions League will never be returned to its status as, well, as champions' cup. All the other indignities and tawdry kow-towing follow from that one decision.

For the poor old FA Cup, the single worst blow came as a final nail in the coffin rather than a knockout punch. When the FA themselves incited Manchester United not to defend the trophy, the Cup seemed to lose the will to live.

Having already endured the crass decisions to allow sponsorship and curtail replays, the invitation to Cliff Richard to sing Abide With Me, this year's crippling shuffle of the calendar and the buttock-clenching embarrassment of "celebrity" draws hosted by David Davies, there is not much left of what the Cup once was. All that is left is for the final to be settled by penalties, as it surely will, if not this year then pretty soon.

Does it matter? Obviously not to some people. But there must surely be a nagging doubt even in their minds when the climax to the season hinges on who finishes third in the Premiership, rather than the championship race or the FA Cup final.

webTitle: How to survive your big day

fields.headline: How to survive your big day
fields.standfirst: The dress, the cake, the flowers, the rows... getting married can be a nightmare. In a bumper year for weddings,  Anna Tims shows how to cut the cost - and the anguish
fields.trailText: The dress, the cake, the flowers, the rows... getting married can be a nightmare. In a bumper year for weddings, Anna Tims shows how to cut the cost - and the anguish
fields.body:
A wedding is probably the most expensive celebration any of us will undertake, and this year, largely due to millennium fever, up to 20% more happy couples are walking down the aisle than in recent years. You and Your Wedding magazine estimates the industry to be worth a staggering £4.5bn, with an average spend of £14,500 on the big day. Weddings are big business - and the expanding industry is ensuring that we spend more than ever on getting it just right.

Mailshots by everyone from bakers to slimming agencies start arriving as soon as the engagement is announced in the newspapers or the couple registers with one of the multiplying nuptial websites. Then there are the wedding guides, all claiming to steer us safely through these perilous waters. Most are good at the obvious - counselling us to choose a dress that we like and to check that there are lavatories at the reception venue - but those who embark on the enterprise are likely to be bruised by unmentioned pitfalls.

The best tip is to do the deed between October and March, when fewer people marry and companies are more inclined to bargain to secure custom. And plan well ahead. Many venues, florists and car hire companies are booked more than a year ahead and even wedding list companies require at least three or four months notice.

For those still tempted, here are some of the stings in the marketplace that no one ever tells you about.

The dress

Fancy a day off in town and a leisurely browse through the bridal shops? Forget it. Most stores insist on an appointment before you can ask questions or try on, and smaller boutiques won't even let you in to flick through their rails unless you've pre-booked up to a fortnight beforehand.

And once shut in the hallowed precincts with an assistant it takes a steely will to resist the sales pressure as gown after gown is brought forth. A stiff gin is required to cope with the prices. The national average is £700 and for anything more stylish than a glorified sundress expect to pay £1,000 plus. You don't buy off the peg even in department stores. The dress is either made up for you to a standard size, or created bespoke, and if you are a trifle larger or smaller than average expect to be talked into the bespoke option with its 10-20% premium. Surprisingly, it can be much cheaper to get a gown made by an independent dressmaker who will have fewer overheads and perhaps a better idea of personal service.

The reception venue

The biggest headache of all. The real fun begins if your chosen establishment does not have in-house caterers. Most, especially historic ones, will insist you choose from a list of approved caterers - which launches you into a mathematical nightmare. Many "forget" to add VAT on to their quotes, requiring you to set to work with a calculator. Some prices include china, cutlery, glassware and waiting staff, others don't. One might look pricier than the other until you find they throw in a half-bottle of wine per head.

The wine, indeed, is the best lark of the lot. Some venues charge you a hefty corkage if you don't buy your wine from them, while your approved caterer may fine you if you do. The same goes for hotels, which can charge up to £18 corkage per bottle if you bring your own champagne. And beware: some hotels keep the cost of their food low to attract you, then clobber you for the drink. Watch too for those alluring packages which offer room hire, food and drink inclusive. It might mean that the wine flow is heavily restricted and while top table rejoices in liberal helpings of the best, the lower ranks are going thirsty. The solution is not to give the staff carte blanche to serve up as much as is needed, because you have no way of keeping tabs on what goes on the final bill. Instead, tell them to consult you when the pre-purchased supplies run low and authorise a set number of new bottles. But don't, whatever you do, get carried away with joie de vivre. Most venues will set a deadline for your departure; exceed that by 20 minutes and you pay twice.

Invitations

Hopeful stationery companies will fling themselves at you once your engagement is made public. Many of the larger ones end up farming out your order to a printer so you end up paying the printing costs and the middleman. They may also be less flexible about the order size, meaning you could end up paying for far more than you need. It can cost you up to half the price if you go to a small printing firm, many of which sell directly to the public, and which should be more amenable to small orders.

Florists

There is a certain snobbery in the flower industry and designers at the top end of the market might insist on working with exclusive blooms for a corresponding price, whereas your local florist will be content to knock together a posy of roses. Don't be tempted to ask said florist to emulate a design by one of the professional designers in the hope of cutting costs, because you get what you pay for and floral artistry is an expensively acquired skill.

Things get more complicated if you live at one end of the country and plan to marry at the other. The chances are you won't have time to seek out a good supplier near the venue and you may already be smitten with one on your home patch. Will they travel and will the blooms look as fresh as they did when they get there?

Self-employed flower decorators who buy the best they can find in the market within your budget are a good solution. They often charge competitively because they have no shop and low overheads and are used to travelling. Florists accustomed to doing arrangements in their shop might find extra decorations are needed when they get to the venue and won't have the necessaries with them.

The cake

Check the tiers and top decorations are included in the quote and ask about travelling charges. You won't be able to transport it on the day and it's too much responsibility for a friend. The best fruit cakes should be kept for several weeks to mature, but if the storage is inadequate the cake will be dry. Ask, therefore, to taste a few samples of previously baked creations. The average cake costs £200 and much of that goes into the fiddly sugar flowers. You can cut costs by settling for fresh or silk blooms or silk invitations.

Transport

Most car hire companies charge a flat rate of around £100, be it for 10 miles or 10 yards. Sad, but inevitable. Limos take a lot of maintenance, as do their chauffeurs, and who's to know a juicier booking won't have to be turned away after they've committed to you.

Useful guides

Milestone Weddings is one of the first of a handful of wedding co-ordinators that do all the work for a fee. Details from 020-8488 7223 or go to milestoneweddings.co.uk .

Confetti.co.uk lists useful suppliers and has dresses categorised by price from £300.

Weddingguide.uk.com has handy hints for the overwhelmed.

The Which? Guide to Getting Married contains useful checklists. Published by Which?Books, price £9.99. Details from 0800 252 100.

webTitle: Mitchell Leisen: Swing High, Swing Low

fields.headline: Mitchell Leisen: Swing High, Swing Low
fields.trailText: The story is nothing special. But the acting is... a critic has called Swing High, Swing Low Lombard's "most flawlessly romantic picture", orchestrated by a gay director who, like Cukor, understood women
fields.body:
The best Hollywood films are often the least ambitious: the more Hollywood tries to be "important", the more otiose it generally gets. Do you recall Swing High, Swing Low, Easy Living, or Remember the Night? Probably not. They were made by Mitchell Leisen, who worked through the 30s, 40s and 50s and was never considered a major director. But looking at his films now, you can see at least a minor master.

I have to thank the San Sebastian film festival for reminding me of that. Two years ago, the festival mounted a retrospective of Leisen's work. Critics from all over the world deserted the main programme to see it, and it was a revelation. Here was style and pace, wonderful decor and costumes, generous wit and unselfconscious romance. And here were stars like Carole Lombard, Fred MacMurray, Jean Arthur and Claudette Colbert handled so sympathetically that they seemed to blossom into superb actors.

It would, of course, be easy to say that during Leisen's high period Hollywood could give a decent director an assemblage of talent with which a monkey could hardly go wrong. But Leisen's signature is as apparent as George Cukor's ever was.

Swing High, Swing Low is a bittersweet romance that was thought to be a little dated at the time of its making. But now it looks great. MacMurray is an ex-soldier who can toot a mean horn, which carries him from a Panama honky-tonk to a class joint in New York. Feckless and unused to success, the trumpeter goes on the skids and a deserted Lombard has to rescue him from himself.

The story is nothing special. But the acting is. MacMurray and Lombard move from flirtation into real love and then something much darker when things go wrong, and the transitions are expertly done. MacMurray is even a convincing trumpeter. And a critic has called Swing High, Swing Low Lombard's "most flawlessly romantic picture", orchestrated by a gay director who, like Cukor, understood women.

Leisen was a director who could make things look good, kept plots rolling along pacily, cherished his casts and was never afraid of exploring the many aspects of romance. Only when he tackled big themes did his films become heavy-handed.

He ended up in the 60s making TV movies, then running a nightclub. What a waste! But at least a dozen of his films remain as good and as memorable as many better-known movies. Even with the flimsiest of vehicles, he could reach 100 miles an hour.

It would, of course, be easy to say that during Leisen's high period Hollywood could give a decent director an assemblage of talent with which a monkey could hardly go wrong. But Leisen's signature is as apparent as George Cukor's ever was. Swing High, Swing Low is a bittersweet romance that was thought to be a little dated at the time of its making. But now it looks great. MacMurray is an ex-soldier who can toot a mean horn, which carries him from a Panama honky-tonk to a class joint in New York. Feckless and unused to success, the trumpeter goes on the skids and a deserted Lombard has to rescue him from himself. The story is nothing special. But the acting is. MacMurray and Lombard move from flirtation into real love and then something much darker when things go wrong, and the transitions are expertly done. MacMurray is even a convincing trumpeter. And a critic has called Swing High, Swing Low Lombard's "most flawlessly romantic picture", orchestrated by a gay director who, like Cukor, understood women. Leisen was a director who could make things look good, kept plots rolling along pacily, cherished his casts and was never afraid of exploring the many aspects of romance. Only when he tackled big themes did his films become heavy-handed. He ended up in the 60s making TV movies, then running a nightclub. What a waste! But at least a dozen of his films remain as good and as memorable as many better-known movies. Even with the flimsiest of vehicles, he could reach 100 miles an hour.

webTitle: FA says sorry for Copenhagen riots

fields.headline: FA says sorry for Copenhagen riots
fields.trailText: The executive director of the Football Association, David Davies, today apologised after the rioting in Copenhagen by English and Turkish football fans, but insisted that it should not damage England's bid to host the World Cup in 2006.
fields.body:
The executive director of the Football Association, David Davies, today apologised after the rioting in Copenhagen by English and Turkish football fans, but insisted that it should not damage England's bid to host the World Cup in 2006.

He also suggested that the government may need to tighten controls to stop football hooligans travelling to the Euro 2000 championships next month, when both England and Turkey will be playing.

"We apologise to the Danes for what happened in the last 48 hours," Mr Davies said. But he told a London news conference that the World Cup decision "will be about which country has the best facilities, the best infrastructure, the best grounds."

Referring to yesterday's violence in Denmark - nine people were injured and 43 arrested in clashes before the Uefa Cup final between Arsenal and Galatasaray - he said: "It's unhelpful, but I don't believe it will be absolutely fundamental to the taking of that [the World Cup 2006] decision."

Violence not as bad as media reported

The fighting came less than six weeks after two English fans were murdered in Istanbul on the eve of the Uefa semi-final between Leeds United and Galatasaray, but Mr Davies said there had been little violence before this.

"Before this week, it was hard to recall the last time Arsenal fans had been linked to disturbance abroad. Until Istanbul, more English teams have played more games in Europe than ever before without any incidents."

Superintendent Andrew Smith, the senior British police officer at the game, said the violence was not as serious as some media reports suggested.

"There were certainly two areas of confrontation of fans - in the main city square and in a smaller square a few 100 metres away," he told the Today programme. "It was more isolated than the impression given by some reports."

Security plans

Mr Davies said that, as Euro 2000 draws closer, the FA would be discussing with its security advisers whether any more could be done to ensure the safety and security of the fans who travel to this summer's tournament in Belgium and Holland. The FA will also report to the government on the violence in Copenhagen, while a meeting with the Turkish FA has been brought forward following the trouble.

"They [the Turkish FA] need to understand much more clearly our concerns ahead of the next time English and Turkish teams travel to each others' countries. We do want to restore the normal relationship between two footballing nations, England and Turkey, and that's what we will set out to do. That meeting will take place in a few weeks. They are very keen that it takes place," the FA chief added.

Commenting on the lessons the government may learn from the violence, Mr Davies said the recent footballing legislation had been "softened somewhat on the very important grounds of people's civil liberties". He compared British laws with Germany, where people passports can be taken away "on the suspicion of intention to cause trouble".

Fans shocked

Arriving back in Luton airport early today, Paul Hill, 26, a graphic designer from Woodford, Essex, said: "When trouble started we just got out of the way. If you want trouble, you can find it, but that is not what it is about. It should be friendly between fans, but that is not what you get. I think it was more Galatasaray really. There may have been an element of Arsenal fans. It was not friendly."

Another fan who flew back to Luton, John Harrison, 36, an accounts manager with Puma from Essex, said: "About 100 people came out of a pub and started trying to rally everyone to charge at the Turks. None of them had an Arsenal shirt. Some had tattoos from other clubs. I swear none were Arsenal fans. That really amazed me."

They also quote chairman Peter Ridsdale as saying: "We are working very hard behind the scenes but as yet there is nothing to announce."

fields.headline: Linux's perilous victory
fields.standfirst: Can the free software movement take on the commercial world without sacrificing its fundamental principles?  Karlin Lillington  investigates
fields.trailText: Can the free software movement take on the commercial world without sacrificing its fundamental principles? Karlin Lillington investigates
fields.body:
Will success spoil Linux? After a spectacular rise from little known, hobbyist operating system to the fastest growing OS in the computing market and bona fide commercial phenomenon, Linux is at the centre of some collective soul-searching.

The freely available operating system, initially developed by Finnish programmer Linus Torvalds and honed by a vast volunteer programmer "community", represents the first triumph for the open source software movement. Open source adherents advocate sharing the code, or basic digital blueprint, for software programs. Programs are developed over time by a sprawling collective. Basically, anyone can work on a bit of the system as long as any new code is also kept public, and programs are either free or available for a nominal sum.

This "gift economy" - the idea that if one gives something freely to the wider community, one will in turn receive things - is at the heart of the open source movement and the genesis of Linux. Of course, this is at odds with the greedy world of big software and hardware companies, profits, initial public offerings and acquisitions. That's what makes Linux's rise and rise one of technology's most curious tales. It's as if a small-town community football team suddenly found itself in Old Trafford with every prospect of beating Man United.

"It's an absolutely fascinating development, and it's glowing red-hot in the US," says analyst Martin Hingley, vice president of the European systems group in the UK offices of International Data Corporation (IDC). Why? "The customer is looking to avoid being tied to a single source [for an operating system]," he says. Linux can be downloaded by anyone for free from the internet, or, if you opt for some CDs and instructions, is available from companies such as Red Hat and SuSE at a small charge (under £50). At last count, more than 145 sources offered a version of Linux.

"The benefit is control," says Red Hat's chief executive Bob Young. "People are no longer beholden to their vendor." If Linux is (in the favourite American phrase) the poster child of the open source movement, then North Carolina-based Red Hat is the poster child for Linux. Yet such are the odd twists and turns of the Linux tale, that Red Hat itself is now seen by some as the Linux vendor that's getting too big and too successful, following an initial public offering (IPO) and the establishment of its own acquisitions fund.

Analysts agree that Red Hat fuelled Linux's success after it drew much-publicised investments from Intel and Netscape a year and a half ago. The Intel stake in particular raised eyebrows, since Linux is seen increasingly as a growing threat to Microsoft's domination in the OS market with Windows, and Intel and Microsoft had been partners for years.

Publicly, Microsoft had belittled Linux, but a leaked memo in October 1998, (www.tuxedo.org/~esr/halloween.html) expressed Bill Gates's true fears. "The journalists thought we were the David to Microsoft's Goliath but we had more engineers working on the OS than Microsoft did on Windows," says Young.

Linux suddenly had the friends in high places needed to get a firm foothold in the corporate marketplace, and software and hardware players practically stumbled over themselves to bring out a Linux product. Corel, Oracle, SAP, Compaq, Dell, IBM, Applix, Informix and Computer Associates all support Linux. The stellar roster of support in turn spurred investor fever and at the end of last year, tiny Linux-based companies saw their valuations head into the ozone when they went public. VA Linux's shares alone jumped 498% on their opening day, setting a market record.

Those developments have been crucial to Linux's rise, says Alan Cox, a core programmer and maintainer of the www.linux.org.uk website. "The rest of the world [has seen] free software going from a crazy concept to a marketed advantage and marketed in a way that the business community understands. The stock market flotations also gave [Linux] a definite air of reality."

But Linux's success isn't just spin. "There has been a lot of Linux hype from companies either because they sell Linux products or because they see it as a stick to bash Bill Gates with (or both). Hype doesn't actually create a large user base and sustained deployment which Linux, unlike Java, is getting."

In particular, Linux has gone from being seen as a desktop system for ubergeeks to colonising the server market, due to its reliability, say analysts. It's now the operating system of choice on 25% of all new server shipments, up from 16% in 1998, according to IDC. Up to 30% of web servers run Linux, according to some estimates.

Linux is expected to see 25% growth every year until 2004, and more than a third of enterprises use or plan to use Linux within the year, according to a recent report by analyst Booz-Allen and Hamilton. The number of Linux users grew from about 1,000 in 1992 to nine million last year, says the Tower Group, which predicts worldwide spending by the top 100 financial institutions on Linux will grow 32% a year - from $50m in 1998 to more than $200m in 2003.

Critics insist Linux will not move beyond servers into the so-called enterprise market of crucial computing functions in big corporations: after all, they say, who will trust a system that is free or comes from young companies just learning how to offer service?

But a Gartner Group survey of 650 companies indicates that 5% intend to use Linux this year for essential computing operations, and 13% say they will do so in the next year. In a much-watched development, IBM has signalled it intends to support Linux. Already the company has Linux up and running on its S/390 mainframe.

"We believe Linux could be the defining platform for all new applications," says IBM enterprise server vice president Launy Vang Anderson. IBM envisions Linux running alongside a business's earlier operating system on the S/390, giving access to a company's old data. He says it is easier to make big enterprise software programs such as SAP run on Linux than other operating systems such as commercial Unix offerings or Microsoft's Windows 2000 or NT. IBM thinks it can make money fromLinux by offering support and services - a plan which must make companies like Red Hat, modelled on the same business plan, nervous.

At the other end of the scale, Linux is increasingly the OS of choice for appliances: it is lean and agile, with a fraction of the code in commercial operating systems. Oracle, Intel, Gateway and NTL have all announced internet access appliances running Linux, and net access appliances are expected to overtakePCs in number by 2005.

So many uses for Linux, and so many vendors in the field, have led to concerns that Linux will "fragment" - split into a number of incompatible, competing OS offerings from different companies. Unix never became the strong, standardised OS many had hoped. With this in mind Linux, which is a clone of Unix, was created to succeed where Unix failed. Red Hat's Young argues that Linux will remain whole because Linus Torvalds still controls the software's core code, or "kernel".

Torvalds, in his Ask Linus column at www.linuxnews.com, says: "What will happen is that the 'market' fragments, as opposed to the technology. Which is good and proper. You'll have different Linux companies going after different markets, and having different priorities. Which means that you won't have any one particular 'Microsoft of Linux': you'll have dominant players, but they'll be dominant in the areas that they are good at. And nobody ever ends up being the best at everything."

Torvalds, who speaks half-jokingly of Linux achieving "total world domination", is clearly comfortable with commercial success (although he will not work for a company that could directly make money off Linux - he sees it as a conflict of interest).

So is Cox, who thinks that developers are nonetheless more loyal to Linux than a company they work for, and that Linux will never produce "Microsoft-like profits".

The developer community, though, still wrestles with the idea of blending success and Linux. Discussion lists on the pro-Linux site Slashdot have dissected the issue from every angle for months. "I write free software to make people (not least myself) happy. I don't do it to crush MS, I don't do it so I can become one of the high priests if the OS cathedral_ and I sure as hell don't do it for the f***ing silicon value mickey mouse money stock options," wrote one programmer.

Even those who cheer on Linux's commercial success wonder how companies will mould a business model around a free OS. Linux-based companies that went public spectacularly last year, including Red Hat, have seen their shares plunge.

But Cox is sanguine: "Linux is the sum of contributions so it will go where the contributors take it. Right now that is everything from IBM mainframes to pocket computers. Some of it is through investment and funding and a lot of it is because someone just thought it would be neat if Linux did XYZ and had fun working on it."

And in the end, fun may well be what ensures Linux's success, precisely because fun, the ultimate carrot on a stick for hard-core programmers, cannot be bought and sold.

webTitle: England's only Test win in Pakistan

fields.headline: England's only Test win in Pakistan
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: When was the last time England won a Test series in Pakistan? asks Reza Rizvi
fields.body:
When was the last time England won a Test series in Pakistan? asks Reza Rizvi

England have only won one series in Pakistan - indeed they have only ever won one Test there, the first one between the two countries in Pakistan, at Lahore in 1961-62. Ted Dexter was England's captain in that series, which England won 1-0: he finished with 66 not out as his side reached 209-5 to win by five wickets, and in the third match at Karachi Dexter made 205, his highest Test score. That 1961-62 series was a peculiar one: the first Test was played in October 1961, and the second in January 1962, after England played five Tests in India. Since then England have made five Test-playing tours of Pakistan: the 1968-69, 1972-73 and 1977-78 series were drawn 0-0, then Pakistan won 1-0 in both 1983-84 and 1987-88.

In 1996-97 Hasan Raza made his Test debut, supposedly aged only 14 years 227 days. That means he's 18 now. What has he done since? asks Garry O'Shanassy

Since his debut, against Zimbabwe at Faisalabad in 1996-97, Hasan Raza has played one more Test - also against Zimbabwe, at Lahore in 1998-99. He scored 27 in the first game and 3 in the second. His published birthdate is March 11, 1982, but medical tests after his debut suggested he was a little older than that (but not much). He has also played 16 one-day internationals, with a highest score of 77 v West Indies at Sharjah in October 1999, so he is still in the Pakistan selectors' minds. In 1997-98 he became, at 15, the youngest player to score a double-century in first-class cricket, with 204 not out for Karachi Whites v Bahawalpur at Karachi.

Cricket records usually list the number of catches held by a player. Do these figures include catches taken as a substitute? asks RJ Gibbs

By convention catches made as a substitute are not counted in career records, presumably because the sub catcher isn't actually playing in the game concerned. The "Wisden Book of Test Cricket" (a new edition of which is out soon) does identify all the makers of substitute catches in Tests.

I have read the 1980 Code of Laws, but where can I find the new 2000 Code? asks Mustapha from Bengal

The new laws were approved by MCC members at a recent meeting, and will come into force on October 1, after the current English season finishes. The new Laws are given in the 2000 edition of "Wisden Cricketers' Almanack", and can also be found on the Lord's website: click here

A friend of mine says she is the grand-daughter of Arnold Warren, who used to play for Derbyshire, but she doesn't know anything else about him. Can you give us any more details? asks Robert Devaney

Arnold Warren was born in Codnor Park, Derbyshire, on April 2, 1875, and died there on Sept 3, 1951. fields.bodyText: When was the last time England won a Test series in Pakistan? asks Reza Rizvi England have only won one series in Pakistan - indeed they have only ever won one Test there, the first one between the two countries in Pakistan, at Lahore in 1961-62. Ted Dexter was England's captain in that series, which England won 1-0: he finished with 66 not out as his side reached 209-5 to win by five wickets, and in the third match at Karachi Dexter made 205, his highest Test score. That 1961-62 series was a peculiar one: the first Test was played in October 1961, and the second in January 1962, after England played five Tests in India. Since then England have made five Test-playing tours of Pakistan: the 1968-69, 1972-73 and 1977-78 series were drawn 0-0, then Pakistan won 1-0 in both 1983-84 and 1987-88. What has he done since? asks Garry O'Shanassy Since his debut, against Zimbabwe at Faisalabad in 1996-97, Hasan Raza has played one more Test - also against Zimbabwe, at Lahore in 1998-99. webTitle: Job losses fuel Blair's euro crisis

fields.headline: Job losses fuel Blair's euro crisis
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The government was yesterday struggling to hold together its wait-and-see policy on the single currency after Peter Mandelson exposed ministers to attacks from both pro- and anti-euro camps with his remarks over the damage to industry caused by the strong pound.
fields.body:
The government was yesterday struggling to hold together its wait-and-see policy on the single currency after Peter Mandelson exposed ministers to attacks from both pro- and anti-euro camps with his remarks over the damage to industry caused by the strong pound.

Despite fresh evidence of job losses in industry, Tony Blair insisted there was no cabinet split over whether Britain should join monetary union and the Treasury said it would not risk economic stability by bowing to pressure for a short-term fix.

But the statement by the Northern Ireland secretary, that business would continue to suffer from exchange rate volatility while Britain remained outside the euro, gave the Conservative leader, William Hague, ammunition to attack the government in question time.

Challenging the prime minister to say whether Mr Mandelson was speaking on behalf of the government, Mr Hague asked: "Why did Mr Mandelson yesterday blow open your real intentions on the euro?"

With Mr Mandelson sitting beside him, Mr Blair replied: "I don't even accept the premise of your question.

"What Peter Mandelson said - perfectly rightly - was that of course if you are outside a currency area then your exchange rate will vary against the currencies inside it. I would have thought even you could have got that one."

The debate over Mr Mandelson's intervention also gave pro-Europeans an opportunity to underline their argument that Britain's opt-out from the euro was inflicting pain on large chunks of industry.

Armed with official figures showing that 210,000 jobs have been lost in manufacturing over the past year, Kitty Ussher, chief economist for the pro-Europe lobby group, Britain in Europe, said: "Anti-Europeans claim that the serious job losses in manufacturing industry are due to a high tax and regulatory burden in the UK. But this is merely a smokescreen to hide the damage being done by the high pound.

"It does not suit the anti-European ideology to admit that the overvalued pound is crushing British manufacturing. But that is the hard truth facing British industry today."

Both old and new industries reported yesterday that they were suffering with the strong pound. Coca-Cola said its earnings in Europe were being hit, while the IT consultancy CMG issued a profits warning. "Our figures for 2000, when reported in sterling, will not provide a full reflection of the good operational growth rates in local currencies," said the CMG chairman, Cor Stutterheim.

The Treasury, while accepting the strong pound was causing problems for some sectors, said using entry into the euro as a way out of short-term difficulties would risk a return to the boom-bust cycle of the late 80s and early 90s.

With figures out yesterday showing that the number of people out of work and claiming benefit fell by 28,000 in April to a 20-year low of 1,111,800, Gordon Brown is insisting that the government sticks by the euro policy outlined in October 1997. This involves the government assessing whether economic tests for entry have been met, early in the next parliament.

After a lunchtime meeting between the chancellor and the prime minister yesterday, Mr Blair deflected attempts to bounce him into expressing an opinion on whether those conditions would be met. The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, demanded clarification of whether Mr Mandelson had been speaking on behalf of the government.

Mr Blair said there were three positions to take on the single currency. "One is to rule it out as a matter of principle, the second is to say that you will join now, immediately, and the third is to say that whether you join or not depends on the economic conditions being met.

"But the timing depends on the economic conditions ... and the sensible position on the single currency is to say the test is jobs and industry and British investment."

webTitle: Factory gloom, but it could be worse

fields.headline: Factory gloom, but it could be worse
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Job losses, plant closures, an overvalued currency - Britain's manufacturers have been here before, suffering from three severe recessions in the last 30 years and now on the brink of a fourth, according to industry's main lobby groups.
fields.body:
Job losses, plant closures, an overvalued currency - Britain's manufacturers have been here before, suffering from three severe recessions in the last 30 years and now on the brink of a fourth, according to industry's main lobby groups.

Following the global financial crisis of 1997-98, output from UK factories has stagnated, order books are becoming slimmer, investment intentions are falling heavily and figures out yesterday showed employment has shrunk below the 4m level for the first time since 1994.

The plight of Britain's textile mills - the cradle of the industrial revolution - symbolises what has been happening. In the past year, 27,000 people have lost their jobs in textiles and leather plants, a drop of 8.3%, with the increased competitive pressures caused by globalisation exacerbated by the strength of the pound.

There is no doubt that manufacturing is under pressure, and not just in the short term. Output from Britain is only about 10% higher than it was in the immediate aftermath of the three day week in 1974, and its share of the total economy has shrunk to just 21%.

However the overall picture not as bleak as it was in the dark days of Mrs Thatcher's ill fated experiment with monetarism in the early 1980s, or during the period when Britain was a member of the exchange rate mechanism in the early 1990s.

What happened then was that the effects of the strong pound on exporters were compounded by a squeeze on domestic demand due to high interest rates. At least 2m jobs were shed in the early 1980s, when output dropped by 15% in 1980 and 1981. A further million jobs were lost a decade later when production diminished by around 7%.

Over the past year, manufacturing production has been weak, but not nearly as weak as in previous decades. Output in the three months to March was 1.2% lower than a year earlier. Weakness caused by the exchange rate is being offset by a pick-up in global demand and a robust domestic economy.

The government argues that bowing to pressure for a short-term solution to the pound's strength would risk repeating the mistakes of Nigel Lawson in the late 1980s, when attempts to bring down the exchange rate triggered an unsustainable boom. This later had to be reined in using ruinously high interest rates.

The treasury believes arguments calling for artificial attempts to trim sterling's sails by either targeting the exchange rate or pledging to join the euro soon are economically lightweight, because a lower pound could only be finessed through a reduction in interest rates which would run the risk of pushing up inflation and re-igniting yet another boom-bust cycle.

Both the prime minister and the chancellor admit that the exchange rate is squeezing the profit margins of exporters, particularly to the euro zone. But they stress that the pound is competitive against the US dollar and the Japanese yen. In private, some industry groups confess to being under pressure from members not to overdo the gloom for fear of giving a misleading impression.

In the recent National Institute for Economic and Social Research quarterly review, Martin Weale and Garry Young said that "the high exchange rate does now seem to be having the effect of depressing manufacturing output. In particular, it seems to be making the production of motor cars unprofitable, or at least not sufficiently profitable in Britain".

But 18 months ago world trade was stagnant. Now it was buoyant. The difficulties were restricted to a relatively small part of the economy. "Despite a weak trade performance overall growth remains brisk."

webTitle: 'Licence to stray' lets Mandelson push euro

fields.headline: 'Licence to stray' lets Mandelson push euro
fields.standfirst:
Britain plc: Shock of economic events forces Blair to allow muffled debate of alternatives to Brown's entry formula

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Cock-up theory is usually a better guide than conspiracy to the banana skins that routinely afflict governments. So it seems to have been the case with Peter Mandelson's latest intervention on the euro which has so angered Gordon Brown's closest allies.
fields.body:
Cock-up theory is usually a better guide than conspiracy to the banana skins that routinely afflict governments. So it seems to have been the case with Peter Mandelson's latest intervention on the euro which has so angered Gordon Brown's closest allies.

The passage that leapt out of the Northern Ireland's secretary's speech to a union conference in Belfast on Tuesday conceded that "there is little we can do to protect industry" from swings in exchange rate values - as long as Britain remained outside the euro zone.

Mr Mandelson's pro-euro views are well known. So reporters were quick to interpret such remarks as a blatant attempt to shift the debate, especially since they surfaced on the very day when Tony Blair was promoting the "no quick fixes" version of the cabinet's post-1997 status quo on sterling in his speech to the CBI's annual dinner.

Can Mr Mandelson have been so careless as to utter such off-message sentiments on the very day his boss was holding firm to the Treasury line ? It is hard to believe this of the arch-spin meister, and Treasury officials saw it as a move to plant pro-euro tanks on the lawn of the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

But the cock-up explanantion may be true on this occasion. Mr Mandelson did not clear the speech with No 10 or No 11 because he thought he was mouthing government policy. He put it out via Labour HQ in Millbank, since his department is busy enough with the peace process.

At question time yesterday the prime minister stressed there was no rift within the cabinet, contrary to William Hague's predictable enthusiasm for a rift.

That is not quite right. Cabinent members have all agreed to follow the Gordon Brown line (we will join when the five economic tests are met) but some think the government should try to change the euro weather.

But to a British public that is lukewarm at best about the euro, its best feature is that its weakness as a currency makes a continental holiday a giveaway.

Even if chancellor Brown was minded (he is not) to try and talk down the pound, he knows he faces a triple risk. He would risk a revival of inflation within the UK economy. In the mess he might revive Labour's old reputation as the devaluationist party, champions of a "soft pound" - just what New Labour has struggled to shake off. Worst of all, an attempt to engineer such a controlled devaluation might get out of hand and trigger an over-shoot in the opposite direction.

Thus Steve Byers, Robin Cook and, of course, Mr Mandelson routinely make speeches which hint that industry, senior Labour MPs, and key unions (like the GMB, which Mr Mandelson was addressing) are right to say that the government must make much clearer its intention to join as soon as possible, and make it much clearer than suits Mr Brown, as he broods like Heathcliff on the right course to take.

Whatever ministers do is never easy. Aides to Robin Cook readily recall speeches which the foreign secretary has made in Europe on non-euro topics, and how at the last minute they have inserted a couple of routine paragraphs about the euro. "If we didn't put them in we'd get 'Cook cools on euro' headlines," explains one. What happens when they do insert those fateful two paragraphs? "We read that Robin is attacking Tony or picking a fight with Gordon Brown," they ruefully concede.

Yesterday Mr Mandelson let it be known that the disputed paragraph had been lifted wholesale from a fellow minister's speech to ensure that he did not step over the line. His own fault, he is telling allies, but not a deliberate ploy. Labour MPs are divided on that bold claim.

It was being emphasised in Mr Mandelson's defence that he was chiefly talking about New Labour's attitude towards economic revival, the need to subsidise new skills and new plant rather than using taxpayers' money to sustain ailing industries.

Mr Mandelson also mocked as typical Tory "old-fashioned laissez faire" the Conservative line of attacking Labour's extra taxes and red tape; such alleged hindrances had not, he said, prevented the creation of 700,000 extra jobs since 1997.

After all, it might be argued, he is an former trade and industry secretary with well-formed views on such topics. Among them is the belief that politicians, union leaders and businessmen who believe that Britain's destiny lies inside the eurozone should say so. They should say so now at a time when rank and file union members can see that the euro-sterling exchange rate is hitting exports and their jobs, runs that argument.

Mr Blair is more cautious on political grounds: the voters remain 60% hostile; and the pro-euro media is more timid than the rabid euro-sceptic press, he complains. Mr Brown is cautious on economic grounds: it is hard to see how convergence can be achieved when the Anglo-American and European economic models remain so divergent, when the euro is so feeble in the markets, even if the pound is slipping against the dollar.

All Mr Mandelson made was "a statement of the obvious", insisted both Belfast and No 10 yesterday. There is a school of thought which says it suits Mr Blair to have a good cop, bad cop routine going to develop the euro interrogation. In effect, they argue that Mr Mandelson is "licensed to stray" off-message.

That may be so in terms of public consumption. Ministers have industry and unions to address in speeches, but also EU leaders and voters who look for guidance.

But, said one MP, "the idea that Mandelson has to make speeches to put pressure on Blair is preposterous. If he wants to do that, he picks up the phone."

webTitle: US owner may close tractor factory hit by strong pound

fields.headline: US owner may close tractor factory hit by strong pound
fields.standfirst:
Jobs on line Famous firm urges Britain to join euro

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: History risks repeating itself after the head of Massey Ferguson, warned that the company's Coventry plant, which employs 1,800, could close if sterling remains so strong.
fields.body:
History risks repeating itself after the head of Massey Ferguson, warned that the company's Coventry plant, which employs 1,800, could close if sterling remains so strong.

It is not the first time exchange rates have threatened the future of the world's biggest tractor factory. A dispute over the pound-dollar rate stalled talks 48 years ago between Harry Ferguson of Coventry and his US rival Massey Harris to create Massey Ferguson.

Back then Mr Ferguson suggested tossing a coin to settle the row. He lost $1m.

That was a personal tragedy, but the closure of the Banner Lane works would be an industrial blow on a grand scale.

Robert Ratliff, chairman of the US Agco Corporation, which now owns Massey Ferguson, raised the spectre as he complained that the pound-euro rate had put the plant under pressure for three years.

Coventry exports 70% of its output, and sterling's rise is leaving it uncompetitive compared with other tractor producers, including the Massey Ferguson factory in Beauvis, France.

"The strong pound is not favouring our continued presence in the UK," declared Mr Ratliff as he urged the government to join the euro.

The company is in a struggling sector, manufacturing, and is trying to sell in a declining sector, agriculture. Three hundred Coventry jobs have already gone, and the workforce has been put on a four-day week this month.

Only 14,000 machines were made last year, way below the factory's 25,000 capacity, and closure would be a big blow to the West Midlands.

Costs are being cut by buying cheaper, imported components, and UK suppliers have been asked to quote parts prices in euros below the official exchange rate. "If that doesn't work we will be forced into considering the relocation of production to other more suitable facilities," said Mr Ratliff.

"For quite some time I have suggested that the UK being part of the euro would balance the economic cost structure for manufacturers and allow the UK to remain a strong competitor for the European and American markets."

He recently "terminated" 1,000 American employees to slash costs, and British unions believe the threat to Coventry is real. Peter Booth, the Transport and General Workers' Union national organiser for manufacturing, said: "We have to take this statement seriously in terms of people's livelihoods.

"The high pound against the euro is posing real problems for exporters and with high interest rates is contributing to chronic underinvestment in industry.

"The weak euro avoided a recession in Europe, while the strong pound is costing jobs in Britain. You have to ask yourself whether we have been suckered."

Nissan, Peugeot and a series of other foreign-owned manufacturers have warned that the high pound could scupper investment plans, but the famous tractor producer is the first to threaten to quit Britain.

Massey Ferguson has also suffered from the Asian economic crisis, and some experts in the West Midlands suspect that Mr Ratliff is sabre-rattling to put pressure on the government, rather than planning to pull out.

Nick Madeley of the Coventry and Warwickshire chamber of commerce said: "There are many firms in the area who are upping productivity to cope with the exchange difference. I would doubt if Agco could find a better production centre."

Coventry has built 3m tractors since it was opened in 1946. But the fear now is that unless the pound falls the Banner Lane complex will pass into history.

fields.headline: Mandelson unmuzzled
fields.standfirst:
Mr Brown is upset. Others should not be

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The charge that Peter Mandelson was speaking out of turn over joining the euro can be dismissed. His timing might have been off - usurping the headlines the prime minister might otherwise have garnered for his speech to the CBI - but his credentials are impeccable.
fields.body:
The charge that Peter Mandelson was speaking out of turn over joining the euro can be dismissed. His timing might have been off - usurping the headlines the prime minister might otherwise have garnered for his speech to the CBI - but his credentials are impeccable. There are only three land boundaries between euro-land and European Union members which have not adopted the single currency: between Finland and Sweden, between Denmark and Germany and between the Irish Republic and Northern Ireland. As secretary of state for the province, addressing a Belfast audience, he was entitled to express a view about sterling's strength, which is having specific and damaging consequences for business and labour on both sides of the Irish border.

Whether Mr Mandelson's prescription for sterling depreciation would work is something else. The Irish economy is overheating and a euro-zone interest rate set according to conditions in France and Germany is not helping. The Northern Ireland secretary does not spell out how the UK economy gets from here to there - from high exchange rate/lowish inflation to much lower interest rates and a sharp drop in sterling's value without accelerating price increases. Some believe a stout declaration of intent by the government would work magic on the markets and pull sterling down relatively painlessly. That is debatable, but debate is just what we do not have - neither about what the government does with sterling nor about an official doctrine of ripe time which may mature a little late for the manufacturers of the north-east and their employees. Some people read Mr Mandelson's every utterance as if the cabinet balanced precariously on the fulcrum of Brown-Blair rivalry. Maybe he does have his next political job in mind. Maybe (which may come to the same thing) he just thinks the loss to Labour of control of Hartlepool council earlier this month needs a muscular response.
