webTitle: Blairs dash to hospital for check-up

fields.headline: Blairs dash to hospital for check-up
fields.standfirst: Blairs' baby: special report
fields.trailText: A heavily pregnant Cherie Blair went unexpectedly to hospital with her husband last night for a one-hour precautionary check-up after she reported she was experiencing discomfort.
fields.body:
A heavily pregnant Cherie Blair went unexpectedly to hospital with her husband last night for a one-hour precautionary check-up after she reported she was experiencing discomfort.

Downing Street confirmed the visit after waiting photographers spotted her arriving with Tony Blair carrying a suitcase at the Chelsea and Westminster hospital.

She is understood to have booked a room at the hospital for over a week, starting tomorrow.

At first Downing Street refused to comment on the reason for her visit, except to say she had not gone to the hospital to have the baby.

She is due to have an elective caesarean birth in six days' time, but it is normal for older mothers to have regular check-ups in the final days.

The couple drove back to Downing Street a little after 10.40pm, making no public comment.

The prime minister's spokesman later issued a statement after Downing Street received dozens of media calls about the sighting, a small foretaste of the avalanche of publicity likely to accompany the birth of their fourth and least expected child.

Mrs Blair has been working right up until the last minute, appearing on her feet for over three hours on Tuesday in a warm courtroom in front of the lord chief justice, Lord Bingham. She had been representing the TUC in its fight to prove that the government policy on parental leave is in breach of EU law.

fields.headline: Footsie distorted by Cable manoeuvrings
fields.standfirst:
Goldman in row over share sales

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Notebook
fields.body:
An extraordinary row has broken out between some of the City's most powerful trading houses over the final dealings in Cable & Wireless Communications, the cable business which is being dismembered - the consumer business being sold to rival NTL and the rump being transferred back into its parent, Cable & Wireless.

In short, Goldman Sachs, the classiest name in investment banking, is being accused of bending London's equity settlement system to make a quick £5m to £10m turn for its proprietary trading desk. The argument revolves around a series of share sales by Goldman to rivals like ABN Amro and Cazenove just before CWC ceased to exist.

The banks on the buying end thought they were purchasing shares which could be turned into cash through the C&W-NTL turnover. But Goldman, doing the selling, is alleged to have tried to dictate the settlement terms to its own advantage.

Against this, those in the market who know Goldman well say traders there simply spotted an anomaly in the documentation accompanying the CWC deal and used it to make money. What is more, to keep their consciences clean, it is said that they pointed out the anomaly to stock exchange officials, who in turn promised to inform top dealers around the City so that everyone would be trading on level terms.

It is a complex matter which the stock exchange, having received a barrage of complaints, is said to have passed over to the financial services authority. At the same time, various heavy-hitters around the Square Mile are threatening legal action.

Whoever was to blame, it may prove to be the case that something close to a false market existed in CWC for part of last week. And, with CWC being a FTSE 100 stock at the time, our premier index was based on a faulty calculation.

Deadly Colt

Dot.com jitters are clearly back with a vengeance, as illustrated by the 3.5% fall on the Techmark index yesterday. But one so-called tech stock avoiding a bashing was Colt Telecom, which ended the day a few pennies higher. It was not difficult to see why.

Colt is essentially the product of a corporate finance laboratory, a jaw-dropping start-up success story which has made billions for Fidelity, the US fund management firm which backed the idea to build a series of highly advanced telecoms networks in big financial centres - starting in London, and then panning out across Europe and around the world.

Now it is joining forces with Cisco, the Silicon Valley internet network specialist to develop internet-based products which can be sold down Colt's fibre optic cables. Cisco's scarily hi-tech routing software - the internet protocols that allow computers to talk to each other - have seen the Californian venture's value rocket and its boss, John Chambers, is on record saying that it will be the world's first $1 trillion dollar company. For Colt this is pure new-economy stuff, and it should scare the hell out every former state-owned telecoms business in Europe.

Anger on street

Word on TheStreet.com is that things are not looking terribly brilliant. The US-based financial news website yesterday cancelled its television programme "TheStreet.com," which runs on the Fox News Channel, because of differences with the broadcaster and its parent company, News Corp.

In a broadside at Rupert Murdoch's media corporation, TheStreet.com said that News Corp was not interested in bringing the show to a global audience and slammed it for criticising the company in public.

"We cannot stand by and let a joint venture partner disparage our integrity and impugn our honesty," said TheStreet.com's chief executive, Thomas Clarke.

Revenues will not be affected but the loss of brand exposure probably will not help morale at either TheStreet.com or its British counterpart, TheStreet.co.uk.

The recently launched offshoot has made great strides in recent weeks, adding subscriber numbers and breaking one or two good stories.

But competition is on the horizon. A heavily funded joint-venture between the Financial Times and CBS Marketwatch launches in Britain soon, while Reuters is working on its own Multex initiative.

An increase in cross-border mergers and acquisition activity - even before the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges team up - means that news wires more and more need to be pan-European and, of course, that kind of coverage does not come very cheaply.

Maintaining visibility in an increasingly crowded market will become more important than ever.

webTitle: EU fights far right with laws on racism

fields.headline: EU fights far right with laws on racism
fields.standfirst: The European Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Euro-MPs are poised to deliver a resounding response today to the rise of rightwing extremism by approving the first EU-wide anti-racism legislation.
fields.body:
Euro-MPs are poised to deliver a resounding response today to the rise of rightwing extremism by approving the first EU-wide anti-racism legislation.

In a long-awaited vote in Strasbourg, a substantial majority is expected for laws banning racial harassment and victimisation as well as introducing sweeping protection against race discrimination in education, employment, access to grants, social protection and social security.

Another key feature of the new laws will be the reversal of the burden of proof in civil race discrimination cases.

The so-called race directive, strongly backed by organisations such as the commission for racial equality in the UK, is part of a package of ground-breaking anti-discrimination legislation. It will require amendments to Britain's 1976 Race Relations Act to incorporate harassment and the new definition of "indirect discrimination".

The legislation is designed to set a minimum standard of legal protection against discrimination across the 15-member union.

Richard Howitt, Labour MEP for eastern England, last night called the directive "the biggest breakthrough in British race relations for a quarter of a century".

He added: "Rightwing extremism is on the rise, not just in Austria, but throughout Europe. This legislation sends the strongest signal to Jörg Haider [leading light of Austria's Freedom party], David Irving [the second world war historian] and every thug who commits a racist crime on Britain's streets. With this new legislation Europe will reject race discrimination in any form." Normally, under EU rules, the European parliament would only be consulted on such legislation, but the urgency of the matter meant that Portugal, current holder of the EU's rotating presidency, had to have MEPs' clear backing before the directive could be adopted.

Crucially, the directive requires a shift in the burden of proof from complainant to respondent, recognising the fact that it can be difficult to obtain evidence in discrimination cases. The onus will be on the accused to prove their innocence "once the complainant has clearly established facts from which a court or tribunal can presume discrimination".

The race directive also incorporates the notion of "indirect discrimination", which exists in UK law but is barely recognised elsewhere in the EU. It extends race discrimination to include situations "where an apparently neutral provision is liable to adversely affect a person or group of particular racial or ethnic origin".

It also provides protection to third country nationals against discrimination on grounds of racial or ethnic origin - thus helping, for example, a Moroccan in Spain as well as a Rwandan in Belgium.

Member states are required to publicise measures covered by the directive, including information about available assistance.

Amendments introduced by the European parliament will require companies to prove that they comply with anti-discrimination law before being awarded a contract. Margaret Thatcher banned this practice when local authorities tried to implement it in the 1980s.

British law already allows group actions in race cases but the directive will introduce the practice across the EU.

The new anti-discrimination laws will be passed under article 13 of the 1997 Amsterdam Treaty, agreed by Britain just weeks after Labour took power. The treaty provides the EU with a legal basis for the first time to take action to combat discrimination on grounds of racial or ethnic origin, religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation.

webTitle: Pressure builds on Meacher as waste strategy is held up - again

fields.headline: Pressure builds on Meacher as waste strategy is held up - again
fields.standfirst: Landfill tax scandal: special report
fields.trailText: The leaked documents linking incinerators to cancer are a stick of dynamite under Michael Meacher, the minister responsible for announcing the government's new waste strategy.
fields.body:
The leaked documents linking incinerators to cancer are a stick of dynamite under Michael Meacher, the minister responsible for announcing the government's new waste strategy.

The policy was to have been announced last month but was postponed for revision by the Downing Street policy unit after the Guardian revealed huge shortcomings in the £1bn landfill tax, Britain's first green tax.

Downing Street's other big concern was over the plans to build up to 165 incinerators across the country, to replace the landfill dumping that has given Britain the reputation for being "the dirty man of Europe". It wanted greater emphasis onrecycling - and far fewer incinerators.

The policy unit also foresaw Labour facing growing protests , and many of the earmarked sites, in places including Moss Side in Manchester and Byker in Newcastle-on-Tyne, are in "heartland territory".

Downing Street's top policy adviser on waste strategy, Geoff Mulgan, will find his fears justified by these revelations and Mr Meacher is already telling reluctant civil servants in the Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions to get on with rewriting the report.

The minister is known to be expressing doubts about the excessive building of incinerators. At one stage he promised to call in all plans for new incinerators for a public inquiry. But he was swiftly overruled by Nick Raynsford, the planning minister.

Yet concern among ministers is growing, particularly among those who face having incinerators built on their doorsteps. Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, whose constituency faces a major expansion of the Byker "energy from waste" plant, has demanded reports from the environment agency and the public health authorities on the dangers of dioxin emissions from the existing plant.

Mr Brown - a long-standing sceptic of the once-environmentally fashionable energy from waste policy - is worried that his constituents who live cheek by jowl to the plant could face health problems.

The removal of more than 2,000 tonnes of poisoned ash from the plant, which had been spread on footpaths and allotments by Newcastle council, has added to his fears. The American findings make it worse.

Support for a limited programme of incinerators comes from Mr Raynsford, who has one incinerator in his Greenwich constituency. He is sceptical of scientific findings suggesting health hazards, and believes that tough standards to be imposed by the EU to clean up emissions should protect the public.

As a former minister for London he clashed with Nicky Gavron, now Labour's deputy mayor, when she proposed a moratorium on all new incinerators for London.

In her new job she has made it clear she intends to implement that policy - and the US findings will give her ammunition against plans for new incinerators and an expanded incinerator at Edmonton in north London.

webTitle: 'I am the scorpion. I captured the lion'

fields.headline: 'I am the scorpion. I captured the lion'
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leone: special report
Interactive: what is happening in Sierra Leone?
fields.trailText: Foday Sankoh was finally captured at the one place no one had thought to look. It was too ludicrous to contemplate that the fugitive leader of Sierra Leone's monstrous rebel army might return home when virtually the whole of Freetown was hunting him.
fields.body:
Foday Sankoh was finally captured at the one place no one had thought to look. It was too ludicrous to contemplate that the fugitive leader of Sierra Leone's monstrous rebel army might return home when virtually the whole of Freetown was hunting him.

But at the crack of dawn yesterday, a Muslim and his young son on their way to prayers stumbled on Mr Sankoh. He was heading towards the very house from which he had fled 10 days earlier as his guards fired on unarmed demonstrators, killing 19 people.

Mr Sankoh tried to disguise himself with a towel wrapped around his head like an Arab nomad. It didn't work. Kabbah Sesay knew instantly who stood before him: the most hated but feared man in Sierra Leone. Yet it was the rebel leader who seemed the more scared despite the bodyguard-cum-medicine man at his side.

"I was going to pray with my son when I saw him in front of me, on the path. I knew who he was but he said: 'I am Foday Sankoh. Don't be scared. Will you help me? I need a taxi to take me to the Nigerian high commission'," Mr Sesay said.

"He looked very worried, and kept looking around. He asked if there were a lot of people left in his house. I said it was looted and empty. We went inside and then I said I was going to call the taxi but I called the army."

Mr Sankoh remained in the house for some minutes. As he was leaving, six Sierra Leonean soldiers arrived. They were led by Mustafah Kamara because he was the only one with a gun. Mr Kamara goes by the nom de guerre of Scorpion.

"I'm a hero. I am the scorpion who captured a lion," he boasted. "We saw this man Sankoh and yelled at him to halt. He just said 'Oh!' but the bodyguard tried to shoot me so I shot him. The bullet went through and hit Sankoh in the leg. He fell down and made too much noise so we stripped him. He is an animal so he should be naked like an animal," he said.

The bodyguard later bled to death, his corpse discarded by the roadside.

The shooting brought a crowd. It swelled rapidly as Sierra Leoneans rushed out to see if it could be true. People tore at Mr Sankoh's bloodied clothes until all that was left was his hat. Pinned inside was a gold pendant of a lion's head with a diamond for an eye.

One of the soldiers, Private Ray Leslie, struggled to stop the mob from killing Mr Sankoh. "He was still trying to argue that he wanted peace. He said he was not the one who caused the destruction of this country. He complained that someone had vandalised his house," he said.

But the crowd was having none of it. The naked rebel leader was shoved and spat at as he stumbled barefoot over the sharp stones leaving a trail of blood from his wounded leg.

Some in the mob demanded the right to kill him. Others made chopping motions to taunt Mr Sankoh with the crimes of his fighters who had hacked limbs off children.

He was stuffed in to a car and driven to the house of Johnny Paul Karoma, a former military ruler of Sierra Leone and still head of a powerful faction fighting on the government side. Mr Karoma, once an ally of Mr Sankoh, insists the two men did not speak in the 30 minutes before the rebel leader was handed over to the army headquarters.

Word quickly spread as to the rebel leader's whereabouts. Another crowd gathered outside the barracks to offer the competing suggestions that he be summarily executed or slowly tortured to death.

In the face of such hostility, the British were called in to extricate Mr Sankoh. He was delivered on a stretcher to an SAS helicopter. Where it went first is the subject of some dispute. The British army's line is that Mr Sankoh was flown directly to the airport and delivered into the custody of the police. But some officers privately say Mr Sankoh was first taken to HMS Argyle to have his leg seen to.

The information minister, Julius Spencer, said the rebel leader was in protective custody near the airport. "He is being held at a secret location for his own good," he said.

Freetown's citizens celebrated the astonishing news. "This is a day of jubilation," said Osman Fofana. "We are so happy. We have suffered so much at the hands of this man and now he must be made to pay for all his atrocities."

But the jubilation was tempered with concern that the rebels would retaliate violently against their leader's capture and humiliation. The Revolutionary United Front still occupies about half the country, and holds 350 United Nations peacekeepers hostage.

Mr Sankoh's capture answered one great mystery of the past 10 days as much of Freetown speculated as to where he was hiding or how he had escaped the city. He apparently spent the entire time in a shack just 100 yards from his house.

Army soldiers concluded that Mr Sankoh returned to recover a diamond stash so as to bribe the Nigerians to get him out of the country. They took to the house with hammers and chisels yesterday in search of the imagined treasure.

Sierra Leone online
Human Rights Watch- Sierra Leone

fields.headline: Blood on the sand
fields.standfirst: Blast Theory first hit the headlines by  kidnapping people in the name of art. Now it  is restaging the Gulf war. Lyn Gardner signs  up for the duration
fields.trailText: Blast Theory first hit the headlines by kidnapping people in the name of art. Now it is restaging the Gulf war. Lyn Gardner signs up for the duration
fields.body:
A few minutes, hours, or even weeks after experiencing Blast Theory's Desert Rain you could be rooting through your bag or pocket when you suddenly discover something you didn't know you had. It is a small plastic box that contains 100,000 grains of sand.

One hundred thousand is the figure some put on the number of Iraqi casualties in the Gulf war. Others claim 1m, while some argue that only a few hundred died, maybe fewer. When, after the war, General Colin Powell was questioned about the number of Iraqi dead, he replied: "It's really not a number I'm terribly interested in."

The tiny, densely packed box in which every grain represents a life suddenly makes you interested. Turning it over in my hand, I thought of Lady Macbeth's belated sense of horror at her own deeds: "Yet who would have thought the old man to have had so much blood in him?"

There is an irony in the fact that the Gulf war was the most reported conflict in history, yet nobody knows how many died. Blast Theory plays cleverly on this in Desert Rain, an event that is part performance, part installation and part computer game.

Blast Theory is the company that attracted admiration and approbation in 1998 for their project Kidnap. For this, members of the public paid £10 to enter a lottery, the winners of which would be put under surveillance, kidnapped and held in a secret location for 48 hours. Two entrants were duly seized, and video footage of their captivity was broadcast on the internet.While some criticised this blurring of the lines between crime and art, the project raised questions about the way media coverage of an event affects our perception of it. A typical response of those in the Kidnap internet chatroom was that they wanted the captors to be more horrible to the captives.

Desert Rain continues the company's interest in new technologies and the way that major incidents are mediated through 24-hour news coverage. Here, the Gulf war - the first virtual war - comes under the microscope.

Blast Theory has found a way of presenting the Gulf war that makes it as accessible to teenage computer freaks as it is to academics. Six at a time, ticket-holders are invited into a briefing room and given human targets to locate. They are then each zipped into a tent-like cubicle, where they enter a virtual world of deserts, bunkers and tunnels projected on to a screen consisting of falling water. Using a foot-operated control panel, they must find their target and the exit within 30 minutes.

Unlike most computer games, the software used in Desert Rain allows the players to talk to and help each other. What's more, the boundaries between real space and virtual reality become confused. Is the figure looming at me out of the light real or virtual?

Geeks may be disappointed that the graphics don't measure up to Playstation, but the experience does recreate some of the fear and disorientation that those on the ground during the Gulf war must have felt. Anxiety makes you start behaving in ways you would never have predicted.

When, with time fast running out, I accidentally locate the exit, I head for it, ignoring the others' cries for help. Afterwards, as we head for the room where we will come face to face with videos of each of our human targets - all turn out to have been real participants in the Gulf war; each has a distinct point of view - I cannot meet the gaze of my team-mates. I feel as if I really have left someone to die in the desert.

As with Kidnap, some will question whether Desert Rain is art or merely a prank; just a game or a genuine attempt to harness new technologies to performance. What seems certain is that Blast Theory's piece is part of a growing trend in performance and installation to blur the line between spectator and participant.

"One of the things I've always found most exciting about theatre and performance is the way it creates bonds between total strangers," says Blast Theory's Matt Adams. "This project just takes that idea further. There's no real difference between the participants in Desert Rain believing in computer graphics and audiences at the theatre looking at an actor in a tinfoil crown and believing he is a king."

fields.headline: Incinerator cancer threat revealed
fields.standfirst: Dioxins from waste burning and industry far more dangerous than was thought
fields.trailText: Dioxins, the highly toxic chemicals produced by waste incineration and industrial processes which tests have shown to be lingering in the bodies of people all over the planet, have been identified as the cause of many cancers in a new report from the US Environmental Protection Agency.
fields.byline: Sarah Boseley, John Vidal  and  Julian Borger in Washington
fields.body:
Dioxins, the highly toxic chemicals produced by waste incineration and industrial processes which tests have shown to be lingering in the bodies of people all over the planet, have been identified as the cause of many cancers in a new report from the US Environmental Protection Agency.

A draft of the EPA report, leaked yesterday to the Washington Post, has taken the US by surprise and is likely to send shockwaves throughout the rest of the world, forcing an upgrade in the assessment of the hazard posed by dioxins. It had been thought that the risk was diminishing because levels of the chemicals in the environment were dropping.

The report will fuel mounting opposition in communities across Britain to a new generation of up to 160 major waste incinerators that the government is expected to encourage over the next 20 years.

Dioxins are chemical compounds unintentionally released by incinerators burning sewage sludge and household, hazardous and medical waste. They are also released in industrial processes such as steel making.

Among the most poisonous man-made chemicals, they accumulate in fat and milk and work their way up the food chain. Even low-level exposure is known to interfere with the immune, reproductive and endocrine systems. The latter is involved in the secretion of hormones. Dioxins also effect the early growth and development of humans and animals.

By far the greatest dioxin producer in Britain, according to the Environment Agency, is British Steel, whose works at Llanwern, Port Talbot, Scunthorpe and Teesside pump out almost as many dioxins as the next 15 most polluting companies.

That dioxins are already widely present in the environment and food supplies of all industrialised countries is well-known, but evidence has been slowly accumulating about how widespread and carcinogenic some are. Yesterday's EPA report is remarkably similar to a more low key report from a group of German scientists, which last year concluded that dioxins might be responsible for 12% of human cancers in industrialised countries.

The British government is gradually accepting that dioxins pose real health threats.

In 1994, the Department of Health published a report saying that "despite insufficient evidence for clear causal links", it would be prudent to regard dioxins as possible human carcinogens".

Health hazard

The proposed incineration plants will be needed, it is claimed, to handle the growing mountains of household waste that the EU is banning from landfill sites. In response to the EU directive, the government is expected to announce that by 2020 it will recycle a third of household waste and burn a third.

Some communities are already arguing that these incinerators will pose a health hazard and that money should be spent on more expensive recycling and composting schemes.

Such alternatives, say Friends of the Earth, would be popular, provide more jobs and be easy for people to understand. They say that £250m collected yearly in waste tax could be used to build new recycling centres.

Chris Pilbury, who works with a coalition of 25 community groups in north-east Wales that oppose a massive proposed incinerator and cement kiln expansion scheme near Wrexham, said: "People will not tolerate these risks. Feelings are running high and this report con firms that we are right to to be concerned."

The document, nine years in preparation, says that for those who eat large amounts of fatty meat and dairy produce the risk - on top of any others they may be exposed to - of getting cancer could be as high as one in 100.

Yesterday the EPA said that at least one scientist involved disputed the statistic and that there was a possibility it would be amended before official publication in June. But there will be no dilution of the message of acute concern about dioxins in the report, which for the first time names the most toxic of the group, TCDD (the infamous Agent Orange of Vietnam) as a human carcinogen.

In 1997, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) categorised TCDD as a "known human carcinogen" after analysing the epidemiological evidence. In 1998, the World Health Organisation decided to slash the safe level for human exposure. Even at the new level of between one and four picograms per kilogram of body weight (a picogram is a millionth of a millionth of a gram) - they were still anxious that "subtle effects may already occur in the general population in developed countries".

Cancer is not the only worry, and other health damage from dioxins has been slightly easier to substantiate. The EPA report will link low-grade dioxin exposure to a variety of problems, including hormonal changes and developmental defects in babies. It states: "It is likely that part of the general population is at, or near, exposure levels where adverse effects can be anticipated."

Risk to babies

Rick Hind, the legislative director for Greenpeace's toxics campaign, which yesterday wrote to the EPA demanding a Dioxin emergency action plan, said: "This means that dioxin levels in the bodies of newborn babies are already at levels that put them at risk of serious illness."

There have been concerns for some time about the high levels of dioxins in human breast milk, although environmental and health groups continue to urge women that the risks do not outweigh the benefits of breastfeeding.

Experts from the Imperial Cancer Research Fund (ICRF) and the Cancer Research Campaign (CRC) in London yesterday agreed that dioxins were a cause of anxiety.

"We know that dioxins are in general highly toxic and can cause cancer," said Tim Key of the ICRF cancer epidemiology unit in Oxford. But more is unknown than known.

"The whole area is full of uncertainty and particularly in relation to cancer," said Lesley Walker of the CRC.

fields.headline: Whitehall fury at spy book
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Dame Stella Rimington, the former head of MI5, is locked in a serious dispute with senior Whitehall mandarins over her decision to write her memoirs, official sources told the Guardian last night.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor, Lucy Ward and  Jon Henley  in Paris
fields.body:
Dame Stella Rimington, the former head of MI5, is locked in a serious dispute with senior Whitehall mandarins over her decision to write her memoirs, official sources told the Guardian last night.

"It is a matter of principle," said one source who pointed to how a book by General Sir Peter de la Billiere, the Gulf war commander, about SAS operations, led to a flood of publications by former special forces' soldiers.

The Home Office insisted that Dame Stella, who was head of the security service between 1992 and 1996, had stuck "entirely to the rules" by submitting her manuscript for vetting by Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary.

Tony Blair repeated that line in the Commons yesterday. However, Whitehall sources also made it clear that while Dame Stella was engaged in what they called "civilised discussions"; the fact there were discussions at all meant there were differences of view about the content.

It is understood that her manuscript - for which she has yet to find a publisher, according to Whitehall - is partly a personal memoir describing what it was like to be a woman in a man's world.

The disclosure that she had written her memoirs was leaked to the Sun yesterday. She told the newspaper: "Yes, I am writing a book. I have written a draft which I have submitted to the relevant government authorities."

It was seized upon by David Shayler, the MI5 renegade, and Richard Tomlinson, a former MI6 officer jailed for sending a book synopsis to an Australian publisher.

Mr Shayler, who marked his 1000th day of "exile" with a demonstration outside the British embassy in Paris, said he was willing to face Official Secrets Act charges in Britain but only if the courts agreed to the disclosure of documents, including those relating to MI6 knowledge of a plot to kill the Libyan leader, Muammar Gadafy.

Speaking from Rimini, Italy, Mr Tomlinson said: "It is hyp ocritical that Stella Rimington is allowed to publish a book and yet I am being harassed because of my plans to publish my book."

He said he had just signed a contract with a Moscow publisher but insisted his work did not include details of his MI6 operations.

Downing Street sought to play down the significance of Dame Stella's book, pointing to a 1955 precedent when former MI5 chief Sir Percy Sillitoe published his memoirs and both main opposition parties stayed out of the dispute over publication.

The Shadow home secretary and novelist, Ann Widdecombe, held back from commenting on Dame Stella's venture, saying: "The prime minister has said all that needs to be said. There is a procedure to be gone through and that procedure appears to be taking place as we speak."

Ian Cawsey, former Labour chairman of the Commons select committee on home affairs, backed any move to shed light in the dark corners of the security services, providing that national security was not jeopardised.

He said last night: "I am all for it. The more we find out about how the security services work, I think is a good thing, not a bad one. I hope these memoirs are published, though of course nothing must be said that puts national security or anybody that works for the government now at risk."

Tony Blair repeated that line in the Commons yesterday. However, Whitehall sources also made it clear that while Dame Stella was engaged in what they called "civilised discussions"; the fact there were discussions at all meant there were differences of view about the content. It is understood that her manuscript - for which she has yet to find a publisher, according to Whitehall - is partly a personal memoir describing what it was like to be a woman in a man's world. The disclosure that she had written her memoirs was leaked to the Sun yesterday. She told the newspaper: "Yes, I am writing a book. I have written a draft which I have submitted to the relevant government authorities." It was seized upon by David Shayler, the MI5 renegade, and Richard Tomlinson, a former MI6 officer jailed for sending a book synopsis to an Australian publisher. Mr Shayler, who marked his 1000th day of "exile" with a demonstration outside the British embassy in Paris, said he was willing to face Official Secrets Act charges in Britain but only if the courts agreed to the disclosure of documents, including those relating to MI6 knowledge of a plot to kill the Libyan leader, Muammar Gadafy. Speaking from Rimini, Italy, Mr Tomlinson said: "It is hyp ocritical that Stella Rimington is allowed to publish a book and yet I am being harassed because of my plans to publish my book." He said he had just signed a contract with a Moscow publisher but insisted his work did not include details of his MI6 operations. He said last night: "I am all for it. The more we find out about how the security services work, I think is a good thing, not a bad one. I hope these memoirs are published, though of course nothing must be said that puts national security or anybody that works for the government now at risk." Links MI5 David Shayler's website

webTitle: Macho man decides: don't get even - get mad

fields.headline: Macho man decides: don't get even - get mad
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is evidently upset by the leaking of a memo in which he appeared to demand help at question time. According to the newspapers, he has been "rattled" by William Hague's success in the weekly joust, and demanded that civil servants provide him with "killer facts" which would make the shaven-headed embryo   squirm with anguish and shame.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is evidently upset by the leaking of a memo in which he appeared to demand help at question time. According to the newspapers, he has been "rattled" by William Hague's success in the weekly joust, and demanded that civil servants provide him with "killer facts" which would make the shaven-headed embryo squirm with anguish and shame.

So yesterday we met the new prime minister, Mr Mucho Macho Man. When asked the formula question - what his engagements were for the day - he snarled like a home football fan trapped in the visitors' enclosure. "This morning I had meetings with ministerial colleagues and others," he barked. "You got a problem with that?"

(Naturally he didn't say the last bit. But he sounded as if he should. William Hague can count himself lucky that his ear lobes are still intact.)

David Winnick, who doesn't so much ask questions as bleat supportively, inquired about Sierra Leone. It was a toss-up whom the prime minister detested most - the African rebels or the Tory opposition. (I wonder what his name will be if he ever takes up WWF wrestling full time: Grizzly Blair, perhaps.)

He was "very, very proud" of our boys in Sierra Leone. "I believe they should be able to perform their task without some of the carping and quibbling from the Conservative party ... a criminal gang, which has visited the most appalling atrocities on innocent civilians." (The latter remark referred to the rebels, it turned out, but since the tone of outrage was identical, it was hard to tell.)

Rebel leader Mr Hague rose to try out a new technique. He quotes a series of people saying critical things about the government, then asks "why do you think he said that?" in an innocent, faux naif tone.

But there's nothing faux naif about this Tone. Ole Grizzly Blair wouldn't know what the phrase meant. Instead he quoted the chief constable of North Yorkshire, whose area includes the rebel stronghold of Richmond. Apparently a wave of lawfulness is sweeping the county. "We are driving crime down, year after year!" he yelled.

Mr Hague tried again, this time quoting former minister Frank Field, the accountants Ernst and Young, various high-ranking policemen and similar riff-raff. Mr Blair glowered at him.

"This week the civil servants have given me some things I would like to tell the house. The system has got better!

"This is what they say: crime doubled under the Tories. Killer fact! Unemployment trebled under the Tories. Killer fact! Thousands of hospital beds closed every day. Lethal earthworms the size of Eurostar trains in every school playground ..." - well, you get the general idea.

Nothing would stop him, though the unbiased observer might have noted that most of the killer facts were very well known and pretty tendentious in the first place.

As slavish Labour MPs yelled "More, more!" he wound up quoting Michael Portillo, whose newfound honesty makes his collected quotes a little treasure chest for Labour MPs.

"'The government is in a strong position when the economy is doing well.' Killer judgment!" He sank back angrily on to the bench.

Moments later my dear old chum Michael Fabricant rose to complain about the BBC's decision not to broadcast live the celebrations of the Queen Mother's 100th birthday. He was, he said, "disgusted".

But of course before the prime minister could agree with Mickey - in itself an unusual event - one Labour MP bellowed at him: "At least the Queen Mother doesn't wear a wig."

Killer fact!

webTitle: Freeserve could be next on the block

fields.headline: Freeserve could be next on the block
fields.standfirst:
Freeserve
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Conspiracy theories about the future of Freeserve are growing stronger. The UK's largest internet service provider is back in the spotlight after Terra Network's $12.5bn takeover of US search engine Lycos, and the word is that Freeserve is unlikely to last the summer as an independent entity.
fields.body:
Conspiracy theories about the future of Freeserve are growing stronger. The UK's largest internet service provider is back in the spotlight after Terra Network's $12.5bn takeover of US search engine Lycos, and the word is that Freeserve is unlikely to last the summer as an independent entity.

Shares in Freeserve fell 11% to 439p yesterday on a volume of 2.3m shares amid concerns that it would try to emulate Terra and buy a sizeable rival. Analysts say it is more likely to be prey than predator, with Germany's T-Online a probable contender.

Chief executive John Pluthero admitted yesterday: "We are thinking through whether we have the scale to do the things we want to."

Some speculate that Freeserve's majority owner, Dixons, will announce a sale of 50% of its stake to coincide with its own full-year results at the end of July, releasing all or most of the remainder a year later. "Freeserve is unlikely to be a predator," said Miles Saltiel, technology analyst at West LB Panmure.

Significant action before the end of June is unlikely. At the time of Freeserve's float last year Dixons made a commitment to hold on to its stake until June 27.

But Dixons need not hurry. Chairman Sir Stanley Kalms' appointment of the investment bank, Goldman Sachs, to examine the future of his company's stake in Freeserve has been interpreted as hanging a for sale sign over the company - in effect starting an auction.

Although the Telekom-owned T-Online is seen as clear favourite to win the day, Goldman is sure to try to drum up as much interest as possible in an effort to secure the highest possible price.

Advisers to companies such as Energis and BT will be ex pecting a call. Freeserve is, after all, the only market-leading internet service provider-cum-portal in Europe that is not connected to a telecoms company.

"As the leading online consumer ISP portal in the UK, Freeserve has strategic importance within a fast consolidating pan-European landscape," said Peter Bradshaw, an internet analyst at Merrill Lynch. Freeserve has gathered some 1.9m users since pioneering free UK internet access in 1998.

One big question remains: price. Terra, by paying an 80% premium for Lycos, could have set a precedent but equally online auctioneer QXL, which earlier this week bought German rival Ricardo.de, has shown that premiums can be kept as lower than 30%.

Freeserve shares closed at 205p on their first day of trading and but have topped 977p this year.

At today's price of 439p and continued market turbulence likely, an offer of around 550p could be enough to tempt Dixons.

webTitle: Violence erupts again as English and Turkish football fans riot in Copenhagen

fields.headline: Violence erupts again as English and Turkish football fans riot in Copenhagen
fields.trailText: Copenhagen's elegant City Hall Square was reduced to a bloody battlefield yesterday as warring English and Turkish football fans ran riot, bringing terror to last night's Uefa Cup final.
fields.body:
Copenhagen's elegant City Hall Square was reduced to a bloody battlefield yesterday as warring English and Turkish football fans ran riot, bringing terror to last night's Uefa Cup final.

In some of the worst scenes of football hooliganism since England fans rioted during the World Cup in France in 1998, mobs of fans fought vicious hand-to-hand battles, sending locals running for cover and leaving a trail of devastation in their wake.

Three fans - two Arsenal supporters and one Turk - suffered stab injuries and a British Embassy spokesman said a second Arsenal fan had been seriously injured after being attacked with an iron bar.

Police said five other supporters had been injured. Officers made at least 20 arrests but were clearly panicked by the scenes of mass violence and had trouble controlling the situation.

Despite staging Denmark's biggest security operation for a football match, Mogens Lauridsen, Copenhagen's police chief, confessed: "We really were not expecting anything like this - so many people fighting. We have never seen a situation like this in Copenhagen. We controlled one area and then trouble would break out somewhere else."

Police fired tear gas to break up the riots in City Hall Square. At one stage fans fought for almost 20 minutes as officers stood by. Market stalls, chairs and tables were used as weapons and reduced to twisted wreckage.

The brawling broke out after Arsenal fans inside a bar opposite the square faced off against their Galatasaray counterparts outside, with each group trying to out-sing the other. There had been violence outside the bar in the early hours of yesterday morning so riot police moved in to push the Turks into the square.

A few bottles were thrown, a few insults and punches traded between rival fans, but there was no sign of the invasion that was to take place moments later.

Most of the Turkish fans had their backs to the main road as they chatted and sang songs. Suddenly a mob of around 500 Arsenal fans marched over.

The rival fans then picked up and wielded chairs that had been laid out in the square for tourists. As the two groups attacked and counter-attacked, handicraft sellers gathered what they could of their damaged wares and ran for cover, along with shoppers and office workers. Families with young children and a man in a wheelchair were caught up in the confrontations as riot police sought to keep the rival factions apart.

As the Arsenal fans were pushed back they could be seen regrouping for another charge.

The game was classified as high risk by soccer officials, partly because of fears that British hooligans might attempt to avenge the killing of two English fans last month on the eve of Leeds' first-leg semi final in Istanbul against Galatasaray.

The violence raised fears over security planned for this summer's Euro 2000 tournament in Belgium and Holland. It also tarnished England's bid to persuade Fifa to let it stage the 2006 World Cup.

At least 24,000 Turkish and British fans had flocked to Copenhagen to watch the match. About 2,000 officers - 20% of Denmark's total police force - were on duty for the game.

An Arsenal fan stabbed near City Hall Square in the early hours of yesterday morning, Paul Dineen, vowed to attend the game to cheer on his team.

The 41-year-old was treated in hospital for a stab wound to the side of his stomach but was released in time for the match.

Four people, including at least one Briton, were taken to Copenhagen's Rigs hospital, a hospital spokeswoman confirmed last night. Two who suffered head injuries underwent brain scans and one had also sustained wounds to the chest and stomach, she said.

Another patient had facial injuries and an almost-severed ear, while a fourth had a broken ankle.

A Turkish cameraman was also hurt in the violence, which had returned to a fragile calm by 5pm local time as heavy rain fell.

Shortly before the match there was one disturbance as fans were making their way towards the Arsenal section of the venue for the final, the Parken stadium, when they started to pull down temporary metal fencing. Large numbers of police in riot gear moved immediately to stop them.

The Football Association executive director, David Davies, speaking at the stadium, said : "As far as the FA in England are concerned, we are very saddened and disappointed about the series of incidents over the past 18 hours ... Let us make it very clear that we deplore and condemn all those - be they Turkish or English - who have involved themselves in violent behaviour."

Whitehall sources said the culture secretary, Chris Smith, and the sports minister, Kate Hoey had asked for regular reports on the situation from the Foreign and Home offices.

fields.headline: Welcome to the Gauloises economy
fields.standfirst: Parisians are learning to live without money
fields.trailText: Paris was learning yesterday how to make do without cash as a week-long national strike by security couriers left banknote dispensers empty of notes. Improvisation was the name of the game as consumers used credit cards for big transactions but other forms of payment - bread and packets of Gauloises - instead of francs.
fields.body:
Paris was learning yesterday how to make do without cash as a week-long national strike by security couriers left banknote dispensers empty of notes. Improvisation was the name of the game as consumers used credit cards for big transactions but other forms of payment - bread and packets of Gauloises - instead of francs.

The innovative means of circumventing a lack of legal tender may have been new to the well-heeled shoppers in the Champs Elysées, but what was happening across France has been mirrored in many parts of the world recently as the number of local currencies has proliferated.

Some economists believe that far from needing just one currency Europe would actually prosper better with a large number of currencies, and a new report out this week suggested that one of the things Ken Livingstone should consider is a new currency for London.

According to a report from the alternative think tank, New Economics Foundation (NEF), London's problem is that it is not one economy but at least three. City workers earn salaries as stratospheric as the skyscrapers they inhabit, but in boroughs within a stone's throw of their offices people survive for a month on what the average bond trader might spend on a good night out.

"The financial services industry may create a trickle down of wealth; it also causes severe distortions," says NEF's David Boyle, the author of the report, Why London Needs Its Own Currency.

"It brings executives from all over the world whose employers pay generous housing expenses - forcing the price of London homes well above the rest of the country." NEF argues that using just the one currency and a single interest rate means that most people who live in London are disadvantaged. "London has a wealth of talent and resources but the single international currency we all live on doesn't use those resources efficiently."

Instead the think tank proposes that each of the capital's three economies - international, local and social - should have its own currency.

Local currencies flourish side by side with national currencies elsewhere in the world. One of the oldest is the wir, set up in Switzerland before the war. It has an annual turnover of £12bn and 65,000 corporate members. The wir is a barter system whose members exchange goods and services without using Swiss francs. The advantage of the system is that because the currency stays in the local economy it creates value where it is most needed. It does not matter, either, if people go into debt in wirs - it simply stimulates demand for more goods and services.

In fact to make barter systems work, people need to run up overdrafts at times. MIT economist Paul Krugman tells the story of a babysitting circle in Washington which issued pieces of paper equivalent to one hour of babysitting time. When members babysat each other's children they were paid in coupons. The system came unstuck because the number of coupons in circulation was too low: people became reluctant to go out because they did not have enough coupons in reserve to pay for babysitting. Most of the members were lawyers and typically, they tried a legalistic solution, passing a rule requiring each couple to go out at least twice a month. But, in fact says Krugman, the right solution was an injection of liquidity into the system. Eventually they figured it out and issued more coupons which encouraged people to go out more - a mutually beneficial solution.

In Britain, local exchange and tradings systems (LETS), have a toehold in many local economies. NEF proposes that a new local currency for London be set up, named the Thames. An interest-free barter currency, it would be of no use to the multinationals but could help reconnect people who are cut off from the cash economy. Local authorities would allow people to pay a proportion of council tax, fines and other charges in Thames. Councils would also spend the Thames they received, either in part payments to contractors and staff, grants to local charities, zero interest loans to small businesses, or some mixture of all three.

There is a third economy which also needs its own currency, according to David Boyle. Economists are fond of talking about social capital, but Boyle prefers the term 'social economy', which he defines as "the crucial human transactions which build families and neighbourhoods, ensure old people are looked after, create the supportive networks we mean when we talk about the 'fabric' of society." As such, London would also have a network of time banks, connecting volunteers with people in need.

Experience has shown that there are problems with local currencies. Some have lacked critical mass, others have become more popular among the relatively affluent than the poor - still others have struggled to find an effective means of connecting to the wider cash economy. However, two recent trends - the rise of the internet and the widening gap between rich and poor - mean there has never been more interest in alternatives to cash, and not just in Paris.

Some have lacked critical mass, others have become more popular among the relatively affluent than the poor - still others have struggled to find an effective means of connecting to the wider cash economy. However, two recent trends - the rise of the internet and the widening gap between rich and poor - mean there has never been more interest in alternatives to cash, and not just in Paris.

webTitle: Rebel leader faces the death penalty

fields.headline: Rebel leader faces the death penalty
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leoneans bay for captured Sankoh's blood

Sierra Leone: special report
Interactive: what is happening in Sierra Leone?
fields.trailText: The crowd outside the gates of Sierra Leone's army headquarters was clear about what it thought should happen to the rebel leader being held inside.
fields.body:
The crowd outside the gates of Sierra Leone's army headquarters was clear about what it thought should happen to the rebel leader being held inside.

"We should chop his arms off like he chopped the arms off helpless people," said Julius Hafi. "We should chop his feet off so he cannot run away, and then we should kill him. But we must not kill him too quick because he cannot suffer enough for what he has done to us."

This is certainly the favoured option of many in Sierra Leone. But the wrangling about what to do with Mr Sankoh has already begun, and the wrong decision could bring down the government.

Some senior UN officials are pressing for the Revolutionary United Front leader to be used as a bargaining chip to win the release of hundreds of peacekeepers held by the rebels. Others argue that there should be an immediate ceasefire and talks to revive widely derided peace accords.

And then there are those, including British military officials and human rights groups, who argue that there is no point in negotiating with Mr Sankoh because his word is worthless and that he should be put on trial for crimes against humanity.

The British defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, said yesterday: "We believe it is a wholly good thing for Sierra Leone that Sankoh is now in custody.

"We hope that will lead to a cessation of rebel attacks."

Sierra Leone's justice minister and attorney general, Solomon Berewa, conceded that the final decision on Sankoh's fate was likely to be more political than legal.

"You have to take into account certain political matters. The priority of the government and the international community is to bring the conflict to an end. There are a lot of pressures from different directions," he said.

If the government does decide to prosecute, it should have no problem putting together a convincing case. Mr Sankoh was granted unconditional amnesty for his many, varied and atrocious crimes under the peace accords signed in July last year. But he has no amnesty for a host of other illegal activities since the peace accord.

The Sierra Leone police, under their British commander, Inspector General Keith Biddle, has been building a comprehensive case against Mr Sankoh for some months. Primarily it has focused on his illegal diamond dealings and the abuse of his position as chairman of the government's strategic minerals commission - another prize he was given under the peace accords - to extort money from foreign firms.

There is also a growing body of evidence that the RUF has continued to murder, mutilate and rape in remoter parts of Sierra Leone.

And last week 19 people were shot dead by Mr Sankoh's guards during a demonstration outside the rebel leader's house. After the killings, angry civilians ransacked Mr Sankoh's house and soldiers moved in to scoop up hundreds of files which provide considerable evidence of the rebel leader's more recent crimes.

Many Sierra Leoneans would like to see Mr Sankoh tried for the full array of his crimes, particularly the mutilation of children, and the abduction of young boys for fighting and young girls as sex slaves.

Human rights groups are arguing for an international tribunal but in Freetown they prefer their own courts, in part because they can pass the death penalty. Mr Sankoh has already escaped the hangman once after being sentenced to death but was reprieved by negotiations.

Whatever the government does, it cannot afford to ignore public opinion. There was general outrage when Mr Sankoh and his cohorts were granted the unconditional amnesty last year. The government argued that it had little choice because the war was going badly and its key allies, particularly Britain, were pressing for a settlement.

But after Mr Sankoh's repeated breaches of the peace accords, President Ahmen Tejan Kabbah cannot hope to win an election next year if he lets Mr Sankoh walk free and return to his position in the government.

fields.headline: Cash-rich C&W on prowl
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Cable & Wireless yesterday said it would have a war chest of at least £4.3bn by the end of the year to further its transformation into an internet-based communications group.
fields.body:
Cable & Wireless yesterday said it would have a war chest of at least £4.3bn by the end of the year to further its transformation into an internet-based communications group.

Much of the money will come from the sale of its 54.2% stake in Hongkong Telecom (HKT) and the disposal of its consumer arm, Cable & Wireless Communications. The new C&W is focused on the provision of internet and data services for business over its own global network.

Chief executive Graham Wallace said the group's cash reserves would enable it to quickly take advantage of opportunities. He said the group would continue buying small internet-related firms and ruled out a bid for another telecoms company, saying C&W no longer needed their switched circuit networks.

C&W is selling its HKT stake to Pacific Century Fibreworks for up to £12.2bn in cash and shares and the CWC consumer business to NTL for £3bn cash plus an equity stake.

Mr Wallace said that when the HKT deal was completed at the end of this month, C&W would formally launch Cable & Wireless Global, which brings together the group's operations in Britain, mainland Europe, the US and Japan.

He said the new group's revenue would grow by 15% to 20% and its margins from 15% to 25% in the next three years.

fields.headline: GUS tries to net 'real world'
fields.standfirst:
Great Universal Stores
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Great Universal Stores wants to become a provider of all round business services to internet and "real world" retailers, offering everything from website design to delivery vans.
fields.body:
Great Universal Stores wants to become a provider of all round business services to internet and "real world" retailers, offering everything from website design to delivery vans.

The company yesterday outlined its long awaited e-commerce strategy, which involves shuffling all its business to business activities into a new division with a total workforce of 14,000, achieving sales last year of around £400m.

GUS's first step in developing the division will be to buy a Glasgow website design company, Reality, for £35m.

GUS's chief executive, John Peace, said: "Website design is all about understanding the behaviour of customers, which we know a great deal about."

The new division will trade under the name Reality, offering call centre facilities, back office support, logistics management and other services.

Mr Peace said he believed these would be attractive to young, dot.com companies and to organisations including financial services groups.

GUS already processes cheques for Barclaycard. New customers include Playtex, the underwear company, for which GUS is designing a website.

In its strategic review, GUS pledged to ensure all its products are web enabled.

The company's online sales last year were £25m, much of it from catalogue retailer Argos. GUS's shares fell 26.75p to 403.5p on the news.

fields.headline: Vizzavi challenge to US rivals
fields.standfirst:
VivendiVodafone
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: UK-based mobile phones group Vodafone and its French media partner, Vivendi, set out ambitious plans yesterday to rival leading American brands such as Yahoo! and AOL with their new multiple-access internet portal, Vizzavi, and bring it to the market within two years.
fields.body:
UK-based mobile phones group Vodafone and its French media partner, Vivendi, set out ambitious plans yesterday to rival leading American brands such as Yahoo! and AOL with their new multiple-access internet portal, Vizzavi, and bring it to the market within two years.

Revealing the plans to make Vizzavi Europe's top portal at a glitzy launch in Paris, Vivendi's chairman, Jean-Marie Messier, said the aim was to make it "the internet in the palm of your hand", and take away the fear of web-based technology from consumers.

But Evan Newmark, the American chief executive of Vizzavi, to be based in London, warned that the new unit had "12 to 18 months at most" to establish itself as Europe's portal of choice. Even so, Mr Newmark insisted a listing could come in two years. "We want Vizzavi to have its own people, own currency and own culture," he said at the launch, which took place six weeks ahead of schedule and will see the portal available in France next month, the UK in July and Germany and Italy by the end of the year.

Mr Messier used the launch to disclose that Vodafone has agreed to sell a 15% stake in Cegetel, the private French telecoms operator, to Vivendi.

Cegetel's SFR mobile phone business alone is worth an estimated £30bn, enabling Vodafone to recoup virtually the entire cost of its successful bid for a UK third generation mobile phone licence at the recent auction, according to company sources.

Vivendi will then offer in turn half of that stake to other Cegetel shareholders, preferably BT. "This will be an opportunity for BT to strengthen its position in Cegetel as part of our partnership," he said of a pending deal that will give him majority (51.5%) control.

Vodafone is handing on to Vivendi the Cegetel stake that it took over when it acquired Mannesmann, the German telephony group. Mannesmann's fate as an independent company was scuppered when Mr Messier spurned its advances - and in secret talks with Chris Gent, Vodafone's chief executive, agreed to combine with the UK group and launch what is now Vizzavi.

The new portal, which acts as both an internet search engine and provider of services such as email, already has via its parent companies a customer base of 70m in Europe and will take over the existing portals offered by units such as D2 in Germany.

It is expected to gain lift-off, according to Mr Newmark, with the growth of the market for new generation mobile phones offering faster data transmission. But this would not occur until the middle of next year.

Vizzavi, extolled by Mr Messier as "my friendly twin" through offering a highly personalised service to consumers, will also be available via the Pay-TV service supplied by Canal Plus, a Vivendi subsidiary.

Ultimately, Mr Newmark said, it would be reached via personal computers. The 50:50 joint venture will see its parents retain 100% of their access revenues while web-based service and content providers will gain 50%. This arrangement will be reviewed in two years, prior to the listing.

"I have no doubt that this will be a Europe-leading and world-leading portal," Mr Gent said. Vivendi suffered a serious blow yesterday, however, when it pulled out of the German auction for third generation mobile phone licences, with Mr Messier arguing that the bidding rules penalised new entrants.

webTitle: Do It All fires final salvo in Wickes battle

fields.headline: Do It All fires final salvo in Wickes battle
fields.trailText: Home improvement group Focus Do It All yesterday fired its final salvo in its battle for control of its rival, Wickes.
fields.body:
Home improvement group Focus Do It All yesterday fired its final salvo in its battle for control of its rival, Wickes.

Focus raised its offer from 375p to 430p a share and revealed that it now owned 29.9% of its prey. The Wickes board immediately rejected the improved bid, which values the company at £327m.

Chief executive Bill Grimsey, who led the turnaround at Wickes over the past three years, said the offer failed to reflect the true value of the company. He said Focus had approached Wickes with a 425p a share offer two weeks previously and had been told that it was inadequate. Focus had been offered more financial information so it could make a more realistic bid, but had rejected the opportunity.

Schroder Investment Management, Wickes's largest shareholder, yesterday sold its 20% stake to Focus.

Mr Grimsey said he was surprised by Schroder's decision since the City firm had backed the company throughout its recovery. "More generally, the premature acceptance by an investor of a low offer like today's from Focus is a worrying signal to the management of good quality growth companies like Wickes.

"Opportunistic bids launched to take advantage of share prices depressed by the so-called old economy company syndrome make it increasingly difficult for management to develop businesses and deliver fair value to all shareholders."

He did not rule out the possibility of a counterbid.

Bill Archer, Focus's chief executive, said Schroder's sale demonstrated that 430p was a fair price for Wickes shares. He said the latest offer was final.

The Focus chief said that the two sides were "clearly poles apart". He said he was astonished that the latest offer had been rejected out of hand.

Focus was offering Wickes shareholders a 78% premium for their shares at a time when consolidation in the sector was inevitable.

Mr Archer said Focus had sought an agreed bid and had hoped that the staff of the two companies would already be planning the consolidation of their operations.

"Unfortunately we cannot take the emotion out of the situation," he said.

Mr Grimsey, who took over at Wickes when it was virtually bust, said: "We believe that shareholders are entitled to expect a fair value for their business and we will continue to resist Focus's bid actively on those grounds."

He has already promised to return £74m to shareholders if the company remains independent, even though critics say this will slow down redevelopment of stores.

Mr Archer ruled out the possibility of a white knight for Wickes and added that the company did not have the firepower to initiate consolidation in the industry itself.

A combined Focus and Wickes would have 11% of the home improvement market, just behind Homebase, which has 12%. The market leader is B&Q with 22%.

Focus is the result of the Focus takeover of the Boots Do It All chain in August 1998. The deal left the management with 40% of the company and private finance group Dukes Street Capital with 60%.

webTitle: Railtrack fined £10m after failing to enable the trains to run on time

fields.headline: Railtrack fined £10m after failing to enable the trains to run on time
fields.trailText: Railtrack is facing a £10m fine - the largest ever handed out to a corporate business - after admitting yesterday that it had failed to reach a target for reducing train delays.
fields.body:
Railtrack is facing a £10m fine - the largest ever handed out to a corporate business - after admitting yesterday that it had failed to reach a target for reducing train delays.

It managed to reduce delays by 10% but this was short of the 12.7% target set by the chief of the rail regulator's office, Tom Winsor, to whom the fine will be paid. Mr Winsor has indicated the cash will be ploughed back into the industry.

Railtrack, however, has appealed against the severity of the penalty. It is also unhappy that it will have to add the 2.7% shortfall for 1999-2000 to a 5% delay reduction target for next year.

The company said that Mr Winsor had proposed a financial penalty of £4m for each 1% by which last year's target was missed. It has lodged a judicial appeal against the level of the fine because it thinks it is disproportionate.

It said: "While endorsing the regulator's agenda, Railtrack feels that an approach which could result in the largest fine in corporate history for an improvement of 10% needs challenging."

The delay figures came as Railtrack announced its end of year operating statistics, during a period "dominated by the tragic accident at Paddington" in which 31 people died.

Railtrack's chief executive, Gerald Corbett, said: "It has been a dramatic year for Railtrack as we have continued to modernise the business to achieve improvements to our public service obligations and implement all the changes highlighted as necessary following the Paddington tragedy."

He agreed that a priority was delivering what had been agreed with the regulator. "But there is much more to be done and we face many challenges over the coming year as the targets become tougher."

His comments suggest that Railtrack will have to meet this year's improvement target of 7.5% set by the regulator.

Railtrack said annual investment was up 16% to £2bn, more than twice the level of three years ago. The number of broken rails had fallen by 4% and track quality had improved and was only 1.2% short of its 2001 target.

The regulator wants to move away from this continuing confrontation with Railtrack. In future years the regulator wants Railtrack to tell him what it aims to achieve in advance, and he will only penalise the company if it defaults without good reason.

fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown's crackdown on the hidden economy is flawed, and the report upon which it is based "no more than an Inland Revenue wish list and has little connection with the public interest," Britain's leading accountancy body said yesterday.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown's crackdown on the hidden economy is flawed, and the report upon which it is based "no more than an Inland Revenue wish list and has little connection with the public interest," Britain's leading accountancy body said yesterday.

The tax faculty of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales said Mr Brown's drive against tax evasion and benefit fraud threatened civil liberties, including the right to a fair trial. It would also effectively mean people seeking permission from the Revenue to be self-employed or to set up a business.

Mr Brown announced in his Budget speech that he would implement the report of QC Lord Grabiner, commissioned by the Treasury and published earlier this year, into moonlighting and welfare fraud. The tax faculty said yesterday the Grabiner report was shoddy, hurried and untroubled by lack of evidence to support its proposals".

Lord Grabiner suggested about 120,000 people were moonlighting while claiming benefits and that fraudulent claims were draining £500m annually from the Treasury, and much more than that when lost tax revenues were taken into account.

Proposals accepted by the chancellor include the creation of a new offence of fraudulently evading income tax, which will be tried by magistrates.

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: Aventis science book prize | And now, gentle reader...
fields.body:
Place your bets on the future
The smart money is on The Brief History Of The Future, by John Naughton, published by Weidenfeld. If the bookmakers have got it right, there will be a puff of white smoke at the Science Museum on Tuesday night and a 2-1 favourite will emerge garlanded with the £10,000 Aventis science book prize. But first, a brief history of the science book prize. It began as the Copus-Science Museum science book prize (Copus being the acronym for the Committee for the Public Understanding of Science).Then it became the Rhone-Poulenc science book prize . This year it carries the name of another French team, Aventis , the pharmaceuticals and agrochemical group headquartered in Strasbourg, and the Institut de France. Aventis is the child of a merger between Hoechst and Rhone-Poulenc, so there is continuity in this narrative of 100 or so books annually in pursuit of big money and demure publicity.

And now, gentle reader...
Naughton's book is subtitled The Origins Of The Internet. Science books mercifully come with tersely informative subtitles. The White Death, by Thomas Dormandy Hambledon Press), second favourite at 3-1, is subtitled A History Of Tuberculosis. Genome, by Matt Ridley (Fourth Estate) third favourite at 4-1, is subtitled The Autobiography Of A Species In 23 Chapters. Time, Love And Memory: A Great Biologist And His Quest For The Origins Of Behaviour, by Jonathan Weiner (Faber) is at 5-1, along with two others. These are Children Of Prometheus: The Accelerating Pace Of Human Evolution, by Christopher Wills (Allen lane) and The Elegant Universe: Superstrings, Hidden Dimensions And The Quest For The Ultimate Theory, by Bryan Greene (Vintage).

From Turner to page turner
Graham Sharpe of William Hill Associates each year tries to second-guess the judges. He has a matter- of-fact take on the sponsorship history of the prize. "As far as the author is concerned, someone is going to give him 10 grand and I don't suppose he is too worried where he gets it from.We talk about the literary merits and scientific merits of book prizes, but the people who put the money up expect to get a PR return, don't they?" Book prizes are good business for bookmakers, he says: the Booker in a good year could attract £50,000 in betting money. He groups the science book prize with the Turner prize, the Oscars and the Eurovision song contest as "something laughably called our cultural file. But if we weren't making the effort to open a book on them, we would not be having that turnover". The science book prize isn't among the biggest, nor yet the smallest, he says. He won't say where it ranks. "Let's just say it is in the middle, shall we?"

Chapters of accidents
Every year, the Booker prize is made newsworthy by a festering row among the judges. The science prize committees are notoriously well-mannered, which might account for the prize's low public profile. There has never been a pattern (except for a period in which the prize thrice went to a professor called Steve) and very little acrimony afterwards because even the disappointed are usually prepared to concede that the winner has written something good. A £10,000 prize will also be announced on Tuesday for the best children's book.
