webTitle: You too can have a mind like this

fields.headline: You too can have a mind like this
fields.standfirst: Richard Hamilton invented British pop art -  then moved on. Five decades later, he is still  recreating himself. In a rare interview, he talks  to Jonathan Jones
fields.trailText: Richard Hamilton invented British pop art - then moved on. Five decades later, he is still recreating himself. In a rare interview, he talks to Jonathan Jones
fields.body:
In the 19th century the poet and critic Charles Baudelaire defined the modern artist as a dandy - an observer of city life who does not judge but watches, ironically. Modern art has thrown up some fine dandies, but Britain has produced just one with the right mix of humour and gravity: Richard Hamilton, the father of British pop art.

If there is one British work of art from the 20th century that is guaranteed to last through the 21st, it is the tiny collage that Hamilton made as a poster for the exhibition This Is Tomorrow, held at the Whitechapel Gallery in 1956. The picture is called Just What Is It That Makes Today's Homes So Different, So Appealing? and in it he uses traditional perspective to give coherence to a chaotic collection of consumer products, from a Hoover to a lollipop. It was, he tells me, "my personal manifesto". It is a defining image of modern art, marking the moment when modern art stopped being about avant-garde opposition and moved into another, apparently less critical gear. It was the birth of pop. Yet if Hamilton is a dandy, his art is nothing if not critical.

In 1957 Hamilton made what he regards as his first mature painting, Hommage à Chrysler Corp. It is about cars. Andy Warhol described pop artists as paying attention to "all the great modern things". As Hamilton drives his huge Audi and talks, you see and feel this. The modern world we live in, the world of stuff, was new when Hamilton fell in love with it. He was born in 1922 and, along with the other members of the Independent Group who met at the ICA in the 50s, saw American consumer capitalism from the vantage point of austerity Britain. "You look at everything. You look at the world as it interests you and the world that interested me was cinema, cars - this was in the 50s when their design was very spectacular."

Hamilton's house is up a lane past a picturesque pond and an orchard in a dreamily English landscape. But it has a barn full of computers, including the one he designed himself and has exhibited as an artwork.

Hamilton is an artist fascinated by modernity. Perhaps that is why of all living British artists he is the one whose work gets the richest showing in the opening displays at Tate Modern. His three Northern Ireland paintings, The Citizen, The Subject and The State, are shown together for the first time, and his print of the Guggenheim Museum - the modern museum as pop artifact - comments wittily on the museum itself. Perhaps his strangest work at Tate Modern is Marcel Duchamp's The Bride Stripped Bare By Her Bachelors, Even (1915-23) - or rather, the reproduction that Hamilton made of it in 1966, and that Duchamp signed.

Think about this. Hamilton was a famous artist by the mid-60s, one of the most brilliant exponents of pop art. He was and is the only British pop artist you could exhibit in a room with Andy Warhol without embarrassment. Yet at the height of his fame he spent two years making a work of art by someone else. This was on top of the time he had already dedicated to producing a typed text of Duchamp's Green Box, a collection of handwritten notes on The Bride Stripped Bare.

"Something like eight years of my life has gone into Marcel Duchamp but I do find him tremendously rewarding," says Hamilton, sitting in a white-walled interior that contains more of his reproductions of parts of Duchamp's Large Glass. "The more I knew about him, the more I felt that this man had tried to reinvent art and to do it in a very purposeful way. Suppose there wasn't a thing called art, what would art be like?"

Artists make careers by having individual styles, by telling a story of self-expression; that's what the market and media like. Yet Hamilton has made artworks in a protean succession of styles and formats. His paintings do not make you ask about his inner life, do not feel like an autobiography. "I disdain to accept the idea that art is about style," he says. "Francis Bacon had a style of painting; you can say that Lucian Freud has a style of painting and Matisse has a style of painting. Style never seems to me very interesting. Style should be appropriate to the subject, rather than the reverse. I've been willing to almost plagiarise; I take anything that I find interesting. I don't think that is illegitimate. Picasso's a master plagiarist."

Hamilton's paintings and prints are images, artifacts. You can't tell if he's being emotional or mocking - though he denies that his art is "ironic". When the Beatles asked him to design a cover for their 1968 album he came up with a blank white cover. This is a joky idea of the ultimate album cover - topping Peter Blake's Sgt Pepper. "There's no reason why art shouldn't be amusing. I like the idea of there being a certain hilarity possible in art."

Hamilton is fascinated, almost as an outsider, by what it is that has made some of his paintings "icons". What is really going on in his 1969 painting Swingeing London, the famous image of Mick Jagger and art dealer Robert Fraser in the back of a police van after being arrested on drugs charges? It looks like Jagger is holding his hand up to hide his face but Hamilton tells me Jagger just wanted people to see the cuffs and later "danced" to show them off. Swingeing London is an image Hamilton selected, painted and put permanently in the public domain; he was motivated by anger that his friend Fraser - his own dealer - was "destroyed" by this prison sentence. "We made an exhibition in his empty gallery," he says. "I was very despondent at this empty space with the gallery girl sitting there looking rather morose."

Hamilton made a collage of news accounts of the Rolling Stones drugs trial - "a meal would be described that was sent to Mick Jagger in jail and each time there was a different menu" - and then turned one of the pictures into a series of paintings. When you paint a media image or turn it into a fine art print, Hamilton says, something strange happens. He has done it with images of a student shot at the Kent State demonstrations, with a sheet of photographs on which Marilyn Monroe crossed out images of herself she didn't want made public, and with his paintings of an IRA dirty protester, an Orangeman and a soldier in Northern Ireland. With the Kent State print he remembers photographing news images off the television: "They were amateur films, taken under tension; it was grainy, and there was that feeling of movement and desperation." He was worried about using the student's image but realised, "It's a subject that should be seen and sealed in the memory of people."

How does an artist turn an event into an iconic image of its time? "I think it's something to do with the... I'm hesitating because I'm trying to avoid the word beauty."

Hamilton painted The Citizen (1981-83) after seeing a TV documentary about Republican prisoners' "dirty protest" at conditions in the Maze. It portrays a protester as a Christ-like, cloaked figure surrounded by sensuous, decorative swirls of his own excrement. Today Hamilton insists this is not a piece of myth-making but an analysis of myth. He wanted to show how the IRA prisoners systematically created an image of themselves as martyrs. "They lived in excrement and wore blankets and refused to have their hair cut and they created this image. They liked to have a little cross hanging around their necks too."

In his subsequent paintings The Subject and The State he focuses on this same process of people's self-representation: the Ulsterman's orange sash, the British soldier's camouflage. Why, he wonders, did British soldiers on patrol in urban Belfast need to wear rustic camouflage? It was, in an inversion of its supposed purpose, meant to be seen. Yet the three isolated figures in these paintings are set against a background of blur and uncertainty - an empty country road, a night-time street, a room covered with shit.

The brown-painted prison cell appears again, blasphemously, in the painting Hamilton is now making for the National Gallery. He is one of the eminent artists invited by the gallery to create a new work in response to a painting in its collection. The exhibition, Encounters, opens next month. He takes me to his studio, where he is painting a modern equivalent of a picture of a church interior by the Dutch master Pieter Saenredam. Hamilton is a political artist, and although he talks about this picture in terms of perspective and form, the resulting painting is nicely satirical. Where Saenredam depicted churches, Hamilton has done a perspective painting of the Sainsbury Wing of the National Gallery, emptied of crowds, transformed into a sublime abstract space - a modern cathedral.

Yet in this space are Duchampian allusions to the realities that high art is supposed to ignore. A naked woman emerges from behind a pillar. At the vanishing point of the painting, where in the real gallery you would find a medieval painting of Christ, Hamilton has hung a miniature version of his dung-decorated Citizen, a kind of anti-Christ. The face, people have told him, looks evil.

Richard Hamilton is simultaneously a great lover of modern things and someone who can stand back from contemporary life, like Warhol, and make disconcertingly objective pictures of it. His favourite term of denunciation is "stupid". His pictures isolate the images that surround us, analyse them, and place them in history. In the future we will be able to look at them and see 20th-century Britain as sharply as you can see 19th-century Paris in the art of Manet. The cars, the toasters and the prisoners.

fields.headline: Apocalypse 2058
fields.standfirst: The millennium bug didn't finish us off, but a bigger bang is yet to come, says  Michael Brooks
fields.trailText: The millennium bug didn't finish us off, but a bigger bang is yet to come, says Michael Brooks
fields.body:
In 2058, we will blast-off to colonise Mars. Or we may enter symbiosis with machines - or find a trick that enables us to tame previously uninhabitable regions of the earth. But something extraordinary is going to happen 58 years from now. How do we know? It's written in the Dow Jones Index.

Didier Sornette, a geophysicist who splits his time between the universities of California, Los Angeles and Nice, specialises in analysing the complex signals that warn of earthquakes or impending crashes in financial markets.

But he recently took a casual look at the variations of the Dow Jones Index, a measure of the prosperity of the world's most profitable companies. From an extrapolation of its past patterns, Sornette came up with a graph showing that the index's value would climb - with some small fluctuations - into the future. His specific predictions of its value, he noted happily, agree with those of US Federal Reserve economists and senior market analysts.

But according to his model, the index's value will abruptly explode in 2058: for no apparent reason the graph suddenly shoots off the scale.

Surprised, Sornette had a look at another fluctuating signal: world population statistics. This too, he found, had a shape signalling an abrupt population explosion at a specific point in the future: 2058, to be precise. Sornette's analysis was based on more than 100 years of the Dow Jones Index, and 2,000 years of available world population data, yet both sets of figures forecasted a singularity for the same year. "That," he says, "was scary."

In 2058, Sornette says, these two factors will hit a massive acceleration in their rate of growth that will take them to a "spontaneous singularity". This is a point where the graphs can't get any steeper. Singularities foreshadow a critical point of fundamental and abrupt disruption to the status quo. Black holes in space are one example. Others include stock market crashes, earthquakes, and catastrophic ruptures in engineering structures.

According to cosmologists, a singularity kicked our universe into existence.

With the world's population and economy hitting a critical point at the same time, the survival of humanity will depend on developing a new way of living on (or maybe off) the earth, Sornette says.

After all, he points out, the two signals are inextricably linked. World population growth must somehow be related to the ability to provide food and habitable conditions for that population. And that requires innovation.

Each of mankind's innovations - fire, tools, agriculture, fossil fuels, vaccines, pesticides and antibiotics - has increased the number of people that can exist on the planet. The technology-led internet is the latest revolution, Sornette says, following the industrial and biotechnological revolutions. But he points out that biotech had hardly begun to fulfil its potential before the internet was born: innovation is accelerating out of control. And that will lead to the singularity.

Hence the search for a "different way" - planetary colonisation, or maybe the development of human-machines? Biologists have even proposed to Sornette that it could be a fundamental mutation in the human genes. "These things have all been suggested by scientists, philosophers and writers; what's fascinating is that we can see it coming in the data," Sornette says.

There are a couple of caveats about the date. The Dow Jones Index is not an ideal measure of innovation, although Sornette believes it is still the best available indication.

Also, he adds, it's only numbers. "Maths is just a language to formalise what we see around us." In reality, things don't always turn out as sharply as the figures suggest. So blast-off for Mars may not come in precisely 2058; it could come sooner or much later. But whatever the timing, Sornette says, mankind is definitely heading towards some kind of new era.

Pessimists will think of it as a catastrophic meltdown, where innovation rates can't sustain the population explosion. Optimists believe some as yet unknown revolution will ease our way. But the optimists have a problem: any further innovation simply accelerates doomsday's arrival.

It's probably best not to get too worked up, though. With one thing and another, the end has been nigh for a very long time now.

Others include stock market crashes, earthquakes, and catastrophic ruptures in engineering structures. According to cosmologists, a singularity kicked our universe into existence. With the world's population and economy hitting a critical point at the same time, the survival of humanity will depend on developing a new way of living on (or maybe off) the earth, Sornette says. After all, he points out, the two signals are inextricably linked. World population growth must somehow be related to the ability to provide food and habitable conditions for that population. And that requires innovation. Each of mankind's innovations - fire, tools, agriculture, fossil fuels, vaccines, pesticides and antibiotics - has increased the number of people that can exist on the planet. The technology-led internet is the latest revolution, Sornette says, following the industrial and biotechnological revolutions. But he points out that biotech had hardly begun to fulfil its potential before the internet was born: innovation is accelerating out of control. And that will lead to the singularity. Hence the search for a "different way" - planetary colonisation, or maybe the development of human-machines? Biologists have even proposed to Sornette that it could be a fundamental mutation in the human genes. "These things have all been suggested by scientists, philosophers and writers; what's fascinating is that we can see it coming in the data," Sornette says. There are a couple of caveats about the date. The Dow Jones Index is not an ideal measure of innovation, although Sornette believes it is still the best available indication. Also, he adds, it's only numbers. "Maths is just a language to formalise what we see around us." In reality, things don't always turn out as sharply as the figures suggest. So blast-off for Mars may not come in precisely 2058; it could come sooner or much later. But whatever the timing, Sornette says, mankind is definitely heading towards some kind of new era. Pessimists will think of it as a catastrophic meltdown, where innovation rates can't sustain the population explosion. Optimists believe some as yet unknown revolution will ease our way. But the optimists have a problem: any further innovation simply accelerates doomsday's arrival. It's probably best not to get too worked up, though. With one thing and another, the end has been nigh for a very long time now.

fields.headline: Blair entices loyalists to devolution
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and the Northern Ireland secretary yesterday risked another dispute with the Irish government as they tried yet again to entice Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble   to sell his party a return to government with Sinn Fein.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and the Northern Ireland secretary yesterday risked another dispute with the Irish government as they tried yet again to entice Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble to sell his party a return to government with Sinn Fein.

Mr Blair tried at prime minister's question time to give Mr Trimble further cover on IRA decommissioning, agreeing that sealed arms dumps could only be a first step to resolving the issue, and indicating that weapons had to be made permanently unusable.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, signalled the most important concession to Mr Trimble when he spoke of an amendment to the policing bill enabling the Royal Ulster Constabulary's title to be incorporated under the law. But he made it clear that the operational name of the force would change. Government sources said that Mr Mandelson would accept opposition amendments, possibly tabled by Ulster Unionists, making it clear the new service evolved from the RUC.

Mr Mandelson called upon Ulster Unionists to seize the credit for progress made in Northern Ireland. He said the present circumstances, hopefully leading to restored devolution, might never return.

Mr Trimble, who said last night that he had made important advances over the past two days, refused to be drawn on his approach to this Saturday's critical meeting of his 858-strong ruling council.

As it stood yesterday, John Taylor, deputy leader of the Ulster Unionists, was opposed to the deal. Mr Taylor, seen as a weather vane of party opinion, backed the Hillsborough Castle proposals the weekend before last. In the Commons yesterday, he asked the Northern Ireland secretary whether it would not be easier for him simply to stick to direct rule.

Mr Trimble is expected to talk to Mr Taylor before meeting his assembly team at Stormont this morning. He will then decide on what would be the biggest, and possibly last, gamble of his career.

To abandon the council meeting would be humiliating, and to press ahead without a vote would run the risk of provoking a hardline motion from the floor. Either move could threaten his five year leadership.

Mr Trimble may yet calculate that the least worst option, even at such a late stage, is to sell the Hillsborough proposals to his council. But defeat would spell the end not only of his leadership, but also of the two year old Good Friday agreement.

Northern Ireland Office sources said last night Mr Trimble had pushed as far he he could for concessions. One said: "The well has run dry."

The Irish government, Sinn Fein and the SDLP were infuriated. The taoiseach, Bertie Ahern, and Brian Cowen, the Irish foreign affairs minister, had been voicing doubts about the policing bill before yesterday's moves.

Gerry Adams, Sinn Fein party president, said: "It is now well past time for the two governments to hold to the deal that was made. The British government must say to the Ulster Unionists, enough is enough."

The fragile peace process was hit by a further blow as police seized four weapons, including a heavy machine gun, and paramilitary material, on a raid on the offices of the loyalist Progressive Unionist Party in Ballymoney, Antrim.

As Sinn Fein demanded to know how the weapons were to be used, David Ervine, one of the two PUP members in the assembly, said there was no excuse to be given - his party and the Ulster Volunteer Force, which is allied to the PUP, were committed to the peace process. "It is very damaging. We have launched an investigation. But the damage has been done as far as our credibility is concerned."

fields.headline: Put it on the bill
fields.standfirst: Sanjida O'Connell on how Australia's most fantastic beast holds secrets of sex and death
fields.trailText: Sanjida O'Connell on how Australia's most fantastic beast holds secrets of sex and death
fields.body:
The first one brought to England was believed to be a fake. Who but a bad taxidermist with a warped imagination would stick four webbed feet and a duck's bill onto a furry stoat-like body?

The platypus, evolution's own brand of magical realism, not only exists, but could, with the help of another Australian oddity, the opossum, help shed light on sex wars, genes and cancer.

When Dr Randy Jirtle, from Duke Medical Center, Durham, North Carolina, examined genetic material from a platypus he was looking for an absence of evidence, an absence of imprinted genes to be precise.

Normally animals receive one copy of every gene from both their parents, but recently scientists have discovered a class of genes which don't obey the rules. These are imprinted: either the mother's or father's copy is shut down. It's a battle of the sexes that begins at conception for the father wants the foetus to grow large, while the mother doesn't want the foetus to be too big to pass through the birth canal or to drain too much energy from her.

Genetic imprinting is thought to be involved in muscle growth, as well as brain development and sexual orientation. Homosexuality and transsexuality could be due to imprinting defects according to Dr Richard Green, from the department of psychiatry at Charing Cross Hospital, London, who worked with Barry Keverne from the department of animal behaviour at Cambridge University.

The hypothesis is that male to female transsexuals inherit one or more imprinted genes from their mother which have a feminising effect.

But back to the platypus: Dr Jirtle and his colleague Dr Keith Killian chose to look at this beast because they thought there should be no sex wars among the platypuses. By a bizarre twist of fate, they are monotremes: they look like mammals but lay eggs. Opossums, the other animal he and his team examined, are marsupials and have a refreshingly short pregnancy which lasts 13 days.

The foetus is then nursed in the mother's pouch. Jirtle's theory was that neither marsupials nor monotremes should have imprinted genes because there was no need for the sexes to battle for resources if the foetus grows in either an egg or a pouch. However, what he and his colleagues discovered was that opossums but not platypuses do have imprinted genes. The imprinted gene from the father causes the young opossums to develop rapidly. This supports the idea that imprinting is the result of a sexual battle, says Jirtle.

"Young opossum must crawl to reach the pouch and latch on, and this is consistent with a battle of the sexes for nutrient allocation as a reason for imprinted genes. For the opossum, it's literally a race for life."

Once newborn opossums latch on to the mother's nipple, the nipple swells and the babies are stuck there for months until their mouths become big enough to open. Since there are only a dozen nipples and up to 50 babies in a single litter, competition is high. The faster a baby opossum can climb, the more likely it is to survive, and the more likely its genes will be passed on. On the other hand, each platypus has an egg to itself, and once the eggs hatch, there's enough to go round: the mother platypus lacks nipples and milk oozes freely from patches on her chest. There are about 30 known imprinted genes, but according to Jirtle, there could be as many as 500.

"We don't know if humans need these imprinted genes, or if we would be okay without them," Jirtle says, "Although this battle of the sexes occurred about 150 million years ago, it's like keeping stuff in the freezer - you jam it in and leave it there even if it's no longer useful. Nevertheless, we have imprinted genes and they are targets for developmental diseases and cancer."

We have only one copy of each imprinted gene because one parental copy is suppressed. If this remaining copy mutates, or is damaged there's no handy back-up.

"A single mutation in a gene for growth can cause cells to develop abnormally and become cancerous. The imprinted gene in the opossum has the cumbersome title of M6P/IGF2 receptor. This gene exists in humans too, and is a tumour suppressor, but is not imprinted. However, even though we have two copies of the gene, it is still implicated in the early stages of cancer: at least one copy of this gene doesn't work in more than 60% of liver cancers, 30% of breast cancers and 50% of lung cancers. Like the opossum, and unlike us, mice do have an imprinted copy of the growth gene.

"It's a funny gene," says Jirtle. "It's the only gene presently known that is imprinted in mice, but not humans."

Jirtle's next plan is to try and develop a mouse that has two copies of the gene. This would make genetically modified mice more similar to humans in their response to carcinogenic agents and thus would be better models to use in cancer research. Ultimately once he and other researchers in the field understand the molecular genetics behind imprinting, they may be able to help treat not only cancer, but a whole range of other disorders. Angelman syndrome, for instance, is a disease caused by the mutation of a maternal expressed imprinted gene which results in retardation, insomnia, seizures and hyperactivity.

Jirtle also believes that the research so far can help us retrace our evolutionary origins. The presence of imprinted genes in the opossum but not platypus suggests that marsupials are more closely related to eutherians - mammals whose offspring develop in the womb - than they are to the egg-laying monotremes. According to his research, the platypus evolved earlier than the opossum.

"When did the imprinting of this gene start and end?" asks Jirtle. "I want the whole family tree known for this gene."

fields.headline: Terror from tourists
fields.standfirst: Pick up your penguin with care. It isn't used to people. But people are turning up in Antarctica in ever greater numbers, writes  Tim Radford
fields.trailText: Pick up your penguin with care. It isn't used to people. But people are turning up in Antarctica in ever greater numbers, writes Tim Radford
fields.body:
Approach your penguin with care. Better still, don't approach it at all. If it is sitting there, stock still in the snow, it is incubating an egg. If you get within 15 feet, says Melissa Giese of the Australian Antarctic Division, it will get off the egg.

That puts the embryo chick at risk. But that isn't all. As you approach a penguin its heartbeat goes up massively. This, too, is a problem for the poor bird, says Dr Giese. It may have to sit on the egg for weeks while its mate is away foraging. Penguins have a tight energy budget. Too many episodes of a heart rate poised for fight or flight and the bird may not be able to sit out its vigil. It may have to get up and go looking for food, and that means goodbye progeny for another year.

Dr Giese, on duty at the Great Australian Science Show in Melbourne this month, is the author of guidelines for tourist operators working in Antarctica. They sure need guidelines, she says. Tourism is growing at 600% per season, as cruise ships gather around the south polar summer shorelines. "Most people who go want to get nice and close to the animals," she says. "They can suffer quite dramatic behavioural and physiological reactions to humans. Their incubation behaviour will be interrupted.

"A penguin under normal circumstances will just be sitting there, minding its own business guarding its eggs, and if it is approached too closely by humans it will stand up and expose the egg to ambient air temperatures."

She observed Adélie penguin behaviour. Using a dummy egg which picks up their heart rate, she organised systematic approaches to observe what penguins did. The hearts of Pygoscelis adeliae beat at human speeds: 90 beats a minute to keep up warmth in a cold climate. If approached, the rate rose 54%. "They are in the colony for anything up to 30 days without being able to go back to sea and forage so they are relying totally on energy reserves built up before they came ashore, and the energy balance is pretty fine, so any increase in heart rate causes an increase in energy consumption."

Tourism could be managed in a way that protected the birds. That is not happening, she says. "The industry is experiencing incredible growth, it is uncontrolled in terms of the numbers of operators, the numbers of tourists and the numbers of sites the tourists can go to. It is unpoliced. If they don't want to stick to the guidelines there is nobody there to watch them."

There are serious hazards from pollution, she says. "It's only a matter of time before there is a major oil spill in Antarctica," she says "and how we would deal with that, I could not begin to imagine. There is also the potential for the tourists to introduce and spread exotic diseases. If it ever did occur, the effect would be catastrophic. A lot of the tour vessels go to one penguin colony and then three hours later they will be landing at another colony. If they were introducing non-indigenous pathogens, there is a great potential for them to be transporting those from penguin colony to penguin colony."

Antarctica is huge, but most of it is high and icebound. Living things cling precariously to little rocky outcrops and to the ice shelves. Survival is on a knife-edge . Some tour operators are doing a good job.

"But some are pretty lousy, allowing people to go close to wild life, and turning a blind eye to people who collect bits and pieces, artefacts or penguin eggs or whatever."

fields.headline: EU raids AstraZeneca
fields.standfirst: Drugs company offices and plant are searched by anti-monopolies investigators
fields.trailText: Britain's second largest drugs company, AstraZeneca, has suffered the embarrassment of a raid by inspectors from the competition services department of the European commission.
fields.body:
Britain's second largest drugs company, AstraZeneca, has suffered the embarrassment of a raid by inspectors from the competition services department of the European commission.

The commission confirmed yesterday that its officers had searched the group's head office in Mayfair and its research and development centre in Sodertlje, Sweden.

Inspectors arrived without warning in February, to seize documents detailing sales of Losec - the world's best selling prescription drug, which is used to treat stomach ulcers. In a statement last night, the commission said it was investigating whether AstraZeneca had violated anti-monopolies laws, focusing in particular on a provision in a European treaty which bans "abuses of dominant positions".

The news sent shockwaves through the industry - AstraZeneca's shares slumped 174p to £27.

If it finds AstraZeneca guilty of an infringement, the commission could theoretically fine the group up to 10% of its turnover - which would be more than £1bn.

However, the commission has never come close to this limit - the biggest fine it has imposed was a €102m penalty levied against Volkswagen, the German car maker.

AstraZeneca issued a defiant response yesterday, saying it was "confident that any allegations or complaint are not well founded and will be held to be unsubstantiated".

The group said the investigation was the result of a complaint by a company which was trying to "jump the gun" by trying to launch a generic version of Losec before the drug's patent had expired.

Reports last night suggested that the complaint could have been made by Ratiopharm, a German firm known to be involved in a dispute with AstraZeneca.

The details of the alleged infringement concern an extension granted to Astra's patent over Losec, under the terms of an EU regulation in 1992.

This ruling benefited all products introduced after January, 1988. However, there is disagreement over exactly when Astra launched Losec - the company got approval for the product in Luxembourg in November, 1987.

One analyst said that the real worry for AstraZeneca was that if it was found guilty in the investigation, the life of its patents over Losec could be shortened. At present, most of its European patents expire between 2002 and 2004. The drug generates nearly a third of the company's revenue.

The analyst said: "This again highlights the exposure of the company to one product. The issue here is whether they managed to get extensions to Losec patents on the basis of invalid documents."

Another analyst, Michael King of SG Securities, said: "Obviously there is some issue or the commission would not be looking into it to the degree that it is. But it sounds like a question of interpretation, rather than of fraud."

The building raided in London is a modest-sized town house, which contains the office of the group's chief executive Tom McKillop and other directors. The building has been the target of environmental protesters in the past - a group dressed as genetically modified tomatoes gained entry last year and locked themselves in.

AstraZeneca insists that it has a successor drug, Nexium, to fill the gap left by Losec. However, some commentators say Nexium will be little better than generic versions of Losec.

Another analyst, Michael King of SG Securities, said: "Obviously there is some issue or the commission would not be looking into it to the degree that it is. But it sounds like a question of interpretation, rather than of fraud." The building raided in London is a modest-sized town house, which contains the office of the group's chief executive Tom McKillop and other directors. The building has been the target of environmental protesters in the past - a group dressed as genetically modified tomatoes gained entry last year and locked themselves in. AstraZeneca insists that it has a successor drug, Nexium, to fill the gap left by Losec. However, some commentators say Nexium will be little better than generic versions of Losec.

webTitle: We are good at getting in, not so good at getting out

fields.headline: We are good at getting in, not so good at getting out
fields.standfirst:
The real test will be to see if we have the nerve to leave Sierra Leone

Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: The Brits are good at getting into other countries fast. Defence chiefs are proud of how they moved 800 men to Sierra Leone quicker, they think, than any other country could have done. It was an object lesson in the rapid deployment that is intended to be one of our 21st-century specialities and requires, as a natural precondition, the burial of any parliamentary debate, let alone national agonising, beforehand.
fields.body:
The Brits are good at getting into other countries fast. Defence chiefs are proud of how they moved 800 men to Sierra Leone quicker, they think, than any other country could have done. It was an object lesson in the rapid deployment that is intended to be one of our 21st-century specialities and requires, as a natural precondition, the burial of any parliamentary debate, let alone national agonising, beforehand. Ten days ago this British talent was displayed to smooth effect. What remains to be seen is whether we are as good at getting out as getting in. It is a critical test for the doctrine of dutiful interventionism Tony Blair enunciated during the Kosovo war. The duty to stay could easily come to seem as pressing as the duty to enter. We can see where duty starts, but where does it end?

As long as we get out clean, the absence of debate doesn't matter much. Unlike Americans, the British, people as well as soldiers, are ready for action. Acquiescence in its possibly painful consequences is in the bones of a military nation. Up to a point, we probably don't mind about the absence of perfect clarity either. The mission that began as a rescue exercise for Europeans (overwhelmingly British) who wanted to leave is plainly being stretched further, to bring aid and comfort to the UN peacekeepers. Ministers dodge around that, and prevaricate when asked to be precise. But people understand that war is messy and, within limits, are probably less fastidious than harrumphing editorialists who complain about mission creep.

Thus far, they have been justified. Only a doctrinaire non-interventionist could complain about the rescue operation. History, in fact, supports something rather bigger. The place is, after all, our legacy. In certain circumstances, as France periodically shows in Chad and Britain in Zimbabwe, special post- imperial duties attach themselves to the former European power. It therefore fell to a British contingent, supported by a British flotilla accidentally in the vicinity, to help out in a Sierra Leone crisis we had botched once before and now have a chance to make more sense of. Still no worries. A job needed doing, and our boys could be swiftly on hand for professional work.

Politics now begins to intrude a little. In Whitehall, people talk less about the politics of disaster if a British cohort gets cornered by drug-crazed rebel gunmen, than about the politics of weakness, with an election looming. The need for Labour Britain not to appear wet and wimpish plays a part in the discussion about how and when to come home. This could yet deform the government's answer to the question Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of the defence staff, immediately put to it on return from his African reconnaissance: what next?

After the first rescue, the British contingent has been helpful in Freetown. It calmed things down. The presence of crack British paras intimidates all and sundry. We've now seen that if the rebel militias attack them they will shoot to kill, ranging beyond the airport whose security is supposed to be their limiting preoccupation. Still OK, surely. And still in line with the Blair Kosovo doctrine of intervention for a moral cause as long as there is a realistic chance of doing permanent good. Under a proactive chief, Brigadier Richards, and wearing its own badges, the regiment seems to have taken over unofficial command, instructing, training, cajoling, helicoptering the UN blue berets towards being a more effective peace force.

Now comes the real political test, which is, quite simply, will we have the nerve to leave? The pressure not to will be great. For Sierra Leone confronts the UN with the greatest crisis in its recent history. Intended to be 11,000-strong, the force there is the largest UN peacekeeping army in the world. Yet it is pathetically failing. It has become hostage - 350 are literally hostages - to the armed gangs of rebel forces who are destabilising the regime it should be defending. Its mandate was clear enough, and extraneous security council complications, such as China and Russia applied in Kosovo, are absent. If this massive UN presence is incapable of sustaining a peace, against a disorderly and largely untrained rabble, one must ask what future there can ever be for the entire principle of humanitarian peacekeeping intervention by the UN.

Some people argue that peacekeeping should stop anyway. Michael Ignatieff, a passionate upholder of international morality, wrote this week in the New York Times that the UN system has reached the end of the road. The neutrality on which it rests is no longer valid, he says. In the post-cold war era, the major disputes, Sierra Leone among them, are between plain good and evil, a dichotomy the UN declines adequately to recognise even as its troops watch Rwandan civilians being hacked to death (1994), or permit the massacre of thousands of civilians by Bosnian Serbs at Srebrenica (1995). A new kind of world order hoves into view, in which the security council authorises combat warriors to deploy against obvious regional barbarians, such as the Revolutionary United Front who are maiming and slaughtering the innocent in Sierra Leone.

This counsel of despair is unlikely to find favour. It begs too many awkward questions about where the lines of evil are drawn, and what sort of warriors might be recruited to fight a foreign war. To stave it off, UN voices will ask the British to stay in Sierra Leone and help the force there turn itself round. The Brits could no doubt achieve a lot, with their superior training and experience. It will be tempting to listen to the case. The moral force of this, after all, will remain. A government that has forsworn the normal rules of national self-interest in judging when to make its forces internationally available - as Blairite Britain, unlike the US, has done - is vulnerable to persuasion that its duty isn't finished. The horrors will go on. The case for an ongoing presence as part of the UN force itself for however long it takes can be powerfully made.

It needs to be firmly resisted. The pocket generals at the Foreign Office and the fervent moralist in Downing Street need alike to restrain themselves. There is a clear limit to what Britain can or should do. Rather effectively, edging beyond the first stated purpose, we are doing it. This could yet become a modest case-study in focused interventionism, provided it acknowledges that a deeply imperfect situation has to be left behind. The struggle must be resumed at a political level to make the UN, especially the security council, more honest: not making promises it cannot keep, not committing to operations its members decline to man, not watching its moral authority drain away. The paras can't be a proxy for that kind of desperately needed renovation. I can't believe their political bosses will contemplate anything other than orderly withdrawal, mission sort-of accomplished.

fields.headline: Imported seeds tainted by GM
fields.standfirst:
Government defends polluted crops planted in UK

GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Thousands of acres of crops tainted by GM pollen have been growing in Britain for more than a year and may have been used in food production, the government admitted last night in a move that is highly embarrassing for its scientific advisers, who had previously claimed there was little risk of cross-pollination with conventional crops.
fields.body:
Thousands of acres of crops tainted by GM pollen have been growing in Britain for more than a year and may have been used in food production, the government admitted last night in a move that is highly embarrassing for its scientific advisers, who had previously claimed there was little risk of cross-pollination with conventional crops.

Hundreds of farmers have unwittingly planted the contaminated seed over two spring seasons without the safeguards used for GM field trials, but ministers, whose officials had known about the problem for a month, insisted there was no risk to health or the environment.

The seeds came from the Canadian prairies, from plants that were growing more than 800 metres away from the nearest GM varieties but still picked up traces of modified material.

The tainted seed is thought to have been used on 9,000 hectares last year, nearly 2% of the rape crop. This year it has probably been used on 4,700 hectares, involving between 500 and 600 farmers.

It also emerged that there had been no random testing of imports of conventional seed for rogue GM material, despite the rapid spread of GM crops through the United States, Canada and Brazil. In this country no GM seeds are to be sold to farmers until after three years of farm trials to test their impact on the environment and wildlife.

Opposition parties immediately condemned ministers for the lack of proper controls on seeds, and for the delay and the low key announcement, made through a parliamentary written answer. The Liberal Democrats' environment spokesman, David Heath, said the delay and the manner in which the government announcement had been made was deeply disturbing. "It is another example of the contempt in which the government holds the British public," he said.

The Tory spokesman, Tim Yeo, accused the government of a "willingness to allow commercial considerations to override the need to protect the British environment".

The latest embarrassment came a day after it emerged that some British honey might have been contaminated by pollen from GM trials.

The seeds discovery was made during testing of imported seeds by the German state of Baden-Wurttemberg. The international company responsible, Advanta Seeds, was informed by one of its customers in the state. Its British arm was told on April 3, and took steps to stop further sales while it began its own testing; this revealed a GM presence of up to 1% in seeds grown in 1998 and sold over the past two years.

The company told government officials on April 17. It was worried because the GM oilseed rape which tainted the conventional seed had no commercial licences for sales to farmers in Europe, but it could not inform its distributors or farmers until the government acted.

"We are absolutely dismayed," said Mike Ruthven, general manager of Advanta Seeds UK. "We are very concerned for consumers, because of the sensitivity of these things. We believe we are extremely responsible and we are gobsmacked that this has happened with an orthodox crop."

He said the advice from the government so far was that no regulation had been broken, and there was no threat to health or the environment - "although we have had some difficulty in getting those statements".

The 1999 seed crop had not been contaminated because the company had by then moved its seed growing from Alberta, Canada, to Ontario in eastern Canada, Montana in the US, and New Zealand.

Oilseed rape is used in foods such as margarine and in industrial processes, but the GM material that has been available from abroad was passed as safe by government advisers several years ago.

The seed is also thought to have been used on 600 hectares in France, 500 in Sweden and 400 in Germany, causing international embarrassment and highlighting a lack of international regulation of seed purity.

Baroness Hayman, the agriculture minister, said there would be new spot checks on imports and work with the industry on a new code of practice: "This is not a safety issue... However, the issue of seed purity is a serious one."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.body:
New chief at ailing Mattel

Mattel, the world's largest toymaker, has named food industry executive Robert Eckert to replace Jill Barad, who the maker of Barbie Dolls forced out in February after a turbulent three years as chief executive.

Mr Eckert joins California-based Mattel after announcing his resignation as president and chief executive of Kraft Foods. Mattel has struggled through a recent succession of quarterly earnings disappointments stemming largely from its acquisition last year of software developer The Learning Co.

Mattel has been trying to sell the business but a buyer has net yet emerged. It is expected that it will fetch far less than its $3.5bn purchase price.

Euro the fund chiefs favourite

The euro is the favourite currency of fund managers in every major global region, according to a survey published yesterday by American investment bank Merrill Lynch.

Investors in the US, Europe, Britain, Japan, Asia and South Africa named the euro as top choice, despite its 23.6% decline since January 1999.

Asked to name three events most likely to trigger a sustained recovery in the euro, the 258 fund managers said a reversal in foreign direct investment flows, European political and economic reform and a slowdown in US growth.

VW aims to slash costs

Volkswagen expects to reduce costs by DM1.8bn (£576m) through measures initiated early this year, works council head Klaus Volkert said yesterday. Under the programme, the VW brand alone should shrink expenditures by about DM1bn while the Audi, Skoda and Seat brands are to cut theirs by a combined DM800m.

BA in pension fund battle

British Airways pensioners have voted to pass a motion of no confidence on their trustees in a poll following an emergency meeting of fund beneficiaries.The vote by 2,935 to 458 was described by the pensioners chairman, Mick Post, as a "reflection of our anger at the way BA is trying to raid the fund's assets".

BA is trying to merge a £6bn pension fund with a smaller one, valued at £3bn. The merger would result in a surplus of £276m, enough to wipe out BA's expected commercial operating loss of more than £200m. The dispute is to go to the high court.

Eurotunnel backs Morton

Eurotunnel is backing its directors - including former chairman Sir Alastair Morton, head of the shadow Strategic Rail Authority - against allegations of publishing false accounts. An investigation is being carried out by a French magistrate.

webTitle: Four die in first clash with British

fields.headline: Four die in first clash with British
fields.standfirst:
Paratroopers defending airport repel attempted rebel advance

Sierra Leone: special report
Interactive: what is happening in Sierra Leone?
fields.trailText: British paratroopers killed at least four rebels in Sierra Leone yesterday in their first clash with the Revolutionary United Front.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal  in Freetown and  Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
British paratroopers killed at least four rebels in Sierra Leone yesterday in their first clash with the Revolutionary United Front.

The army said that 29 British soldiers, all but four of them members of the Pathfinder battalion, were dug in with 20 Nigerians at Lungi, about 20 miles from Freetown's international airport, when their night sights picked up rebels moving through the bush.

"The RUF were advancing in classic military style. They put up tracer and opened fire. British forces put up illuminating mortars and returned a 'wall of fire'," said one source.

When the rebels began to retreat, the Pathfinders called in two helicopter gunships carrying additional troops and mortars. While the paratroopers pursued the rebels on the ground, Chinook helicopters with revolving machine guns chased stragglers a further 10 miles to the contested town of Port Loco.

The bodies of at least four rebels have been found. British officials believe several more may have been killed. A woman with them was wounded. It is not certain whether she was a combatant. There were no British or Nigerian casualties.

British officials said the Pathfinders were dug in deep far from the airport to act as a "trip wire" for any rebel attack. But the size of the response, and the pursuit of the RUF back to their bases, demonstrated the willingness of British commanders to engage the rebels.

"We are not here to fight the government's war, we are here to help them win it with strategy and organisation and logistics. But if our forces come under attack we are not going to just sit and take it. The RUF now understands that it is dealing with an army prepared to fight if necessary and that when it crosses us it will pay a high price," said one British military official. In London, Tony Blair's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, said the clash between the rebels and paratroopers was "all within the robust rules of engagement" given to the British forces.

In the Commons, Mr Blair went out of his way to praise the actions of the British troops. "We can be very, very proud of our armed forces and what they have done in Sierra Leone," he said.

"The whole world is witnessing and applauding their central role in trying to deal with this so-called rebel army - that in truth is a criminal gang, that has visited the most appalling atrocities on innocent civilians in Sierra Leone."

The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, denied the firefight showed that British troops were getting sucked into the civil war.

"This was wholly consistent about what we have always said about the role of British forces," he said.

"They were there to protect the airport, part of that inevitably means patrolling around the airport to gather information and intelligence. They were attacked while engaged in that very important task."

The British troops had returned fire after being shot at, added Mr Hoon. "They have been given robust rules of engagement. If they are attacked they certainly will defend themselves and they certainly will defend the airport."

The government insists that British troops will pull out once the UN force is up to strength - perhaps by the middle of next month.

However, despite the prime minister's praise for British troops, MPs from all parties sense that the government has little idea how long British troops will remain in Sierra Leone and suspect that they have no exit strategy.

"They are heavily involved from the touchline but are refusing to get on the pitch", one senior western diplomat said yesterday.

A British forces spokesman said the paratroopers had no immediate plans to step up patrols in Freetown, but officers said they would be watching the situation closely.

The RUF gained the upper hand in another raid near Port Loco on a joint Nigerian and Sierra Leonean army post. At least one Nigerian and six Sierra Leonean soldiers were killed in a firefight that lasted about two hours. The UN said the rebels used mortars and rocket propelled grenades to attack the post before withdrawing.

The area around Port Loco is the focus of a push by British-backed government forces to dislodge the rebels. Although most of the fighting is being done by the Sierra Leone army, the Pathfinders have dug themselves in close to rebel-held areas. The paratroopers have occupied villages, burning and clearing the bush around for 100 metres or more so the RUF cannot hide.

They were attacked while engaged in that very important task." The British troops had returned fire after being shot at, added Mr Hoon. "They have been given robust rules of engagement. If they are attacked they certainly will defend themselves and they certainly will defend the airport." The government insists that British troops will pull out once the UN force is up to strength - perhaps by the middle of next month. However, despite the prime minister's praise for British troops, MPs from all parties sense that the government has little idea how long British troops will remain in Sierra Leone and suspect that they have no exit strategy. "They are heavily involved from the touchline but are refusing to get on the pitch", one senior western diplomat said yesterday. A British forces spokesman said the paratroopers had no immediate plans to step up patrols in Freetown, but officers said they would be watching the situation closely. The RUF gained the upper hand in another raid near Port Loco on a joint Nigerian and Sierra Leonean army post. At least one Nigerian and six Sierra Leonean soldiers were killed in a firefight that lasted about two hours. The UN said the rebels used mortars and rocket propelled grenades to attack the post before withdrawing. The area around Port Loco is the focus of a push by British-backed government forces to dislodge the rebels. Although most of the fighting is being done by the Sierra Leone army, the Pathfinders have dug themselves in close to rebel-held areas. The paratroopers have occupied villages, burning and clearing the bush around for 100 metres or more so the RUF cannot hide. webTitle: Anthrax link to deaths of 11 Scottish heroin addicts

fields.headline: Anthrax link to deaths of 11 Scottish heroin addicts
fields.trailText: Government analysts said yesterday that evidence of anthrax had been found in victims of a mysterious disease that has killed 11 Scottish heroin addicts in recent weeks and left 15 more in hospital.
fields.body:
Government analysts said yesterday that evidence of anthrax had been found in victims of a mysterious disease that has killed 11 Scottish heroin addicts in recent weeks and left 15 more in hospital.

Scientists at Porton Down, Wiltshire, confirmed a report in the forthcoming issue of New Scientist magazine that antibodies against anthrax spores have been found in blood samples from two of the victims. The anthrax theory is expected to be confirmed or ruled out by the end of the week after further tests.

If confirmed, the deaths suggest that a consignment of heroin contaminated with the deadly bacterium is loose on the streets of Europe.

However, Glasgow health officials yesterday played down the theory, saying the Porton Down findings were only weak, indirect evidence.

"I'm very sceptical," said Laurence Gruer, consultant in public health medicine on Greater Glasgow health board. "I can't 100% rule it out, but I would have expected a lot more evidence for anthrax."

Cases of dead and dying heroin users with similar and unusual symptoms began to pile up on Dr Gruer's desk at the end of last month. The 11th victim died on Tuesday.

All had injected the drug into their muscles, rather than their veins, either by accident or because scars from overuse of a needle meant that free-flowing blood could no longer be found in surface veins. Many of the victims have been women, whose veins tend to be less accessible than men's.

The anthrax connection was first mooted by scientists at the centre for applied microbiology and research, which is alongside the Ministry of Defence's biological warfare lab at Porton Down but is run by the Department of Health.

They noticed a report from Norway, posted on the internet, of an Oslo addict who died in April after injecting heroin into his muscle. A postmortem showed anthrax bacilli in his spinal fluid. Aware of the deaths in Scotland, CAMR asked the Glasgow health board to send some samples.

A CAMR spokesman, Phil Luton, said: "We got two very weak positives, which is not conclusive evidence of anthrax, but we can't rule it out and are continuing to test."

The victims' symptoms were indicative of anthrax, he said. Phil Hanna, an anthrax specialist at the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor, made the same observation in the New Scientist report.

The Scottish victims - 10 from Glasgow, one from Aberdeen - all died in a similar way: several hours after injecting they had accumulated symptoms including a heavy build-up of fluid, leakage of fluids round the heart and lungs, and rapidly rising white blood cell counts as their metabolism rallied to fight a major infection.

Dr Gruer said he hoped to get the further test results from CAMR today or tomorrow.

Besides the Porton Down tests, he said, Glasgow specialists had been culturing blood and tissue samples from the victims to see if anthrax spores could be detected through a microscope, but with negative results.

Other theories have included necrotising fasciitis, known as flesh-eating disease, or alternative contaminants in heroin, or the citric acid used by addicts to dissolve heroin in water to make an injectable solution.

The muscle-injecting addicts have complained that lately they have had to use more acid than usual, causing a burning sensation and, doctors speculate, severe muscle damage.

Dr Gruer said one possibility was that the muscle damage had combined with minor bacterial infections to cause the addicts' deaths.

Anthrax is not passed from person to person, so there is no risk of an epidemic outside the heroin-injecting community even if it turns out to be the cause.

It is not clear how it may have contaminated heroin, although the bacterium is endemic in livestock in prime heroin poppy growing regions such as Afghanistan.

webTitle: Cannes clashes mirror Björk's film set flare-up

fields.headline: Cannes clashes mirror Björk's film set flare-up
fields.trailText: Dancer In The Dark, a film musical starring the singer Björk, became an instant sensation yesterday when its premiere at Cannes was both cheered and booed.
fields.body:
Dancer In The Dark, a film musical starring the singer Björk, became an instant sensation yesterday when its premiere at Cannes was both cheered and booed.

There were heated exchanges afterwards between critics, some shaken by the film, others angry at "being so crudely manipulated".

The clashes mirrored the tantrums on the set between its quixotic Icelandic star and its uncompromising Danish director Lars Von Trier.

From the ovation given to Von Trier at a press conference afterwards, it is clear that many critics will be annoyed if the film does not win the Palme O'Or, although with opinions so divided, there may also be protests if he does.

Bjork - who Von Trier branded a "mad woman" a fortnight ago after she tried to block the film's screening because of cuts to her score - refused to appear alongside him and her co-star, Catherine Deneuve, to answer questions. However, she did attend last night's gala screening in Cannes.

Björk's spokeswoman said she was "too frightened" by the attention her performance had attracted. Deneuve said she was so traumatised by the experience of playing the part of Selma, a Czech immigrant in 1950s America, that she may not be able to talk about it for 10 years.

Von Trier, who was nominated for an Oscar for Breaking The Waves, has admitted to being a tyrant and made no attempt to play down the rift with the singer which culminated in her storming off the set for four days.

Asked what it was like to work with Björk, he replied: "It has been terrible but the results have been incredible. Björk is not an actor. What was a surprise for me is that she seemed like a professional but she really isn't. She is not acting in this film but feeling everything, which is extremely hard on her and everyone else too. It was like being with a dying person. I was in the awkward position of being the hangman who was pushing her towards her death. But it is the only way it could have been done."

Von Trier, 44, said that despite their differences he admired her performance. "I am extremely fond of the work she has done and I would like to thank her for it."

Deneuve, who formed a close bond with Björk during the filming, and spent new year in Iceland with her, did not deny the tension with Bjork on the set.

"But it would be very perverse with such a very special film to give such importance to something behind the scenes," she said. "Nothing that is really worth it goes without difficulties, without tension, without crying. The more difficult and intense a film the more painful it is. Björk is very special. She cannot really act, she can only feel. Some of the situations in the film are so hard, and she was in so much pain, she could not recover from one day to the other. Those things made her behave sometimes like a child, like a human being who couldn't take it anymore. Like a child running out of school, sometimes she would run away. But when you compare that to the level of her performance in the film those things become so little."

Deneuve, 56, who has been acting since she was 14, said it was most the most "extreme" experience of film-making. "It was incredible what has been done," she said.

Von Trier, who is regarded as a force in world cinema, joked that he hoped to cast Deneuve, who famously played a prostitute in Belle de Jour in 1967, in his next project, a porn film. "She knows many things about the world that I don't," he said.

Security in Cannes, already tight, with hundreds of riot police and gendarmes deployed, was last night stepped up after a series of muggings and break-ins in the streets behind the beachfront Croisette where most of the star-studded parties are held.

Two British women, two Swedes and an American were attacked on Tuesday night. Police said yesterday that gangs of thieves were in the resort for the festival as well as "opportunists" working the main hotels.

Meanwhile, Derek Malcolm, who has written for the Guardian for 35 years, was yesterday presented with a medal "for his services to cinema" by the retiring Cannes president, Gilles Jacob. He described Malcolm as "one of the world's most distinguished critics".

webTitle: ITV to screen Queen Mother's pageant

fields.headline: ITV to screen Queen Mother's pageant
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: ITV has stepped into the breach left by the BBC's decision not to screen live a parade of soldiers and civilians in honour of the Queen Mother's 100th birthday.
fields.body:
ITV has stepped into the breach left by the BBC's decision not to screen live a parade of soldiers and civilians in honour of the Queen Mother's 100th birthday.

Sir Trevor McDonald, Kirsty Young and John Suchet will front ITV's coverage of the pageant, as part of a deal agreed yesterday. The BBC had faced a barrage of criticism from sections of the media for refusing to broadcast the event in full.

The ITV announcement is a boost for the event's organisers who had been wrong-footed by the BBC. Before the corporation opted not to screen the pageant, the army had decided to hire out 30 corporate boxes, each holding 20 people, for a fee of £10,000 each, thereby reducing the number of free places available along the parade route to members of the public.

It was alleged that BBC1 had rejected the event, on July 19, because it clashed with the early evening soap Neighbours and the 6pm news. The BBC rejected the claim, pointing out that it was already planning to spend £1m on broadcasts celebrating the Queen Mother's life.

David Liddiment, ITV's director of programmes, said yesterday: "The organisers want this event to be seen by as many people as possible and asked ITV if it could help. Clearly the British public wants the chance to share in this historic event."

Major General Evelyn Webb-Carter, the chairman of the event's organising committee, said: "We are delighted that, thanks to ITV, this tribute will now be seen by many more people around the country."

The BBC pointed to its two-hour live outside broadcast on the Queen Mother's birthday on August 4 as the centrepiece of its coverage. A spokesman said: "We thought long and hard about covering the event, but decided that Her Majesty's birthday itself should be our main priority, and that the BBC's comprehensive level of coverage was right."

Clarence House declined to comment on the deal, but officials at Buckingham Palace are delighted that the event will be televised live.

"It is encouraging to know that more people will be able to see it," one said.

It is thought that the channel will pay ITN about £200,000 to screen the event, although it is not known how much the news broadcaster has agreed to pay the event organisers.

webTitle: Police could lose right to investigate each other

fields.headline: Police could lose right to investigate each other
fields.standfirst:
Police complaints authority
The Issue explained
fields.trailText: Police stand to lose responsibility for investigating serious allegations against fellow officers under plans unveiled by the Home Office yesterday to shore up public confidence in the service.
fields.body:
Police stand to lose responsibility for investigating serious allegations against fellow officers under plans unveiled by the Home Office yesterday to shore up public confidence in the service.

Skilled investigators drawn from Customs & Excise, the Inland Revenue, the Serious Fraud Office and the legal profession will be asked to carry out inquiries into police misconduct. The shake-up, ordered by home secretary Jack Straw after the Macpherson report on the bungled inquiry into Stephen Lawrence's murder, aims to address increasing public cynicism about police investigating each other. Around 18,000 complaints a year are investigated by officers under supervision from the police complaints authority.

Launching a consultation process on reform yesterday, Mr Straw said that, in most cases, police investigated complaints "with great thoroughness, integrity and impartiality".

But he added: "It is hard to convey that when the system is always open to the charge of 'the police investigating themselves'. Justice must be seen to be done."

In a Commons statement, home office minister Charles Clarke said: "Any reform of the current system must, if it is to command public confidence, involve a greater independent element in the investigation of complaints and greater openness in respect of the result of those investigations."

Tories backed the plan for a fully independent complaints authority, but home affairs spokesman Oliver Heald warned against any move to include journalists or any other non-trained investigators to conduct inquiries.

Mr Clarke backed calls by Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Simon Hughes for a "lay element" in investigations.

Two visions for a reform of the system were unveiled yesterday; one commissioned by the Home Office and drawn up by management consultants KPMG, and an independent report from the human rights watchdog Liberty.

Under both schemes, out for consultation until June 30 with a decision expected by the end of the year, the majority of complaints will continue to be investigated by police officers. But both reports recommend setting up independent teams of investigators for the rest.

The Liberty report goes further than the KPMG proposals, which recommend that only the most serious complaints - those involving deaths in custody, police chases which end in fatal crashes, and serious criminal offences - be investigated by outside teams.

Liberty recommends that in all cases involving the death of a civilian, serious injury, corruption or racial discrimination, an outside investigation would be compulsory.

The human rights group also argues that at least 25% of all other complaints should be subject to an external investigation.

The KPMG scheme would investigate around 1,000 cases annually, compared with 2,000 under Liberty's proposals, making the latter more expensive.

The human rights group's plan would cost more than £20m, while the management consultants estimate theirs at £14m annually.

The existing police complaints authority, which would be disbanded under both schemes, costs around £3.4m a year.

fields.headline: An African silence
fields.standfirst:
South Africa's president arrives in Britain today, in a delicate situation. Mugabe resents him, too

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: President Mbeki of South Africa arrives in London today for a two-day visit, in the midst of still greater pessimism about "the hopeless continent", as the Economist calls it. With most of South Africa's neighbours in disarray, western investors and diplomats fear that it will soon be infected by the crisis in Zimbabwe.
fields.body:
President Mbeki of South Africa arrives in London today for a two-day visit, in the midst of still greater pessimism about "the hopeless continent", as the Economist calls it. With most of South Africa's neighbours in disarray, western investors and diplomats fear that it will soon be infected by the crisis in Zimbabwe.

The British media have complained that Mbeki has not spoken out against Mugabe's violence; and even the Foreign Office, influenced by Robin Cook's "ethical foreign policy", have appeared critical of his restraint. Why doesn't he speak out more openly against Mugabe's plunder of white farms, and his encouragement of violence? Why does he have to follow the tradition of African presidents closing their ranks to rally round dictators?

But the trouble with these criticisms is that they all depict the Zimbabwe problem in racial terms, in simple black and white - which is just what Mugabe needs to win his election. The more he can depict his opposition as being supported by white farmers and the British government, the more he can deflect criticism of his own corruption and disastrous mismanagement. And it is just this racial polarisation which President Mbeki has to avoid.

It is important to try to see the problem of Zimbabwe from Mbeki's viewpoint. He has always been a master of discreet diplomacy, and his handling of Mugabe may prove his most difficult test. Many colleagues have warned him that Mugabe is psychologically unbalanced, in a very dangerous mood, which foreign criticism will make more dangerous. Mugabe's illness is not the familiar political paranoia of heads of government, white or black, who feel themselves with some reason besieged by a hostile press and public. It is a much more irrational psychological state which thrives on foreign enemies. The most obvious enemy is Britain. (When I saw Mugabe last September at a breakfast in New York, he seemed calm and businesslike until the subject of Britain caused a furious outburst on Blair's gay government).

But the next favourite enemy is South Africa, which has usurped Mugabe's role as the leader of southern Africa and which is easily depicted as the bully-boy of the region. When Mandela became president in 1994 he faced intense resentments from Mugabe, and had to handle him with kid-gloves. Mandela has remained very cautious about Mugabe, until 10 days ago he finally exploded with an attack on ex-liberation leaders who "despise the people who put them in power and want to stay in power for ever".

But Mbeki, cannot afford to be so outspoken. He desperately wants to ensure peaceful elections, to get Zimbabwe's troops out of the Congo, and to restore the Zimbabwean economy which is so closely interlocked with South Africa's. But any criticism, sanctions or support for the opposition will provide Mugabe with electoral ammunition to depict Pretoria as the foreign bully and lackey of the whites.

The race card makes intervention still more dangerous, as the western media concentrate on the murders of white farmers and ignore the mounting black casualties. The noisy support of white farmers for the black opposition in Zimbabwe gives Mugabe an electoral boost.

Mbeki and Mandela have to do everything possible to avoid a civil war in Zimbabwe: the final collapse of the economy could lead to chaos, with angry soldiers returning from the Congo with weapons but no money. Refugees would flood across the South African border, swelling the unemployed and increasing tension in the border areas. In the ultimate nightmare, rural black South Africans would take their cue from Zimbabwe, and begin invading the white farms.

Will South Africa really go the same way as Zimbabwe, as foreign investors are already fearing? In fact the South African situation is quite different: though 80% of its land is still white-owned, it plays a far less important role in the economy and employment, and the ANC has announced that redistribution is being speeded up. But the foreign perception is very damaging, pulling down the currency to new lows.

Mbeki's first priority in London must be to to make clear that South Africa will not be infected by Zimbabwe's violence. But he cannot afford to inflame Zimbabweans against their powerful neighbour, and he will not be helped by simplistic comparisons between the two countries in racial terms, as being both riven be tween white managers and black workers.

The success of South Africa's peaceful revolution (which Mbeki helped to negotiate under Mandela's leadership) depends on maintaining the multiracial political settlement, and on providing the industrial powerhouse which depends on white management as much as the black workforce. It is a society and economy which is quite different from anything in the rest of Africa and it emerged from a quite different history. But it requires the confidence and support of western governments and investors to sustain its prosperity, and to protect it from the Zimbabwe virus.

 Mandela, the Authorised Biography, by Anthony Sampson, is re-published this week in paperback by HarperCollins.
