And it is just this racial polarisation which President Mbeki has to avoid. It is important to try to see the problem of Zimbabwe from Mbeki's viewpoint. He has always been a master of discreet diplomacy, and his handling of Mugabe may prove his most difficult test. Many colleagues have warned him that Mugabe is psychologically unbalanced, in a very dangerous mood, which foreign criticism will make more dangerous. Mugabe's illness is not the familiar political paranoia of heads of government, white or black, who feel themselves with some reason besieged by a hostile press and public. It is a much more irrational psychological state which thrives on foreign enemies. The most obvious enemy is Britain. (When I saw Mugabe last September at a breakfast in New York, he seemed calm and businesslike until the subject of Britain caused a furious outburst on Blair's gay government). But the next favourite enemy is South Africa, which has usurped Mugabe's role as the leader of southern Africa and which is easily depicted as the bully-boy of the region. When Mandela became president in 1994 he faced intense resentments from Mugabe, and had to handle him with kid-gloves. Mandela has remained very cautious about Mugabe, until 10 days ago he finally exploded with an attack on ex-liberation leaders who "despise the people who put them in power and want to stay in power for ever". But Mbeki, cannot afford to be so outspoken. He desperately wants to ensure peaceful elections, to get Zimbabwe's troops out of the Congo, and to restore the Zimbabwean economy which is so closely interlocked with South Africa's. But any criticism, sanctions or support for the opposition will provide Mugabe with electoral ammunition to depict Pretoria as the foreign bully and lackey of the whites. The race card makes intervention still more dangerous, as the western media concentrate on the murders of white farmers and ignore the mounting black casualties. The noisy support of white farmers for the black opposition in Zimbabwe gives Mugabe an electoral boost. Mbeki and Mandela have to do everything possible to avoid a civil war in Zimbabwe: the final collapse of the economy could lead to chaos, with angry soldiers returning from the Congo with weapons but no money. Refugees would flood across the South African border, swelling the unemployed and increasing tension in the border areas. In the ultimate nightmare, rural black South Africans would take their cue from Zimbabwe, and begin invading the white farms. Will South Africa really go the same way as Zimbabwe, as foreign investors are already fearing? In fact the South African situation is quite different: though 80% of its land is still white-owned, it plays a far less important role in the economy and employment, and the ANC has announced that redistribution is being speeded up. But the foreign perception is very damaging, pulling down the currency to new lows. Mbeki's first priority in London must be to to make clear that South Africa will not be infected by Zimbabwe's violence. But he cannot afford to inflame Zimbabweans against their powerful neighbour, and he will not be helped by simplistic comparisons between the two countries in racial terms, as being both riven be tween white managers and black workers. The success of South Africa's peaceful revolution (which Mbeki helped to negotiate under Mandela's leadership) depends on maintaining the multiracial political settlement, and on providing the industrial powerhouse which depends on white management as much as the black workforce. It is a society and economy which is quite different from anything in the rest of Africa and it emerged from a quite different history. But it requires the confidence and support of western governments and investors to sustain its prosperity, and to protect it from the Zimbabwe virus.  Mandela, the Authorised Biography, by Anthony Sampson, is re-published this week in paperback by HarperCollins. comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Male nurse used sedative to kill and rape

fields.headline: Male nurse used sedative to kill and rape
fields.standfirst: Department of Health to issue new rules on storage of drugs after manslaughter conviction of man who exploited access to anaesthetic
fields.trailText: Department of Health to issue new rules on storage of drugs after manslaughter conviction of man who exploited access to anaesthetic
fields.body:
A male nurse convicted yesterday of the manslaughter of a colleague and of drugging and raping three female patients may have attacked dozens of other women during a two year period in which his crimes went undetected, police fear.

Kevin Cobb, 38, faces life imprisonment after being found guilty at the Old Bailey of the manslaughter of Susan Annis, who died after he spiked her drink with the sedative Midazolam in order to rape her in November 1996. The two had been taking part in a residential course on paediatric care at the Royal Brompton hospital, west London.

Cobb, from Yateley, Hampshire, was also convicted of administering Midazolam and raping two women at St Peter's hospital, Chertsey, Surrey, where he was a senior staff accident and emergency nurse in January 1999, and drugging a third woman with the intention of raping her in December 1998.

Adjourning sentencing pending psychiatric reports judge Martin Stephens told Cobb he could expect a "lengthy prison sentence" and indicated he would consider life.

Cobb stood motionless as the jury of seven women and five men returned the guilty verdicts, watched by Ms Annis's parents, Audrey and David and his three surviving victims who wept in the public gallery.

Midazolam, a powerful anaesthetic used in minor surgery, leaves patients unable to remember what has happened to them.

"We cannot dismiss the existence of other victims," said DS David Cook of Surrey police, who led the investigation."Between killing Susan Annis in 1996 and the three later attacks in 1999, I find it hard to believe that an evil and dangerous man like Kevin Cobb was not active in that time."

Ms Annis's death was not initially thought to be suspicious. At her inquest traces of Midazolam found in her stomach were dismissed by the coroner as a "red herring" and an open verdict was recorded.

Cobb only came under suspicion when his final victim awoke from a Midazolam dose as she was being raped, and two other victims subsequently came forward.

The investigation into Ms Annis's death was reopened when a friend and colleague who had been troubled by the discovery of Midazolam contacted police after hearing that Cobb, who gave evidence at the inquest, had been arrested for drugging and raping another woman.

The case is expected to have far reaching implications for the way in which drugs are stored in hospitals, and for the guidelines concerning the chaperoning of male nurses. St Peter's was operating at double capacity at the beginning of 1999 and Cobb was able to take advantage of short staffing to isolate female patients in order to attack them.

Midazolam is a schedule four controlled drug, meaning it does not have to be kept secure. Since Cobb's arrest St Peter's has treated the drug as a schedule three substance requiring safe custody and the presence of two doctors before it can be dispensed.

The Department of Health said last night it would be examining the implications of the Cobb case for the NHS and that it would take whatever action was deemed necessary. New guidelines on the classification and storage of drugs would be circulated to hospitals shortly, a spokesman said.

Drug that made victims forget

Clinical amnesia, the quality which makes Midazolam medically valuable, enabled Cobb to mount a systematic campaign of rape and sexual abuse.

A member of the benzodiazepine sedative group (along with Rohypnol and Temazipan) Midazolam is prized for its amnesiac qualities.

It is widely used in paediatrics and dentistry, typically for endoscopic examinations where a child may find the experience traumatic unless sedated.

A patient will come round from a 5ml intravenous dose of the drug within two hours and not recall details of an operation, but doctors administering the drug always carry the antidote with them to guard against accidental overdoses.

The drug breaks down rapidly and will disappear from a patient's system within 48 hours, making its detection in criminal cases problematic - forensic evidence of Midazolam was obtained for just two of Cobb's victims.

Midazolam can also cause paralysis, blurred vision and sexual fantasies in some patients, another factor that complicated the prosecution case against Cobb.

When mixed with alcohol Midazolam, like other "date rape" drugs, becomes potentially fatal. It was this combination that killed Susan Annis, who had drunk two cans of cider on the night of her death.

It is thought the Cobb case is the first known instance of Midazolam being used as a date rape drug. As a non-prescription drug it is relatively difficult to obtain.

Graham Rhodes, chief executive of the Roofie Foundation, which campaigns on behalf of the victims of drug rape ("roofie" is street slang for rape drugs) said: "The only reason this guy could get his hands on the drug was because he is a nurse."

webTitle: The hospital rapist who enjoyed taking sexual risks

fields.headline: The hospital rapist who enjoyed taking sexual risks
fields.trailText: When Kevin Cobb slipped the anaesthetic Midazolam into Susan Annis' cider, intending to rape her once the drug took effect, he knew she might not live.
fields.body:
When Kevin Cobb slipped the anaesthetic Midazolam into Susan Annis' cider, intending to rape her once the drug took effect, he knew she might not live.

A staff nurse with more than 10 years' experience, Cobb knew the dangers of mixing powerful sedatives and alcohol. He knew also that Ms Annis, a nurse he had met on a residential course at the Royal Brompton hospital, London, suffered from a condition which caused her heart to race.

But he went ahead with his plan anyway. The drug and alcohol combined to supress Ms Annis's breathing and the subsequent adrenalin release proved too much for her weakened heart.

Within two hours she lay dying on the floor of her room while Cobb administered mouth-to-mouth resuscitation in a desperate attempt to save her life, and himself from a prison sentence.

Despite the assistance of doctors and nurses at the hospital, Ms Annis, 31, was declared dead in the early hours of November 26 1996, presumed to be a victim of her unreliable heart.

Yesterday Cobb was found guilty at the Old Bailey of manslaughter, two counts of rape and four of administering drugs with the intention of committing sexual assault.

He brazenly attended Ms Annis's funeral where he wept and accepted the thanks of her parents for attempting to save her life, and gave evidence at her inquest. It was more than two years before police suspected that the unremarkable staff nurse at St Peter's hospital, Chertsey, was a rapist and a killer .

Cobb raped two other women at St Peter's after secretly administering Midazolam, and drugged a third woman with the intention of raping her. A grade E staff nurse at the time of his arrest in July last year, Cobb, 38, began his training in 1983 after a spell working as a picture framer and qualified as an enrolled nurse two years later. In 1986 he married Anita, a GP in Yately, Hampshire. They have a two-year old son.

In 1990 Cobb qualified as a registered general nurse and, after working at hospitals in Feltham and Ashford, settled in the A&E department at St Peter's in 1992. Colleagues there described him as a competent but far from outstanding nurse, a touch on the lazy side.

His statements to police revealed a man nurturing resentment at his lack of advancement. He complained that managers had failed to appreciate his skills and that he deserved promotion. He was sacked by St Peter's for falsifying his qualifications in a promotion application.

Cobb was also a man who enjoyed taking sexual risks. A former girlfriend, also a nurse, said he enjoyed having sex on night shifts in a small room adjoining a ward at Ashford Hospital, Middlesex. They also made love in a changing cubicle at a public swimming pool.

According to the police, by the time of Ms Annis's death Cobb's need to take risks manifested itself in a desire to rape, and crucially to exert control.

A senior officer said: "He was systematic, he targeted his victims carefully. They were all of a similar age, all professional. Once he targeted them, he created an environment in which he could do what he wanted.

"It's clear from what witnesses have told us he finds power appealing. He enjoys manipulating people for his sexual gratification, and he used his position at St Peter's to do it."

The police failed to pursue their investigation into Susan Annis' death following the inquest in February, 1997. The postmortem concluded that levels of Midazolam and alcohol "in no way contributed to death" and in recording an open verdict the Westminster coroner, Paul Knapman, dismissed the presence of of Midazolam in her stomach as "a red herring".

Midazolam is valued in dentistry and paediatric care because of its principal side effect, clinical amnesia. After coming to, patients are unable to recall clearly what has happened to them.

John Parsley, a doctor, was a close friend and colleague of Ms Annis at Crawley hospital and was deeply upset at her sudden death. His grief, combined with professional curiosity, took him to Westminster coroner's court. He doubted that Ms Annis would have taken Midazolam herself and wrote to Dr Knapman asking him to carry out further tests. Dr Knapman did so but decided to take the matter no further.

Dr Parsley kept his misgivings to himself until a chance conversation at a friend's retirement party last year. He was told by an accquaintance from St Peter's that a nurse at the hospital had been arrested in connection with the drugging and rape of a patient. The nurse was Cobb, the drug Midazolam.

The following day Dr Parsley contacted Surrey police anonymously and told them to re-examine the death of Susan Annis.

Yet had Cobb administered a larger quantity of Midazolam to his final victim, an IT manager aged 34, he might have escaped conviction. His undoing was that for once the drug failed him, and his victim remembered what happened.

In mid-January last year the woman, who cannot be named, attended St Peter's complaining of abdominal pains. Cobb wheeled her to a cubicle where he told her to undress while he left the room. When he returned he said he wanted to take a blood sample and told her to look away. As she did so he pumped her vein with Midazolam.

His victim told the Old Bailey: "Next thing I knew I seemed to be coming round in a concerned state to a strange situation ... something was horribly wrong ... He was naked from the waist down ... I thought 'Oh my God he's penetrated me'...

The following day Cobb was arrested. Six months later, following Dr Parsley's call, he was re-arrested and charged with Susan Annis's murder. The publicity brought another victim forward. A mother of three, aged 34, a business analyst, had attended St Peter's in December, 1998, with appendicitis. Cobb took her to a treatment room, asked her to undress, then told her he was going to administer a pre-med injection. No pre-med had been ordered. While she was unconscious Cobb raped her.

The woman was troubled by a dream that someone had had sex with her. At an identity parade she picked Cobb out of a line-up.

St Peter's wrote to patients asking if anything unusual had happened to them during their visit. A warehouse manager aged 34 came forward. She too had been injected with Midazolan. She also picked Cobb out at an identity parade.

fields.headline: Secrets and spies
fields.standfirst:
Stella Rimington, the former head of MI5, wants to publish her memoirs. But they'll be worthless

Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: At first glance, we should welcome it. A former head of MI5 embarrassing her erstwhile colleagues and the Whitehall establishment by writing her memoirs. A rare opportunity for us to find out the truth about what the security service has been up to.
fields.body:
At first glance, we should welcome it. A former head of MI5 embarrassing her erstwhile colleagues and the Whitehall establishment by writing her memoirs. A rare opportunity for us to find out the truth about what the security service has been up to.

But it will be nothing of the kind. Certainly the way the Sun yesterday treated its exclusive story under the headline "MI5 Chief in Book Sensation. Dame Stella Vows to Publish her Explosive £1m Memoirs" has embarrassed the government, MI5, and - so Whitehall says - Stella Rimington herself (although the newspaper's treatment of the story won't do any harm to her search for a publisher).

What the Sun leak has really exposed is a cosy deal being hatched by Rimington and the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson. It has all been done "entirely within the rules", the Home Office insisted yesterday. Rimington submits her manuscript and Whitehall ensures that nothing is published which damages "national security", a feeling, we are told, that Rimington shares.

National security, a nebulous concept at the best of times, covers a multitude of sins. A taste of how Whitehall mandarins interpret it is depicted in the archives on the expurgation of the memoirs of Sir Percy Sillitoe, one of Dame Stella's predecessors.

The mere act of her writing her memoirs might present Rimington in a favourable light. After all, it may be argued by some enthusiasts, better something than nothing. Surely there must be some illuminating insights into the life and work of MI5? There may be. But her memoirs, if they do see print, will by definition be sanitised, approved in secret by a coterie of Whitehall insiders dedicated to suppressing the truth. Is she going to be allowed to, does she even want to, reveal what MI5 was up to during the 1984-5 miners' strike, or in Northern Ireland, or spying on so-called "subversives"? Hardly.

Under New Labour as in the past, just how the secret police (MI5's footsoldiers) treat those others who want to tell the real truth, has been more than amply demonstrated.

Tony Geraghty last year became the first journalist to be charged under the Official Secrets Act. His alleged crime was to have written a book in which he reveals the extent of the army's surveillance operations and MI5 dirty tricks in Northern Ireland. He describes in The Irish War how army computer systems "provide total cover of a largely innocent population". Charges against Geraghty have been dropped but one of his alleged contacts, Colonel Nigel Wylde, still faces the prospect of a criminal trial.

Martin Ingram, the pseudonym of a former member of the army's force research unit, a clandestine cell set up to handle informants in the IRA and loyalist paramilitary groups in Northern Ireland, has revealed, among other things, how an arson attack was mounted on offices outside Belfast occupied by Sir John Stevens, now the Metropolitan police commissioner, when he was investigating allegations of collusion between loyalists and members of the security forces in 1990. Fire broke out hours before he planned to arrest Brian Nelson, paid by the army while also acting as intelligence officer for the Ulster Defence Association, and implicated in the unresolved murder of Catholic solicitor Pat Finucane.

Ingram also claims that at least one soldier was killed because army handlers of an IRA quartermaster in Londonderry refused to sabotage weapons, fearing it would compromise him. The IRA later discovered his double life, and murdered him. A man accused of being Ingram has been arrested under the Official Secrets Act, his house has been burgled and a manuscript of a book he was writing went missing. The manuscript turned up a few days later in the hands of the prosecution at a court hearing, when government lawyers obtained an injunction preventing him from publishing his book.

The Ministry of Defence has also obtained an injunction preventing the Sunday Times from publishing his information. Liam Clarke, the newspaper's Northern Ireland editor, now faces the prospect of being arrested under the Official Secrets Act. He has been summoned by the police special branch and advised to bring a lawyer with him. The police want to question him, not about the truth behind the allegations of wrongdoing by army intelligence officers, but for revealing the allegations.

Ingram, meanwhile, wants to give evidence to the Bloody Sunday inquiry, challenging the army's version of events, notably that they possessed no intelligence about the tactics of the civil rights marchers. The inquiry has so far refused to give him the assurances he wants - to give evidence anonymously (something the courts have allowed the paratroopers involved in the shootings) and immunity from prosecution under the Official Secrets Act.

Meanwhile, the editors of the Guardian and the Observer face potential charges of contempt of court for refusing to hand over any emails or notes they may have relating to the renegade MI5 officer, David Shayler. The Observer journalist, Martin Bright, faces charges under the Official Secrets Act for talking to Shayler, a sin which applies to many others. Though some ministers have expressed their horror at the secret police going after newspapers in this way and MI5 has distanced itself from the action of special branch officers, government lawyers say they intend to oppose the newspapers' court challenge next week to an Old Bailey judge's ruling that they must hand over any Shayler material.

Some of Shayler's claims, notably that MI6 was involved with plotters who carried out a failed assassination attack on the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy, are backed up by MI5 documents posted on the internet. Shayler himself faces secrets charges if he returns to London.

Richard Tomlinson, the former MI6 officer was also sentenced to a year in prison for sending a book synopsis to an Australian publisher. MI6 are now hounding him across Europe, but have not, in fact, succeeded in preventing him from finding a Russian publisher for a new book he has written.

In any mature political culture, the public, and not least MPs, would be allowed to know what past antics the security and intelligence agencies have engaged in. More openness would have prevented former agents and SAS soldiers from being offered huge advances for disclosing information which should not have been secret in the first place, as when revelations about SAS operations by the Gulf war commander, General Sir Peter de la Billière, prompted a spate of books about the exploits of Britain's special forces.

If Dame Stella really is determined to push the boat out, she could yet promote a constructive debate on what is "necessary in a democracy" - the test applied by the European human rights convention which will be part of English law in October. But we should not bet on it.

Could it be that ministers themselves leaked Rimington's intentions to publish her memoirs to make the point that they are less than pleased with an initiative that smacks of rank hypocrisy?

Is she going to be allowed to, does she even want to, reveal what MI5 was up to during the 1984-5 miners' strike, or in Northern Ireland, or spying on so-called "subversives"? Hardly. Under New Labour as in the past, just how the secret police (MI5's footsoldiers) treat those others who want to tell the real truth, has been more than amply demonstrated. Tony Geraghty last year became the first journalist to be charged under the Official Secrets Act. His alleged crime was to have written a book in which he reveals the extent of the army's surveillance operations and MI5 dirty tricks in Northern Ireland. He describes in The Irish War how army computer systems "provide total cover of a largely innocent population". Charges against Geraghty have been dropped but one of his alleged contacts, Colonel Nigel Wylde, still faces the prospect of a criminal trial. Martin Ingram, the pseudonym of a former member of the army's force research unit, a clandestine cell set up to handle informants in the IRA and loyalist paramilitary groups in Northern Ireland, has revealed, among other things, how an arson attack was mounted on offices outside Belfast occupied by Sir John Stevens, now the Metropolitan police commissioner, when he was investigating allegations of collusion between loyalists and members of the security forces in 1990. Fire broke out hours before he planned to arrest Brian Nelson, paid by the army while also acting as intelligence officer for the Ulster Defence Association, and implicated in the unresolved murder of Catholic solicitor Pat Finucane. Ingram also claims that at least one soldier was killed because army handlers of an IRA quartermaster in Londonderry refused to sabotage weapons, fearing it would compromise him. The IRA later discovered his double life, and murdered him. A man accused of being Ingram has been arrested under the Official Secrets Act, his house has been burgled and a manuscript of a book he was writing went missing. The manuscript turned up a few days later in the hands of the prosecution at a court hearing, when government lawyers obtained an injunction preventing him from publishing his book. The Ministry of Defence has also obtained an injunction preventing the Sunday Times from publishing his information. Liam Clarke, the newspaper's Northern Ireland editor, now faces the prospect of being arrested under the Official Secrets Act. He has been summoned by the police special branch and advised to bring a lawyer with him. The police want to question him, not about the truth behind the allegations of wrongdoing by army intelligence officers, but for revealing the allegations. Ingram, meanwhile, wants to give evidence to the Bloody Sunday inquiry, challenging the army's version of events, notably that they possessed no intelligence about the tactics of the civil rights marchers. The inquiry has so far refused to give him the assurances he wants - to give evidence anonymously (something the courts have allowed the paratroopers involved in the shootings) and immunity from prosecution under the Official Secrets Act. Meanwhile, the editors of the Guardian and the Observer face potential charges of contempt of court for refusing to hand over any emails or notes they may have relating to the renegade MI5 officer, David Shayler. The Observer journalist, Martin Bright, faces charges under the Official Secrets Act for talking to Shayler, a sin which applies to many others. Though some ministers have expressed their horror at the secret police going after newspapers in this way and MI5 has distanced itself from the action of special branch officers, government lawyers say they intend to oppose the newspapers' court challenge next week to an Old Bailey judge's ruling that they must hand over any Shayler material. Some of Shayler's claims, notably that MI6 was involved with plotters who carried out a failed assassination attack on the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy, are backed up by MI5 documents posted on the internet. Shayler himself faces secrets charges if he returns to London. Richard Tomlinson, the former MI6 officer was also sentenced to a year in prison for sending a book synopsis to an Australian publisher. MI6 are now hounding him across Europe, but have not, in fact, succeeded in preventing him from finding a Russian publisher for a new book he has written. In any mature political culture, the public, and not least MPs, would be allowed to know what past antics the security and intelligence agencies have engaged in. More openness would have prevented former agents and SAS soldiers from being offered huge advances for disclosing information which should not have been secret in the first place, as when revelations about SAS operations by the Gulf war commander, General Sir Peter de la Billière, prompted a spate of books about the exploits of Britain's special forces. If Dame Stella really is determined to push the boat out, she could yet promote a constructive debate on what is "necessary in a democracy" - the test applied by the European human rights convention which will be part of English law in October. But we should not bet on it. Could it be that ministers themselves leaked Rimington's intentions to publish her memoirs to make the point that they are less than pleased with an initiative that smacks of rank hypocrisy? richard norton-taylor@theguardian.com Links MI5 David Shayler's website

fields.headline: Second sight
fields.standfirst:
It's time to 
use technology 
to revolutionise the way the  NHS works, says the former head 
of BT's inland operations
fields.trailText: It's time to use technology to revolutionise the way the NHS works, says the former head of BT's inland operations
fields.body:
The combination of text and video over handheld phones, video over BT's latest broadband wire technology (ADSL) and systematic application of computing and IT has a key part to play in modernising the grass roots of the NHS and upgrading health services for the disadvantaged and the housebound.

Today I and a group of my former senior BT colleagues are holding a demonstration in London in which we shall show that between them these technologies can work a minor revolution in local health services, dramatically cutting delay in treatment, saving money and improving the quality of care. This revolution could be complete by 2003.

We are presenting the results of a year's study of future communications for Nelson and West Merton NHS Primary Care Trust and its patients in Wimbledon, London. Primary care trusts and groups are a key building block in the government's strategy for modernising the NHS, and replace the Conservatives' GP fundholder arrangements. Each one groups 20 or so general practitioner practices into a unified management unit, with its own chief executive and spending budget. We need them to succeed, and the marriage of IT and advanced communications will be vital for this.

At the core of our demonstration are four scenarios, devised with the help of practising doctors, which show how two-way video through the air and by wire, plus advanced IT, could be used to help patients in the surgery and in the home.

In the most dramatic of these, Ann Shurrock, who is totally paralysed in real life, will act the part of a multiple sclerosis patient with a life-threatening kidney infection. She is dealt with in a matter of hours wholly in her home, with text and video over handheld technology playing a key part. In another Julie Paul, who acted in the original Avengers, will play a patient with a positive smear test for cancer who is examined and reassured online by a consultant at her local hospital while she is still only on her first visit to her GP's surgery, using video images sent over a broadband wire technology like ADSL, which is now being introduced by BT across the country.

The other two demonstrations will show an NHS Direct nurse using video over handheld to make a firm diagnosis and recommend treatment for a minor skin condition for an elderly patient at home, and video over wire being used for online training of health trust managerial staff. Despite all the hype, the telecoms industry has seemed in recent years to be remarkably ineffective at devising new services of its own.

It wasted several years in a search for a "killer" application for broadband to justify putting optical fibre through to the home - an effort which got nowhere. In the end it was computing which, through the internet and the web, made the breakthrough to new applications which needed broadband.

The logical next step for telecoms after public voice and data service was full quality public videophone. The technology is at last there to create this (it would make a big difference to the traffic problem by offering a viable alternative to physical travel) but there is no sign of it happening.

To try to crack this hang-up, we decided to use actors to test out new service ideas in simulated real life situations. Hammering out the scripts for them with the professional users concerned, like the doctors in the present case, turns out to be the key. It forces you to think out the working of your idea in concrete detail.

We have already used the technique with judges and solicitors to try out online civil law services: they loved it. The technique could be used to develop all kinds of new services. I think it is a breakthrough.

The demonstration will include a talk by Ian Ayres, chief executive of the Nelson Trust. He says that "one has only to walk into a local surgery to see that the building has been built round a series of paper-based nodes surrounded by a series of consulting rooms".

"The challenge," says Ayres, "is to move from that to an environment where clinicians have magically in their hand the information they need to see and treat a patient at wherever might be the appropriate location and at whatever time."

We believe that NHS GP practices and the community health services will grind to a halt within a few years unless they face and master Ian Ayres's challenge. Between them handheld radio, wire broadband and modern IT are providing the technology to make this possible. All that is needed now is the management will.

 Seaford Head Advisers' demonstration takes place today at the National Liberal Club, London, at 2.30pm.

fields.headline: Operation dessert storm
fields.standfirst: Take one raw dot.com business, grill for four hours, reposition and serve with lashings of Hot Custard. Justin Hunt reports on the agencies promising a recipe for internet success
fields.trailText: Take one raw dot.com business, grill for four hours, reposition and serve with lashings of Hot Custard. Justin Hunt reports on the agencies promising a recipe for internet success
fields.body:
If you are a struggling dot.com and you cannot understand why your site is not attracting huge amounts of traffic, you might need a dollop of custard.

As internet fever cools and investors become increasingly sceptical about sinking their hard-earned cash into the net, a new agency called Hot Custard has launched offering dot.coms an online rescue service.

Set up by former Marks & Spencer retail marketeer Jan Selfridge and ex-creative director of Abbott Mead and Vickers Ian Standing, Hotcustard.com hopes to fix everything from marketing and technology problems to any e-fulfilment difficulties.

So why the off-the-wall name? "You can pour custard on anything and you can make it better," quips Selfridge, who knows that in a crowded agency marketplace the name will be hard for budding net entrepreneurs to forget.

Convinced that too many web sites lack a coherent strategy, she claims Hot Custard's hard-nosed approach is attracting a lot of interest from floundering dot.coms. "It's not about the number of whizzy devices you can put on a screen, it's about having a purpose for being on the web and devising a strategy to drive people to your site. "There are an awful lot of dot.coms who have got a good idea but have not executed it from a marketing perspective. Unless your site appeals to the people you are aiming at, it's not going to work."

Hot Custard offers sickly web sites an e-doctor service and currently one of the most common complaints is falling traffic. In finding a cure, the Hot Custard team will assess the functionality of the site, its ease of use, and how people get to it from other destinations on the web.

Both Selfridge and Standing have strong backgrounds in creative advertising and they are pretty scathing about the calibre of recent dot.com campaigns. Selfridge says that dot.coms have been over-ambitious in their advertising and have strayed from relaying the key simple messages. "What they have to offer often gets lost in off-the-wall executions," he adds.

It is often bewildering for internet businesses to know where to go for reliable advice if they are in trouble, and if they are not careful the risks are they can be fleeced by an unscrupulous operator.

Jon Bains, chairman of new media agency Lateral claims dot.coms generally expect too much from agencies. "If agencies could solve all dot.com problems they wouldn't be agencies. The reason why most people work in agencies is because they do not have the level of focus or expertise you need to run a successful internet company."

Lateral handles new media strategies and marketing for high-profile clients such as Stella Artois and is currently creating sites for the new Harry Potter book and Nick Park's forthcoming film, Chicken Run. Bains maintains there is a tendency to treat dot.coms generically when in reality the problems they individually encounter can be fundamentally different.

Typical problems Lateral has come across include having to find and coordinate 27 different distributors in Europe and trying to set up and manage specialist multi-lingual customer support for online sales of wine and sexy lingerie. Management consultancies are often the fall-back for serious dot.com players. Nick Greenspan has successfully set up Bainlab, the internet incubator service which is part of management consultancy Bain&Co, and he is acutely aware of the pitfalls new agencies such as Hot Custard are trying to remedy.

"Dot.coms can encounter a raft of difficulties. The biggest positive problem is that their systems are not robust enough to survive the growth of their business." Not putting in place proper customer fulfilment processes and failing to accurately anticipate the costs of acquiring customers are other common troubles.

Sites are often not laid out in the way consumers want at the outset and have to be re-arranged, which is complicated and costly. The bill for re-designing a portal can run to hundreds of thousands of pounds. Hot Custard hopes to succeed by cleverly exploiting a niche in the market. But other new media agencies warn that they will find it extremely frustrating dealing with dot.coms. Lateral insists that new internet companies pitch to them first before they will consider working for them. Bains says: "My confidence in dot.coms has been quite battered in the past by dealing with people who don't have a clue. They have a half-baked idea and they expect you to sort it out."

He complains that internet entrepreneurs often get so gripped by an idea that they fail to think it through and do not prepare properly. So eventually they find they cannot distribute what they hoped to or are unable to get around the regulations of a particular country.

Getting an internet business off the ground is hugely demanding, both physically and emotionally, and it is clearly sensible to hire independent quality advice to support any new e-venture. The editor of New Media Age, Mike Butcher, says it can be difficult for the serious dot.com players to get help because of a growing mood of scepticism in the market which has been generated by some flaky online business-to-consumer propositions. He says: "If there are any serious players who are in dire straits either they did not get enough funding or the right people."

While Hot Custard undoubtedly sounds soothing, warm and nice. Its sudden appearance on the virtual table is a clear indication that a cold and unforgiving shake-out is starting. Those internet entrepreneurs who rushed onto the web, borrowing more than they could afford with ill-thought out business plans, look set to receive their just desserts.

webTitle: Straw pledges cash to boost recruitment

fields.headline: Straw pledges cash to boost recruitment
fields.trailText: New money for 1,000 extra police recruits over the next 12 months was announced yesterday by the home secretary, Jack Straw, in an attempt to take the sting out of the growing political battle over law and order.
fields.body:
New money for 1,000 extra police recruits over the next 12 months was announced yesterday by the home secretary, Jack Straw, in an attempt to take the sting out of the growing political battle over law and order.

Mr Straw faced renewed criticism yesterday over police numbers and resources from the Police Federation, which claimed that Britain's rank and file officers were facing "a crisis of self confidence, of no cash and of no colleagues".

In a speech to the federation's annual conference in Brighton, the home secretary denied there was a crisis but said he was willing to talk about the problems and the demands for a royal commission.

William Hague, the Conservative Party leader, will this morning try to add to the pressure on Mr Straw when he presents, to the same police audience, his party's anti-crime policy, including the plan to abolish "double jeopardy".

Yesterday, Mr Straw rejected talk of inner city no-go areas because of a lack of police, and told federation members he wanted to work with them to tackle the problems. "Honest assessment reveals a mixed picture. Some types of crime are falling. Others are rising. Some areas do much better than others. But I recognise that resources, numbers and pay are vital," he said.

He announced that he was, for the second time, accelerating plans for forces to recruit 5,000 more officers over the next two years. The amount of new money available this year for recruitment would rise from £35m to £59m, so that a maximum of 3,000 extra police could be recruited.

The decision to step up recruitment again will leave the police service near its maximum training capacity and it will have to mount a special campaign this summer to fill the jobs. "In all, the service will be planning to recruit and train about 7,000 this year and 6,000 next - this should mean that the total numbers of police officers will be around 126,500 in March 2001, and 127,000 in March 2002," said Mr Straw.

The home secretary's announcement came after Fred Broughton, chairman of the Police Federation, had told him that police numbers were inadequate for meeting the mounting commitments facing the police.

fields.headline: Karl Shapiro
fields.standfirst: Paradox of the man of passion who, as a wartime serviceman, found the serenity to write good poetry
fields.trailText: At the age of 86, the poet and critic Karl Shapiro is definitely dead. He would appreciate the adverb, for he was was often assumed to be one of those - Sylvia Plath, Randall Jarrall - who had opted for suicide in the 1960s.
fields.body:
At the age of 86, the poet and critic Karl Shapiro is definitely dead. He would appreciate the adverb, for he was was often assumed to be one of those - Sylvia Plath, Randall Jarrall - who had opted for suicide in the 1960s.

That had its origins in an article by a disgruntled graduate student; at first, he ignored it, but it gained currency and he took out a lawsuit on the grounds of malice - but shied from pursuing it when he studied the document and the absurdity of his distress being worth a cool million. Had he taken the loot, the publicity might have forestalled the occasion when he was stumped by the New York Times crossword and the clue "dead American poet" - until the adjacent words made these seven letters the inevitable Shapiro.

Poetry was the stuff of life itself for Shapiro. Palpably so. In bed with a woman not his wife, "he was on the rise, pushing away at her with her legs over his shoulders, when she said to him in a calm voice, 'Allen Ginsberg says you can't write for shit.' His erection immediately shrank and his penis fell out." Such was Shapiro's generosity that he had encouraged Ginsberg, but of the century's poets it was WH Auden that he revered.

Born in Baltimore, the son of a travelling salesman, he was acutely aware of being in the shadow of a brother to whom he was close and also of an American melting pot which ranked "Jews as a cut above Negroes but not much". Shapiro, with what he called an irrational fear of those Jews who sported long black coats and broad-brimmed black hats, was himself more attuned to that cast of mind in which everyone "was engaged in a game of discontinuity, the loosening of ties, the cultivation of forgetfulness... the ones who prided themselves on continuity were to be feared or laughed at - Americans with coats-of-arms!" Even so, he turned Carl into the tonier Karl when he was an adult.

When he was six, the family moved to Chicago, returning to his birthplace a decade later. Early on, he delighted in the sets of classic authors collected by his father, simultaneously finding relish in women's ankles, later asserting that their inner thighs were "the most exquisite curve in the universe". Which makes it surprising that Gerard Manley Hopkins's poetry was to be his "guide for life". Shapiro knew that he himself was not homosexual "and eventually felt the cruder for it".

As an adolescent he sported an unread copy of Immanuel Kant's The Critique Of Pure Reason. Unemployed, he wrote tragedies in iambic pentameter. There were consolations. Always referring to himself in the third person with that involved detachment which also characterises his best poems, he recalled the widow who "seduced him, and that was not what he wanted. He wanted the daughter. That was not quite it, either; he wanted culture, with the daughter thrown in for good measure perhaps."

Such was the pattern of his life. He now discovered Auden and, as his father had made money by selling oil in cans, Shapiro could publish a volume of his own poems: he gave away copies, reviewed it under a pseudonym - and later regretted the whole endeavour, but that did not prevent a microfilm edition in the 1960s by a firm "in England, wherever High Wycombe was".

Auden said that poetry does not make anything happen, but this volume got Shapiro into university - and a letter from William Carlos Williams. But he could not study. At the University of Virginia, preoccupied with his own writing, he became a rare drop-out. It left him with a taste for classical music - and, needs must, two years of touring the country to sell samples, which led to relationships along the way, including one in which they "pushed tearfully and willingly, she in the direction of marriage, and he in the direction of himself".

His father then left, with which Shapiro, his mother, sister and a schoolmistress went to California - he and the schoolmistress duly absconding on a boat to Tahiti, which only brought him a craving to be in Atlantic City. He did not know quite why, but it was partly a desire for education and for the schoolmistress's sister, who, to his chagrin, duly locked one of his plays in a trunk.

In a vivid piece of analysis, he recalled leaving another girl's bed before her father returned and, on the walk home, saw an automobile smash. The grim event gave him new metrical insight as he fashioned an opening line about an ambulance "its quick soft silver bell beating, beating". (He is always excellent on metrical matters, "a thing of second nature".)

He had a night job at Sears-Roebuck, to fund his studies at Johns Hopkins University, where he recalled sex with almost as much relish as his enjoyment of Milton and Rupert Brooke. Across an examination paper a don wrote, "too bitter against big business". He lost his scholarship. Sad and relieved to leave the place, he joined Baltimore's Enoch Pratt Library School, but all the while war threatened and in March 1941 he was summoned to the United States army.

"In the army one could be a poet without anybody knowing it." Poetry was the stuff of life itself for Shapiro. Palpably so. In bed with a woman not his wife, "he was on the rise, pushing away at her with her legs over his shoulders, when she said to him in a calm voice, 'Allen Ginsberg says you can't write for shit.' Shapiro, with what he called an irrational fear of those Jews who sported long black coats and broad-brimmed black hats, was himself more attuned to that cast of mind in which everyone "was engaged in a game of discontinuity, the loosening of ties, the cultivation of forgetfulness... the ones who prided themselves on continuity were to be feared or laughed at - Americans with coats-of-arms!" fields.headline: Barry MacSweeney
fields.standfirst: Tyneside poet who lived out the myth of exemplary failure
fields.trailText: Barry MacSweeney, who has died aged 51, had a varied and brilliant poetic career. He was unabashed in his pursuit of poetry as a high and illustrious vocation, never treating his calling lightly, although he damaged his own life and some others.
fields.body:
Barry MacSweeney, who has died aged 51, had a varied and brilliant poetic career. He was unabashed in his pursuit of poetry as a high and illustrious vocation, never treating his calling lightly, although he damaged his own life and some others. There was no element of posture in his make-up; his fantasy went into his poetry, where life encountered art to be articulated as a series of imagined voices.

MacSweeney was born in Newcastle upon Tyne and educated at Rutherford Grammar School. After O-levels he joined the Newcastle Evening Chronicle, went on Harlow technical college's journalism course and subsequently worked on Westminster Press local newspapers. This included a long stint on the Kentish Times, and he was finally deputy editor of the South Shields Gazette, to which he contributed the column Mouth Of The Tyne. He contracted the journalist's industrial illness, alcohol dependency, the struggle with this losing him (temporarily) his ability to write poetry, his job and eventually, despite support from the Royal Literary Fund and the Society of Authors while in detox at Farm Place, his life.

Newcastle in the mid-1960s was a good place for a young poet: Basil Bunting was at the Chronicle, receiving overdue recognition as England's major modernist poet; his protégé Tom Pickard ran an eclectic series of readings at the Morden Tower, on the circuit for any visiting American poets; Jon Silkin moved from Leeds, bringing with him the long-established magazine Stand. This ambience, including a thriving youth culture, was self-consciously local, either to the city or the region and the north-east - both the moorland landscape around Allendale and its derelict industrial sites and communities inadequately redeveloped - remained a constant frame of reference for MacSweeney.

He was not inward-looking, however, and made contact with a network of young poets grouped around the English Intelligencer, and the milieu of little magazines and small presses that then opened up to him, where his own imprint Blacksuede Boot Press had a distinguished part to play in the rediscovery of the 1940s poet Nicholas Moore.

He also came to the attention of Michael Dempsey, editor of Hutchinson's New Authors imprint, who published his first book, The Boy From The Green Cabaret Tells Of His Mother (1968). This was an ill-conceived at tempt to launch MacSweeney as a 1960s counter-culture personality, with maximum publicity: he was mentioned in Vogue and nominated for Oxford University's chair of poetry. None of this can have done MacSweeney much good, but I doubt that it did him any harm, for he was a poet of quite different mettle.

His notion of the artist was formed around a myth of exemplary failure and belated recognition: Rimbaud was an early model for this, others included Chatterton, Shelley, Van Gogh, Jim Morrison and Robert Johnson. Such identifications were the basis for a poetics of direct utterance in which MacSweeney's voice mixed with others to inveigh, to celebrate or entreat. More than he detested the destruction of communities witnessed in the last two decades, he loathed its impact on individual lives, whose vulnerability he already understood. Posited against social and personal crisis were exalted recollections of a natural world of plants, creatures and the elements. What carried this through as poetry was verbal flair raised to the highest level, enabling him to manoeuvre from tact to excess, from the elevated to the plain, with the confidence of an adept.

MacSweeney was prolific, publishing more than two dozen titles between 1968 and 1999. Particularly notable were The Last Bud (1969), Brother Wolf (1972), Odes (1978) and the selection included in The Tempers Of Hazard (1993) which, to his distress, was pulped by Paladin in the year of publication. Pearl (1995), a work of redemptive pathos, evoking the figure of a childhood sweetheart as a presence in nature, on the confines of social existence, was reprinted with The Book Of Demons (Bloodaxe, 1997), his most substantial recent collection, where he projects himself as maimed and abject, hapless yet percipient victim of the demon drink, in writing that is both comic and terrifying.

It would be unfortunate if this final self-identification became his own myth, for although here he foresaw, correctly as it happened, the manner of his own death:

    One day choke on it, tongue
    jammed backwards down
    throat's clogged highway
the poet he might have survived to become, discovering fresh instigations to rage or rapture in old age, remains far from unthinkable.

He married twice.

webTitle: Marines defy the elements to reach north pole unsupported

fields.headline: Marines defy the elements to reach north pole unsupported
fields.trailText: After overcoming whiteout blizzards, cracking ice and near starvation - and initially walking past their intended destination - two royal marines yesterday became the first Britons to walk unsupported to the north pole.
fields.body:
After overcoming whiteout blizzards, cracking ice and near starvation - and initially walking past their intended destination - two royal marines yesterday became the first Britons to walk unsupported to the north pole.

Fuelled in the final stages of their journey by a daily ration of two pieces of chocolate and a half cup of porridge, Charlie Paton, from Aberdeen, and Alan Chambers, from Scunthorpe, reached the top of the world with only moments to spare on a trek that started on March 9.

As their emergency food supplies ran out and ice cracked on Tuesday, there was increasing concern at their base camp in northern Canada.

It was decided they had until yesterday to complete their 700-mile trek or else the expedition would be aborted and they would be airlifted out.

But, at 1.47am UK time, colleagues monitoring satellite navigation systems at the base camp watched as the pair finally made it to the north pole. "We actually walked past it to start off with and went across to the Siberian side and then back-tracked. We just fell on our knees and took some photos of the global positioning satellite. It read 8959593 geographic north pole, top of the world," Corporal Chambers told Sky News.

For their final 40 days the pair were forced to survive in sub-zero conditions on only 29 days worth of rations and they have each lost around three stones in weight.

Only three other teams have reached the north pole unsupported and the two royal marines who survived the journey - from an original band of four - endured considerable hardship to notch their place in history. After 16 weeks training, the marines set up base camp in Resolute Bay, the most northerly settlement in arctic Canada.

On March 9, they were air lifted to Ward Hunt Island; and their journey began in earnest. Pulling sledges laden with 250lb of equipment, the four set out.

Half way through the journey, two of the marines developed severe frostbite and had to be airlifted to safety. Although Marine Paton had twice fallen through the ice, he managed to continue on the expedition with Cpl Chambers. Things went slowly but assuredly, and they looked set to reach the north pole on schedule last weekend.

But, with less than 60 miles to go, the ice ahead of them cracked. In a whiteout blizzard, they were forced to walk for two days to find a way round the open water.

Their achievement yesterday earned the praise of their patron, the first sea lord, Admiral Sir Michael Boyce. "I am immensely proud of them and wish them a safe and speedy recovery to Resolute Bay and then home to their loved ones," he said.

fields.headline: Anger over court's floral fine
fields.trailText: Women's groups yesterday criticised a magistrate who earlier in the day ordered a man to spend £10 on flowers and chocolates for his girlfriend as compensation for punching her in the face.
fields.body:
Women's groups yesterday criticised a magistrate who earlier in the day ordered a man to spend £10 on flowers and chocolates for his girlfriend as compensation for punching her in the face.

The magistrate told David Tucker, 47, to buy the gifts after he admitted striking his girlfriend during a row, leaving Sheena Robinson, 31, with facial bruising. He pleaded guilty to common assault and was given a year's conditional discharge by Exeter magistrates' court.

The chairman of the bench, Peter Gove, then told Tucker: "As the prosecution has made no application for costs, I order that you buy the lady a box of chocolates and bouquet of flowers of not less than £10 in value."

Ms Robinson, a pub landlady, said of the magistrates' decision: "There is no way it is any kind of recompense for what I went through."

Julie Bindel, of Justice for Women, said: "This woman wants justice, not chocolates and flowers. How dare he suggest this. The sentence the man was given sends out a terrible message to society."

Tucker's solicitor, Vanessa Francis, said a domestic dispute had "got out of hand" and her client regretted hitting his girlfriend. Their relationship was "still up in the air".

Speaking after the case, Mr Gove, 61, said his comments had been "only a suggestion", adding: "We do our best to rectify situations and in this case both parties wanted to get back together but Mr Tucker couldn't because of a condition of his police bail."

fields.headline: Niels Viggo Bentzon
fields.standfirst: Mercurial Danish composer of more than 1,000 works
fields.trailText: Niels Viggo Bentzon, who has died aged 80, was a prodigiously gifted poet, painter, pianist, critic and teacher and the composer of over 1,000 musical works. Bentzon was the youngest and most mercurial member of the triumvirate of composers (with Vagn Holmboe and Herman D Koppel) that dominated Danish music in the two decades following the second world war.
fields.body:
Niels Viggo Bentzon, who has died aged 80, was a prodigiously gifted poet, painter, pianist, critic and teacher and the composer of over 1,000 musical works. Bentzon was the youngest and most mercurial member of the triumvirate of composers (with Vagn Holmboe and Herman D Koppel) that dominated Danish music in the two decades following the second world war.

Although his last published work, the guitar solo Strumenta diabolico, premiered in February 1999, bore the high opus number 664, his actual tally of compositions was far greater since many opus numbers comprised sets of three or more works; each of his 13 volumes of The Tempered Klavier run to 24 Preludes and Fugues, which can be played separately.

Bentzon composed music in every known classical form, including four operas (one left unfinished in 1970), 24 symphonies, a Sinfonia da camera and a large number of other orchestral works, including the magnificent Symphonic Variations (1953). He wrote over two dozen concertos, including eight for his own instrument, the piano, five for violin, three for cello, and others for standard orchestral instruments, even accordion ensemble.

Bentzon was born into a highly cultured and musical family in Copenhagen, and one of his cousins was the noted composer Jørgen Bentzon. In 1938, after studies in jazz piano with Leo Mathiesen, Bentzon entered the Copenhagen conservatory studying piano and organ, graduating in 1942 with the conservatory's highest marks. From 1945-49 he taught piano and theory at the Aarhus conservatory, and from 1950 taught composition at the Copenhagen conservatory.

As with his hero, Paul Hindemith (on whom Bentzon published a study in 1997), he composed at least one sonata (with piano accompaniment) for each orchestral instrument, extending the series to include the entire saxophone family. His chamber output included 18 string quartets ; trios, quartets and quintets for varying combinations, such as three quartets for four flutes, as well as his celebrated 1948 Chamber Concerto for 11 instruments - including three pianos - recorded in the 1960s.

Bentzon first made his name as a composer in Denmark in 1943 with his Toccata, Op 10, for piano. But it was in 1947 that he burst on to the international scene when his Partita, Op 38, was played at the ISCM festival. In all he composed two dozen piano sonatas and a host of other pieces, many of which, such as Wood-cuts (1951), enjoyed wide currency. Bentzon made many recordings of his work over the years, including his entire Tempered Klavier (1964-96), the first volume of which was written for his son, Nicolaj, who helped premiere his father's For Six Hands at the composer's 80th birthday concert last year.

Bentzon's was a constantly questing and exploratory spirit. He tried his hand at every music genre and style, from jazz (an early, but lifelong, enthusiasm), to 12-note music (on which he published a book in 1953), to neo-classicism, the style in which most of his finest and best-known music was written in the 1940s and 1950s.

Although Nielsen, Brahms, Hindemith and Bartok formed his stylistic bedrock, in the mid-60s Bentzon's pieces such as the ensemble improvisation Third Stream Music, Bijouterie and Variable Music showed him tackling the "music of chance" espoused by John Cage and "happenings" of the avant-garde which resulted in an "audio-visual concert piece" in 1971.

Such an interest was not surprising given Bentzon's studies in jazz and organ-playing, both disciplines employing improvisatory techniques. Indeed, there was a fundamentally improvisational character to Bentzon's music, and although his least inspired works were simple note-spinning, his best rank among the finest post-war Nordic music.

He was a great communicator, and his enormous energies were not wholly devoted to composition and piano-playing. A noted critic, he wrote for the main Copenhagen daily, Politiken, and published several books, including one on piano technique (1953) and another on Beethoven (1970). He was also an avid painter, publishing monographs on Joseph Beuys (1979) and Aagaard Andersen, Wilhelm Freddie and Per Kirkeby (1988).

He wrote the texts of most of his vocal works, including his operas; poetry (Poets In A Charabanc, 1969) and surrealist short stories (The Dryworld, 1987). A second set of stories remained unfinished.

Bentzon gave his last concert in September 1999. He was married four times, the last in 1963 to Birthe Walbum, who survives him along with their son, Nicolaj and Birthe's son and daughter from her previous marriage, whom Bentzon adopted. A son by a previous marriage predeceased him.

webTitle: Patty Hearst defies judge's gag order

fields.headline: Patty Hearst defies judge's gag order
fields.trailText: Patty Hearst, the newspaper heiress kidnapped by urban guerrillas in California in 1974 and later jailed for participating with them in a bank robbery, could find herself back in court this week for contempt.
fields.body:
Patty Hearst, the newspaper heiress kidnapped by urban guerrillas in California in 1974 and later jailed for participating with them in a bank robbery, could find herself back in court this week for contempt.

Despite a gagging order, she has given an interview about the pending trial in August of a group member, Kathy Soliah (now Sarah Jane Olsen), captured last year after a quarter of a century on the run.

"I'm at the end of my rope," Ms Hearst, 46, told Talk magazine, which is partly owned by her family's firm, Hearst Communications. "I'm fed up to the eyeballs. It's not Kathy Soliah's trial. It has turned into my trial. And I'm not going to play dead any more."

Ms Hearst served two years in jail in the 1970s for her part in a bank robbery with the Symbionese Liberation Army before having her sentence commuted by President Jimmy Carter.

Ms Olsen, who had become a conventional middle class family woman and changed her name, was arrested in Minnesota last year and charged with plotting to kill Los Angeles police officers, under whose cars she was alleged to have placed bombs that failed to explode. Ms Hearst has been subpoenaed as a prosecution witness.

She said she remembered chatting with Ms Olsen before the SLA robbed a bank in Sacramento in which a woman was shot dead. Ms Hearst said another woman, Emily Harris, who has already served time, carried out the shooting. She said Ms Olsen and others funded "the revolution" by stealing wallets from health clubs and shoplifting.

Ms Olsen's lawyer plans to file a legal motion against Ms Hearst this week for violating a strict gagging order by the judge in the run-up to the trial.

Ms Hearst has also been angered by the "deathbed confession" in February by the radical sportswriter Jack Scott, who claimed that she staged her kidnapping. She described his claim as a "publicity stunt - Jack Scott's last clenched fist", made to help Ms Olsen.

fields.headline: Two charged for 1960s race bomb
fields.standfirst: Suspects surrender over Alabama atrocity that shocked even segregated South and spurred on civil rights struggle
fields.trailText: For nearly 40 years, Birmingham, Alabama, has lived with the restless phantoms of four black girls who were murdered in a church bombing by the Ku Klux Klan at the height of the civil rights struggle. Yesterday the city took a belated step towards putting those ghosts to rest when two of the bomb suspects were charged.
fields.body:
For nearly 40 years, Birmingham, Alabama, has lived with the restless phantoms of four black girls who were murdered in a church bombing by the Ku Klux Klan at the height of the civil rights struggle. Yesterday the city took a belated step towards putting those ghosts to rest when two of the bomb suspects were charged.

Thomas Blanton and Bobby Cherry, who surrendered to the Jefferson county sheriff's department yesterday, were members of the Cahaba Boys, a particularly vicious splinter group which believed that the mainstream KKK was not radical enough. The gang was suspected of a string of bombings of black businesses and the flogging of countless unfortunate black people as it rampaged across Birmingham in the early 1960s.

Gang members went looking for victims armed with foot-long chains, battery cables and baseball bats filled with lead. They singled out black travellers on public buses whom they judged to be sitting too close to white passengers.

But the bomb which exploded in the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church on September 15 1963, killing the four young girls as they prepared for a Sunday service, shocked a state inured to segregation and the klan's casual brutality. The atrocity began to turn the tide in southern white opinion and gave the civil rights movement fresh impetus.

"It was very shocking. It was a very dark hour, a dark period for the civil rights movement," said John Lewis, who was then a leader of the Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee, and is now a Georgia congressman. "We made a commitment that we would do whatever we could to continue the struggle to end discrimination and racial segregation, in the name of these little girls."

The Cahaba Boys (named after a sluggish Alabama river on whose banks the gang used to meet) immediately fell under suspicion, and FBI investigators soon reported to their boss, J Edgar Hoover, that it was "apparent" that the bombing was the work of at least four suspects: Robert Chambliss, Mr Cherry, Herman Cash and Mr Blanton. But even with testimony from klan informants and family members of the suspects, Hoover shelved the case on the grounds that it would not be upheld by an all-white southern jury.

The inquiry, however, was reopened in the 1970s when Chambliss, the gang's leader, was convicted of the murder. He died in prison in 1985. But investigators were sure other gang members were involved.

The horror of the crime ensured that it would not be forgotten. Survivors said that Denise Mcnair, 11, Cynthia Wesley, Carole Robertson and Addie Mae Collins, all 14, had just left Sunday school and were standing in front of a mirror, adjusting their white dresses and combing their hair, before the service.

The 11 sticks of dynamite planted in the church the night before killed them instantly and broke a stained glass window portraying Jesus surrounded by children. The blast knocked out Christ's face.

The funeral drew 8,000 people. In his eulogy, Martin Luther King said the girls were heroines of a holy crusade. A civil rights institute now stands opposite the church, which remains an icon of the movement.

The bombing is only one of a series of unsolved or partially solved racial killings being re-examined as a changing South finally summons up the courage to confront its ugly past.

In Mississippi, state prosecutors are examining FBI documents on the 1964 murders of three civil rights activists by klansmen who buried the bodies under a dam - a case portrayed in the film Mississippi Burning.

The FBI reopened the Birmingham church bombing case in 1997, focusing on the remaining members of the Cahaba Boys gang. By then, Cash had died.

Mr Cherry had moved to the backwoods of Texas, where he lived a reclusive life only a few hundred yards from his son Thomas, who voiced doubts about his innocence. The two have not talked to each other for more than a year.

Before his indictment yesterday for the 1963 bombing, Mr Cherry was out on bail after being jailed earlier this month for molesting his stepdaughter 29 years ago.

Mr Blanton, 61, worked as a sewer cleaner in the town of Fultondale for much of his life. His lawyer, David Luker, said he had not personally seen the charge but added: "Obviously, it's for murder". He said his client maintained his innocence, and the lawyer would be asking for the former klansman to be released on bail.

Penny Weaver, of the Southern Poverty Law Centre, said she hoped Mr Blanton's arrest would lead Birmingham one step closer to coming to terms with its past.

"A good portion of us are happy to feel that the perpetrators will come to justice, even if it is nearly 40 years later," she said yesterday.

webTitle: Milosevic closes down opposition press and TV

fields.headline: Milosevic closes down opposition press and TV
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Slobodan Milosevic's regime silenced the leading non-government television, print and radio media in a clampdown in Serbia yesterday that many viewed as a prelude to the imposition of martial law.
fields.body:
Slobodan Milosevic's regime silenced the leading non-government television, print and radio media in a clampdown in Serbia yesterday that many viewed as a prelude to the imposition of martial law.

Hundreds of armed police stormed the Belgrade headquarters of Studio B, the only opposition television station able to broadcast to a large part of the country.

Police also shut down the highest circulation newspaper in Yugoslavia, Blic, which sells 200,000 copies a day, Serbia's popular radio station B2-92, the student radio Indeks and another television and radio station, all of which were housed in the same building.

Leaders of Belgrade council, which is controlled by the opposition and owns Studio B, met diplomats from at least 11 countries soon after the shutdown. The mayor, Vojislav Mihajlovic, said the closure of the television station was "an assault on the very foundations of press freedom". A spokesman for the opposition Serbian Renewal Movement called it "the beginning of open dictatorship".

Opposition leaders called for a rally in Belgrade last night, which they said would be the first of many protests across the country against the Yugoslav president.

Last night a team alleged by Studio B chiefs to be linked to the state-owned Radio Television Serbia (RTS) were broadcasting from Studio B, airing news similar to that of RTS, viewed as the mouthpiece of the regime. The regime's latest move gives it an effective monopoly on countrywide broadcasting in the runup to local and federal elections due by the end of the year. The raid on Studio B came when only a skeleton staff was on duty, said its deputy manager, Danka Kojadinovic. "About 2am, several hundred policemen in plain clothes, some wearing masks, entered the premises [and] smashed their way into our offices," she said. Police later moved against the station's transmitter, on the city's outskirts.

"The government accuses us of violating state property and calling for a popular uprising," Mrs Kojadinovic said, calling the allegations "notorious lies".

"We are forbidden to enter the premises and to perform our jobs." She said she feared the crackdown could be a prelude to the introduction of a state of emergency or martial law before the elections.

During the day large crowds gathered outside the Studio B building and the city assembly, where opposition leaders met editors and directors from the media to discuss a response.

On the city's streets, people expressed dismay at the media clampdown. "It's terrible", said 40-year-old Dara Mihajlovic, an engineer. "The situation will simply get worse if Milosevic does not give up power. If he stays, this will be a catastrophe." But when asked if she would support a rally against the action, she said she had to go to work.

On a bench just up the road from the Studio B building, Jovan Smidling, 60, a telecommunications mechanic, was waiting for his daughter before he set off for the afternoon protest. "I came here when I heard what had happened," he said. "I think it's important, but it will make things happen much faster. The end will finally come."

A Serb refugee from Kosovo, Vladimir Kostic, 25, hurrying down the hill toward toward the studio, said: "This is the second time this has happened to me. I was in Pristina, working in multi-ethnic radio and the police came into our offices and shut our frequency down. So I came here to show support for my colleagues.

"This is what happened to Albanians for 10 years in Kosovo - and exactly the same thing is happening to the Serbs now.

"This is not an ethnic conflict any more. This is an internal conflict. And I don't know where to go. I'm a refugee in Belgrade, but I don't want to go to another country. I want to make this a decent place to live."

Other useful links:
Free B92 homepage

webTitle: Short labels EU the worst aid agency in the world

fields.headline: Short labels EU the worst aid agency in the world
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: European Union aid delivery is the "worst in the world", Britain's international development secretary, Clare Short, complained yesterday as Brussels detailed radical new plans to clean up its act.
fields.body:
European Union aid delivery is the "worst in the world", Britain's international development secretary, Clare Short, complained yesterday as Brussels detailed radical new plans to clean up its act.

Ms Short is famous for outspoken comments that are often characterised as "gaffes" but which are invariably delivered with genuine, if undiplomatic, passion.

Chris Patten, the EU's external relations commissioner, showed disarming candour in admitting that the union had an "appalling reputation". But he urged Ms Short to help raise more resources for his understaffed bureaucracy.

Mr Patten said the EU's $8.6bn (£5.65bn) aid effort was in urgent need of improvement but rejected criticism voiced by British Eurosceptics.

"It's not a question of fraud or incompetence," insisted the former Hong Kong governor and Conservative party chairman. "We have excellent staff but the fact is there aren't enough of them to do the job effectively."

Recent investigations of EU aid performance revealed an embarrassing catalogue of problems from central America to Tibet and the Gaza Strip - illustrating the ambitious reach of the world's largest aid donor.

Proposals unveiled by the commission include an office dubbed "Europe Aid", which would be a globally recognisable "brand name" to boost the EU's poor international reputation and increase efficiency and speed.

The long-awaited overhaul will also include the simplification of some 80 different regulations and 50 related management committees.

Mr Patten said a current backlog of unpaid commitments to aid recipients worldwide totalled $18.7bn. The average delay over the past five years for disbursements of payments was around four-and-a-half years. But Mediterranean countries wait around nine years before seeing any money.

"We cannot commit money we cannot spend," Mr Patten told a press conference. "It's dishonest and incompetent. What is the point of raining down commitments like confetti if you can't deliver on the ground? We don't have to work out how to get from A to Z. We have to work out how to get from A to B."

Ms Short welcomed the proposals but in a BBC Radio 4 interview suggested that the third of the UK aid budget currently spent through the EU would be better spent in the national programme, which she said was "effective".

She added: "Anyone who knows anything about development knows that the EU is the worst agency in the world, the most inefficient, the least poverty-focused, the slowest, flinging money around for political gestures rather than promoting real development."

Ms Short is famous for outspoken comments that are often characterised as "gaffes" but which are invariably delivered with genuine, if undiplomatic, passion. webTitle: Library gets archive of a century

fields.headline: Library gets archive of a century
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Six thousand recordings, taken across the UK and making up the world's largest oral history archive, were handed to the British Library by the BBC's director general, Greg Dyke, yesterday.
fields.body:
Six thousand recordings, taken across the UK and making up the world's largest oral history archive, were handed to the British Library by the BBC's director general, Greg Dyke, yesterday.

Forming a detailed record of the 20th century, the interviews - on life, love, food and the future - were gathered last year for a 16-week BBC radio series, The Century Speaks. Yesterday they arrived at the library's national sound achive where, via a juke box-style sound bank, visitors will be able to hear excerpts. Known as the Millennium Memory Bank, the recordings are the personal testimonies of people reminiscing about the past 100 years, providing an insight into how lives and communities have changed.

Mr Dyke said he was happy to be "the bearer of a great gift to the nation". He added: "The interviews breathe life into our social history ... a century of turbulence ... of shifting religious and personal values, of boom and bust, of transformed landscapes, of an increasingly diverse, mobile, secular society."

The archive is the largest in Europe and second in size only to the video holocaust project of the film director Steven Spielberg.

The recordings will be available to researchers when the archive catalogue goes online in the autumn. Mr Dyke said Radio 4 would also broadcast highlights from the archive.
