fields.headline: Game to Sir Humphrey
fields.standfirst: A historical precedent is revealed
fields.trailText: One previous head of MI5, Sir Percy Sillitoe, did succeed in publishing his memoirs, in 1955. But Public Record Office archives reveal why they are such a poor historical source.
fields.body:
One previous head of MI5, Sir Percy Sillitoe, did succeed in publishing his memoirs, in 1955. But Public Record Office archives reveal why they are such a poor historical source.

The former chief constable's style did not endear him to colleagues. He courted publicity, even holding a press conference about Klaus Fuchs, the British nuclear scientist and Soviet spy. In 1952, due to retire, Sillitoe asked permission of Sir Edward Bridges, head of the Civil Service, to publish.

He did not intend to produce a detailed account. Yet he argued that, since his position was "fairly well known", he would create an "anti-climax" if he said nothing about MI5. His intended solution was to write a general piece of anti-communist propaganda with chapters on "The Cold War"; "Russia's direction of World Communism, her strategy and tactics"; "Spies"; "The Western defence dystem" and "The British concept of security".

Sir Edward minuted: "My doubts are in part instinctive, and are a good deal stronger than perhaps I can justify by a process of logical reasoning ... I suspect we shall find many passages to which we cannot raise serious objection but which would leave us all vaguely uncomfortable and wishing they were not there." His Home Office colleague, Sir Frank Newsam, chimed in: "I was indeed brought up in the tradition that the existence of MI5 should never be mentioned save in the highest of circles."

Sir Edward, Sir Frank, Sir William Strang from the Foreign Office and the cabinet secretary, Norman Brook, all conferred. Sir Edward recommended that home secretary David Maxwell-Fyfe should refuse authority "for anything to be included by Sir P Sillitoe in his autobiography about MI5". Only Brook dissented: "We are long past the time when we can hope that the head of the Security Service will remain anonymous ... Our objections are old fashioned." Maxwell-Fyfe ruled that Sillitoe could "end ... his book by stating that in 1946 he was appointed head of the Security Service and giving a very brief explanation of the service ... discussing in broad outline cases offending against security but using for his material only such information as been published in the press".

This concession Sillitoe exploited to the full. His chapters caused dismay when submitted. Sir Frank in a memo objected to sections about MI5's history and structure; and to Sillitoe's emphasis on its anti- communist activities on the grounds that this might suggest political bias by the service. Unflattering descriptions of the Kenya government's initial response to Mau Mau were also criticised, as were mentions of civil servants and intelligence officials, irrespective of whether their names had already appeared in print. A harmless reference to the usefulness of missionaries as a source of information to the colonial police, earned the following rebuke: "If the author wishes to jeopardise the lives of some of these missionaries he could hardly find a better way to do it."

The memo even objected to the words, the "late Bob Chiffley". "Questions of taste," it asserted "arise in relation to this over-familiar reference to a former Australian prime minister."

Dick White, successor as head of MI5, objected to Sillitoe saying: "MI5 were badly taken in over Fuchs." He described this as a "slur" on the Security Service. (Sillitoe changed it to the slightly less offensive "MI5 was mistaken".) White also complained Sillitoe "had made a personal reference to the head of the FBI and, knowing Mr Hoover's extraordinary sensitivity to criticism, this would undoubtedly have caused some trouble between us". White also for some reason sought to have removed a reference to an audience with the Pope.

Sillitoe complained his material had already appeared in some form or other in the press. "After reading Sir Winston Churchill's memoirs, I suggest to you ... you have, by mutilating almost to the point of destruction some of my own poor and humble efforts, treated me on an unfair basis." One official called this "sheer effrontery ... he is probably impelled by a hard-faced publisher who finds the manuscript in its reduced form unlikely to command the sales he had expected". Sir Edward wrote: "The whole of this rather chatty account of MI5 and its doings will do harm to [its] reputation ... and make it infinitely harder to deal with others in the public service, who may wish similarly to embark on undesirable publicity."

Sir Frank even suppressed one titbit they had previously approved, which had actually already been quoted in the press: "Although the Russians had already read the article in the Empire News, it seemed rather a pity to offer it to a much wider audience." When the book, Cloak Without Dagger, finally came out, it contained little of value.

The author lectures in history at Reading University

webTitle: Airline pilot stays cool in emergency

fields.headline: Airline pilot stays cool in emergency
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: An airline pilot forced to make an emergency landing told yesterday how he kept his 44 passengers calm for three hours beforehand by pointing out landmarks as they circled above Liverpool airport.
fields.body:
An airline pilot forced to make an emergency landing told yesterday how he kept his 44 passengers calm for three hours beforehand by pointing out landmarks as they circled above Liverpool airport.

Other crew on the British Regional Airways flight spoke of a party atmosphere on board before the plane, a British Aerospace Advanced Turboprop, landed in a shower of sparks on Tuesday evening. Two people were taken to hospital with whiplash injuries.

Captain Nick Davies said: "The weather was quite nice. I remember the sun setting, and thinking how nice North Wales was looking. As we came in to land, I mentioned that we could see Liverpool on the left - perhaps a bizarre thing to say, but it seemed to raise the passengers' spirits."

Though labelled a hero by some passengers, the captain said he was just doing his job: "I remained confident it would be a textbook landing."

Jane Aston, a steward on the Belfast-bound flight from Manchester, said: "There was almost a jolly atmosphere, which sounds quite ridiculous in the circumstances."

It emerged yesterday that the civil aviation authority had banned all such planes from taking off or landing in high winds following similar incidents involving the undercarriage. British Regional Airlines said that it had checked the plane in question six weeks ago, and had re-examined its 13 others after Tuesday's incident. An official investigation has begun.

fields.headline: Britain asked to back flexibility
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Britain is being urged by the European commission to accept the idea of a "two-speed Europe" in which pro-integrationist countries can forge ahead unhindered by less enthusiastic member states.
fields.body:
Britain is being urged by the European commission to accept the idea of a "two-speed Europe" in which pro-integrationist countries can forge ahead unhindered by less enthusiastic member states.

Michel Barnier, the French commissioner in charge of institutional reform, meets MPs and Tony Blair's European advisers in London today to persuade them to drop British objections to a more flexible EU, and do more to make a bigger union work better.

Mr Barnier's brief is the "inter-governmental conference", which is haggling about the key changes necessary before the 15-strong union can accept new members from eastern and central Europe. Reducing the number of commissioners, changing national voting weights and increasing the use of majority voting are the main issues facing the body; Mr Blair is resolutely opposed to surrendering the veto except on minor matters.

"I certainly respect British reservations, but I hope to be able to overcome them by explaining the commission's position," Mr Barnier said. But with the domestic debate about the single currency raising the political temperature in London, he will face suspicions about plans by France and Germany to revive themselves as the driving force behind the "hard core" of a flexible union.

France, Germany and Italy all want greater flexibility to be part of the Treaty of Nice, due to incorporate the reforms in December - Britain does not.

"We cannot put off these reforms. We certainly won't be able to do them when we are 21 or 22 [member states] if we can't do them when we are 15. The enlarged union will not work unless we get the institutional machinery right."

Mr Barnier praised the "brave vision" of the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, who made waves last week with a passionate call for a federal Europe. Mr Fischer's speech was warmly welcomed by Romano Prodi, the commission president, but met with a frosty silence from Britain.

"Frankly I don't see why the UK should be opposed to the idea that a group of countries could go ahead to illuminate the path for others," Mr Barnier said. "Some countries should be able to go ahead without being stopped by others or others being prevented from joining. In a union of 30 members this would be extremely useful.

webTitle: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital

fields.headline: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital
fields.trailText: Good Will Hunting | The English Patient | I Married A Witch
fields.body:
I Married A Witch (René Clair, 1942)

7pm, Carlton Cinema

Clair, who is better known for his frothy French musicals, has fun here with a spirited American comedy. Veronica Lake plays a witch who was burnt at the stake in New England back in 1690, reincarnated in contemporary times to avenge herself on the descendants of her po-faced Puritan persecutor. Fredric March, would-be governor, is the unfortunate chap whose political ambitions end up being sabotaged by Lake's mischievous spells. A charmingly oddball blend of comedy, romance and imagination - Lake is enchanting as the wicked witch, and March perfectly stuffy as the man who can't resist her charms.

The English Patient (Anthony Minghella, 1996)

10pm FilmFour

The arty tale of hot sex (well, it happens in the Tunisian desert) that mopped up nine Oscars. Adapted from Michael Ondaatje's excellent novel, the film has Ralph Fiennes' cerebral and detached Almasy drawn into a passionate but adulterous affair with sparkling newlywed Katharine (Kristin Scott Thomas) while on a North African mapping expedition at the start of the second world war. The action switches forward and back to Almasy, in an Italian monastery,now hideously burnt and being cared for by nurse Juliette Binoche (one of the Oscar winners). Fiennes and Scott Thomas might lack her emotional power, but Minghella's film has all the stunning beauty of pure romantic epic.

Good Will Hunting (Gus Van Sant, 1997)

10.10pm, Sky Premier

The film which showed that hot young actors Matt Damon and Ben Affleck could write as well. They scripted this well crafted drama about Damon's Will Hunting, a university janitor-come-maths whizz who is far brighter than the students. He has to learn to trust himself, and others, such as Minnie Driver's loving Brit student and Robin Williams' volatile shrink - a wounded soul, like Will.

fields.headline: The war that never was
fields.trailText: There were a number of revealing moments in Brits: The Secret War (BBC2). Particularly delicious was when an intelligence officer, quizzed over rough handling of terrorist suspects, denied knowledge of guns put to heads or use of broken-glass assault courses. The camera lingered long enough to catch a near-imperceptible smirk, giving the game away.
fields.body:
There were a number of revealing moments in Brits: The Secret War (BBC2). Particularly delicious was when an intelligence officer, quizzed over rough handling of terrorist suspects, denied knowledge of guns put to heads or use of broken-glass assault courses. The camera lingered long enough to catch a near-imperceptible smirk, giving the game away.

Reporter Peter Taylor's success with Brits, as with the previous series in the trilogy, Provos, first screened in 1997, and Loyalists, broadcast last year, is in revealing what makes people tick.

His style of questioning is familiar, short and pointed, encouraging interviewees to talk freely. As with the other programmes, the contribution of ignorance and fear to the ratcheting up of violence in the early days is clear.

The programme had a wide appeal. It both broke new ground, and set a readily accessible framework.

There is cod drama in the titles, all masked guys firing big guns in a barn somewhere - why would they do that? - amid booming music. And the use of night shots of murky Belfast streets with an accompanying threatening score is close to irksome.

But the material, including first accounts from undercover agents, was hair-raising. It is no exaggeration to say that they lived with death every day, though what was missing last night was any insight into why they were prepared to do so, other than the inference that it was simply their job.

One sergeant, discovered by the IRA, told how he was led out to be executed in darkness. He heard the pistol being cocked, counted to three, and moved slightly. It saved his life - all the bullets went into his right leg.

There was also a fine juxtaposition, where an army agent and terrorist told the same tale from their own viewpoints; it was brilliantly cut together.

One hilarious sequence recounted the tale of IRA commander Brendan Hughes after escaping from the Maze prison. He went to live in a posh house in affluent south Belfast, posing as a toy salesman, and, from there, he bugged army HQ.

The army surveillance team included a guy hiding in a rhododendron bush for 24 hours. Attempts to pass him fish and chips failed when the meal was thrown to the wrong bush.

Hughes, arrested with Gerry Adams in another amusing mission related in the programme, tried to bluff it out when he was held. The security forces told him to give it a rest, that he had enjoyed a good run. He laughed and congratulated them on a fine operation. They offered him suitcases full of cash to become an informer. He refused. They understood, and returned him to jail.

If that sounds like an honourable game, the next two programmes are more pointed. Next week looks at the security forces' alleged shoot-to-kill operations of the 80s, while Holding The Line, on May 31, will outline how British intelligence tightened the noose around the IRA, encouraging it to the negotiating table.

Lady Audley's Secret (ITV), with flouncing skirts, sumptuous country homes, and piano being tinkled gently as log fires roared, initially looked like a costume drama too far, after Madame Bovary and Anna Karenina. But it was soon rollicking along at breakneck pace.

Suspending disbelief about the myriad of coincidences - so Bobby's best mate Gordon just back from Australia was married to the penniless woman who has somehow just got spliced to his rich uncle Sir Michael? - and about Lady Lucy's unnecessarily self-incriminating behaviour, it was rather impressive. Even if, as Bobby said, "it doesn't make sense".

A Victorian thriller with bodices always threatening to rip, and a fine smattering of cliché tossed in too. That Neve McIntosh as Lady Audley - well, winsome would be the most dignified expression. And Steven Mackintosh, as Bobby Audley, again played the dashing lead with a fine line in brooding angst.

Even Channel 5 came up with something interesting, in a cheap and tacky fashion, with Urban Gothic, 13 home-grown horror half-hours. Dead Meat, last night's offering, seemed a bit daft, and never quite worked for me, but looks well worth another go. Next week's is meant to be good.

Suspending disbelief about the myriad of coincidences - so Bobby's best mate Gordon just back from Australia was married to the penniless woman who has somehow just got spliced to his rich uncle Sir Michael? - and about Lady Lucy's unnecessarily self-incriminating behaviour, it was rather impressive. Even if, as Bobby said, "it doesn't make sense". A Victorian thriller with bodices always threatening to rip, and a fine smattering of cliché tossed in too. That Neve McIntosh as Lady Audley - well, winsome would be the most dignified expression. And Steven Mackintosh, as Bobby Audley, again played the dashing lead with a fine line in brooding angst. Even Channel 5 came up with something interesting, in a cheap and tacky fashion, with Urban Gothic, 13 home-grown horror half-hours. Dead Meat, last night's offering, seemed a bit daft, and never quite worked for me, but looks well worth another go. Next week's is meant to be good.

webTitle: Hague demands tougher law on light sentences

fields.headline: Hague demands tougher law on light sentences
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague will today broaden his assault on Britain's "failed liberal consensus" when he calls for a change in the law to allow victims of serious crime to appeal against lenient sentences.
fields.body:
William Hague will today broaden his assault on Britain's "failed liberal consensus" when he calls for a change in the law to allow victims of serious crime to appeal against lenient sentences.

Buoyed up by the furore over his recent hardline speeches on law and order, the Tory leader will portray the new policy as a sign of his determination to tackle the alarming rise in crime which, he will claim, has seen a doubling of the murder rate.

In a speech to the Police Federation annual conference, Mr Hague will say that the current law on sentences fails to offer enough protection to the victims of crime. At the moment the law, which was introduced by the Tories in the late 1980s, offers a right of appeal against lenient sentences only for murder and rape.

Mr Hague will say: "Many crimes which spark real fear and anger among the public - grievous bodily harm, actual bodily harm, burglary, racially aggravated offences - carry no right to appeal. So we will extend the right to appeal against an over-lenient sentence to all so-called 'either-way' offences tried at the crown court." He will make clear in his speech that he remains unapologetic after being widely criticised for his recent pledge to lock up all asylum seekers and to help people like the Norfolk farmer, Tony Martin, who was jailed for the murder of an intruder.

In his widely trailed speech, the Tory leader will pledge to abolish Britain's "double jeopardy" rule which says that defendants cannot be tried twice for the same offence, other than in exceptional circumstances.

Mr Hague will describe his proposals as "the most concerted attempt by any British political party to challenge the failed post-war liberal consensus and to win the war against crime". The Tory leader will add: "I reject the defeatist nonsense that says crime is just a function of economic and social trends. For that is the implication behind the government's favourite soundbite about being tough on the causes of crime."

Mr Hague will offer what central office billed as a "stern warning" to criminals. He will say: "I want criminals to be fearful of getting caught and fearful of punishment so they will choose not to commit crimes ... I want the law-abiding millions in our country to feel free from fear in their homes and on the streets." As his officials finalised his speech, Mr Hague rounded on the prime minister in the Commons yesterday over his record on crime, challenging Mr Blair over the claims by the Police Federation chairman, Fred Broughton, that the reduction in police numbers has led to a sense of anarchy in some inner city areas.

Mr Blair replied: "I don't believe that policing is in crisis. I do accept that the numbers, which went down 2,000 in the last years of the government of which you were a member, continued to go down in the first three years of this government. By the end of this year, however, these numbers will be rising again."

Unveiling more hardline policies on law and order will renew criticism that Mr Hague is only interested in reaching out to the Tories' core rightwing supporters. However, Tory sources have indicated that Mr Hague will follow up his interventions on law and order with speeches designed to appeal to voters on the centre ground.

Labour last night dimissed Mr Hague's speech, saying that his political heroine, Margaret Thatcher, would be disappointed. Charles Clarke, the home office minister, said: "I'm not sure Margaret Thatcher will be flattered by being described by William Hague as being part of the 'failed post-war consensus'."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Wizard? | Costing The Earth
fields.body:
Within a year of its appearance in 1900, Frank Baum's book had been translated to the Chicago stage as a highly successful children's spectacular. Quite a coup for one of the Windy City's lowly newspaper reporters. In the intervening century, as Dick Vosburgh recalls in Wizard? (11.30am, Radio 4 FM), the story of Dorothy's meeting with the Wonderful Wizard Of Oz has never palled. The 1939 film starring Judy Garland is still the best known adaptation, but it's only one of hundreds.

The worldwide march of the soya bean is investigated by Alex Kirby in Costing The Earth (9.0pm, Radio 4). Third world farmers were originally encouraged to grow the crop as a way of raising much needed cash from exports. But it now threatens to devour them, replacing all but a fraction of India's 20,000 varieties of rice, and largely taking over the Brazilian savannah. Such dependence on a single crop could spell economic disaster.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
Cabinet secretary Sir Richard Wilson may be amused to learn of the valiant, if unknowing, part he has played in the fight for urban regeneration on Merseyside. On Tuesday, US Airways announced its new operations centre in Liverpool, but at one point when the airline favoured Manchester the deal looked doomed. Then, however, noting that a visit by airline vice-president Mark Schwab coincided with one by Sir Richard, crafty Liverpool council arranged a lunch for them both at which they gave Mr Schwab the impression that having the cabinet secretary over was a regular event, such a special place in Mr T's heart does their city occupy. Although Wilson looked baffled as all these strangers told him how nice it was to see him again, Wilson avoided shrieking "I don't beliiieeeeve it!" - and soon after an impressed Schwab chose Liverpool. "I did have lunch with him, although at that point we weren't really thinking about Liverpool," confirms Mr Schwab, adding that meeting Sir Richard and his "friends" on the council was "useful for our thought process".

Sadly, the relationship between American companies in the transport sector and British jobs isn't always so happy. Visitors to www.ford.com who type Dagenham in the search box receive this information: "Sorry! Your search didn't turn up any matches." That was quick.

On Nicky Campbell's Radio 5 Live show, Tory MP Roger Gale, not the brightest fairy light on the Christmas tree (he's the chump who argued strongly for tighter divorce law, forgetting that he's on his own third marriage) is wheeled out, this time to deliver the blue rinse line on pornography. Roger's brain may not be up to much, but his courage is beyond question. As always, in his blithe refusal to accept a hiding in the debate, he trots out cliche after cliche, like a horribly outclassed boxer ploughing on to inevitable defeat. (Big fight fans may recall Alan Minter's first and last defence of his middleweight title against Marvellous Marvin Hagler.) Is there no one out there with a towel and a little compassion?

In the Daily Mail, I am astonished to find the byline of my friend Gerald Kaufman, Sycophant Laureate in the court of New Labour. Gerald writes pungently about the BBC, a phobia of his, claiming that it is out of touch, and possibly not worth the licence fee. It's an old and familiar rant, but what is surprising is the venue. It seems only a few months since Gerald was publishing a weekly "Mail Monitor" newsletter, attempting to rebut items in that paper. Come to think of it, it was only a few months ago. Poor Gerald, his memory must be going.

Elsewhere in the Mail, my so-called rival Ephraim Hardcastle speculates about Andy Marr's jug ears, fearing these may distract viewers when Andy succeeds Fatty Oakley as BBC political editor ("especially those without wide screens"), and quoting an assurance from BBC chief Alan Yentob that "obviously we would pay for any plastic surgery he has to have". One sees the temptation, but it would be a mistake. A distinguishing feature is essential in this line of work. Robin Day's bow ties, John Cole's raincoat ... Andy Marr's ears. Keep them, Andy. They're worth their weight in gold.

Confusion enshrouds yesterday's item about Home Office minister Charles Clarke's recent announcement that Nato is an acronym for "Northern American Treaty Organisation", something I suggested we knew already. My thanks to all who complained that Nato stands for North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. We were trying to make a satirical point about US domination of Nato being so absolute that one can understand Mr Clarke's confusion. There is no better sign that a joke really worked than when you have to explain it the next day. Why do they continue to employ me?

fields.headline: Watchdog overruled
fields.standfirst:
MPs back Prescott over flat rented from union

Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: MPs yesterday overruled Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards watchdog, and exonerated John Prescott from having to declare a £220-a-month rented London flat provided by the Rail, Maritime and Transport union.
fields.body:
MPs yesterday overruled Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards watchdog, and exonerated John Prescott from having to declare a £220-a-month rented London flat provided by the Rail, Maritime and Transport union.

Ms Filkin ruled that the deputy prime minister - who has had the flat since 1970 - should have declared it in the register of members' interests from 1997, when the RMT ceased its sponsorship of the MP. The union allowed Mr Prescott to continue renting the flat at Maritime House, in Clapham, south London, after he had moved out to "grace and favour" accommodation in Admiralty House, Whitehall.

Ms Filkin's report, published yesterday, said that Mr Prescott had discussed the move with the RMT general secretary, Jimmy Knapp. He had asked to keep the tenancy and to allow his son, a freelance journalist, to use it until he left the government. She ruled: "Mr Prescott should certainly have registered the flat in 1997 in light of the new circumstances created when he moved out."

However, MPs on the Commons standards and privileges committee - which includes two Tories, Peter Bottomley and Eric Forth - unanimously overruled Ms Filkin after hearing a plea from Mr Prescott that he was entitled under the rent acts to keep the tenancy without consulting Mr Knapp. In a letter to Robert Sheldon, chairman of the committee, Mr Prescott wrote: "My understanding of the legal position is that nothing changed in 1997 as a result of my accepting an offer of accommodation in Admiralty House on entering government. I have never stopped being the tenant. My furniture has remained in the property and at all times I have paid my rent." Even if Mr Knapp had objected "my position as tenant would have been unaffected".

The complaint which prompted Ms Filkin's inquiry was brought by Tory MPs David Heathcoat-Amory, and Andrew Robathan. A third Tory MP, Archie Norman, the party's environment spokesman, complained to Tony Blair that Mr Prescott had broken the code of conduct for ministers by occupying a flat owned by a union which was lobbying him on transport issues.

The committee ruled retention of the tenancy "was not a new concession on the part of RMT but a legal right. Accordingly we do not uphold the complaint relating to non-registration". The MPs did invite Mr Prescott to add it to his entry now, "in the current climate".

Last night Mr Blair backed the deputy prime minister, saying the committee had vindicated him. Mr Norman said the episode reflected "the complacency and arrogance" of a government "enjoying the trappings of office and maintaining a relaxed attitude towards ethical standards in the conduct of ministers."

webTitle: Work in progress: Brian Park, TV producer

fields.headline: Work in progress: Brian Park, TV producer
fields.trailText: Here at Shed Productions it's more like work in limbo actually. Like anxious relatives clustered around a cardiac patient, we monitor the heartbeat highs and lows of Bad Girls ratings. More highs than lows - thank you for asking.
fields.body:
Here at Shed Productions it's more like work in limbo actually. Like anxious relatives clustered around a cardiac patient, we monitor the heartbeat highs and lows of Bad Girls ratings. More highs than lows - thank you for asking.

We have further trials ahead: ITV has asked us to tender for the early evening soap to replace Home And Away (as in away to Channel 5). Down to the final four candidates, yesterday we were summoned to hear their initial views. It took you back - as my colleague Maureen Chadwick observed - to the days of the old schoolyard. Drama supremos Nick Elliott and Jenny Reeks, a very creditable headmaster/matron combo; us, eager pupils awaiting end of term results. So, cheesy grins (they "liked the overall concept") and bottom lips quivering ("they "nevertheless had some concerns").

I can't divulge too much about our bid - suffice to say that it isn't based in a motel somewhere in the Midlands. What we do learn (and probably suspected already), is that a new soap for the millennium (and I bet that was in everyone's proposals) often means the conciliation of the seemingly contradictory. It has to be young, but not frighten off the grannies. It can be metropolitan, but can't alienate the regions. Not too gritty, not too fluffy, not too... etc, etc.

It could all be so daunting, but what no commissioner - ITV or BBC - wants is some sitting-on-the-fence compromise. You may trim, but ultimately you have to go with your gut and what you believe in. So while we bid a reluctant farewell to the notion of the pink Cadillac carwash (too bubblegummy) and our Big Issue seller (too inner-city), we embark with enthusiasm on the little task of writing three pilot scripts and 65 storylines to prove our instinct right. Maybe they'd buy a blue Rover carwash?

 Brian Park is producer of ITV drama, Bad Girls

webTitle: Bush and Clinton unite to block Kosovo pullout

fields.headline: Bush and Clinton unite to block Kosovo pullout
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Senate Republicans who are pressing to set a date for the withdrawal of US troops from Kosovo have been ambushed by an unlikely alliance between President Clinton and the Republican presidential candidate, George W Bush.
fields.body:
Senate Republicans who are pressing to set a date for the withdrawal of US troops from Kosovo have been ambushed by an unlikely alliance between President Clinton and the Republican presidential candidate, George W Bush.

The two political opponents have joined together in a last-ditch effort to prevent the passage of a bill which would cut off funds for the 5,900 US troops in Kosovo by July 1 2001, and which observers believe was on the verge of winning majority support in the Republican-controlled Senate.

The bill, jointly sponsored by the Republican armed services committee chairman, Senator John Warner, and the veteran Democrat Senator Robert Byrd, would pull the US troops out unless Mr Clinton or his successor obtains congressional approval for continued deployment.

The president would also be required to put forward a timetable for the transfer of responsibility for peacekeeping in Kosovo to European nations, and to certify that all Nato countries are paying their share for the operations.

The Byrd-Warner bill has been described as "a de facto pull-out decision by the United States" by the former Nato supreme commander General Wesley Clark, and is viewed with alarm in most European capitals.

Domestic political opposition to the bill has mainly come from Democrats, who are in a minority in the Senate, and from Republican Senator John McCain, who warned this week that the bill would "send the message to Nato that the United States is an unreliable ally".

Until yesterday, momentum had seemed to be growing for the bill, with most Republicans assuming that the plan had the support of Mr Bush, the Texas governor. But the Republican Senate leadership was taken by surprise by Mr Bush's statement this week that the bill interferes with the constitutional powers of the presidency.

"The Clinton-Gore administration has failed to instill trust in Congress and the American people when it comes to our military and deployment of troops overseas, but the governor does not believe this provision is the way to resolve the lack of presidential leadership," the statement said. "Governor Bush views it as a legislative overreach on powers of the presidency."

Senior members of the Clinton administration kept up the pressure against the bill yesterday. The plan to withdraw US troops was "playing with fire", the secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, said. "We are more than bookkeepers and spectators. We are leaders."

Meanwhile, the defence secretary, William Cohen, said that President Clinton might have to veto the bill, even though that would jeopardise $8.6bn (£5.76bn) worth of new defence spending projects contained in separate sections of the bill.

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.trailText:
Small talk
The annual Webby awards presentation in San Francisco last week was over in two hours thanks to the strict limit on speeches - five words or less . There were two sets of winners: sites nominated by members of the International Academy of Digital Arts & Sciences, and sites picked by 134,000 webizens. The big winners included Napster, the MP3 music site, Google, the best search engine, and Slashdot, the Linux community site. See Six of the Best Webby winners below.

Small talk
The annual Webby awards presentation in San Francisco last week was over in two hours thanks to the strict limit on speeches - five words or less . There were two sets of winners: sites nominated by members of the International Academy of Digital Arts & Sciences, and sites picked by 134,000 webizens. The big winners included Napster, the MP3 music site, Google, the best search engine, and Slashdot, the Linux community site. See Six of the Best Webby winners below.

Art prize
The SFMoma (San Francisco Museum of Modern Art) Webby Prize for Excellence in Online Art, which carries a $30,000 prize, went to the Entropy8Zuper! team - Michael Samyn and Auriea Harvey - from Belgium. See www.sfmoma.org/info/webby_winner_announce.html.

Film fun
AtomFilms, Be Here and Intel have teamed up to encourage film makers to produce 360 degree "immersive movies" for the web. The first, The New Arrival, written and directed by Amy Talkington, has just been unveiled at the Cannes Film Festival. Proposals for films can be submitted at www.atomfilms.com/default.asp?spot_id=88. For further information, see www.behere.com/aboutus.htm.

Thumbs down
Warner Bros new Battlefield Earth is generating huge interest because of the Scientology connection: it stars Scientologist John Travolta and is based on a book by the cult's founder, science fiction writer L Ron Hubbard. webTitle: Britain builds temple to a new era in heart of Moscow

fields.headline: Britain builds temple to a new era in heart of Moscow
fields.standfirst:
Russia: special report
The British embassy
fields.trailText: Blair's new Britain has come to Moscow in the form of an angular, glass-fronted British embassy building, slotted between Stalinist structures on the banks of the Moscow river.
fields.body:
Blair's new Britain has come to Moscow in the form of an angular, glass-fronted British embassy building, slotted between Stalinist structures on the banks of the Moscow river.

The result of 13 years' tortuous planning, the £81m modernist embassy opened by Princess Anne yesterday was hailed as a new gateway between Russia and Britain.

The architect who created the building, Richard Burton, admitted that the building's conception had been unusually fraught as a result of radically shifting political circumstances in Russia.

His company, Ahrends Burton and Koralek, originally put forward a fortress-like design. This was torn up at the beginning of the 1990s, when embassy officials decided it no longer reflected the post-cold war spirit of relations between the two countries.

Instead he was ordered back to the drawing board to design a "more outgoing" building - reflected in the airy, transparent new structure.

Conveniently, the redesigned plans also halved projected construction costs because of a reduction in expensive security measures.

However, the new symbolic openness did not mean a wholesale abandonment of security concerns.

The 1985 US embassy debacle had not been forgotten. During the construction of their new Moscow base, American officials allowed Russian contractors to work unsupervised, only to discover that the building had been crammed full of KGB listening devices - many buried inside steel girders. They were forced to abandon the building on completion, rejecting it as an "eight-storey microphone".

This time, builders imported pre-fabricated materials from Britain to ensure that there was no bugging. Work on the most sensitive areas of the building - particularly the political offices - was carried out exclusively by British builders, supervised by security staff.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, who was also at the opening ceremony, was determined to stress the inclusive nature of the design rather than the anti-surveillance measures. "Look around you and you will see that it is light and open. We want it to be part of Russia not apart from Russia," he said.

Mr Burton agreed. "The building isn't monolithic. It's broken up into four parts. It's transparent - there's air and light going through the four buildings. It's meant to look welcoming."

Russian architectural commentators are not convinced. Some have raised eyebrows at the building's chalet-style timber balconies and open-air walkways, questioning how much use they will be when temperatures drop to -30C.

"It looks a bit like a spa or a health resort. It's as if the building was designed not to stand on the banks of the Moscow river, but on the shores of a Pacific ocean resort," said Grigory Revzin, a writer on architecture.

Nevertheless the attempt to dispense with the stiff formality of the old embassy - a 19th century palace overlooking the Kremlin - is impossible to ignore. The old building, now used exclusively as the ambassador's residence, was filled with chandeliers, mahogany panelling and lifesize portraits of past and present royals.

The walls of the new building have been hung with modern art, some by artists who appeared in the provocative Sensation exhibition at the Royal Academy. A huge sofa in the shape of a pair of lips stands in the entrance hall.

Just a month after Vladimir Putin's controversial meeting with the Queen in London, the Princess Royal was received by Mr Putin in the Kremlin on Tuesday - a further demonstration of Britain's determination to embrace the new Russian president, despite international concern about human rights violations during the prosecution of the war in Chechnya.

This approach was underlined by Mr Cook, making his second visit to Moscow this year; he spent the afternoon in talks with Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov.

fields.headline: The unhappy prince
fields.standfirst:
The troubling thoughts of a troubled man

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Prince Charles's Reith lecture last night represented an astonishing departure for the Royal Family. Never before has one of its members made such an intensely personal speech - both a highly idiosyncratic credo and a manifesto for social, political and economic change. It reveals a tortured, shy man with mystical leanings who seems to find it easier to commune with the sunset than with his fellow human beings.
fields.body:
Prince Charles's Reith lecture last night represented an astonishing departure for the Royal Family. Never before has one of its members made such an intensely personal speech - both a highly idiosyncratic credo and a manifesto for social, political and economic change. It reveals a tortured, shy man with mystical leanings who seems to find it easier to commune with the sunset than with his fellow human beings.

But he has finally decided what to do with the extraordinary position to which he was born - and his project is hugely ambitious. His oratorical sweep embraces the entire tradition of western intellectual thought, how we educate our children, and the formation of our souls. It is one of the speech's many odd contradictions that this ambition is combined with an apologetic humility ("I happen to believe ...").

The prince will have many critics, and with some reason. His thinking is often incoherent - he drops a heterogeneous raft of names and quotations to support his assertions - and is characterised by a deep romantic nostalgia about an idyllic lost past.

Where this grows embarrassing and possibly even dangerous is when he appeals to the "instinctive awareness" buried in all of us to care for the planet. Such "wisdom of the heart" has led people to hell as well as to heaven, and it is self-deluding not to acknowledge that.

But setting aside such caveats, the Prince has boldly aligned himself with radical environmental campaigners such as Vandana Shiva, and has rightly asserted the need for a sense of urgency and moral purpose to achieve sustainable development. He also points out that underpinning that goal there must be a spiritual appreciation of the natural world and our place in it. Unfortunately, the way he develops this argument will alienate many potential allies. Firstly, he insists that a reverence for nature comes from a belief in a creator, but many environmentalists do not have such a belief. Secondly, he attacks scientific rationalism for the global exploitation and destruction of the environment. He makes no attempt to distinguish between the scientists' research and its commercial application, and offers no more than a token nod towards the huge achievements of western science.

His lecture has infuriated some of those most likely to share his concern for the environment. There are risks that it will fuel the growing backlash against science; yet science has a huge role in helping us tackle the problem of billions of human beings surviving on this planet. If the Prince really aspires to the role of visionary idealist, he needs a speech writer who can hammer out a simpler, clearer set of ideas.

But we cannot simply assess him solely as a thinker. He holds a constitutional position. There is no sign here that he relates his radicalism to his future role. It is not tenable to rebrand the House of Windsor as a visionary leadership. Many in Britain will fear having an ageing New Age hippy as king.

Even more strikingly, the Church of England can hardly stomach a pantheist divorcee, cohabiting with another divorcee, as its titular head. The Prince managed to make a whole speech on the sacred without mentioning Jesus Christ once; God was replaced by euphemisms such as "guiding hand". Even the reference to the Gospel attributes a thought to St Matthew rather than Christ.

Whatever else he may be, he is not on the basis of what he said here a Christian by any definition that the Archbishop of Canterbury could accept. At the very least, this speech will trigger hard thinking in Lambeth Palace about disestablishment.

fields.headline: Here comes the stutter cutter
fields.trailText: The next version of Lernout & Hauspie's Voice Xpress program, which is expected shortly, is a huge improvement on anything released before, writes Jack Schofield
fields.body:
The next version of Lernout & Hauspie's Voice Xpress program, which is expected shortly, is a huge improvement on anything released before, the company claims. Rather than simply trying to recognise speech, it also tries to recognise things that aren't speech, and discard them.

Voice Xpress 5.0's new "disfluency filter" is designed to pick up the ums and ahs and ha-ha-has and remove them. These unwanted elements are not only tedious to edit out of recognised text, but they also make it harder for the software to follow sentence structure and use this knowledge to improve accuracy.

Dr Alex Waibel, a professor at both Carnegie-Mellon University in the US and the University of Karlsruhe in Germany, has been working on the problem for some time. His company, Interactive Systems Inc, is also one of many that the fast-growing Belgian language giant has taken over.

Waibel and his students have been researching the problems involved in recognising conversations, rather than dictation. "Conversational speech includes a lot of stutter, people leave out a lot of things, they mumble a lot of things," he says. "Some of the voice material is simply not there any more."

The solution is to exploit much more of the information that's available. For example, it's possible to extract an image of the lips from the face and get the computer to do "visual lip reading". On its own, the approach doesn't work very well, says Waibel, but it can be used to increase the accuracy of speech recognition systems. For example, lip reading systems can easily distinguish between b and v, which to speech recognition systems sound the same. As with humans, visual lip reading also becomes more valuable in noisy environments. Some of Waibel's students have also developed a "meeting browser" which can recognise emotions -whether people are neutral, angry or sad, for example. The browser makes it possible to move backwards and forwards through a recording of a meeting and identify emotions. It's accuracy is limited, but people aren't always much better at the task.

Waibel says it's important to look at gesture, speech, and eye movements to extract meaning: "Who are they talking to? What are they looking at? The purpose of speech is only known when you know something about the scene. We've just scratched the surface."

fields.headline: Farming officials condemned
fields.standfirst: Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: A hit squad of civil servants should be sent into the Ministry of Agriculture to end its "outmoded" and "misplaced" attachment to intensive farming and the subsidy culture of the EU's common agriculture policy, backbench MPs recommended yesterday.
fields.body:
A hit squad of civil servants should be sent into the Ministry of Agriculture to end its "outmoded" and "misplaced" attachment to intensive farming and the subsidy culture of the EU's common agriculture policy, backbench MPs recommended yesterday.

Only sweeping changes could accelerate the "glacial" progress towards a new approach to the countryside and end the damaging system of production payments to farmers made "regardless of environmental or social concerns", said the environment select committee.

"What has traditionally been spent on agriculture must start to be used to protect and enhance the countryside and maintain the social fabric of villages," said its report, offering advice on the government's rural white paper expected later this year.

The ministry appeared to think "agricultural competitiveness is synonymous with big farms, capable of mass producing cheap food", it said. Instead more effort should be made to encourage small farmers producing food customers wanted to buy, help the growth of farmers' markets and pay for more farmers to turn organic.

The MPs recognised there had recently been attempts to make some subsidies dependent on eco-friendly policies but much more needed to be done. "Few can see an unchanged (ministry) at the vanguard of a new approach to rural policy ... It is often the case that the senior and long-serving staff of an organisation find change most difficult to accommodate."

The report exempted the countryside minister, Elliot Morley, from criticism but the damning verdict on the ministry's culture is shared by many Blairites.

Richard Packer was forced out as permanent secretary recently, although he was given a knighthood, and his replacement next month will be Brian Bender, who has never worked at the ministry.

The ministry, which employs about 9,000 staff, has already lost its control over food safety and hygiene because it was seen as putting the interests of the farming and food industry above theats to consumers.

The Council for the Protection of Rural England, whose criticism of the "glacial" progress at the ministry was said by the committee to be "scathing but accurate", welcomed its verdict.

The committee underlined concern at the continuing threat to village banks and post offices, said supermarkets must do more to help save village shops, called for maximum speed limits of 30mph in villages and said more funds must be made available for affordable housing.

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.body:
"It is not absurd to compare Mo Mowlam to Princess Diana. Like Diana, Mo is out of the ordinary. Like Diana, she has a way of reaching out to the people ... Both women were given gifts that transcend the conventional tramlines of the world in which we live and it is crazy as well as wrong not to cherish them. Prince Charles ... failed to show her [Diana] the love she craved and deserved. And he envied her immense popularity. That was the biggest mistake of all ... Towards the end of her life, Diana's status as a national icon was turning into a destructive, republican force which endangered the very future of the British royal family. Tony Blair ought to ponder deeply on all of that when he next discusses what must become of Mo Mowlam with his sombre, besuited, mainly male advisers"

- Peter Oborne pens a love letter to Mo, Daily Express

"Now, more than ever, we are surrounded by nudity ... Why such a barrage of flesh? Part of this has occurred as a form of female emancipation; part as a result of media sublimation. Some is the pressure - some might call it tyranny - of fashion. Part is mass confidence ... But do we feel more comfortable with our own naked bodies? Or is it just another pressure, another way of controlling us?"

- Janine di Giovanni on nudity, Vogue

"She needed what my husband bluntly terms a 'Marie Antoinette job'. The body, tanned and toned, is in enviable shape; the dress is OK ... What jars is the head"

- Brenda Polan's verdict on the strapless turquoise dress Carol Vorderman wore to the Baftas, Daily Mail

"Lighten up, everyone - I wore a dress. Nobody died"

- Carol Vorderman, Mirror

"If a man is married or has a girlfriend, I don't want any of it ... I've stopped all that. I've become very interested in the adventure and intimacy of monogamy"

- Cybill Shepherd, Evening Standard

"I did feel very guilty because he did get a lot of ribbing for it and I don't want people to think I'm the one who wears the trousers, because that's not how it is"

- Victoria Beckham expresses regret about "joking" that her husband wears her thongs, Heat magazine

fields.headline: Travels with maiden aunts
fields.standfirst: Are saintly old spinsters a dying breed, as new figures suggest?  Joan Smith  considers their legacy
fields.trailText: Are saintly old spinsters a dying breed, as new figures suggest?  Joan Smith  considers their legacy
fields.body:
Maiden aunts are dying out. Not from old age, but as a species. New figures released by the government this week show the number of single women over the age of 65 is at a record low - 6% compared with over 10% in 1980. This means that only around one in 20 elderly women has never been married and they are easily outnumbered by women who are widowed, divorced or separated.

So no more Miss Marples, quietly observing village life and drawing deductions that have eluded their married counterparts? No more reclusive spinster novelists, beavering away in the parlour like Emily Brontë or Jane Austen? Even if she did not secretly aspire to fame, the maiden aunt was, for many families, a godsend. She was willing to look after nephews and nieces, step in when parents were unwell and display the endless patience that comes more easily - in theory - to those who have not had children themselves.

But what about the maiden aunt herself? Was she really content with her lot? On the whole, no one bothered to inquire and even when Agatha Christie turned a maiden aunt into a central character, she could not avoid investing her with stereotypical character traits.

Miss Marple is brighter than her neighbours give her credit for, but only because she has never really had a life of her own. Her wisdom comes from observing other people, making her a nice version of another female stereotype, the nosy spinster. She is unexpectedly tolerant of other people's passions, but that is because Christie expected her readers to assume that all unmarried women were sexually inexperienced - and quite possibly frustrated to boot.

This is an increasingly dodgy expectation, as a seventysomething friend of mine attests. Never married, without children of her own, she is a classic maiden aunt, doted on by younger members of her family. Yet she has had a positively racy life, remaining single from choice and not regretting her lack of children for a moment. Nor is she remotely defensive, like two older single women I once met in an English village. "We live together," one told me, within minutes of being introduced, "but we're not lesbians."

What this reflects is years of fending off other people's assumptions, including the notion that unmarried women of a certain age must have been "left on the shelf". What the new population figures seem to reflect is a change in the expectations of women themselves, with many marrying for the first time at an age when an earlier generation had settled into reluctant - or so we assumed - spinsterhood.

This was only one of the cruel assumptions that used to be routinely made about older women who had not married. One of the kinder ones was that their fiancés had died "in the war" and they had subsequently dedicated themselves to siblings' offspring or found surrogate children by becoming teachers. At the school I attended, we wrote this script for any unmarried schoolmistress, romantically imagining a handsome young subaltern who had died in the trenches in the first world war.

It was only much later that we realised most of our teachers were not even born when that conflict ended. But we still assumed they could not be spinsters or even career women by choice. The most common attitudes to older single women were pity and condescension, as though they had missed out on life's most important experiences. It is true that there have been times, including the period after the first world war, when single women outnumbered single men and it was not possible for every woman to find a husband. But it is also the case that some women prefer not to marry, though that certainly does not mean they have never had sex.

With so many women choosing to cohabit these days, it is quite possible that the number of never-married over-65s will start to rise again. Single women with children and grandchildren, and two or three ex-lovers, are hardly going to be maiden aunt material when they reach their 70s. But how many women ever fitted the crude old maid or spinster labels? If the maiden aunt is an endangered species, perhaps it is time we stopped thinking of older unmarried women as clones of Miss Marple, played to tweedy perfection by Dame Margaret Rutherford. Elizabeth I, Gloria Steinem, Anne Brontë and Deborah Harry all fall into the category of spinster, if it still exists. But who would dare to describe any of them as old maids?

fields.headline: Queen mothers
fields.standfirst: When Norway's Prince Haakon this week made public his love for a woman who is a commoner  and a single mother, was the nation shocked? Not a bit of it.  Valeria Criscione reports from Oslo on why every woman is a winner there (even without the prince)
fields.trailText: When Norway's Prince Haakon this week made public his love for a woman who is a commoner  and a single mother, was the nation shocked? Not a bit of it.  Valeria Criscione reports from Oslo on why every woman is a winner there (even without the prince)
fields.body:
What if Sophie had been a single mother when Prince Edward came courting? Would he still have proposed and been allowed to marry? Consider now if Sophie's ex and the father of her child had been prosecuted for narcotics involvement. Would that have cooled the prince off?

That is the predicament currently facing Norway's monarchy. Crown Prince Haakon, 26, wants to continue to court (in private) Mette-Marit Tjessem Hoiby, a 26-year-old single mother whose ex-partner was recently sentenced for possession of cocaine. Prince Haakon believes so strongly in the affair that he has this week gone on Norwegian national TV to defend his love for the student and former waitress. "Yes, I have a girlfriend and her name is Mette-Marit," he told curious viewers who had been monitoring Mette-Marit mania.

Both his open admission and public support for the affair say more about the status of women in Norway than about the modernisation of the monarchy. Norwegian royals have broken tradition before and married commoners. It was in fact Prince Haakon's father, King Harald (great-great grandson of Britain's Queen Victoria), who took that bold step in 1968 by wedding Sonja, Norway's current queen.

What is new this time is that the prince's date comes complete with that modern-day extra, a child from another relationship. Having children outside marriage is quite common in Norway. Approximately 49% of all those born in the country in 1998 were outside wedlock - the highest percentage in Europe.

At first glance, it might look as if Norway were a land of debauchers procreating legions of illegitimate children. But the numbers shroud the fact that recognised partnership is a legitimate form of a family relationship in most Nordic countries. Norway even started allowing same-sex couples to enter into a registered partnership in 1993 and it is not uncommon to find a man and woman who have been living together for decades, have had several children, but have found no reason to marry.

One simple reason for this is that, economically, they don't have to. Norwegian law protects women so that they are still entitled to half a man's assets, even if the couple were only "sambo", or living together. And if things do go sour, the Norwegian social welfare state provides low-cost medical care for all, public day-care centres and a child cash benefit scheme for those who opt to stay at home with their toddlers.

Among other social safety nets available, Norway offers generous parental leave for new mothers and fathers. A woman can safely leave her job without the worry of being replaced and get paid 80% of her salary for a full year off with her child. In addition, the father must take one month off - paid, of course - or forfeit the quota.

Lill-Margrethe Stene, a 33-year-old art teacher in Oslo, is an example of a Norwegian mother able to enjoy a comfortable standard of living, despite the fact that her relationship lies outside other countries' conventional norms: she is the breadwinner in the family and was five months pregnant when she took her marriage vows.

Lill-Margrethe became pregnant with her daughter, Selma Margrethe, now 18 months old, while living with her partner, Oyvind Bakke Haaland, in Oslo. He was a literature student with a part-time job. Lill-Margrethe said there was no stigma attached to walking down the aisle pregnant. "It was romantic to confirm [the relationship] through a ceremony," she says. "We had decided we wanted children, so it was practical to be married. If we divorced, we would both have equal rights."

The couple are able to get by economically despite the fact that she, as the sole income earner, temporarily left her teaching job to take care of their daughter. She opted to collect 100% of her salary over nine months - the law allows shorter childcare leave with higher pay. She has recently returned to work and put their daughter in public childcare costing NKr3,500 (£267) per month. But she will receive NKr1,500 (£114) per month in childcare assistance until the child is three and a lesser amount between three and 16 years.

These benefits apply to single mothers, too. As early as 1919, those in Oslo were given the right to municipal provisions. In 1967, the national insurance scheme, a unified social security system, secured a basic pension independent of former income, including rights for unmarried mothers. In 1981, these provisions were extended to include unmarried fathers and divorced/separated mothers and fathers.

Not only is it economically feasible to be a single mother in Norway, it is also socially acceptable. Marit Arnstad, oil and energy minister from the previous government, conceived a son during her administration without revealing the name of the father, took maternity leave during a trying time in Norway's oil politics and returned as a single working mother. This all took place under the Christian Democratic prime ministership of Kjell Magne Bondevik, a Lutheran-trained priest and creator of an ethics and value commission in Norway. Her decision attracted some media attention, but she emerged relatively unscathed.

Given this social and political climate, many believe the question is not whether the prince can marry a single mother, but what the role of the child from a previous relationship would be. While recent polls show that three out of four Norwegians support the prince's choice to go public with the relationship, Mette-Marit's son would most likely not be an heir to the throne.

As for the boy's mother: "I think it is absolutely possible she can become queen," Lill-Margrethe says. "We are a little country and have a looser relationship to royalty than in England. Even the king took the public trolley car to go skiing."

A tale of two countries

Britain

1918 Women over 30 and married women gain the right to vote. Ten years later, women can vote, on equal terms with men, from the age of 21.

1919 Nancy Astor becomes the first woman MP actually to take her seat.

1970 The Equal Pay Act is passed.

1975 The Employment Protection Act gives limited maternity rights, the Equal Opportunities Commission is created, the Sex Discrimination Act is passed and the UN Decade for Women established.

1979 Margaret Thatcher becomes first woman prime minister.

1996 Employment Relations Act extends maternity leave to a minimum of 14 weeks.

1999 Maternity leave is extended to a minimum of 18 weeks, at 90% of salary for six weeks, then £60.20.

Norway

1913 Women gain the right to vote.

1922 First woman is elected a Member of Parliament.

1979 The General Equality Act comes into force, including a Gender Equality Ombud and Appeals Board.

1988 The Gender Equality Act is passed, ensuring 40% representation of both sexes on official boards, councils and committees, and in the cabinet.

1981 Gro Harlem Brundtland becomes first woman prime minister.

1993 Parental leave period extended to one year at 80% of salary. Four weeks are reserved for the father.

1995 The right to unpaid parental leave is extended from one year to three years.

webTitle: Go on, give yourself a medal

fields.headline: Go on, give yourself a medal
fields.standfirst: Awards abound for websites, but which are worth winning? Sudipta Dev investigates
fields.trailText: Awards abound for websites, but which are worth winning? Sudipta Dev investigates
fields.body:
If you have a website, why have just one feather in your cap when you can have a hundred? Look around the web and there is a plethora of awards all waiting to be won. Flashily designed icons ranging from family honours to cool pet site prizes are there for the taking - for in most cases you just need to apply.

The list is almost endless... the Surreal Website award, Duke of URL Classy Site award, Bonnie and Rex's Radical award, the Zilinsky Family award, Cyber Teddy People's Choice top 500 award, Lisa/Lothy/Judy's creative site award.

Then there are those which cost - they redesign the web page for a fee, before you apply for their award. The Webby awards in the US, held last week in San Francisco, and the Yell UK awards - due in July - might have prestige, but they are only two in the sea of icons with which you can embellish your site. So can anyone give anyone an award in the cyber world? The answer is obviously yes. Why issue them? Because the more awards you hand out, the more web pages will link back to your own.

But surprisingly, there are a few website builders who have benefited from it all. Dr Vijay Prakash, a resident of Lucknow in north India, swears by the awards which have made him an instant net celebrity. His site Guide to Home Remedies and First Aid http://dr-vijayprakash.hypermart.net has won him no fewer than 80 awards within a year. Up to 40 emailed queries are sent to him from all over the world each day, ranging from people worrying about snakebites to those looking for long-term asthma cures. He answers them all free, sometimes issuing "dadima ke nuskhe" - ancient herbal remedies passed down generations.

The fame which the paediatrician could never earn even after practising for 14 years in his hometown is now his after just a few months on the web. "These awards help in getting publicity. Earlier I used to apply to go to international conferences, now I get invitations to attend the same," says Dr Prakash. "They also agree to pay for the air fare," he adds, laughing.

'Money is secondary - the response which I have got in the last few months is mindboggling. I also keep getting emails from expatriate Indians from all over the world who chance upon my site and are proud to see that I have bagged so many honours."

Although he was the site of the month on AOL last October, he says his biggest recognition is the link provided to his site by the prestigious Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, USA. For someone like Phil Barnett, a Cheshire bird watcher and winner of 1999 Yell best personal site and site of the year awards for his Birds in a Cheshire Garden, his dual feat has not only made him famous overnight, but given him a career. "I had been suffering from ME and had been on a wheelchair for 10 years. Unable to do anything I used to keep watching birds in my garden," explains Barnett. "When my condition improved I bought myself a computer in 1997, got an internet connection and started designing web pages on my subject - birds.

"After getting the best personal site award I was shocked when my name was announced for the best site of the year award," says the self-taught web designer. He has now opened his own web designing agency with a small, but growing, nationwide clientele.

Barnett says that most web site awards are meaningless, but serve a purpose as another link in the web. "One has to separate the wheat from the chaff," he adds. "I know of people who have got a hundred awards for sites which are not the least good."

But the popularity of the big awards keeps growing. Nigel Marson, marketing communications controller at yell.com says nominations have increased by 25% this year. "There are new categories this year for small business, which also include nominations from people like plumbers and antique dealers," he says.

Insisting that it is not just hits but the merit of the sites which bags them the awards, he cautiously declines to comment on the thousands of other little known prizes. But for all those who get the honours just for asking, the prestige and origins of the award probably don't matter - they just want another icon to decorate their page.

fields.headline: The Cerne Abbas giant
fields.body:
Age: Anything from 350 to 2,000 years old.

Height: 180ft.

Profile: Two-dimensional.

Appearance: Chalky, grassy - and shameless.

Really? He's stark naked and priapic.

Habitation: Come rain or shine, a hillside in Dorset.

A giant for all seasons! More like a giant for all silly seasons, actually.

Cynical. Well, the debate about whether he's really ancient or just a few centuries old has been rekindled, once again, just in time for the start of the tourist season.

So what does this enormous chalk carving actually represent? Take your pick: (a) a local representative of a Celtic fertility god; (b) an early Dorset mead lout; (c) a sort of mid 17th century Ali G poking rude fun at Oliver Cromwell.

Don't quite get the Ali G bit. The theory gaining ground among experts is that the figure was carved on the orders of a Dorset landowner and MP, Denzil Holles, as a satirical, subversive swipe at the Lord Protector, whom he detested. So it's not really ancient at all.

All right. And what's with the club and the huge penis? If you believe the Denzil theory, the club could represent Cromwell's repressive policies, and the phallus could be intended as a way of poking fun at his prudery.

Crude. No cruder than the behaviour of some amorous couples who, over the intervening years, have clambered on to the giant's belly in the belief that a night spent making love there is a sure way for a woman to conceive.

Well, the debate about whether he's really ancient or just a few centuries old has been rekindled, once again, just in time for the start of the tourist season. fields.headline: Surgeons warned on child ops
fields.trailText: Surgeons should not operate on children if they lacked practice because most of their patients were adults, the Royal College of Surgeons said yesterday.
fields.body:
Surgeons should not operate on children if they lacked practice because most of their patients were adults, the Royal College of Surgeons said yesterday.

Occasional paediatric practice was unacceptable, it said in a report. The minimum to have acquired sufficient skill was two sessions a month, and two sessions a week in the case of heart surgeons.

The report's authors, two consultant paediatric surgeons, said they had few facts and figures to back up their view, but were concerned by anecdotal evidence they had encountered.

"Children are not miniature adults," said Lella Kapila, one of the authors. "Some of the surgical disorders of the paediatric age group are rarely encountered in adult surgical practice."

Before 1989 it was not known even how many surgeons there were, until a survey by the college recorded around 5,000. The Bristol Royal infirmary, the hospital in the scandal over deaths of babies after heart operations, now had one of the best set of operation records in the country, but elsewhere, said Barry Jackson, the college president, hospitals did not have the funds.

David Thomas, the report's other author, said what was needed was NHS investment in information systems to provide objective data and make comparisons between individual surgeons and hospitals.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In our obituary of Baroness Wharton, page 22, yesterday, we incorrectly said she was unsuccessful in her bid to remain in the House of Lords in the peers' election last year. She was one of the hereditary crossbench peers elected to stay. Apologies.
fields.body:
In our obituary of Baroness Wharton, page 22, yesterday, we incorrectly said she was unsuccessful in her bid to remain in the House of Lords in the peers' election last year. She was one of the hereditary crossbench peers elected to stay. Apologies.

In an article headed Sick to the back teeth, pages 8 and 9 (Health), G2, May 9, we said that Dr Jack Levenson, founder of the British Society for Mercury-Free Dentistry, had removed fillings from the teeth of more than 6,000 patients over the past 20 years. In fact Dr Levenson has carried out no dental treatment in that period. He provides patients with a report which they then present to the dentist of their choice. Dr Levenson's book, referred to but not named in a piece headed Toxic debate, on the same pages, is called Menace in the Mouth? published by What Doctors Don't Tell You.

In a panel accompanying an article headed The missing link in heart disease, page 8 (Health) G2, May 16, we said that we got B vitamins from fresh green vegetables, fruit and whole foods. That is nearly true. But B12 is only naturally present in quantities sufficient to meet human needs in animal foods (including dairy produce and eggs).

In our profile of the England cricket captain Nasser Hussain, pages 6 and 7, Saturday Review, May 13, we said that he was once "yorked [bowled by a ball that hits the base of the stumps without bouncing] in a match against Surrey ..." Yorker: a ball bowled to pitch just under or just beyond the bat (Collins Millennium). A ball that hit the base of the stumps without bouncing would be a full toss.

CR Boxer's famous books included the Dutch Seaborne Empire, and the Portuguese Seaborne Empire (rather than Seaborn), Obituaries, page 20, May 16.

The commander of the German 6th Army who was captured with his entire army at Stalingrad in 1943 (a column, page 20, yesterday) was Friedrich Paulus, rather than the persistent von Paulus (see britannica.com or Chronicle of the Second World War).

Homophone corner, from our television review, page 22, G2, yesterday, where we noted that "literary adaptations are no longer Paul Eddington in breaches and pointy helmet hamming up ..."

fields.headline: Sound policy
fields.standfirst: Royal Festival Hall prepares for a facelift
fields.trailText: Helicopters over the Thames usually mean a river rescue attempt. The helicopters recently seen hovering over the roof of the Royal Festival Hall   mark a final attempt to rescue the notorious acoustic of the 3,000 seat concert hall, which has tormented musicians and audiences for 50 years.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Helicopters over the Thames usually mean a river rescue attempt. The helicopters recently seen hovering over the roof of the Royal Festival Hall mark a final attempt to rescue the notorious acoustic of the 3,000 seat concert hall, which has tormented musicians and audiences for 50 years.

Acoustic engineer Larry Kirkegaard yesterday revealed that he had borrowed the helicopters from the RAF to measure sound penetration into the auditorium, and help design a solution to the problems which defeated the original architects.

The efforts of the Chicago based adviser are part of a £50m restoration project, which promises to respect the original shimmering optimism of the 1951 Festival of Britain, of which the hall is the last survivor. The Grade I listed hall - it was the first postwar British building to be given such an honour - will close for at least a year for the refurbishment.

In the concert hall, materials lining the walls and ceiling swallow some sounds while making others blaringly loud.

Chief executive, Karsten Witt, yesterday promised that the revamp would make the concert hall into one of the best in Europe, and restore features including a small recital hall, the original grand entrance, bars and rooftop garden terraces.

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Scottish first minister Donald Dewar was discharged from Glasgow Royal infirmary after undergoing heart surgery 10 days ago. Mr Dewar, known to have been fed up at his enforced inactivity in hospital, now faces a two-month convalescence from an operation to have a leaking aorta valve replaced by a mechanical device.

Outrage of day

Former maverick Labour MP Ron Brown threatened legal action after he was wrongly dubbed gay in Peter Hitchens's new book The Abolition of Britain. It appears the Daily Express columnist confused "Red Ron" with agriculture minister Nick Brown, who is gay. "I've been wrongly labelled a lot of things in the past, from KGB spy to Gadafy's friend," said the leftwinger, deselected in 1992. "It is not that I have anything against gays, it is just that I am not one."

Today

Commons: Care standards bill, second reading. Lords: Financial services and markets bill, third reading.

fields.headline: Camden to help save schools
fields.trailText: A local education authority in north London yesterday became the first LEA to be chosen by the government to help to turn around failing schools in other areas.
fields.body:
A local education authority in north London yesterday became the first LEA to be chosen by the government to help to turn around failing schools in other areas.

Camden was named on a list of government-approved contractors which can apply to take over the services of LEAs that are not providing acceptable services, or to provide support.

Ministers hope that more councils will voluntarily seek outside help from contractors.

Camden is the only LEA on the list which is not part of a consortium. The other new service providers include private sector organisations and consortiums with education, financial and legal expertise.

The government also extended the list of consultants who can recommend what action should be taken in LEAs that are having difficulties.

Announcing the new list, Estelle Morris, minister for school standards, said: "Last month Camden LEA received an excellent Ofsted report, and its background serving one of the most diverse communities in the country will be of tremendous benefit to other areas."

Camden ruled out the prospect of large-scale school takeovers, saying it was a relatively small authority (with fewer than 60 schools) and would prefer to stick to consultancy services or strategic support. It is also likely to limit its activities to London boroughs.

To date the private sector has been called in to help the LEAs in Hackney, Islington, Haringey and Southwark in London, and in Liverpool, Walsall, Bristol, Leicester, Sandwell, Doncaster, Sheffield, Rotherham and Leeds.

Useful link
Camden Learning

fields.trailText: For 51 Saturdays a year, the BBC broadcasts sport while ITV screens ancient movies (Lack of sport stops Grandstand, May 17), so the reversal this Saturday hardly amounts to humiliation for Greg Dyke, particularly as it was reported on the day the BBC showed Arsenal's UEFA Cup final live, while ITV made do with, er, Soap Secrets III.

Bath

Denis MacShane MP

London

Hull
