fields.headline: Reviews
fields.standfirst: Playing house on screen
fields.trailText: Real Home Magazine's 3D Designer
fields.body:
Real Home Magazine's 3D Designer

Broderbund £29.99
This program is clever, but not clever enough. This thinly-Britified US import (on the boxlid, a Tudor cottage with roses - typical English house) promises to let you visualise your home in three dimensions and then play around with it, adding furniture, moving walls and redecorating.

Since I'm moving into a new flat, this seemed like a good idea. And, up to a point, it works. Having already measured the rooms, it wasn't difficult to recreate the two floors in plan form on the screen and put them together with various menus and mouse-clicks. You add doors and windows, and then the fun begins. Switch to aerial view, lift off the roof, and you can rotate a three-dimensional doll's-house view of your future home. Switch to walk-through view, and you can take a slow, rather jerky virtual tour.

This is the point at which you can begin to furnish and decorate - change the colour of the walls, install a bed, kitchen units, a wardrobe. When everything's set up to your satisfaction, pick a decent viewing angle, pick the lighting you want, and select the highest quality screen rendering.

In a few minutes a Toy Story-quality snapshot of your fantasy room will appear, with shadows, lamplight and texture all nicely reproduced. The reflection of our virtual bedroom in the mirrored doors of our virtual wardrobe was particularly impressive.

In short, a good idea, and a useful tool to stop you slapping a pink four-poster in the lime-green boxroom (unless that's what you like). So much for the good news. Unfortunately the inherent complexity of the challenge isn't fully overcome.

The software is happiest creating square or rectangular spaces, particularly where outside walls are concerned. I found it impossible to recreate the flat's L-shaped hallway, and the stairs between floors were tricky to get in the right place.

You don't need a piece of computer software to rearrange the furniture in your sitting room, but shifting kitchen units and plumbing around is a different matter. Probably the most useful feature of 3D Designer for ordinary householders is the ability to visualise new kitchens and bathrooms.

Here another weakness comes in - the limited number of kitchen and bathroom furnishings and fittings included in the software. I wanted to see how the washing machine would look in the kitchen, for instance, but the only image available was of a top-loading white monstrosity which looked as if it had been designed in the 1950s.

Broderbund provides links to an American website which, supposedly, enables you to download images of thousands of brand-name goods, but on two attempts I've been unable to do so.

And if the virtual catalogue is in the US, how relevant is it to the UK? This is two thirds of the way to a winner, but lacks a more user-friendly interface and a more thorough Europeanisation.
fields.bodyText: Real Home Magazine's 3D Designer Broderbund £29.99 This program is clever, but not clever enough. This thinly-Britified US import (on the boxlid, a Tudor cottage with roses - typical English house) promises to let you visualise your home in three dimensions and then play around with it, adding furniture, moving walls and redecorating. Since I'm moving into a new flat, this seemed like a good idea. And, up to a point, it works. Having already measured the rooms, it wasn't difficult to recreate the two floors in plan form on the screen and put them together with various menus and mouse-clicks. You add doors and windows, and then the fun begins. Switch to aerial view, lift off the roof, and you can rotate a three-dimensional doll's-house view of your future home. Switch to walk-through view, and you can take a slow, rather jerky virtual tour. This is the point at which you can begin to furnish and decorate - change the colour of the walls, install a bed, kitchen units, a wardrobe. When everything's set up to your satisfaction, pick a decent viewing angle, pick the lighting you want, and select the highest quality screen rendering. In a few minutes a Toy Story-quality snapshot of your fantasy room will appear, with shadows, lamplight and texture all nicely reproduced. The reflection of our virtual bedroom in the mirrored doors of our virtual wardrobe was particularly impressive. In short, a good idea, and a useful tool to stop you slapping a pink four-poster in the lime-green boxroom (unless that's what you like). So much for the good news. Unfortunately the inherent complexity of the challenge isn't fully overcome. The software is happiest creating square or rectangular spaces, particularly where outside walls are concerned. I found it impossible to recreate the flat's L-shaped hallway, and the stairs between floors were tricky to get in the right place. You don't need a piece of computer software to rearrange the furniture in your sitting room, but shifting kitchen units and plumbing around is a different matter. Probably the most useful feature of 3D Designer for ordinary householders is the ability to visualise new kitchens and bathrooms. fields.headline: Artificial intelligence
fields.standfirst: Simon Dessain is worldwide managing director of Cincom's intelligent Document Solutions Group (iDS)
fields.trailText: Simon Dessain is worldwide managing director of Cincom's intelligent Document Solutions Group (iDS)
fields.body:
What is iD Solutions? iD Solutions is a group dedicated to the document domain. When people say document management, even in IT-literate circles, some people immediately think of archiving, storage and imaging systems. Others might think of it as document content management - looking after huge libraries of information and tracking the change to it. The third group is what I would call document generation. That's the consistent high-quality production of statements, insurance policies or correspondence. It's in this last area that Cincom's iD Solutions is strong.

We're into large-scale, generally interactive, document generation. With the term "document" being used to describe the process and the content creation rather than the delivery mechanism.

How do the UK's IT and internet skills compare with other countries? We are so risk averse. Obviously Cincom's based in the US, which is a very exciting environment, but in the UK it's amazing how many Australian software companies you come across. Statistically there may not actually be that many but it appears that they're more prepared to take a risk.

How do you feel major corporations are adapting to e-commerce? What we see is the large companies plucking one person from here and one from there then whacking them into a new office and saying "go do it". It's easier to do that than it is to tell the whole organisation to give these people freedom to change the way in which that company does business. It does, however, mean that those people are re-inventing a hell of a lot of wheels!

Is there real money being made from e-commerce? Absolutely. The example I always give is the penetration of mobile phones - Finland now has 86% of over 14 year olds with a mobile phone.The level of penetration of e-commerce is going to go the same way ... whatever prediction people make, just double it.

Any thoughts on the proposed break-up of Microsoft? I can't believe it will happen. Why would America take its crown jewel and break it up? If you break up Microsoft, you will lose that critical mass and I find it hard to believe that somebody won't realise that before they do it. It would be like America giving up their leadership of IT and I wouldn't like to be the president that signed that off.

Any favourite places on the web? I had my laptop stolen in Brussels recently and I was devastated as I lost all my favourite bookmarks. I do love some pretty standard sites. I'm going to say Amazon because I love being able to go in, browse, then one click into the basket and all my credit card and address details are stored. They're a market leader that doesn't need any endorsing from me. I also really like the Nasdaq site. It's easy to use - you've got your 10 favourites in there, and I can put half a dozen of my main competitors in and bounce in there for 30 seconds once a week to see if there have been any great spikes or changes.

webTitle: Prince Charles reflects on the Reith lectures

fields.headline: Prince Charles reflects on the Reith lectures
fields.standfirst: A sacred trust between mankind and our creator
fields.trailText: Like millions of other people around the world, I have been fascinated to hear five eminent speakers share with us their thoughts, hopes and fears about sustainable development, based on their own experience.
fields.body:
Like millions of other people around the world, I have been fascinated to hear five eminent speakers share with us their thoughts, hopes and fears about sustainable development, based on their own experience.

All five of those contributions have been immensely thoughtful and challenging. There have been clear differences - of opinion and of emphasis - between the speakers, but there have also been some important common themes - both implicit and explicit.

One of those themes has been the suggestion that sustainable development is a matter of enlightened self-interest. Two of the speakers used this phrase, and I don't believe that the other three would dissent from it - and nor would I.

Self-interest is a powerful motivating force for all of us, and if we can somehow convince ourselves that sustainable development is in all our interests then we will have taken a valuable first step towards achieving it.

But self-interest comes in many competing guises, not all of which - I fear - are likely to lead in the right direction for very long, nor to embrace the manifold needs of future generations. I am convinced we will need to dig rather deeper to find the inspiration, sense of urgency and moral purpose required to confront the hard choices which face us on the long road to sustainable development. So although it seems to have become deeply unfashionable to talk about the spiritual dimension of our existence, that is what I propose to do.

The idea that there is a sacred trust between mankind and our creator, under which we accept a duty of stewardship for the earth, has been an important feature of most religious and spiritual thought throughout the ages. Even those whose beliefs have not included the existence of a creator have, nevertheless, adopted a similar position on moral and ethical grounds. It is only recently that this guiding principle has become smothered by almost impenetrable layers of scientific rationalism.

I believe that if we are to achieve genuinely sustainable development we will first have to rediscover, or re-acknowledge, a sense of the sacred in our dealings with the natural world, and with each other. If literally nothing is held sacred any more - because it is considered synonymous with superstition, or in some other way "irrational" - what is there to prevent us treating our entire world as some "great laboratory of life," with potentially disastrous long-term consequences?

Fundamentally, an understanding of the sacred helps us to acknowledge that there are bounds of balance, order and harmony in the natural world which set limits to our ambitions and define the parameters of sustainable development. In some cases, nature's limits are well understood at the rational, scientific level. As a simple example, we know that trying to graze too many sheep on a hillside will, sooner or later, be counter-productive, for the sheep, the hillside, or both. More widely, we understand that the over-use of insecticides or antibiotics leads to problems of resistance.

And we are beginning to comprehend the full, awful consequences of pumping too much carbon dioxide into the earth's atmosphere. Yet the actions being taken to halt the damage known to be caused by exceeding nature's limits in these and other ways are insufficient to ensure a sustainable outcome.

In other areas, such as the artificial and uncontained transfer of genes between species of plants and animals, the lack of hard scientific evidence of harmful consequences is regarded, in many quarters, as sufficient reason to allow such developments to proceed. The idea of taking a precautionary approach, in this and many other potentially damaging situations, receives overwhelming public support, but still faces a degree of official opposition, as if admitting the possibility of doubt was a sign of weakness or even of a wish to halt "progress." On the contrary, I believe it to be a sign of strength and of wisdom.

It seems that when we do have scientific evidence that we are damaging our environment we aren't doing enough to put things right, and when we don't have that evidence we are prone to do nothing at all, regardless of the risks. Part of the problem is the prevailing approach that seeks to reduce the natural world, including ourselves, to the level of nothing more than a mechanical process. For whilst the natural theologians of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, like Thomas Morgan, referred to "the perfect unity, order, wisdom and design" of the natural world, scientists like Bertrand Russell rejected this idea as rubbish. "I think the universe," he wrote, "is all spots and jumps without unity and without continuity, without coherence or orderliness." Sir

Julian Huxley wrote in "Creation: a modern synthesis" that "modern science must rule out special creation or divine guidance." But why? As Professor Alan Linton of Bristol University has written: "Evolution is a man-made 'theory' to explain the origin and continuance of life on this planet without reference to a creator." It is because of our inability, or refusal, to accept the existence of a guiding hand that nature has come to be regarded as a system that can be engineered for our own convenience, or as a nuisance to be evaded and manipulated, and in which anything that happens can be "fixed" by technology and human ingenuity. Fritz Schumacher recognised the inherent dangers in this approach when he said that "there are two sciences - the science of manipulation and the science of understanding."

In this technology-driven age it is all too easy for us to forget that mankind is a part of nature, and not apart from it, and that this is why we should seek to work with the grain of nature in everything we do. For the natural world is, as the economist Herman Daly puts it, "the envelope that contains, sustains and provisions the economy" - not the other way round. So which argument do you think will win - the living world as one, or the world made up of random parts, the product of mere chance, thereby providing the justification for any kind of development? This, to my mind, lies at the heart of what we call sustainable development.

We need, therefore, to rediscover a reverence for the natural world, irrespective of its usefulness to ourselves - to become more aware, in Philip Sherrard's words, of the "relationship of interdependence, interpenetration and reciprocity between God, man and creation." Above all, we should show greater respect for the genius of nature's designs - rigorously tested and refined over millions of years. This means being careful to use science to understand how nature works - not to change what nature is, as we do when genetic manipulation seeks to transform the process of biological evolution into something altogether different. The idea that the different parts of the natural world are connected through an intricate system of checks and balances which we disturb at our peril is all too easily dismissed as no longer relevant. So, in an age when we are told that science has all the answers, what chance is there for working with the grain of nature?

As an example of working with the grain of nature, I happen to believe that if a fraction of the money currently being invested in developing genetically manipulated crops were applied to understanding and improving traditional systems of agriculture, which have stood the all-important test of time, the results would be remarkable. There is already plenty of evidence of just what can be achieved through applying more knowledge and fewer chemicals to diverse cropping systems. These are genuinely sustainable methods. And they are far removed from the approaches based on monoculture which lend themselves to large-scale commercial exploitation, and which Vandana Shiva condemned so persuasively and so convincingly in her lecture.

Our most eminent scientists accept that there is still a vast amount that we don't know about our world and the life forms that inhabit it. As Sir Martin Rees, the Astronomer Royal, points out, it is complexity that makes things hard to understand, not size. In a comment which only an astronomer could make, he describes a butterfly as a more daunting intellectual challenge than the cosmos!

Others, like Rachel Carson, have eloquently reminded us that we don't know how to make a single blade of grass. And St Matthew, in his wisdom, emphasised that not even Solomon in all his glory was arrayed as the lilies of the field... Faced with such unknowns, it is hard not to feel a sense of humility, wonder and awe about our place in the natural order. And to feel this at all stems from that inner, heartfelt reason which, sometimes despite ourselves, is telling us that we are intimately bound up in the mysteries of life and that we don't have all the answers. Perhaps, even, that we don't have to have all the answers before knowing what we should do in certain circumstances. As Blaise Pascal wrote in the seventeenth century: "It is the heart that experiences God, not the reason."

So do you not feel that, buried deep within each and every one of us, there is an instinctive, heartfelt awareness that provides - if we will allow it to - the most reliable guide as to whether or not our actions are really in the long-term interests of our planet and all the life it supports? This awareness, this wisdom of the heart, may be no more than a faint memory of a distant harmony, rustling like a breeze through the leaves, yet sufficient to remind us that the earth is unique and that we have a duty to care for it.

Wisdom, empathy and compassion have no place in the empirical world, yet traditional wisdoms would ask "without them are we truly human?" And it would be a good question. It was Socrates who, when asked for his definition of wisdom, gave as his conclusion: "Knowing that you don't know."

In suggesting that we will need to listen rather more to the common-sense emanating from our hearts if we are to achieve sustainable development, I am not suggesting that information gained through scientific investigation is anything other than essential. Far from it. But I believe that we need to restore the balance between the heartfelt reason of instinctive wisdom and the rational insights of scientific analysis. Neither, I believe, is much use on its own. So it is only by employing both the intuitive and the rational halves of our own nature - our hearts and our minds - that we will live up to the sacred trust that has been placed in us by our creator - or our "sustainer," as ancient wisdom referred to the creator.

As Gro Harlem Brundtland has reminded us, sustainable development is not just about the natural world, but about people, too. This applies whether we are looking at the vast numbers who lack sufficient food or access to clean water, but also those living in poverty and without work. While there is no doubt that globalisation has brought advantages, it brings dangers, too. Without the humility and humanity expressed by Sir John Browne in his notion of the "connected economy" - an economy which acknowledges the social and environmental context within which it operates - there is the risk that the poorest and the weakest will not only see very little benefit but, worse, they may find that their livelihoods and cultures have been lost. So, if we are serious about sustainable development, then we must also remember that the lessons of history are particularly relevant when we start to look further ahead. Of course, in an age when it often seems that nothing can properly be regarded as important unless it can be described as "modern," it is highly dangerous to talk about the lessons of the past. And are those lessons ever taught or understood adequately, in an age when to pass on a body of acquired knowledge of this kind is often considered prejudicial to "progress?"

Of course, our descendants will have scientific and technological expertise beyond our imagining, but will they have the insight or the self-control to use this wisely, having learnt both from our successes and our failures? They won't, I believe, unless there are increased efforts to develop an approach to education which balances the rational with the intuitive. Without this, truly sustainable development is doomed. It will merely become a hollow-sounding mantra that is repeated ad nauseam in order to make us all feel better. Surely, therefore, we need to look towards the creation of greater balance in the way we educate people so that the practical and intuitive wisdom of the past can be blended with the appropriate technology and knowledge of the present to produce the type of practitioner who is acutely aware of both the visible and invisible worlds that inform the entire cosmos.

The future will need people who understand that sustainable development is not merely about a series of technical fixes, about re-designing humanity or re-engineering nature in an extension of globalised industrialisation - but about a re-connection with nature and a profound understanding of the concepts of care that underpin long-term stewardship. Only by re-discovering the essential unity and order of the living and spiritual world - as in the case of organic agriculture or integrated medicine or in the way we build - and by bridging the destructive chasm between cynical secularism and the timelessness of traditional religion, will we avoid the disintegration of our overall environment.

Above all, I don't want to see the day when we are rounded upon by our grandchildren and asked accusingly why we didn't listen more carefully to the wisdom of our hearts as well as to the rational analysis of our heads; why we didn't pay more attention to the preservation of bio-diversity and traditional communities or think more clearly about our role as stewards of creation. Taking precautions, or achieving balance in life is never as much fun as the alternatives, but that is what sustainable development is all about.

webTitle: Zimbabwe face two tests in one

fields.headline: Zimbabwe face two tests in one
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe have had to wait more than eight years to play their first test in England and they are now bracing themselves for a welcome that will range from the indifferent to the downright hostile.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe have had to wait more than eight years to play their first test in England and, now that the invitation has been tendered, they are bracing themselves for a welcome that will range from the indifferent to the downright hostile.

Their players have been warned to expect demonstrations outside Lord's today against the politically motivated violence that puts in question the desire of the Zanu PF ruling party to conduct next month's elections in a peaceful and democratic manner.

As pre-match ticket sales suggest that Lord's may be less than half full throughout the game, it is fortunate that the England and Wales Cricket Board had the foresight last summer to lift the ban on placards. At least that should allow a few extra people through the gates.

For Zimbabwe's players, who have been on tour since the troubles began, initially in Pakistan and now England, the anti-Mugabe T-shirts and banners will be a disturbing reminder of the uncertain future that awaits them. Although the tightly knit squad have managed to submerge their concerns on the field, evenings frittered away in anonymous hotel rooms are not designed for peace of mind.

Andy Flower, Zimbabwe's captain, has found time to spend three nights in Zimbabwe over the past few months. "We're expecting a few placards and things," he said, "but it shouldn't be a problem, unless some of the players start wearing T-shirts on the field. The problems can wear at our minds a little but during the game I expect us to put it all out of our minds."

England, it is timely to recall, unsuccessfully led the resistance to the bestowing of full test status on Zimbabwe. There were fears that Zimbabwe would further weaken the traditional Anglo-Australian power base, that their player-base was too small and, most spuriously, that the game's statistics would be irredeemably devalued.

In one-day cricket, discipline, organisation and athleticism can go a long way - as six wins in 12 such matches against England illustrate - but at test level their record is mediocre. They have won three of their 41 tests and there are suspicions that the two successes against Pakistan may have been part of the match-fixing scandal.

Flower, the only Zimbabwean to have played in all their tests and one-day internationals, said: "We have a strong spirit, which is perhaps born out of necessity. We draw from a small pool of players, even though we are working hard to expand that. In such circumstances you have to draw on other reserves."

Their experience of English conditions is also tiny. They acquitted themselves nobly in last summer's World Cup but their first-class exposure in the past couple of weeks amounts to three matches, all disrupted by rain.

If they field a leg-spinner, Brian Murphy, it will not be because the conditions demand it but because they feel more comfortable that way. Should Murphy find himself disconsolately blowing on numbed fingers, he might consider that at least his immediate future is not as precarious as that of Adam Huckle, his predecessor as Zimbabwe's leg-spinner, who retired from international cricket last year to run a farm near Bulawayo.

 Lashings, the East Kent League club, a haunt of former West Indies test players, has failed with its most outlandish attempted coup, for Hansie Cronje. The former South Africa captain has turned down an approach from the club, which is sponsored by an internet betting company, Intertops.

webTitle: The oldest keeper is still keeping well

fields.headline: The oldest keeper is still keeping well
fields.trailText: Frank Keating The first test match morning of any summer provides a buzz of eager expectancy: fresh white paint on the pickets, gleaming green grass, some brand new faces, some auld acquaintance... and by happy coincidence, a notable cricketing birthday.
fields.body:
The first test match morning of any summer provides a buzz of eager expectancy: fresh white paint on the pickets, gleaming green grass, some brand new faces, some auld acquaintance... and by happy coincidence, a notable cricketing birthday.

The first test batsman I ever saw at the crease was Bill Edrich. He scored 13. Middlesex were playing at Gloucester 54 summers ago. My father took me for a couple of hours after business at the city's morning cattle market.

On the same Saturday, England began their first post-war test, against All-India at Lord's, so both counties at Gloucester were missing their champions (each was clean-bowled by the demon Lala Amarnath: Walter Hammond for 33 and Denis Compton for a first-ball duck).

Short-trousered at Gloucester, I was transfixed with the wonder of it all as the off-spin ancient Tom Goddard, as old as the century, became my first sporting hero by taking six for 72 and bowling Middlesex out for 152. Almost simultaneously Gloucestershire's pint-pot wicketkeeper Andy Wilson became my second sporting hero by making two raucous snakebite stumpings in a whirr of gloves and bails.

Of the 22 giants on that long-vanished Gloucester field that day, only one man survives. And Wilson is 90 today. The world's oldest living first-class cricketer is Jim Hutchinson, Derbyshire bat, who was 103 last November. The world's oldest test cricketer is England's Alf Gover, 92 in February. Cricket's oldest first-class wicketkeeper is my boyhood wizard, Wilson.

"Still short, squat and ugly, that's me," says Wilson. He lives in (wouldn't you know?) Keeper's Cottage in a blissful village in the Malverns. This morning he will lay some spring flowers on the grave of his wife, then be taken by his niece to the Rose and Crown for lunch.

"Apart from losing my beloved Liz a few years back, my only real regret is the five years of our prime us cricketers missed through the war," he says.

Even so, Wilson logged more than 10,000 runs (average 25), 416 catches and 168 stumpings. When the sun-browned, hale and horny-handed 5ft 3in dumpling tot retired in 1955 to work for the National Farmers' Union, John Arlott's valediction in these pages acclaimed: "You learn a lot about a man when you are out in the field with him six hours a day all summers long, and up and down England I do not believe you will find one cricketer who does not like Andy Wilson with a fraternal fondness."

He remains in awe of Hammond, patrician and "president of the immortals", and is astonished his county captain failed to make Wisden's top five of the century. "I never saw WG, of course, nor Bradman, but on all wickets Wally was surely unsurpassable.

"In 1935, my first season, a fuming Wally was left high and dry with the tail. I was No9 and he looked at me like dirt when I got to the wicket and ordered, 'Boy, just run when I tell you.' He never said another word to me for the next three hours. In the first six overs he never allowed me to face a single ball. It was magnificent, heroic leadership."

Wilson ended with 83 (Hammond 271) and their 239 for the eighth wicket remains a county record.

Wilson finished at the Cheltenham festival of 1955. "In the penultimate match against Sussex, I batted out the last over for a draw instead of going for the handful of runs for a victory and the blokes weren't best pleased with my caution.

'It upset me a lot - and next day against Worcester, dear old Reg Perks, Roly Jenkins and that lot, I determined to go out on a high and show Glos what they'd be missing. Reg was absolutely livid. Look, here's Wisden." And he pulls it from the shelf: "'Milton and Wilson put on 101 in 58 minutes, with Wilson's blazing 82 containing only six singles and an astonishing 76 in boundaries.' Dear old days, eh?

"I began 70 summers ago on the Lord's ground staff and was Denis Compton's very first captain for the MCC Young Professionals - he was a truly lovely, happy boy from the very start - and ended giving a furious Reg Perks what-for at Cheltenham. A real good innings I had, sure and I thank God for it, but I just wonder what might have happened in those five war years ..."

And the watery-bright, soft-boiled eyes get more moist. And even on the eve of a new test series you don't like to interrupt a contented birthday boy's reverie with topical questions....

webTitle: Warne avoids fate of Somerset railwayman

fields.headline: Warne avoids fate of Somerset railwayman
fields.standfirst: Hampshire 227-9 v Leicestershire
fields.trailText: Hampshire 227-9 v Leicestershire
fields.body:
Hampshire's coaching staff, headed by Tim Tremlett and Jimmy Cook, were out in force, with understandably serious intent and expressions. So far the county have, despite a gambler's investment on costly and glamorous newcomers, seen a minimal return to reinforce their pre-season excitement and hyperbole.

Yesterday, after winning the toss and batting, there were again too many wanton or wayward shots, and in some cases lack of judgment. They were saved from a continuing sequence of modest achievement substantially by a ninth-wicket stand of 64 by Adrian Aymes and Simon Renshaw.

This was Aymes's first cham pionship match of the season after a knee injury a month ago during a Benson & Hedges match. By nature he is a player who abhors self-sacrificial gestures, a fighter at the crease who impresses most when his team are struggling.

Yesterday he immediately averted a hat-trick by Anil Kumble; and by good sense and stubborn, selective scoring he was 74 not out when bad light stopped play. He had taken three hours over his invaluable 50, and deserved the isolated let-off at gully off Scott Boswell soon afterwards.

Until then Leicestershire's bowling, patently deficient of the injured James Ormond and Chris Lewis, was made to look better than it was. Derek Kenway beat out some worthy early runs before pushing Kumble apprehensively to be caught at silly mid-off.

But what was Robin Smith doing - after deftly square-cutting Kumble and driving Vince Wells through midwicket for fours, and then appearing to be arresting another collapse - slashing fatally at a wide delivery from Boswell? Or Will Kendall prematurely playing across the line? Or Giles White padding up first ball to a Kumble googly?

Which brings us to Shane Warne, whose introductory four championship innings had failed to produce a single run. Phillip DeFreitas's immediate lbw appeal, supported by collective shouts, suggested that the hapless pattern might be sustained, even if not quite in the fruitless pre-war style of Somerset's Seymour Clark, a railway worker who did not score a run in nine innings for the county.

Warne, certainly not to be disregarded as a batsman, now survived and quickly struck a couple of boundaries to reach a mildly reassuring 16 before being bowled by Darren Maddy when working the ball to leg. It was perhaps enough to lift personal spirits, not least when his team-mates emerged on the players' balcony to cheer his virgin runs.

Leicestershire can hardly be pleased at the way Hampshire, or rather Aymes, were allowed partly to extricate themselves. Kumble, who had taken two wickets in eye-blinking fashion, continued his rich variety without much sign of further success. DeFreitas had responded well to the additional needs of his side, but too much of the bowling looked ordinary when a lethal demolition of the Hampshire tail was required.

webTitle: Ramsden chips in with a swinger

fields.headline: Ramsden chips in with a swinger
fields.standfirst: Derbyshire 285-8 v Yorkshire
fields.trailText: Derbyshire 285-8 v Yorkshire
fields.body:
Rob Bailey, making his 350th first-class appearance, took guard with the easy air of a man who had already dealt with every sling and arrow the perverse old game had to offer. Though diffident by nature, the batsman once known as the Biddulph Biffer has the confidence that comes with considerable ability and long experience.

But Bailey had never seen Gary Ramsden before. Nor had anyone else. Plucked from Huddersfield New College, where he is in the middle of three A levels, Ramsden, 17, was told only yesterday morning that he would be making his first-class debut in this First Division fixture.

Short and slight, he did not look an imposing figure when he entered the Yorkshire attack with Derbyshire 68 for one on the first morning. Nor did his opening spell, 4-1-20-0, amount to much, though he was unlucky to bowl against a fluent Michael di Venuto.

He showed some character when he returned for a second spell. He bowled much better and took his first wicket when he had Bailey caught behind with a beauty that swung away and bounced surprisingly.

Young Yorkshire seamers normally wear a disconsolate air for there are few opportunities for them. But yesterday Darren Gough and Craig White were elsewhere and Chris Silverwood had a heel injury. They were also without Ryan Sidebottom, who suffered a groin injury in the nets the previous day.

Ramsden (Chippy?) finished with figures of one for 32 and we will see him again. But Paul Hutchison's first appearance of the season was of greater significance for followers of Yorkshire cricket.

The left-arm seamer played only three games last season after back surgery following the England A team tour of South Africa and Zimbabwe in 1998-99. Here he bowled a good attacking line and took three of the first four wickets.

Derbyshire won the toss and chose to bat on a fine, straw-coloured pitch which belied the recent rains. They were disappointed to close the first day on 285 for eight, even though there was swing and occasional seam movement.

Matthew Dowman went first when he drove Hutchison to Matthew Wood at short cover. Di Venuto then produced a busy cameo, striking five fours in his 29-ball 30 before Gavin Hamilton beat his on-drive with a full-length delivery that swung late.

Steve Stubbings played well before he was caught by the only slip when one short of his half-century. And Derbyshire were 166 for four when Matthew Cassar was caught-and-bowled for 47 by a delivery that stopped on him.

The most enterprising batting came from the captain Dominic Cork and Simon Lacey, who added 70 in 25 overs after Derbyshire had slumped to 198 for six. Cork's bellicose 43 included a six over extra cover off Matthew Hoggard.

At the end Darren Lehmann, bowling left-arm spin, claimed some of the bowlers' limelight with figures of 6-2-6-2. In wet and windy conditions which forced four brief breaks in play this was a good day's cricket.

webTitle: Don't let the young ones get you down

fields.headline: Don't let the young ones get you down
fields.standfirst: Rachael Roberts seeks out resources and training for teachers who need to adapt to Young Learners
fields.trailText: Rachael Roberts seeks out resources and training for teachers who need to adapt to Young Learners
fields.body:
There is an increasing awareness that the adult-oriented training most teachers receive at the beginning of their careers is only of limited use when you find yourself in a job that involves teaching Young Learners (YL). Suddenly you need to find out more about what motivates young learners, how they learn and the differences between age groups. You need to learn about planning lessons, using engaging topics and materials and taking account such things as concentration.

Perhaps most dauntingly for newer teachers, you need to think again about how to organise the classroom effectively and keep control of the class. So where can you go to find out more? The first place to look might be in the teachers' guide that accompanies your coursebook. A particular favourite of mine is the Magic Time! series, by Herbert Puchta, published by Longman. As well as being full of great practical teaching ideas the notes also contain a lot of useful information about children's learning styles and how to cater for them.

In addition to coursebooks, the number of methodology and teaching ideas books aimed at teachers of Young Learners is rapidly increasing. If you want to find out more about how their minds work, try Margaret Donaldson's Children's Minds (Fontana). Among the books I have found useful for general methodology are Opal Dunn's Beginning English With Young Children (Macmillan, no longer in print) and Susan Halliwell's Teaching English In The Primary Classroom (Longman).

Some of the best advice on young learners comes from other teachers and it is well worth joining a teachers' association. The International Association of Teachers of English as a Foreign Language (IATEFL) has a Young Learners' Sig (special interest group) with more than 500 members worldwide. Members receive a regular newsletter with plenty of practical ideas. There are also conferences and seminars worldwide (Madrid in September, Estonia in October) and members can make contact on the internet with other teachers in similar situations via a discussion list.

Non IATEFL members can also access the YLSig's website where there is a huge collection of links to other YL sites. Two of the best-known sites are the Internet Tesl Journal and Dave Sperling's ESL Cafe. Both contain thousands more links to lesson plans, handouts, activities and advice on teaching specific age groups and nationalities.

The amount of information you can access for yourself is enormous, but clearly there is still a need for some professional training. Fast gaining worldwide recognition is the University of Cambridge Local Examination Syndicate's (UCLES) Certificate in English Language Teaching to Young Learners (CELTYL).

The course is designed primarily for those with little or no previous experience in YL teaching. You can concentrate on one of the following age groups: 5-10 or 8-13 or 11-16. There are two possible course modes. The first is parallel to the adult CELTA certificate (a minimum of 100 hours, usually run over four weeks), and the second is a shorter "extension course", often two weeks, for candidates who have already gained the CELTA.

Trinity College also offer a Certificate in Teaching English to Young Learners with a 140-hour syllabus for those entering the profession. There is also a 70-hour version for those who are already trained teachers of primary or secondary children and wish to move into EFL. Contact UCLES and Trinity College for lists of course providers worldwide.

With the growth in the use of the internet, distance teacher-training courses are starting to flourish. Open Learning International offer a distance Certificate in TEFL to Young Learners, in which your teaching practice sessions are videoed and assessed.

After some initial training you may find that you actually want to move into mainstream primary or secondary education. There are thousands of courses worldwide to train you for this. You may choose to specialise within this field in teaching children whose first language is not English (ESL). Much of the training in the United States is of this nature. If, however, you want to remain in EFL rather than ESL there are also courses available at a higher level.

Several universities in Britain offer specialised postgraduate courses. Warwick University offers a taught MA in ELT to Young Learners, Leeds University offer an M.Ed. in TESOL for Young Learners and York University offers a two-year, part-time distance MA in Teaching English to Young Learners.

Demand for English language teaching to children is exploding, especially in Central and Eastern Europe, Japan and Latin America. As well as helping you cope with your job, you may find that further YL teacher training is a sound career move.

For more information

IATEFL@compuserve.com
tesol@trinitycollege.co.uk
cilts@ucles.org.uk

 Rachael Roberts is head of ELT and ELT Teacher Training at Solihull College, Britain

fields.headline: Bring back the Bard
fields.standfirst: Long dismissed as too hard or irrelevant, Shakespeare deserves a new hearing in EFL classrooms, argues Luke Prodromou
fields.trailText: Long dismissed as too hard or irrelevant, Shakespeare deserves a new hearing in EFL classrooms, argues Luke Prodromou
fields.body:
How relevant is Shakespeare to the study of English as a foreign language? Indeed, how relevant is English literature in general to the study of the world's lingua franca?

Globalisation has brought with it the need for millions of people of diverse linguistic and cultural backgrounds to communicate simply and effectively using a language they both understand. For better or worse, English has come to fulfil this need. Whether English poetry, prose and drama or the Bard himself have any place in the scheme of things in ELT at present is a question we cannot answer without asking why the world is learning English in the first place.

For a long time, it was assumed that people wanted to learn English because they were interested in the culture of native speakers of English. A closer look at the linguistic needs of the learner has exploded this myth. What learners want is to do business in English, study abroad or make friends.

Another controversial axiom in ELT has been that you cannot learn a foreign language if you do not at the same time learn the culture of its native speakers. This too has given way to an intercultural model of language acquisition that foregrounds the culture of the learner rather than the culture of the native speaker.

From the 1970s onwards, ELT methodology came under the influence of speech-act theory that gave us the Functional Syllabus. The kind of language considered relevant here was utilitarian: ordering a meal in a restaurant, apologising, making requests and so on. Keats and Shakespeare do not meet your needs when you are ordering a meal in a restaurant or saying you're sorry. Indeed needs analysis became the dominant framework for determining what became the Communicative Syllabus. In its pure form this led to English for Specific Purposes (ESP) whose aim was to meet the needs of the learner as accurately as possible. Students, especially adults, are prepared to pay very high fees for such tailor-made courses. In short, Communicative Syllabus design analyses literature and Shakespeare out of the picture.

By defining the teaching of English in essentially business terms we may, in fact, be short-changing the learner in educational terms. If we broaden the terms of needs analysis to include other educational criteria, and what little we know about language acquisition, we may find that an exclusive diet of structures and functions is not the best way to make the language memorable. If our job as teachers, course designers and managers is ultimately to create the conditions in which successful acquisition can take place and not to feed the learner a pre-packaged syllabus, then Shakespeare may still have a place. His place will not be down the learners' throat, but one strand in an awareness of language in action.

Recent paradigm shifts in ELT, largely under the influence of the various so-called humanistic approaches, have highlighted the need to engage the learner in the learning process - this means engaging them as individuals with emotions and opinions, not merely as language acquisition devices. A cognitive-affective approach to teaching English as a foreign language sees language in the service of self-expression; language as the interface between cultures; language as a tool for naming the world and interacting with it; language not only for getting things done in the utilitarian sense but also for expressing ideas and feelings.

Clearly the language of The Tempest is useless, functionally speaking, but it has the power to sensitise any learner of English to how language works, to express the Self, and this is something engineers or business people also have and may wish to express. In short, we can see the usefulness of Shakespeare from two perspectives: from the point of view of the learner and the from the point of view of the teacher.

For learners who have reached a level capable of coping with the linguistic difficulties of the text, Shakespeare can bring them into contact with language that expresses a wide range of human emotions in their most powerful and memorable form. Although the learner will not be able to use speeches from Hamlet when writing a business letter, the universal problems faced by the Prince of Denmark may motivate the learner to engage with the foreign language in ways which an newspaper article or a dialogue in a textbook may fail to do.

Intermediate and advanced students' performance in examinations is widely regarded as more successful when they have included a set text in their study of the language. Though the term is slightly off-putting, the "set text" recycles language in natural and memorable contexts and even if the language in the case of Shakespeare is not bang-up-to-date, it can serve as a catalyst for a wide range of linguistic skills: language awareness; discussion; role-play and writing tasks.

For the teacher, Shakespeare's plays provide the most powerful example of effective communication in the English language. In so far as language teachers are in the business of communication, Shakespeare should be worthy of study.

A Shakespeare play performed or read well is a paradigm of what effective language teaching should be: it engages the attention of the listener and holds it, and it makes you remember the message. The good language teacher has something in common with Shakespeare's "lunatic, the lover and the poet" who has the capacity to transform reality through the use of imagination to give a name and shape to "airy nothing". Teachers may well find demotivated teenagers or tired adults an airy nothing that needs to be transformed into an energised group of keen language learners.

The good teacher gives a local habitation and name to learners' explicit needs and often unstated wants. The process of transformation of experience through language into something rich and strange, so characteristic of Shakespeare's plays, is one language teachers can learn from when considering the nature of good language teaching.

 Luke Prodromou is a teacher and trainer with the British Council in Greece, and a textbook author.

The good language teacher has something in common with Shakespeare's "lunatic, the lover and the poet" who has the capacity to transform reality through the use of imagination to give a name and shape to "airy nothing". Teachers may well find demotivated teenagers or tired adults an airy nothing that needs to be transformed into an energised group of keen language learners. The good teacher gives a local habitation and name to learners' explicit needs and often unstated wants. The process of transformation of experience through language into something rich and strange, so characteristic of Shakespeare's plays, is one language teachers can learn from when considering the nature of good language teaching.  Luke Prodromou is a teacher and trainer with the British Council in Greece, and a textbook author.

webTitle: England expect to reap an ill wind

fields.headline: England expect to reap an ill wind
fields.standfirst: Hussain warms to the challenge as the weather turns against Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Mike Selvey on how Nasser Hussain is warming to the challenge as the weather turns against Zimbabwe.
fields.body:
It was uncanny how the weather changed yesterday: how the wind veered towards the north, the cloud rolled over and the temperature dropped like a ton of bricks.

Today, the earliest date a test has started in Britain, it promises to be so blustery and bitter at Lord's that England might consider opening the batting with Ranulph Fiennes and Nanook of the North. Welcome, Zimbabweans all, to test cricket in England.

The reception from the England team promises to warm them up a little. Even if rankings are not a complete pointer, it is evident on results that Zimbabwe are the worst of the test countries and England are not much better.

There is little affection for England at present, so they need to begin resurrecting their esteem by performing above themselves in this two-match series. They know they should win comfortably, given a clear run at Lord's and Nottingham. Performing badly cannot be countenanced.

But there is a fine line between confidence and complacency and Nasser Hussain let it be known that underestimating the qualities in a side who boast no genuine stars but who scrap mightily is the road to disaster. "Respect," the captain said yesterday. "You have to respect the opposition."

The truth is, though, that over the past 12 months, during which Zimbabwe lost to New Zealand and South Africa, they have produced few positives to carry forward.

"On results we should win the match," Hussain continued. "But they get the absolute utmost from their players. They have great concentration, great discipline, know their tasks and their limitations and stick with it. We have to match that."

England can begin by getting the side right for the conditions. The pitch yesterday had substance to it but there was live grass and it was damp. There were cracks too, lateral and horizontal, which are solid enough now but may provide uneven bounce later.

"A typical Lord's pitch," said Hussain, who would not elim-inate any of the 13 players at his disposal until seeing the overhead conditions this morn- ing and a detailed forecast.

With the batting settled - Mark Ramprakash will be Mike Atherton's 12th opening partner - the first decision will be whether to jettison spin for a seam-loaded attack. All Hussain's instincts lean towards having a spin option and this would give Chris Schofield his first cap.

However, spinners generally contribute little to the wicket- taking process at Lord's - 10 of the 88 wickets to fall in the past three tests - and the combination of moisture and a cold, blustery wind would make finger spin arduous, never mind wrist spin.

Seam, with the option of a little spin from Graeme Hick and Ramprakash if necessary, might be the pragmatic choice. There would then be the question of whether to play the all-rounder Craig White with either Steve Harmison or Ed Giddins, or whether to go with both pace bowlers at the expense of the all-rounder.

Choosing between Harmison and Giddins might not be easy. But the ball would swing less in cold weather for Giddins, and Harmison, as Hussain pointed out, has real pace, a commodity to be prized above others. A northerly wind blows across the square so there will be no into-the-wind donkey work either.

There is another consideration because, respect or not, here is a golden opportunity to blood a player against a weaker side. Failure to do so might mean waiting until the winter or next summer against Australia. Playing Harmison now would represent an investment for the future.

Zimbabwe are likely to include both their highest wicket-taker Heath Streak, despite his knee injury, and the leg-spinner Brian Murphy, who arrived here only on Friday; the thinking being that in 40 of their 41 Tests they have played a leg-spinner and, with no high pace, they might be bland without the variety. But, as they won the odd match out with an all-seam attack and have never played at Lords in mid-May, they ought to rethink.

Murphy is accurate rather than mesmeric, backed up by deep-set and highly agile fields. Much the same goes for the seamers, who have the discipline to plough a deep fur row outside off stump once the shine has gone. Henry Olonga, the mercurial and occasionally profligate pace man, has developed what might be a diplomatic ankle injury and the more restrained Bryan Strang and Pommie Mbangwa may play.

Playing off-stump patience with the opposition is a very southern African method and one with which Hussain is familiar. Last weekend for Essex he batted against it for two hours 40 minutes, making 33. However, anyone who saw his six-hour hundred against KwaZulu-Natal in Durban and his 10-hour test marathon there will know that in Chelmsford he was only clearing his throat for the grand aria. It may be worth hearing.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Jonathan Lewis of Gloucestershire ignored superstition when he took a hat-trick in the 13th over against Nottinghamshire during the county championship Second Division game at Trent Bridge yesterday.
fields.body:
Jonathan Lewis of Gloucestershire ignored superstition when he took a hat-trick in the 13th over against Nottinghamshire during the county championship Second Division game at Trent Bridge yesterday.

Nottinghamshire's captain Jason Gallian must have regretted his decision to bat when, with Darren Bicknell run out, he became Lewis's first victim, falling lbw for 11. Lewis, who finished with five for 55, then trapped Usman Afzaal and had John Morris caught by Thomas Cotterell.

With Wayne Noon departing soon after, Nottinghamshire were in deep trouble at 40 for five, but their opener Guy Welton dug in to lead a revival and his 74, plus an unbeaten 36 by David Millns, steered them to 215.

Paul Franks (three for nine) and David Lucas (two for 31) then reduced the visitors to 47 for five.

Dominic Ostler of Warwickshire was on the verge of his first championship century since 1995 when a heavy shower brought an early close to the opening day of the match against Essex at Edgbaston. Coming in first wicket down, Ostler produced some delightful strokeplay to make an unbeaten 93 out of Warwickshire's 160 for two.

In the day/night National League First Division match at Hove Sussex's James Kirtley took four for 41 as Worcestershire were restricted to 206 for seven.

 The president of the Indian board AC Muthiah said yesterday that any cricketer found guilty in India's federal match-fixing investigation would be banned for life and his name erased from the record books.

webTitle: Smith makes three against Stoke's nine

fields.headline: Smith makes three against Stoke's nine
fields.standfirst: Gillingham win 5-3 on aggregate (3-3 at 90 min)
fields.trailText:
Gillingham 3 - 0 Stoke

Gillingham win 5-3 on aggregate (3-3 at 90 min)
fields.body:
Having waited 106 years to make their first Wembley appearance Gillingham are fast becoming acquainted with the the old stadium when they head back there on Sunday week to try to clinch the place in the First Division that eluded them a year ago.

They needed extra-time to overcome a Stoke City side reduced to nine men early in the second half after Clive Clarke and Graham Kavanagh were sent off. Although Barry Ashby brought the aggregate scores level immediately after Kavanagh had joined his team- mate in the dressing room, the Kent side could not break through again until Iffy Onuora headed home, then Paul Smith made sure in the last few minutes.

Either Carl Asaba had made a miraculous recovery from injury or Gillingham had deliberately surrounded his availability with a smokescreen. His inclusion was as much a surprise as the non-appearance of Peter Thorne. Stoke's leading scorer had sustained a knee injury in the first game.

The early goal at the Britannia Stadium, which had set up a mighty tussle, could not be replicated here. Stoke, anticipating the aerial onslaught, put three giants in the middle of their defence this time and knew they would have to show far more resilience.

They saw off the first blue waves but Gillingham's momentum began to look ominous for the visitors as the wing thrusts of Roland Edge and Nicky Southall produced a decent supply.

Following one Edge advance Gillingham won a corner from which Gavin Ward had to move smartly to keep out an Ashby flick.

Asaba's effectiveness had already been seen when, in the 20th minute, he cleverly made room to receive Andy Hessenthaler's low cross. Having done the hard part, however, he slipped his shot wide.

Stoke were being pulled apart and Kavanagh and James O'Connor were forced deeper and deeper to help out. Apart from a Bryjar Gunnarsson header on the half-hour which demanded a stretching save, the visitors were unable to threaten and consequently the ball kept finding its way back into their territory. Shortly, following a curling centre from Ty Gooden, Southall stuck out a leg for a hopeful attempt on goal and was only narrowly off target.

The pressure was exacting a toll: when Kavanagh fouled Hesselthaler it brought him a yellow card and there was one too for Clarke who retaliated against Ashby. Within 60 seconds the full-back disputed another free-kick and was ordered to the dressing room.

That was just before half-time. Another illegal challenge on Hesselthaler early in the second half brought another angry m lée in which Kavanagh emerged holding his chin. However, he was the only one to see red and Stoke were down to nine. They could not hope to hold out and within a minute their aggregate lead had disappeared as Ashby nodded in a Gooden corner.

fields.headline: Sheridan ends rivals' run
fields.standfirst: Wigan win 1-0 on agg
fields.trailText:
Wigan 1 - 0 Millwall
Wigan win 1-0 on agg.
fields.byline: Daniel Taylor  at the JJB stadium
fields.body:
For Wigan it was case of never mind the quality. An uninspiring game ended with John Benson's team heading to Wembley and Millwall facing another season in the game's third tier.

For the opening hour such was the paucity of goalmouth action that it seemed both sides were playing for penalties. But a 62nd-minute goal from Darren Sheridan was sufficient for the home side to squeak through despite a belated onslaught from their visitors.

Fewer than 600 Wigan supporters had ventured south for Saturday's scoreless draw at the New Den and the vast expanses of empty seats here last night suggested it will be some time before this part of Lancashire can be regarded as anything but a town where football comes a poor second to rugby.

At least the apathy was not contagious. The Millwall chairman Theo Paphitis had laid on free coaches for their fans and more than 3,000 headed north, as vociferous as ever. At times it sounded more like 13,000, although it would be stretching the truth to say there anything for them to get excited about. Indeed, in a setting worthy of the Premiership, never mind the First Division, neither side managed a noteworthy attempt on goal during the entire first half.

Instead the game rapidly degenerated into a battle for midfield superiority, all huff and puff but precious little in the way of guile.

Having nurtured a reputation as a neat passing team, Wigan were particularly disappointing. Most of their team may have played in the top flight at one time or another, but on this evidence it is easy to see why their services have been relinquished.

Still, no one could question the players' commitment. No quarter was given by either side and the referee David Laws had to be diligent to prevent things getting out of hand on more than occasion.

Without producing much in the way of flowing football, both sides showed a greater sense of ambition after the interval.

And then - joy of joys - the first meaningful chance. It well to Millwall somewhat against the run of play. Neil Harris manoeuvred space to thrust from the right but Tim Cahill's shot lacked any true conviction.

The next time Harris infiltrated home ranks Millwall came even closer to breaking the gridlock. This time the striker whipped in a low left-wing delivery and, when the ball was stilled by Wigan's goalkeeper Derek Stillie, it needed a desperate clearance from Pat McGibbon.

But just as Millwall seemed to be taking the initiative, Sheridan put the hosts in front. His free-kick was struck with power but the Millwall goalkeeper Tony Warner was well-placed to avert the danger until the ball took a slight deflection off his team-mate David Livermore.

fields.headline: Late goals seal Ipswich's escape
fields.standfirst: Ipswich win 7-5 on aggregate (5-5 after 90min)
fields.trailText:
Ipswich 5 - 3 Bolton

Agg: 7-5, 5-5 after 90min
fields.body:
Extra-time goals from Martijn Reuser and Jamie Clapham saw Ipswich through to the play-off final just when they thought they were going to be knocked out for the fourth season running.

A Jim Magilton volley in injury time brought Ipswich back from the dead in a rivetting and bad-tempered match that had three penalties for the home side and two Bolton players sent off.

Tension was in the air last night, but it could not excuse the disgraceful way in which Bolton players harangued the referee Barry Knight after he gave two penalties against them in the first 45 minutes. At one point a steward had to intervene. Players scuffled with each other.

From the football point of view, Bolton's tactic was clear: close down Ipswich and disrupt their passing game. Although David Johnson, passed fit before the game, forced Jussi Jaaskelainen to make a smart save on four minutes, it was the visitors who produced the greater early threat.

Michael Johansen nearly caught Richard Wright out with an audacious 35-yard chip and then Bolton took the lead.

England's young No3 keeper was at fault, flapping at Johansen's high cross. The ball fell to Dean Holdsworth, Bolton's lone striker in the absence of the injured Eidur Gudjohnsen, who poked the ball home from close range.

Johnson shot just wide before Ipswich equalised controversially. After a one-two with Johnson, Magilton went down in the area under a challenge by Paul Warhurst and the referee pointed to the spot.

Bolton players accused Magilton of diving. Scuffles broke out and the referee was surrounded by angry white shirts.

Eventually Magilton tucked away the penalty to bring Ipswich level but on 40 minutes Bolton regained the lead. Ipswich conceded a free-kick about 20 yards out. In a rehearsed move two Bolton players ran over the ball before Holdsworth curled in a low shot just inside the far post.

But more controversy was at hand. Ipswich's £2.5m striker Marcus Stewart went down in the area under a challenge by Paul Ritchie and the referee awarded another penalty.

Again Bolton players were incensed, five of them chasing the referee. One had to be pulled off by a steward. After more scuffles, Magilton hit the spot-kick in the same place as the first. But Jaaskelainen guessed right and pushed the ball round the post.

Three minutes into the second half Ipswich hit home. What a goal it was. The old campaigner Magilton went past three defenders on the right of the area before cracking a shot into the far corner.

Portman Road erupted in delight and relief. The dream was back on. But the home crowd's cheers were stopped dead in their throats when, just a minute later, Bolton took the lead yet again.

Nothing seemed on for Allan Johnston as he picked the ball up about 25 yards out on the left. But the winger, who has signed a pre-contract to join Rangers next season, unleashed a corker of a shot which Wright knew little about as it flew into the top corner.

In injury time Magilton hit the all-important equaliser and Mike Whitlow was sent off minutes later. Ipswich could feel glad that the away goals rule had been abandoned this year.

Another penalty in extra-time, this time taken by Clapham, put Ipswich ahead for the first time in the tie and Reuser sealed it after Robbie Elliott was sent off.

fields.headline: Farrell's hat-trick provides Posh spice
fields.standfirst: Peterborough win 5-1 on aggregate
fields.trailText:
Peterborough 3 - 0 Barnet
Peterborough win 5-1 on aggregate
fields.body:
David Farrell scored three spectacular goals as Peterborough cruised to the final at the expense of Barnet last night.

Holding a 2-1 lead from the first leg, Barry Fry's side ensured their first trip to Wembley since success in the Second Division play-off finals of 1992. It was followed by a mass pitch invasion during which Farrell, who had saved his best until last with a chip from 30 yards after 89 minutes, was carried to the dressing room.

Both sides made changes from the first leg, Peterborough forced to leave out the former Nottingham Forest striker Jason Lee, a goalscorer on Saturday, who had not recovered from a knee injury.

Given the Posh's propensity for leaking goals - they conceded 30 at home in the Third Division - the loss of Lee might have proved a major headache for the manager Barry Fry. But his fellow striker Andy Clarke, Peterborough's other scorer at Underhill, almost gave his side a two-goal aggregate lead after three minutes. Having seen his first shot spilled by Lee Harrison, the former Barnet striker was unable to beat the goalkeeper at the second attempt from six yards.

The chance suggested that yet another high-scoring game between the sides was likely. The nerves proceeded to set in, though, and an error-strewn spectacle ensued for 25 minutes. It was some surprise, then, when Farrell received a pass from Richard Scott 25 yards out and unleashed a shot which flew into the far corner giving Harrison no chance.

It was an especially sweet moment for Farrell, whose touch on a net-bound shot from an offside position on Saturday had cost Peterborough a precious goal.

Though it was harsh on Barnet, who had enjoyed most of the scrappy possession, for all their endeavour they created little indeed: the only time Peterborough's keeper Mark Tyler was troubled came when he spilt a cross. The lucky deflection off Ken Charlery's back which allowed the ball to settle in Tyler's arms suggested that the fates were firmly with Peterborough.

Their need for goals led their manager John Still to introduce a third striker, Marlon King, after nine minutes of the second half and within 30 seconds he had a great chance to give Barnet a lifeline. His scuffed shot, however, was easily cleared and with that Barnet's hopes disappeared.

The visitors' desperation was evident. They poured forward but were always liable to be caught on the counter-attack. So it was on 70 minutes when Farrell again punished them.

fields.bodyText: David Farrell scored three spectacular goals as Peterborough cruised to the final at the expense of Barnet last night. Holding a 2-1 lead from the first leg, Barry Fry's side ensured their first trip to Wembley since success in the Second Division play-off finals of 1992. It was followed by a mass pitch invasion during which Farrell, who had saved his best until last with a chip from 30 yards after 89 minutes, was carried to the dressing room. Both sides made changes from the first leg, Peterborough forced to leave out the former Nottingham Forest striker Jason Lee, a goalscorer on Saturday, who had not recovered from a knee injury. Given the Posh's propensity for leaking goals - they conceded 30 at home in the Third Division - the loss of Lee might have proved a major headache for the manager Barry Fry. But his fellow striker Andy Clarke, Peterborough's other scorer at Underhill, almost gave his side a two-goal aggregate lead after three minutes. Having seen his first shot spilled by Lee Harrison, the former Barnet striker was unable to beat the goalkeeper at the second attempt from six yards. The chance suggested that yet another high-scoring game between the sides was likely. The nerves proceeded to set in, though, and an error-strewn spectacle ensued for 25 minutes. It was some surprise, then, when Farrell received a pass from Richard Scott 25 yards out and unleashed a shot which flew into the far corner giving Harrison no chance. It was an especially sweet moment for Farrell, whose touch on a net-bound shot from an offside position on Saturday had cost Peterborough a precious goal. Though it was harsh on Barnet, who had enjoyed most of the scrappy possession, for all their endeavour they created little indeed: the only time Peterborough's keeper Mark Tyler was troubled came when he spilt a cross. The lucky deflection off Ken Charlery's back which allowed the ball to settle in Tyler's arms suggested that the fates were firmly with Peterborough. Their need for goals led their manager John Still to introduce a third striker, Marlon King, after nine minutes of the second half and within 30 seconds he had a great chance to give Barnet a lifeline. fields.standfirst: Darlington win 3-0 on agg
fields.trailText:
Darlington 1 - 0 Hartlepool
Darlington win 3-0 on agg
fields.body:
Darlington will be a town of sick notes and the funerals of long-lost aunts on Friday week. David Hodgson's team are on the way to Wembley. A sell-out crowd of 8,238 -their best for nine years - witnessed a victory which earned Darlington a place in the Third Division play-off final at the end of a season spent mostly in an automatic promotion spot.

In the aftermath of the crowd trouble that marred the first leg, Darlington's chairman George Reynolds toured the pitch with a microphone before the start with a personal plea to their fans. "Please don't go on the pitch for the sake of the club and the players," he said, repeating the message half a dozen times to force home his point.

However, the two-goal cushion from Saturday ensured that some of the heat had been taken out of last night's meeting, which was also watched by Hartlepool fans on a giant screen at Victoria Park.

Hartlepool had enjoyed scant good fortune in the first leg and fared no better last night when Gary Strodder headed into his own goal after only nine minutes. The veteran defender was unchallenged when he met Phil Brumwell's cross 10 yards from goal only to deflect the ball into the bottom corner.

It was an undeserved setback for Hartlepool, who had created an early chance for Tommy Miller. They were stunned by the goal and almost succumbed again five minutes later when Peter Duffield headed against the bar.

Hartlepool still had a vestige of hope, as would any team committed to playing three strikers - all different from the trio in Saturday's line-up. But the attacking instincts of their manager Chris Turner often left Miller and Paul Stephenson outmanned in midfield.

The start of the second half was briefly delayed because the Hartlepool goalkeeper Andy Dibble was the target for objects thrown from the crowd, but it was the only hint of crowd trouble.

Hartlepool believed they had opened a small avenue of hope in the 71st minute when Chris Freestone headed in but the goal was disallowed.
